content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
Price (regular): $29.99 ($39.99 for deluxe)Price (lowest): $7.49 (75% off)My overall rating: 9.5/10Easily one of my favorite games of all time.Value: 9/10Most other games this age are already down to $20, however the singleplayer is a lot longer than most other action/shooter games, making it well worth the price.Singleplayer: 10/10Amazing singleplayer. Capturing outposts is probably the best part. There are over 30 spread over the massive map. The main story has some pretty good action too. Plus there is hunting, racing, and assassination side missions and a lot of other things that are a lot of fun.Co-op: 5/10 (2-4 players)Co-op has some serious issues. When the match tries to launch it almost always crashes or freezes when loading. Due to this you wont be able to find players unless you are playing with friends. When it works it is decent but doesnt have the openness that makes far cry great. Update: co-op has been working better lately.Multiplayer: 6.5/10The multiplayer is actually pretty good, but a little generic. Doesn't have enough players to reach its full potential though.Content: 9.5/10Both the co-op and multiplayer are pretty basic, but the singleplayer makes up for it. You of course have the story and outposts, but there is also tons of ruins and caves to be explored for relics and loot, side missions, trials, races, dlc missions, and even knife throwing and poker.Length: 10/10An average playthrough of the singleplayer will take you roughly 30 hours, doing the main storyline capturing all the outposts and doing most of the side missions.Story: 8/10The story really tries to be great and in some ways it is but also is a little flat. You and your friends are having the time of your life until getting caught by slavers on a remote island. You escape and have to save your friends and liberate the natives from the pirates in the process.Gameplay: 10/10Very good, open gameplay. Most situations you can choose to attack however you like. Climb any mountain for a good vantage point with a sniper rifle, use stealth with a bow and using knife takedowns, attack head on with an lmg, or charge in with a truck with c4 planted on it.With freinds: 6/10The co-op and multiplayer are pretty fun with friends but doesnt have a lot of substance.Graphics: 9/10Good graphics, very good considering the scale of the game.Physics: 9.5/10Maybe not as smooth walking around a small area and shooting a few people as call of duty, but all in all the physics are a lot better than just about any other game. Driving really feels good. Good fire physics, you can light large areas of brush with a flamethrower.Performance: 9/10Works good for the most part. Can easily play it on max setting with my laptop, core i7 4810mq @ 2.80 GHz (turbo to 3.80 GHz) 12gbs ram and gtx870m 3gbs dedicated. Haven't had any notable issues or bugs.Sound: 8/10Sound is good but maybe a little rough here and there.Polished: 8/10Nothing majorly wrong with it but it does have the usual trees growing through rocks and animals spawning inside stuff.Atmosphere: 8.5/10The vast landscape gives you a good immersive feel but could be better if they didn't have so much of the same plants making it all feel the same.Objectives: 7/10Objectives are pretty basic. Pretty much go fight through these people and do (insert objective here). Some are a little more in depth.Clarity: 9/10No problems with knowing where to go or what to do. The story line is linear and very easy to follow.World: 9.5/10Unparalleled world. Massive world with large mountains, caves, ruins, shanty towns, vast foliage, ocean, and tons of wildlife to try and kill you. Although most of the landscape has the same trees and plants so a lot of it looks the same.Characters: 8/10The characters are interesting. The antagonists really make you want to kill them. All the characters are just a little thin but still good.UI: 6.5/10The menus are pretty poor. Pulling up your map is really slow. All other menus are in the escape menu which is pretty slow and not that great to navigate. Plus there's Uplay which is horrible.Controls: 9/10Mostly standard controls. Not my favorite layout but close enough I didn't feel the need to change anything.Freedom: 10/10As much freedom as you could ask for. You can ignor your current mission to go off capturing outpost, doing side mission, or just go for a nature hike.Influence: 2.5/10The story itself is very linear. Only choice in the game is the ending and what happens after.Settings: 9/10Four difficulty setting so good for most any skill level. Average control options.Character progression: 6/10Sometimes feels like they resticked what you can do at the beginning instead of allowing you to do more later on.Weapon selection: 9/10Has plenty of weapons. Handguns, SMGs, assault rifles, shotguns, LMGs, sniper rifles, launchers, explosives, and specials. Over 30 total, though some feel similar.Customization: 7/10Most weapons can be modded. Higher level guns can have up to 3 mods. Mods incude extended mags, silencers, and several types of sights, though most guns are limited on which mods are available. Almost all weapons can be painted.AI: 8.5/10For the most part the ai is fairly intelegent. Considering what they have to do in an open world unrelated to a story, it's very good. Though this causes a few quirks.Up to date: 9/10Only came out at the end of 2012 and there isn't any notable aging to the game. Not lacking anything that newer games might have.Replayability: 8.5/10The story doesnt give incentive replay it, but since you can whatever you like however you like, the rest of the game has a lot of replay value.Pace: 8.5/10For such a long game the balance between length and action is very good. You can go straight to the next mission, rush through a few outposts, or take your time doing everything at your own pace.Repetitiveness: 8/10If you were to just walk up with an assault rifle everytime it would probably get very repetitive, but change up your approach everytime and it won't be much at all.Realism: 8.5/10It has some good aspects and a few poor ones when it comes to how realistic it is. Even compared to other games the amount of people you are able to kill is a little ridiculous. It has some supernatural elements which isn't bad but they are a little lame and seem to be inspired by acid trips. Other than that it's actually got good physics and overall better than most games.DLC: 5/10The downloadable content is all pretty mediocre. A few independent short story missions that are okay, some co-op and multiplayer content, and a few other things that are all insignificant.Achievements: 6/1050 achievements but only on Uplay not Steam, and 6 are for co-op making them near impossible. The rest of the achievements are great. Good amount and some challenging but nothing too hard.Trading cards: N/ADoesn't have Steam badges/trading cards.Series improvement: 10/10Far Cry 2 was a good game, however has aged a lot and lacked in a few aspects. Far Cry 3 did a great job at improving and made a very well rounded, good performing game.Originality: 10/10Bottom line is that no other game is very much like Far Cry. Maybe slightly similar to games like Just Cause or some RPGs and it may have some Tomb Raider elements but not enough that its overall gameplay is at all the same as anything else.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												So, here's my final verdict for Far Cry 3. Well, I'm currently doing my fourth playthrough of the game (been doing every difficulty) And I still enjoy it just as much as when the first time I played it. I guess that tells you a little bit if the gameplay/story is good, if not, let me go deeper into it. Story: Without spoiling anything, I'm going to briefly tell you what the game is about. You're jason, some guy who was on a nice trip with his friends until everything went downhill. You find yourself caged with your brother on an island full of crazy pirates.Then you have Vaas, in my opinion one of the coolest villains ever in video game history. Actually, I'm not gonna tell you anything about him, why don't you just get the game and take a look yourself? Throughout the game, you become more powerful, powerful enough to decide you want to take down the people who run the Islands. Are you able to do so, though? You can only find out yourself. There are 2 different endings. Gameplay: Far Cry 3 offers a LOT. It's not your regular shooter, no, It's more like.. Hmm, It's quite hard to say really. On Rook Island, you can find plants, animals and useful gear to upgrade your Jason with. You do this by crafting either ammo pouches, medicine, or useful items that can make hunting a little easier. There's quite a lot of different weapons to find/buy, and they all seem to be pretty damn well done. I didn't find any guns that seem underpowered. A single playthrough of the game should take you well over 20 hours, maybe even 30, if you take your time to explore the amazing landscape and secrets the island has to offer. I don't want to go on too much, so I'm just gonna leave you guys to decide wether or not to get the game. Would I recommend it? YES. Absolutely YES. There's nothing you can go wrong with here. Oh, before I miss it, this game support MODS. If you want more of a challenge, try out Ziggy's Mod. It makes the game a lot more challenging by removing the hud, spotting and free weapons. My final verdict for Far Cry 3 is a 9/10. Only because it wasn't a perfect game, I still wish the multiplayer could be worked on a bit more, but the 9 goes to the singleplayer alone. Thanks for reading my review, and I hope you'll get your hands on this amazing game. :)

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												Far Cry 3 is maybe one of those games that really would put anyone in the protagonist's feelings. It is an open world game that makes you think throughout any kind of missions such as stealth, dinamic or other ways of dominating outposts and the entire island. Unlike Far Cry 2, Far Cry 3 is more into the first game made from the Far Cry series, in the way that the action is based on a dangerous, hostile island and the protagonist has to make his way to get away from it. The storyline is as thrilling as it can be, stuck on a place you do not know, pirates, enemies, predators, all sorts of plants that you have to collect so you can survive, an insane journey. The main character has little battle and combat experience, so he has to learn how to survive from scratch, little supplies, he is going to be helped by many people who will soon become his buddies/friends. During the game, you have to gain the "tatau", which is their way of calling "tattoos". They are essential from the beginning of the game to the very end; they are the symbols of a whole, representing the skills you have to gain in order to finish Far Cry 3.One more interesting fact is introducing the bow. The protagonist can finally use the bow and customize it in the way the player wants to, paint it, use different arrows etc.Last but not least, there are lost loots, lost letters, relics, radio towers to activate (to free new guns) and other things that need you to be discovered, in the game, you can play games such as poker, throwing knives, car races, in order to gain or lose (in bad luck :/) money. I have played this game for more than 30 hours, and I can say i have not finished even half of it (the storyline is excellent). The missions, outposts, helping people in need, searching for artifacts and so on is just amazing for any of us to try.I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who is willing to try it :)Thank you for reading this review, I would also like to ask, my readers, to comment upon this review, whether good or bad, I would be more than pleased to know your pieces of advice. ^_^

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												The sandbox world has just about everything you could ask for. The only thing I can think of that is missing is an actual volcano, otherwise the two islands that make up this game's playable area are everything you'd expect on a tropical island. The addition of wildlife in this game adds such an aspect of realism, I found myself stalking a tiger just to watch him take down a deer or goat. This addition also adds a new type of terror/suspense to the game. There is nothing like quickly trying to escape a firefight that you plundered into, running through the jungle and finally escaping your assailants, just to be mauled and pummeled by a tiger. While the resilience and toughness of some of the animals detracts from realism, it certainly adds to the anxiety. The firefights, especially towards the beginning are very intense. Until you unlock enough of the "skills" to boost your health bars and make body armor more effective, only a couple of bullets will drop you on the intermediate setting. However this is followed by most of the enemies being easily eliminated by a small string of fire to center mass. What is different for this game is the implementation of cover. While the system is a little rough around the edges, it does allow you to hide behind cover and then peek out and fire rounds off at hostiles.The challenge in this game comes mostly from the improved use of enemy AI. While they are still not brilliant, they do notice sounds and are spooked by finding their buddy lying dead on the ground. The enemy itself will work together to suppress and kill you, as well as take cover to hide from your fire. The confrontations with some of the islands predators is also challenging, as well as occasionally terrifying, though the idea of a shark attack bothers me anyways. The enemies are also specialized, making some of them quite difficult to kill and makes plotting strikes against enemy establishments require careful and thorough planning.The game overall is worth every penny just for the single player. The addition to weapon customizations and the improved system controls, should also make this an interesting and likely worthy multiplayer. This game has a few small quirks, and no one should expect a Shakespeare story, but you should expect hours of thrills and plenty of enjoyment.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
IntroductionI am Tigerfrost. I would like to apologize for anything that is miss-spelled or any grammar issues. Thank you.If you'd like to skip straight to Pro's & Con's, please move to the bottom of the page. Thank you.How I Found Out About "Far Cry 3"Well, where to start. To put it simply, I rented Far Cry 3 on the Ps3 a little while after it came out. After it's release, weeks went by, as I heard more and more about Far Cry 3. Nothing was spoiled, but I heard so many good things about it. At the time, I really didn't have the money, so I decided to rent the game, like I use to do back in the day.After picking up the game, I was able to play through about half of it, before needing to take it back. However, around Christmas, my parents got me Far Cry 3 on the Ps3 and I was able to finish my adventure.About six months after that, I saw the Deluxe Edition of Far Cry 3 on sale on Steam, and picked it up. Then things became really good. Unfair FIrst ImpressionsEvery game genre gets hate by some people. Mainly because of opinions, which is okay. There are genre' I don't like, and others I do. However, the main thing I see about Far Cry 3 in reviews that give it a low score is.....Uplay. Why, oh why must you give the GAME a bad score because it uses Uplay? I understand, it's annyoing at times, especially needing to run it through two different clients, but to give the game itself a bad score because it uses Uplay, is very unfair. I have never had any problems running Far Cry 3 through both Steam & Uplay. Basically, when it says someone is playing Far Cry 3 on Steam, they actually have their Uplay open, as the game itself doesn't need to be running to say you're actually in-game.Not to mention, Far Cry 3 has crafting in it, along with survival tactics. Someone went as far to report the game for being a Minecraft clone because of it. Review Of "Far Cry 3"Far Cry 3 is an open world, first person shooter, survival type game. With a very in depth story. Good and memorable characters. Amazing world, and game mechanics. The game takes you in the shoes of "Jason Brody", a rich kid who takes a vaction to an island with a group of friends. Before having enough time to enjoy themselves, Jason and his friends find themselves captured by pirates ruled by "Vass". It's Jason's job to break out of the slave camp and get his friends back. Having never shot or killed anyone, it is up to you to learn how to take down your foe using a wide variety of weapons. Using drugs made off of plants from the jungle, and working alongside people like Denis. Can you make it happen?Far Cry 3 allows you to form your story. Everyone's playthrough will be different. The world of Far Cry 3. The world is massive. In my Just Cause 2 review, I talked about the world being massive, but mostly empty. Here, the world is not only massive, it isn't empty. Everywhere there is something to collect, capture, destroy, hide from, or DIE from. The world is split between two islands, which take part at different sections of the story. Each lush with plains, jungle's , a lot of killer animals, green, some more green, beautiful oceans and caves. Far Cry 3 is a graphically intense looking game. The views are just amazing. The world is populated by loot, like weapons, money, and relics. There are also deadly animals, like the Tiger, or Cassowary. Not only that, pirates, who only mean to kill you. Far Cry 3 does it nicely, where the whole game isn't out to kill you. The pirates will get into fights with the natives. Angry animals will attack civilians, and pirates. You could sit at a far, watching through the scope of a sniper rifle, as a Tiger slips through the enemy defense and takes down a group. Thrown about this world are these plants. These plants can be used to craft drugs to help you with many things. Like detecting animals, or increasing maximum health, etc. Along with crafting drugs, you can also craft other items. Like wallets to carry more money, weapon holsters to carry more weapons, or munitions pouch to carry more grenades. One thing that's strange about this is the fact that you must skin animals to craft these. However, for one thing you might need 2 Tiger skin, and the next, 1 Deer skin, see my problem with this?Scatered around the world are strongholds or "outposts" that are controlled by the pirates. You can take these down by killing all pirates on the inside. By capturing one of these strongholds, it makes the territory around you safe, and creates a fast travel system. Now, how you approach these strongholds to take them down is all up to you. You have full freedom to do what you want. You could run right in with heavy machine guns blazing it out. You sit from a far with a sniper rifle and pick them off. You could sneak in, perform takedowns and use a stealth recurve bow. Or you could lure an animal into the base. There are so many things you could do. To take down these strongholds, you need weapons, right? Worry no more. The weapons provided in Far Cry 3 consist of pistols, SMG's, Assault rifles, snipers, shotguns, HMG's, flare gun's, flame throwers, and way more.Now, while on a mission, though they provide a good story, you are restricted most of the time. Meaning you can't really approach the way you may want to. Alongside the main story, you of course have side missions. These are of two types, but work and are fun. The first of them being the Hunter missions. Where you take out an animal for various reasons. The second being the Wanted Dead missions, where it is your job to take down a baddie with your knife/machete. You also earn XP for getting kills and completing missions. XP will gain you skill points, which then lead to you choosing a skill you'd like. One problem with this system is, you don't have access to all the skills until you get futher into the story. As the skills move on, they get kind of more useless. However that's just my opinion.If there is really anything else I don't care about in this game, it's that the second half falls short of the first half. It doesn't really keep the hype going, it kind of dies down. Thoughts (Other)I'd like to post this here. Far Cry 3 is so far my most favorite single player experience of all time. The story was great, the gameplay was great. The soundtrack is amazing, and brings man tears. This was one of the best things I have ever played. Now a days, I use a hardcore mod. Mods are available for Far Cry 3 that can fix things, or make the game more realistic and hard. Now, obviously Far Cry 3 being my favorite, I cannot wait for the release of Far Cry 4 which only comes in a couple weeks. I cannot WAIT.Pro's & Con's (Overall Rating)Far Cry 3 is a great game that is well worth the time. For the story, the world, and the gameplay. Every piece of this game is full of greatness. You ability to do what you want beings a new level to video games. We need more, like this.Pro's:+Amazing story.+Great memorable characters.+Beautiful world that's full of life.+Great weapon mechanics.+Fantastic gameplay.+Big populated open world.Con's:-Second half of game falls a little short.-Multiplayer feels just slapped on.-Some of the crafting is strange.-Skill tree could use a little work.Overall Rating: About a 14/15 (Must Own!)Credits & DisclaimerThank you for taking the time to read my review, I hope this helped out with your decision on whether to make a purchase or not.Remember, this review is based off of opinion only. You may not think the same way as me towards something, but that's okay, because we are all human.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												Far Cry 3 is one of those open-world games that actually makes you FEEL you'd WANT to explore the Rook Islands with its varied wild flora AND fauna (hostile or indifferent), as well as the various enemies (pirates or privateers) and with the Rakyat assisting at times. The story missions are quite a lot of fun, and if you level up properly none of them are very difficult (i.e. do the stealth kills and try to take down outposts undetected to get extra XP for the skills). You started out as a party guy Jason Brody, who can't do anything. Your brother Grant was the ex-Army, and somehow you ended up captured on this island held by pirates and right in the INTRO sequence your brother got killed and your mad dash to freedom ended up with you diving over a waterfall, but you lived, and you woke up in a village, and handed your first mission... and a wimply pistol... get up this tower on top of the hill, and activate it. From there on, you steadily progress from a wimpy adrenaline junky to a fearsome killing machine capable of mowing down squads of professional mercenaries with LMG or assault rifle, hit wings off a fly at 100 yards with a sniper rifle, blade dance with professional knife fighters, stealth kill like a ninja, as you liberate the Rook Islands from two megalomaniacs, Vaas, and his boss, Hoyt, while recovering your friends one by one. The islands are beautiful, and the animals behave independently of you. Goats and Buffalos and pigs and more wander the landscape, and predators like bears, leopards, even tigers wander the wild hunting them, and if you get in the way, you as well. In the ocean there are bull sharks and regular fish, and in the swamps there are crocodiles. Yes, it's a ton of fun exploring the place. There are small villages, pirate and merc outposts (that you can liberate... by killing everybody), unoccupied villages that were sites of atrocities, more radio towers you can deactivate, plus for the obssessive collectors, various artifacts to collect, such as 120 relics from the past cultures (including one from Chinese history!) letters from the Japanese WW2 occupation (plenty of bodies left around), memory cards left in outposts detailing the sordid narc industry links of Rook Island, as well as different animals and plants (they go in the survival handbook). There are also untold number of caves, underground passages, leading to totally unknown areas deep within the bowels of the island that makes you wonder if you're playing Tomb Raider. :D  Indeed, the radio towers and many other sequences do require a bit of jumping and climbing to accomplish. Even on the surface, there are random things happening. Friendly and enemy jeeps patrol the routes. Enemy soldiers will patrol, and sometimes, force march prisoners / slaves on the road. You may engage, or not as you see fit, but they are excellent source of XPs, as valid as any one. And animals do roam the island, as it is wild out there. There are plenty of side missions, some of which are handed out by locals, like "help find my daughter, who ran away with boyfriend!"  in addition to the story missions. Furthermore, conquered outposts often have bounty missions (kill a pirate or a merc and his minions) as well as "path of the hunter" missions (hunt down X animals using provided weapons). (HINT: you only have to use the same CLASS of weapon, not the specific weapon. If they provide a regular .45ACP, bring your customized .44 Magnum or .50AE Desert Eagle)Ah, speaking of weapons... lots and lots of weapons. Pistols, sniper rifles, shotguns, assault rifiles, grenade launchers, light machine guns, special weapons (including recurve bow), and signature weapons. Some weapons can be customized with different type of sights, extended magazines, even a suppressor. And there are different paintjobs available too. Add the oddballs, like repair tool (welding torch), flamethrower, and even a flare gun... and things can get interesting indeed. Did I mention that many vehicles have mounted weapons, like a HMG that you can wield?  How you tackle mission (usually involving killing everybody at a certain place) is entirely up to you. Run and gun? Snipe and hide? Silent and deadly? Lure and ambush? It is all up to you. When you have the best sniper rifle (.50 cal with suppressor two-stage zoom scope) you can kill even a heavy with a single shot to the head from afar. There are also sometimes captured predators that you can "liberate" with a shot to the cage, thus letting it attack the enemies in the camp for you! Remember, bonus points if you were never detected (1500 xp instead of 500 xp). I have tried many open-world games before, from Far Cry 2 to Mercenaries 2, from GTA 3 (and sequels) to many others. Far Cry 3 stands above the rest because it is so well balanced. it doesn't unlock too many skills (some require you to unlock via story missions) at once, no matter how much XP you accumulated. it also doesn't unlock the 2nd island until well past 75% point. At each point you are reminded of the stakes you're playing with... the lives of your friends that may still be in pirate's hands, and each and every one will be scarred for life. The villians are psychopaths, but interesting psychopaths. And the other characters that you meet? They all have their own motivations, which may or may not match your own. Somehow, FC3 just struck the right balance between too "scattered brained", i.e. "Too many choices! What do I do now?" vs. "where's the freedom? I am bored, I want to do something ELSE"...  And there are plenty of variety in the missions as well as outposts. On the hunt missions, you have to use the specified weapon class/type., which can be challenging, such as hunting tigers with a pistol, or bears with a shotgun. On the bounty missions, you are to kill the one or two "leaders" with your blade. The rest are up to you with no restrictions. Just keep in mind in late game there can be two leaders with a dozen minions around them, and killing them all can be a difficult endeavor, esp. if you can only knife the leaders. The skills you learn are divided into three categories: crane, shark, and spider, which of which has a different "tree". As mentioned before, they are unlocked by progressing in the story missions and can be learned by spending "skill points" which are earned by every few thousand XP. And they add a lot of fun abilities, such as chain takedowns, knife throw take down, grenade takedown, double take down, death from above, death from below, and so on. There are bazillion crates scattered on the island, each containing some artifacts and/or money. You can further loot the bodies (enemy or friendly) for more artifacts, many of which can be sold for $$$. If you have killed some fauna, you cna often skin them for making containers / slings for ammo, wallet, and so on, and it's the only way you can carry more weapons, more ammo, even more money. In fact, you can also craft herbal medicine from the plants you gathered (which are generically divided into "colored leaves", and you need X of Red and Y of yellow and so on. As you progress you'll learn other formulas, like animal repellant, hunting instinct (lets you see animals, even behind hills), as well as herbal medicine that just heals you, deep dive potion that lets you go below 60 meters deep, and more. All in all, Far Cry 3 is a ton of fun with variety of missions, side mission, as well as plenty of freeform encounter play. The story of growth and one man's journey from wimp to hero is the story of the player. And THAT ultimately, is why it's so much fun.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Far cry 3's best moments are also some of my best moments in gaming, I'll leave my love for this game aside and try be fair evaluating it's aspects.First of all, you can feel the Far cry 2 engine here, similar animations and gunplay, but its definitley improved. Graphics are pretty, shaders could have been a little less saturated for a more realistic look, but its an art direction choice, still beautiful anyway! I found a few bugs, objects revealing geometry, shadows loading in a weird way and black textures appearing on roads whenever I was nearby, It breaks immersion but don't compromise the fun.Gameplay is fluid, animations are well made, guns feel powerful and there are plenty to choose from your loadout, you can craft boosts from herbs you harvest in the jungle, use a bow that add's a Hunter feel that we all love, and take a stealthy approach if that's your thing, that was something I wasn't sure it would work out well but It did, I finished the game using the knife and bow mostly.Performance is pretty fair, the game runs well if you have a good machine and still pretty even on medium specs, I played this with an GTS450 on medium and then maxed out with a 650ti Boost, running with 40fps most of the time.Story and characters are quite memorable, did I ever tell you the definition of good character design? you got it.After you finish the story you still have activities to complete, hunt & assassination missions, outposts to clear,  towers to climb and work your magic to unlock new weapons, it's a very rewarding game and it has lore on every item you acquire. I still have to try the co-op, if you're reading this maybe we should give it a try!? tl;dr+ Open world+ Memorable story and characters+ Gun customization and variety+ Stealth is an option + Replay value + Burning weed with Skrillex™- Minor graphic bugs sometimes- Requires Ubi-Launcher- DLC is Irrelevant and Skippable- Dead multiplayer

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
Exceptional open-world shooter with a dark twistFar Cry 3 was developed by Ubisoft Montréal & Shanghai and published late 2012 to great ciritcal acclaim. I played it only recently (early 2015), but even though some years old, this game feels like it was made recently. As the third installment in the famous Far Cry franchise, it continues upon the open-world orientated gameplay establised by Far Cry 2, while fixing almost all of the problems that game had and offering a feel and way of playing all of its own.The game makes one identify to a degree with Jason Brody, the playable protagonist who is taken captive together with his friends on a tropical island by a gang of pirates lead by someone called Vaas. The opening sequence of the game, from the initial cutscene with the rather vainly partying friends up to the first encounter with Vaas and the escape from his claws, stands out as a classic way of making clear what a game is all about. Vaas is a sinister character, as dark and evil as one could imagine, and more. His fascination with utter violence and the madness of the human mind offers some memorable gaming moments, that made me stare at my screen in utter disbelief and will stay with me for a long time.Jason Brody starts out as a rather unsure would-be-hero, who is shocked whenever he sees someone killed, and who is very reluctant to kill himself. But his encounter with the sheer evil of Vaas and his fellow criminals, gradually turns him into a killing machine, with only one goal: to free his friends, and ultimately seek revenge. The game cleverly underscores this development by offering some role-playing element: finishing missions or killing enemies grants experience points and levels you up so that you can acquire several abilities which help to overcome obstacles more easily. While the game is rather challenging during its first hours, with raising in level and acquiting more special abilities and better weapons it gets easier, which helps to get the idea of turning into a mean killing machine rather well.Apart from Jason Brody and Vaas, Far Cry 3 contains several interesting and even unique characters along with three "factions" spread out on two distinct islands. There are too many characters to mention them all, but standing out apart from Vaas is Citra, the priestess of the natives who introduces an almost palpable sexual, brooding tension into the game. One of the best parts of the game is the excellent voice-acting: every charachter, how odd or sinister, is made completely believable through his or her voice.The world itself is huge: longer journeys can take up to ten minutes, even by car, jeep or boat (of which there are several types). All in all, the story is not only gripping and very well told, it is combined with the freedom of an open world in a very convincing way. You can play this game in several different ways, the options being almost limitless. Following the main story is a valid possibility, but I found it more interesting to divert from this quite often, roaming around in the astoundingly beautiful world in order to capture an enemy outpost (either by force, stealth or cunning, the choice is once more yours!), gather some useful plants or just hunt for animals (who offer several rewards as well).Apart from the 38 missions in the main storyline, there are over two hundred (!!) side-missions, ranging from stealth kills to hunting specific animals with a specific weapon, trying one's driving skills in a race, climbing communication towers in order to reveal parts of the map or even playing some poker. The amount of gaming hours to be got in singleplayer alone runs into several dozens or more, comparable to a game in that other famous open-world franchise, Assassin's Creed. I tried the multiplayer as well, but the servers are almost empty by now, alone the rather bland co-op still offers some possibilities.Apart from the amazing game- and gunplay, the game is a prime example of state-of-the-art graphics and sound, excellently optimized and hardly showing that it was primarily aimed at consoles. It runs flawlessly on my 7-year old pc with a 2,66 Ghz cpu, 4 GB ram and a GeForce GTX 650 ti. All the expected options and tweaks for optimal performance are there, but it has to be said: the game does look much better on the highest settings (very high or ultra), so even if it costs you some fps, do try those. The one thing that could offset several players is the mandatory use of the "infamous" Uplay, a platform that gets huge criticism more often than not. However, for me Uplay just works fine, not only in this but in every other game I played on it. Granted, the achievements are a bit pointless since they don't show on Steam, but the possibility of unlocking extra content by gaining U-points in quite nice. Apart from that, the few dlc packets for the game are completely superfluous, but that's a very, very minor criticism.Anyone interested in the recent developments of first-person shooters or in the way a modern game can tell a story in combination with an open gaming world, should buy and play this game.Gameplay: 28/30Graphics: 19/20Sound: 9/10Longelivety: 9/10Technical: 9/10Steam Integration: 6/10 (Uplay required, but that works fine for me)Personal appreciation: 10/10Overall: 90/100

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												Solution to the Uplay issue: Disable the Uplay overlay1) Go into Uplay settings2) General settings tab3) Untick the "enable in-game overlay for supported games" box4) Start the game and click to confirm you want to start the game without the Uplay overlay onThe issue is Steam AND Uplay tries to enable their overlays to the game which cancel out and makes the game freeze and crash. By disabling the Uplay overlay, it allows Steam to take over and the game runs smoothly. I had this issue for about 5 months before figuring it out, sadly.Review: Solid game, played it on console back in the day when it first came out but never finished the story, just fooled around in the open-world. 4/5 stars. Only 4 stars because the graphics are slightly dated in 2016. Good tropical setting, amazing story, good believable antagonist (the voice acting is where the villian really shines). It's better than Far Cry 4 in all departments besides graphics. There's even more players on Far Cry 3 than all of the Far Cry titles on Steam (perhaps the summer sale has something to do with it, who knows?).

Posted: December 25, 2013
												It might not be fair to "downvote" this game for that reason, but I feel it needs to be mentioned. The "Steam" version of the game also bundles a ton of crapware that gets installed on your PC, whether you want it or not. Namely, it installs Ubisoft's "Uplay" DRM/Steam-like system. It also forces you to create an Uplay account. Basically, Steam serves as a glorified CD-key seller, whereas your CD-key actually needs to copied and activated on UPLAY.I think this is unacceptable. We buy games on Steam, because it's a streamlined delivery method, and the DRM is handled by Steam itself (or at least transparent to the user). If Ubisoft wants to shove their DRM and services down everyone's throat, that is fine, but Steam should not be enabling them without being very explicit to their players. Of course, there are no refunds, and uninstalling the game DOES NOT remove all of the installed crapware.

For me it's one of the best Single Player game.Gameplay - 10/10Beautiful world depicted on the tropical island, giving many opportunities for the player. We can explore caves, forests, mountains, hunting for animals on land and under water. We can attack the enemy camps and capture them. These sandbox gives many, many opportunities.Storyline - 9/10Story is presented in a nice method. We have many ways to pass the mission. We can do it quietly or destroying and killing everything what we meet on the way. The story is for 10h game.Characters - 10/10Each character has its own charm. Characters are well matched to the storyline and to the environment. My favorite character in this game is Vaas Montego, he fits to this game like a "fist to the eye". Is also a plus, we can choose the path of the main character.Graphics - 9/10Graphics in this game is amazing. Even the smallest details are well refined, for example when we move the grass moves with us. Graphics capabilities used in 100%. Water, sky, trees, etc. are beautiful.Sounds - 10/10Music and ambient sounds in this game is great fits. I liked moment with Skrillex (Make It Bun Dem), but I don't wanna spoiler. Animals noises are natural.Overall - 10/10If you are thinking about purchase this game, if you like open world and First-Person Shooter games, I would recommend these game for you, and I guarantee a lot of fun comes from the game.

Posted: May 28, 2016
 Doesn't Play Nice With Windows 10	This is a very good game. Still looks good, even today. A competant story (that eventually runs out of steam hard toward the end), and at this point an iconic villian. Fun gameplay and will run like butter on most modern systems.Oh hello there windows 10, care to screw it all up?So yeah at least in my case and a couple other forum users, Windows 10 made launching this game a nightmare. Either it wont launch through steam at all or it will immediately crash. Here's what you do:Go to your folder for the game, for example: C: > Program Files 86 > Steam > Steamapps > Common > Far Cry 3 > binRight Click on farcry3_d3d11.exe (not farcry3.exe), go to properties > compatibility and set it to windows 7 (8 may work too but i use 7). Then launch THAT executable and only that one. Should work fine then.If you're willing to deal with that headache, then it's still a great game.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												The game itself is enjoyable, but I can no longer play it. A couple months ago I uninstalled this game because I wasn't playing it. After installing it I can no longer access my Uplay account because Uplay wouldn't accept my password. I tried to recover my password, but Uplay refused to send me a password recovery email. I tried to get support, but in order to get Uplay support you have to log in to Uplay. I can't play anymore because Uplay won't let me log in. Thanks, Ubisoft. You truly are my greatest ally.Also if you're wondering "Why didn't you make an account to contact support?" Well I did, but even after a couple months I never did get that confirmation email.[No Spoilers and tl;dr at the bottom]Edit: After numerous comments asking me to change my review to postive, I've decided to go in-depth as to what I think about the game. I'd advise you to take my opinions with a grain of salt because I haven't been able to play the game in about a year. As for the game itself I would say that it's enjoyable at best. The story isn't interesting in the slightest, but the occasions when Vaas shows up can be quite entertaining. I would say that Vaas was the only reason the story slightly interested me at all because I didn't care at all about my friends. Why would I considering they weren't developed enough for me to even care? Without spoilers the ending gives 2 choices that you have to make on the spot and none of them effect anything. They're not satisfying and the only reason there are 2 choices is because you gotta have that variety right? Anyways I don't think that the story is the reason people play Far Cry 3, because the game is more focused towards free-roam. The world is big, but there isn't much to do. You can hunt, do some side missions, take down enemy outposts, pick flowers, find some collectables, but that's about it. There isn't much going on around you so it makes the world feel empty. I don't remember seeing many animals besides a couple of herds and a few lone panthers. When you take down an outpost the enemies stop spawning in the area, which makes sense, but it makes that area far more boring and almost usless in terms of replay value. One thing they did to fix this is that you can reset the outposts when they're all overtaken. It's a much appreciated feature that should add a lot of replay value if you've enjoyed the main game. There is around 4 weapons for each class (Snipers, pistols, rifles and such) and some special weapons, but most of the common weapons are just generic. A few good examples of the less generic weapons are the A2000, U100, Flamethrower, and BZ19. Shooting in this game shouldn't be that interesting, but it feels much more satisfying due to the fantastic animations. One last thing I liked is that you can customize if you want to go in with a stealthy or more explosive approach. The game gives you a lot of options if we're talking about how you want to approach enemies.I'd say if you want to have a game you can play sometimes and have a bit of fun go ahead and buy this one. If I remember correctly there is co-op so that might be fun with your friends. I've never tried it, but it might be worth a shot. Twenty dollars isn't too bad of a price, but at that price you're better off getting Deus Ex: Human Revolution, Bioshock 1, Rainbow Six Vegas 2, Insurgency, Fallout New Vegas, Splinter Cell Choas Theory, or Far Cry 3 Blood Dragon (I like the atmosphere and weapons in Blood Dragon more than 3 because it feels a lot more unique. Also it has laser guns + lazer lizards) If you want a free-roam jungle fps I don't know any others besides Far Cry 3, so if you want to play this game specifically for that reason alone it wouldn't be too bad of an idea to get this. If you want this for the story just look it up on Youtube. If you want this just for Vaas, refer to my previous statement.tl;dr: Get it if you want a free-roam fps jungle game. The story sucks, Vass is kind of cool, and the free roam and variety of approaches may be the deal breaker for you. It's all right as a free-roam game, but don't expect to be blown away at all or interested for more than 20 hours. There is co-op but I can't say anything about that sense I haven't played it. It might be worth a try with your friends.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Far Cry 3 was my introduction to the Far Cry franchise. Now I’m not a huge fan of first person shooters (FPS) but there are some goods and this is one of them. This is a open world game which other then the story missions to advance the main objectives you can play how you like.  Set on an island where you Jason Brody must free your friends from the psychotic Vaas.  And there are times you wish you could play as Vaas or enter his mind at least because he is an first-class psycho.  Rook island is a land semi-forgotten by the world.  Where you hunt down relics of the ancient ancestors that lived on the island.  See and feel the effects of World War 2 on this Pacific island.  Truly a world where anything goes and does happen.  The story happens in a nonlinear fashion but as you progress you will see how it all fits together and how this forges your champion Jason Brody.  And the nice thing about the far cry series is each game is its own other then being an open world shooter you don't need to play them in an particular order.  If your looking for a game you can run through swamps, jungles, and mountains you found it don't get me wrong it is no Skyrim on that size but it will take you a good 10+ to get from one side to another.  But if you are one of the people that has to everything in a game you can easily get 60+ hours of play time.  The biggest downside of the game is your friends you are rescuing how they seem unaffected by this island.  The graphics are awe inspiring and the cut scenes will have your heart racing especially.....* NO SPOILERS*  Get the game and find out for yourself.

Posted: July 13, 2013
												Far Cry 3 is a first-person shooter action game created by Ubisoft Montreal in 2012.The player, Jason Brody, skydives with friends and ends up on an island full of pirates and natives called Rakyat that are in conflict . Jason escapes but is unconscious. An inhabitant of the island, a Rakyat called Denis rescues him and performs a tattoo that gives Jason powers. This is the first step on his journey to become a warrior. From there he must find and free his friends.The game is a sandbox, and the main story is just a little part of it, the player is free to make a huge amount of fun activities. Play racing , throw knives , face challenges, hunt animals , free towers and regain positions held by pirates. The game has the graphic quality of a first person shooter with the freedom of an RPG .The graphics engine is called Dunia Engine. The graphic quality is very good , similar to Crysis, awesome for being a Sandbox. Far Cry3 was one of the best and most complete games of 2012. Extremely funny and fascinating.It is a worthy successor to Far Cry , well above the poor Far Cry 2 . A true wonder for lovers of external environments and forests in games.The game was released for PC , PS3 and XBOX 360. The PC version has superior graphics and a powerful graphics card with DirectX 11 is seriously recommended.And Trisha the Warrior ..... ohh, I can't tell you how hot she is.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ESPAÑOL-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Far Cry 3 es un juego de acción en primera persona creado por Ubisoft Montreal en 2012. El jugador, Jason Brody, hace paracaidismo con sus amigos y termina en una isla llena de piratas y nativos llamados Rakyat que están en conflicto. Jason escapa pero queda inconciente. Un habitante de la Isla, Rakyat, Denis, lo rescata y le realiza un tatuaje que le brinda poderes y es el primer paso para convertirse en un guerrero. A partir de allí deberá buscar y liberar a sus amigos. El juego es un sandbox, si bien tiene su historia principal, el jugador es libre de hacer una enorme cantidad de actividades divertidas. Jugar carreras, lanzar cuchillos, enfrentar desafíos, cazar animales, liberar torres y recuperar puestos tomados por los piratas. El juego posee la calidad de un shooter en primera persona con la libertad de un juego de rol.  El motor gráfico se denomina Dunia Engine. La calidad gráfica es muy buena, similar a un Crysis, impresionante para ser un Sandbox. Fue uno de los mejores y más completos juegos del año 2012. Sumamente divertido y fascinante. Es un digno sucesor del Far Cry, muy superior al pobre Far Cry 2. Una verdadera maravilla para los amantes de los juegos en selvas paradisíacas con entornos externos y animales.El juego se lanzó para PC, PS3 y XBOX 360. La versión de PC tiene gráficos superiores y se recomienda una poderosa tarjeta gráfica con DirectX 11. Y la Guerrera Trisha..... uhh ni les cuento esa guerrera como está.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												Uplay really ruined this game. Your game does not save, even if you do a manual in-game save, if it doesn't sychronize with the Ubisoft cloud. If you have a sporadic internet connection, as I do, you can basically kiss your in-game progress goodbye. After the game crashed on me and I restarted it, I load my game to find out I am about a dozen hours of gameplay back. This is completely unacceptable, considering every other game I have encountered has no trouble saving or loading your progress. There is no reason you should have to be sync'd to a company's servers the entire time you are playing a single player game.The money I spent on Far Cry 3 is the only money that Ubisoft will ever see from me. Hopefully they can use it toward updating their awful system.

number of helpful: 81 of 103 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: Far Cry 3 

			Views: 1,346		

			Join Trent on a summer vacation to Rook Island as he reviews Far Cry 3 in anticipation of Ubisoft's upcoming Far Cry 4. Does this open world FPS intelligently convey the regression of civilized man...		

Many people dream of finding themselves posted on a white sand beach on an island in the pacific, sipping a tropical drink and flicking tenacious hermit crabs from their belongings. If you are ambitious and a bit stupid, like Jason Brody and company, then you may try to spice up the proceedings with a bit of skydiving. So begins, Far Cry 3, a game about a bunch of American yuppies on a vacation that has seriously gone wrong. Back and 2004 Far Cry's open world gameplay was revolutionary, roaming tropical islands slaying mercs and trigens created quite a splash before being encumbered by the tsunami that was Doom 3 and Half Life 2 later the same year. With S.T.A.L.K.E.R being the only other franchise to successfully merge open world shooting with light RPG elements, and Crytek moving toward more traditional levels for their Crysis games, the market is wide open for Ubisoft's vacation from hell simulator.  While living it up in Bangkok in order to celebrate his younger brother obtaining his pilot's license, Jason Brody and crew make the ill fated decision to go skydiving. They happen to land on an island infested with pirates and they are taken hostage where they are being primed to be sold into slavery. Jason escapes and meets some locals who aid him in his quest to find his friends and escape since they see it as an opportunity to have Jason liberate their island. It's a tale that's part Deliverance, part Indiana Jones with a dash of the drug abusing hijinx in Alice in Wonderland. Far Cry 3's narrative benefits from a number of eccentric personalities like Spike Lee's Island dwelling clone Dennis, gaming's most possessive and insane ♥♥♥♥♥ Citra,  and doctor who indulgences in enough mind altering substances to make Hunter S. Thompson blush. Topping off the insane cast of character's is Vaas, the leader of the pirates. Unfortunately, Far Cry 3 blunders Final Fantasy VIII style by shifting the focus away from Vaas partway through the game and substituting a far less engaging and charismatic villain. The well worn theme of civilized man reverting to a more primitive state to survive in a primitive environment is a bit hamfisted as every few missions has Jason returning to his girlfriend so that she can keep pointing out how he has changed... Also, the plot is tainted by a white messiah complex. For some reason it seems that the legions of native warriors are not the equal of one white guy with a crappy tribal tattoo and a desire to save his friends.  While Jason is not a soldier or gun toter by trade, he quickly warms up to carrying a firearm and explosives in order to liberate his friends. Missions give Jason the opportunity to earn money and experience which he can use to augment his skills and buy new weapons and attachments. Slaughtering the wildlife also gives Jason the opportunity to craft new storage for ammo, explosives and money. The flora can be harvested in order to create medicines that allow Jason to heal and enhance his senses. While all of these crafting opportunities help make use of the large game world and the critters that inhabit it, it also means that the game can have an agonizing start. Initially, Jason can only carry one weapon and very little ammo meaning that exploration grinds to a halt after only a few minutes before needing to resupply. You will want to craft new holsters to hold more weapons and compartments for more ammo immediately. Torching bears with flame throwers, using grenades as depth charges to kill crocodiles and sharks and running kommodo dragons over with jeeps does provide a depraved and perverted form of entertainment. Also populating the world are radio towers that have to be scaled in order to unlock a section of the map a la Assassin's Creed and Outposts that need to be cleared out in order to keep those pesky pirates from roaming certain regions of the map. Both the towers and the outposts have unique layouts and terrain that distinguishes one from another but never the less you will fall into a pattern of uncovering the map then liberating the outposts as you progress deeper into the game which becomes terribly repetitive. The wildlife in Far Cry 3 doesn't exist solely for the benefit of adding pouches to Jason's belt either. Animals are often found in cages in enemy outposts where they can be freed to create havok. It just so happens that pirates are much easier to kill when they are trying to save one of their buddies from getting murdered by an angry cassowary. While Far Cry 3 provides weaponry and attachments that encourage stealth, it's also possible to raid outposts full shock and awe style with guns on full auto chucking grenades like Eli Manning throws interceptions. Both methods have their thrills but almost invariably players will lean on their overpowered weaponry late in the game to steam roll the opposition. The extra 1,000 experience just isn't worth the time saved by storming an outpost Rambo style.  Fortunately, Far Cry 3's main missions provide a much needed reprieve from the repetition of radio tower climbing and outpost raiding. Missions often take Jason to instanced areas like abandoned Japanese bunkers from World War 2 and ancient temples with Indiana Jones style perils. Even a handful of late game filler missions offer some riotous thrills and enough fireworks to please even the most jaded action gamer. Forced stealth sections are staged in such a way they they are painfully easy however and some really irritating quick time events rear their ugly heads and detract from the experience. Like wise a mid game string of quests that have you raiding ancient temples to reassemble a magic compass throw the tone of the game off. If all of the aforementioned content isn't satisfactory to you there are also extra missions that have you killing animals and special targets with a specified weapon, score-based Rakyat challenges and some small errands given to you by NPCs. It's a rather robust singleplayer that will last most gamers 15 to 20 hours.  The Far Cry 3 experience doesn't stop with it's campaign however. There are six co-op missions that tell the story of a group of rough around the edges characters who have been duped out of their money by the Pirates and are pursuing them on Rook Island. The narrative is sparse and the gameplay does little to really take advantage of having three friends playing alongside you. You earn experience that unlocks upgrades that can also be used for the competitive multiplayer suit. Multiplayer is a collection of variations of classic multiplayer modes like Team Deathmatch, King of the Hill, capture the flag and domination. The multiplayer does little nothing to take advantage of some of Far Cry's more unique features. Don't expect your foes to be mauled to death by tigers or to be able to jump into a vehicle to make a hasty escape. Odds are, players will get more time out of the main campaign.

												By far one of the best games I have ever played.Storyline - 9/10Would be 10/10 but I think the player would need to have more influence in particular events. Apart from that, brilliant story and I was so excited to see what happened at the end!Characters - 10/10The main characters that you will encounter throughout your playthrough are: Jason, Vaas, Hoyt, Riley (debateable) and Dennis. A great set of characters, who are very interesting and hard to read just by their actions (I think this is a good thing).Graphics - 10/10For a 2012 game, the graphics are brilliant, . The sky is awesome and some of the scenery is just unbeatable in my opinion!Performance - 10/10Don't really need to explain this one. The rating I have given it explains it all.Open World - 9/10 Would be 10/10 but when you are trying to hunt and explore for instance, you are constantly being attacked by bandits or privateers, but if this wasn't a problem the game would probably be less enjoyable, I just think it could have been toned down a little bit. Apart from that, the open world is fantastic, you can hunt, explore, drive, just go on killing sprees or just admire the beautiful scenery that this game provides.Overall - 9.5/10I have came to this conclusion because this is a brilliant game with only a few minor problems. 												Just finished the single player game and I did a good chunk of the side stuff other than some stuff like the gambling and racing... the game sure does pack a lot of content and has some pretty cool moments. Easy to recommend to anyone that enjoys sandbox FPS action. I kind of got fed up with the game 80% of the way in and just wanted to finish it already but that's just me. I was more patient with far cry 2 and I enjoyed that game overall more than this game even though in many ways this has improved on fc2's most obvious annoyances though it does introduce some of its own. The game's key fights are decided by quicktime events... that was really lame but I'm really just nitpicking. There's so much stuff do in the game that it practically has something for everyone. Solid game that is amazing in parts.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is wonderful in terms of the environment and graphics (stunning visuals!). There are not many games that have such an enjoyable system of roaming around the map, hunting, driving, swimming, flying etc. The fight is often easy, but fun. The singleplayer experience is quite tense and full of fast-paced action (car chases, bomb escapes, burning houses, helicopter flights, ambushes... a lot of good points). There are even some stealth aspects, you may conquer the outposts in a silent-assassin way and I admit - it gave me a lot of good gameplay experience, especially with later knife skills. Aside from the outposts you'll see it's just a nicely scripted shooter often with no practical use for silent approach :)So, why do I give it a negative mark? Let me explain in a few points...If you spend some time on doing side miniquests and hunt, you get really powerful - I quickly got to point when I maxed my skill tree, had bought everything I could and still had overflow of money. Of course, it's up to you how far you go with exploring the map, so let's say it's not a minus, more like neutral remark.The game has a very dark feeling in it. A lot of despair, loneliness, brutality, often without reason. Sometimes the protagonist make extremely stupid, unbelievable decisions. Your enemies (and some allies...) are psychopatic maniacs. There are a lot of drug themes. I know a lot of these are justified by the plot, but every time I moved a bit forward in game (not counting map exploration), I felt sad and dull. (game music even amplify it) Watch out, if you feel pesimist, probably this game might just make you feel worse...Whole drug aspect - not only there's too much of it for my taste, I also feel that the game creators took it as a handy shortcut for fixing loose plot points. I don't want to leave spoilers here, so let's just say that replacing a few proper fights with drug induced visions (and then, magically, your character somehow won everything!) is very cheap. You see a problem but don't solve it, just hop into narcotic projection, see some ghosts and delusions, get back to 'real' world and everything is already done. Yay...Although many parts of the campaign were enjoyable (especially action scenes mentioned before), the ending itself was so disgusting/stupid (I chose "good" ending, "bad" one was even worse) that it totally threw me off this game. Honestly, I haven't played it anymore since I finished the main plot.Multiplayer - I managed to unlock everything before I finished singleplayer and then, without the feeling of getting rewards, it got very boring. It's not a bad experience, but it's very chaotic, certainly not better than other shooters. There are no dedicated servers, so you have little influence on any technical aspect of the game. Also, expect A LOT of hosting problems, a few host migrations during one match seemed like a standard...Oh, also the game needs to be played under Uplay - Ubisoft DRM system, which is very inconvenient, much less comfortable than Steam... (a bit ridiculous, that we already have to use two platforms, Steam and Uplay, at once to play a game, who knows how many additional programs we will have to run in future to play one game?)

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Uplay... god-damnit. Uplay means Noplay for me. I am tired of running extra 3rd party clients. I already play through Steam, and that is perfectly fine for me, it has more than enough DRM features. I don't want to run Uplay as well and have it all linked up. I don't care, I don't want it. Uplay is one of the heaviest DRM I have seen in a while. It's a hassle, and I use Steam already...I don't want yet another program open to "connect" with others and "track my progress". For Steam being what it is, I forget how much Ubisoft likes to really remind the player that they are playing UBISOFT'S game and the player just has "access" to it. It's like long term renting at a flat price.As far as FarCry 3, the game itself, by this time the internet is full of Reviews by now. So I won't recap. I hear it's a good looking game and can be a lot of fun. But combined with the issues above and being at a point in my gaming life where I just didn't care as soon as the opening scene started. I just wanted to get out on the islands, wander, explore, adventure, blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up. Yet as I listened to the story drone on, and started the first stealthy escape sequence I just remembered: "I don't care... I really don't care. I don't want to go through this 'tutorial' period. I don't want to be introduced to a bunch of characters I don't care about , locations half of which I won't return to, objectives I'll forget what they are related to, skill trees I'll get tired of trying to unlock, loot out the a-hole, blueprints for too many things  won't make, and everything else for the first few hours or so. Just leave me alone, let me wander. Basically, give me the end game freedoms. I don't have time for all this." (Note: I am just stating my personal sensation at the time, clearly not all games are approached with this level of cynicism. But this one did not grab me enough to fight through it this time. And although I do greatly enjoy open world exploration games with many of these features, this one felt to tedious and predictable right off.)Obviously, this isn't really a review of the game, just a friendly reminder of "Uplay" and it's annoying " joys ". And combined with a bit of a predictable set-up, I just can't say I want to deal with it. Even after a good sale. It looks cool, and there looks like some good fun moments, but I guess I just don't want to put in the time to get there.For you real fans, I am not putting down the games themselves. I am not trying dissuade anyone seriously interested in this game, or the franchise. But those on the fence, stay there and maybe lean back a little. Uplay is freaking annoying. It's like running a whole 'nother Steam while you are already playing your game through Steam. You even have to activate other Ubisoft games with activation keys inside Uplay the same way as you do in Steam. And while in game you get a little prompt to open Uplay with shift+F2 just like you can with the Steam overlay...seriously, if you are wondering if maybe you could waste a little casual time for fun in FarCry 3 with the ease of Steam...Nope. It is all an extra annoying hassle with Uplay. It's lame. And consider, if Uplay servers go down, you may not have accessto your game/s. If you already really like the game and very much want it, go for it. You've already made the choice and it does look good.[If it was without Uplay, and a "standalone" game in this way, I would recommend on sale; post FC4 release.]

content:
Posted: January 18
												Far Cry 3 is an action packed adventure. You have multiple objectives you can do and they don’t have to be done in order or you can simply never do them! You can find relics, raid outposts, explore, find treasure chests, and many more endeavors within Far Cry 3. The campaign reminds me of college students on vacation and things go south and rather rapidly. I don’t want to spoil anything, but the story itself contains mysteries, mystical happenings, and a crazy adventure that won’t leave a bad taste behind like other action adventure titles. The game itself is open world and both islands are living, breathing entities. Whether its people driving around, guards patrolling, or a lion prowling in the tall grasses of the jungle, there is always some form of activity going on in the background or around you. To explore this vast world, one can obtain ATVs, vehicles, boats or air gliders and enjoy the beautiful scenery of the Rook Islands. The scenery has lush jungles, waterfalls, white sandy beaches, clear blue waters, swamps, and green grasslands. The developers put a lot of thought in this game and it seems they added a bit of every biome in this title. You’ll notice outposts and telecommunication towers – the outposts provide you with a means of fast travel, a place to sell/buy items, and local militia to fight near your proximity. The telecommunication towers help you reveal large portions of the map so you can prioritize your next adventure or continue your way on the campaign. There are a few factions on the islands, but I won’t go into them since they may or may not be a spoiler (I’d rather be safe than sorry). With any open world game there is customization or crafting (most of the time) and this game delivers, even though it is on a smaller scale than other titles. Your crafting consists of killing wildlife and using their hides to make a bigger holster, a bigger ammo bag, etc. in order to obtain more items (ammo, syringes, etc.). You can customize guns (paint, scope, magazine, etc.), but don’t assume the customization is big compared to Battlefield titles or other shooting games. They do bare bones on customization with guns, but they do improve a big portion of the stats relating to the gun (aim, ammo capacity, range, etc.). They could have added more customization/crafting options in the game, but I did like the quests that one must obtain to maximize their crafting potential. The UI was clunky at times; I’d have to press multiple times of ESC to get back to the game as one example. The game was well enough to ignore the clunkiness of the UI and the game has a few years on it, so it isn’t ‘modernized’. I didn’t have any FPS drops or bottlenecking when playing this title. I never experienced any crashes or delays or audible problems that sounded off or distant. The voices were done in a way to have an emotional experience and trying to connect with the player when going through the campaign and experiencing the hardships from protagonist, his friends, and his enemies.A title like Far Cry 3 needs no spoilers and I truly think most people who like action adventure games will enjoy this title. I might not have done everything (finding relics, treasure, etc.), but I did finish the campaign and I would recommend this title to anyone. There are still a lot of content for me to finish, so this game is worth its price.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Far Cry 3 is an open world first-person shooter published by Ubisoft Entertainment. It is the next installment of Far Cry series after Far Cry 2.Far Cry 3 gameplay, it has open world, it has small RPG element, and it has one of the best villain character ever. In my opinion Far Cry 3 open world feature is almost similar to Assassin's Creed where you have to climb a radio tower, interact some sort of panel to explore some area on the world around the tower. In Far Cry 3 you don't just get to shoot somebody and run. You can buy and upgrade weapons in store, level up getting new tattoos which conveniently giving you new abilities such as walk faster or something, also, there are some upgrades that require you to hunt for animals hide or plants. The best part is, when you shoot a tiger, it will fight back! Let your guard down and a leopard will eat you. Got bored? Maybe you should go to a village and play some poker games and rob those poker players. Do you want to become Hawkeye? Legolas? or maybe Rambo? Use explosive archer and blow some goats. Got angry? Use a flamethrower and burn the forest! Far Cry 3 has many great feature for a first-person shooter. You will like it.Far Cry 3 has cool graphics, it is one of the best graphics I've ever seen, not because its so advanced, but because the weapons first-person animation is unique, so alive and... Okay maybe it's not one of the best, but I like it. Far Cry 3 has very good performance.Too bad Far Cry 3 multiplayer feels like it has been left out, because it's not as awesome as the singleplayer mode. I was thinking the multiplayer will be more like huge maps on the same island, hundreds of players fighting together, something like that. Same thing about the cooperative play. But at least you get to blow something up with bow in singleplayer.Far Cry 3 is not bad, its good, I recommend this.Rating 8/10

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is a blast! Immersive landscape and environments, living wilderness, lots of enemies and multiple possibilities to take them down. Will you raid a camp Rambo-style, gun-blazing everything and everyone? Will you put C4 bombs on your car and use it to make a diversion? Will you open a cage to release a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ tiger on your enemies? Or will you sneak your way through? The choice is all yours.The story is simple but feels alright, the characters are all pretty charismatic and have their own personalities; the game has humour and dramatic moments. It is beautiful and immersive. The gameplay is varied enough, and when you think it might become boring, new gameplay elements come in. Lots of missions and side-missions to keep you occupied for quite some time; I've played more than 16 hours when I'm writing this review and haven't even finished it yet. Take your time, do some missions, get lost in the jungle, plan your tactics and stop being a prey: be the predator.I only wish the stealth approaches would be more realistic like it was in Far Cry 2, and a better crafting system.At first I didn't think I'd like this game, but now I love it.A solid 8.5 or 9/10 for this piece of work.

number of helpful: 26 of 30 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												If there's one thing Far Cry 3 does incredibly well, it's give you a very detailed, open-ended game world that's loaded up with so many optional objectives, collectibles and side missions that you'll probably put the game's main narrative on hold in favor of exploring. It's a fantastic-looking first person shooter with a great combat system, and while the main story isn't exactly Shakespeare, there's enough interesting stuff going on to more than make up for it.Far Cry 3 takes players to the tropical paradise of Rook Island, where Jason, a young 20-something vacationing in the South Pacific with his friends, is captured by a notorious pirate gang led by the violently insane Vaas. After losing his brother in an escape attempt, Jason is rescued by a man named Dennis, who brands Jason with a mysterious tattoo. Apparently, Jason has the hidden potential to become the legendary warrior that the local tribe, the Rakyat, and it's up to you to save your friends, free Rook Island from the pirates and most importantly, kill Vaas.While Far Cry 3 may not have the same kind of gritty narrative that's chock full of grim moral ambiguity like its predecessor, Far Cry 2, the adrenaline-fueled, action-packed adventure that Far Cry 3 offers instead is still entertaining. Each story mission has a nice mix of open-ended game play and scripted sequences that can be a lot of fun to play through, but when you're crawling through ancient Chinese ruins trying to find a mythical artifact, hidden away centuries ago, or the leader of the Rakyat starts talking about how great a warrior you are, it can feel like Far Cry 3 is taking a few ideas from other popular action-adventures and trying to put a darker, edgier twist to them - and it can come across as a tad melodramatic as a result.One of the most intriguing things about Rook Island is that it has a really complex ecosystem that feels active and alive. Throughout your travels, you'll encounter flora and fauna of all shapes and sizes, from wild boars and leopards to birds of paradise. You're just as likely to be killed by a tiger or a Komodo dragon as a gun-toting pirate or mercenary, and you'll occasionally run into skirmishes between the Rakyat and pirate forces. As you progress through the game, you'll get to see how your actions have an impact on this environment. The island starts out full of enemy-occupied outposts, and hacked radio towers make navigation difficult by shrouding large chunks of your in-game map. But as you liberate those towers and outposts, they'll reveal the surrounding area and reduce the pirates' influence in the region.Liberating Rook Island is where Far Cry 3's impressive combat comes into play. Almost every engagement offers flexibility as to how you want to take out your opponents, and you'll build up a large arsenal of customizable weapons provided you've spent some time unlocking radio towers and looting corpses and containers for cash. Every gun, such as shotguns, silenced pistols or flamethrowers, have their own uses in a firefight, depending on if you like fast-paced battles with lots of explosions and bullets or if you prefer something that lets you be more quiet and subtle. Far Cry 3 also introduces skill and crafting systems for improving your abilities and making equipment. Completing missions and killing enemies will grant you skill points to use on various perks that'll increase your health, damage resistance or allow you to pull off nifty action hero moves, like being able to fire a gun while riding down a zipline or using an enemy as an impromptu human shield as you gun down his buddies with his own sidearm. The crafting system is oriented around making items to support you in your adventure. Most of the island's animals can be killed and skinned to give you the materials to craft larger grenade or ammo pouches, and you'll also forage for plants to make syringes that either heal you or give temporary bonuses, like detecting enemies or animals through walls.Far Cry 3 does have a few minor issues that could've used a bit more polish. Navigating the myriad of menus can be a pain for one, and occasionally the context-sensitive HUD has issues distinguishing whether you want to pick up a weapon or loot a corpse. Also, whatever behind the scenes mechanic controlling the random placement of NPCs can seem overeager to spawn enemies for you to encounter, leading to weird instances where you drive along an empty stretch of road only to watch as a truck-full of pirates materializes behind you. Thankfully, that happens so rarely that's it's more of a minor annoyance than anything else, but it can break the immersion slightly when it does.If you need a break from the already content-heavy single player portion of the game, Far Cry 3 also has a robust multiplayer component with a Call of Duty-style style leveling system that'll unlock new weapons, equipment, and ally-boosting abilities as you play. Far Cry 3 also comes with a four player co-op mode, where you and a handful of friends can play through a side-narrative of four people seeking vengeance against a cruise liner captain that tried to sell them out to pirates.Far Cry 3's single player story may have its ups and downs, but it's still an incredibly in-depth action experience. Its combat and open-ended gameplay is engaging and well-designed, and there are plenty of incentives to explore the game world to see what you can find. The multiplayer modes, while not as detailed, are a nice extra feature that's just as enjoyable as the single player campaign.
