content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Within the first thirty minutes I experienced an incredibly emotional and engaging introduction that rivaled all my favorite memories from similar games. Remember the beginning to Half Life 2 or dying in the beginning of Call of Duty: Modern Warfare? Far Cry 3 wipes those experiences under the table and then continues to give you things you never thought possible in a game of this magnitude.  Every drug-laden sequence early in the game makes you feel like first-person shooters have risen to a new level in terms of creative narrative story-telling.We are presented with a very typical open-world game. We can explore the scenic island, take on a slurry of optional missions, search for a staggering amount of collectibles, or take on the newest gaming cliche: hunting. The exploration feels very reminiscent of Skyrim. The stealth elements are familiar for fans of those genres. There are role playing elements and skill tree upgrades. It’s got a little bit of everything and at first-glance they’re all done well.Even with a new high-end PC I couldn’t play this game on ultra, but on high Far Cry 3 looks absolutely incredible. Environments are gorgeously rendered allowing the player to immerse in every detail of the beaches and jungle down to single blades of grass. The character models are perfectly motion captured and so well acted that you want to know “Who is this guy playing Vaas?” These elements provide a real emotional connection to what’s happening. From the very start you become completely immersed and invested in your motives, the story, the characters, and the world as a whole.So what’s the problem? Far Cry 3 is a great game that suffers from the trappings of what makes it a game. The strengths and impact of the opening sequence are quickly diminished when your first few mandatory missions act as tutorials of collecting plants and skinning pigs. With further progression you are inundated with endless optional missions, while entertaining, are irrelevant to the larger story. More may not always be better. And the more you play, you’ll realize: this game is riddled with all the tropes of similar experiences.You’ll need to escape from a burning building, hunker down for turret sequences, use “stealth” to follow a person in broad daylight, and deal with a car chase where you blow up pursuers with a grenade launcher. Meanwhile, every meandering story mission you go on seems to further remove you from any logical character development. Fighting a giant tribal ink demon in a drug-induced state looks cool, but it’s completely pointless and punctuated by a ridiculous first-person sex scene. There are multiple times in the game that make you question what you’re doing and why, because at a certain point none of it makes sense.This game would have benefited immensely from a shorter and focused campaign. What should have been a linear and powerful storyline is ruined by padding the game out with irrelevant mechanics and tired plot sequences. There was such amazing potential dealing with concepts of human trafficking and how revenge at any cost can transform an ordinary person.  However, the human drama takes a backseat. We’re left with a game that feels manipulated to meet bullet-points on a marketing checklist and a feeling that we are the lowest common denominator for a target demographic.A lot can be learned from games like Spec Ops: The Line. What seemed like a formulaic shooter was actually a concise narrative that took risks. It explored and engaged the player with what trauma and death can do to the human psyche.Far Cry 3 could have easily cut characters like Willis, Citra and Hoyt and focused on the drama with Vaas. The optional missions could have been made available as a narrative hook after the main campaign or online experiences with friends. The problem I have is that mechanically the game is still fun. I can recommend it for those reasons. However, narratively speaking, it had so much potential and in the end I was just disappointed with the entire package.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												Far Cry 3, a story driven first person shooter.I purchased the Deluxe edition of the game when it was on the summer 2014 sale for $9.99 and have played a total of 7 hours as of this writing.I would fit this game into the FPS genre and add that this is more then just an FPS, its a Story Driven FPS. There is a compelling and interesting story to go through with the solo campaign of the game and the game starts off with an intense beginning.My first several hours into the game and I have to wounder why I didn't get into the Far Cry series before. Far Cry 3 is the first game in the series I have played and I am pleased with it thus far. I do want to keep playing more and finish the story line to see how it all comes to conclusion.There is more to the game if you play a multiplayer coop campaign but I have not yet tried that as I want to experience it all at my pace and not run and gun through it all. I will eventually play coop but not for a while.There is lots to do in the game other then the main missions. I have spent time hunting down animals for there skins, collecting plants and exploring sunken ships, caves and ruins.The crafting in the game is simple, its not overly complex like other games with crafting. If you want to upgrade your wallet to hold more money then you will need to collect animal skins of a certain animal. You will see what kind of animal skin is needed when you select the upgraded version and then on the map you will see the symbol of the animal. In that area somewhere you will find it, kill it and skin it. This will be how you will go about hunting animals to get there skins so you can upgrade your various gear, like, Loot sack, ammo pouch, weapon holster and so forth.When gathering plants (Green, Blue, Read, White) you will use them to make syringes for restoring health or to make a boost in abilities. I have only made health restorative ones as of yet.There is allot more to the game beyond the main missions. There are random supply drop's side missions where you will drive a vehicle from point to point (a marked flare on the ground) till you get the supplies to the needed person. Hunting various wildlife, timed runs, finding lost relic's, letters and video memory cards.The game map starts off with a small section visible and as you activate radio towers throughout the map more sections become visible. The areas that are not visible also do not show up on the mini-map making it more interesting to explore and find the path the to other radio towers.Hang-gliders are also around the island to use and sale through the air to other sections. Its kind of nice to to glide in the air over the island areas and see what there is around.Far Cry 3 is very Xbox 360 controller friendly. Button arrangements are done well and its a joy to play with the controller over keyboard and mouse.I didn't like that I have to access the game menu to get to the crafting and would have rather seen an option of a work table or something in a safe zone (or in the game world) for doing crafting. Other then that, I have to say that this game is very impressively done and UbiSoft did an excellent job. I am looking forward to the next Far Cry game.Having waited during the Summer Sale of 2014 for the Deluxe edition of the game to go on sale and getting it for $9.99 I have to say a resounding Yes! I am sure that subsequent sales will have the game on sale as well. Look for it during the Holiday Sale folks.Pro'sGraphics are incredibly amazingStoryLots of places to exploreVerity of weaponsA.I. is goodCon'sHave to go to game menu for craftingCVGAnton's Ratingːfirst_starːːfirst_starːːfirst_starːːfirst_starːːfirst_starː

number of helpful: 44 of 65 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												I have mixed feelings about Far Cry 3:The good:1. Great world environment.  The jungle, water, caves, underground bunkers, ancient temples all look beatiful.  2. Hunting is fun and exciting.3. Open world to explore.  I'm a fan of open world games :)4. Good selection of skills and weapons.5. A lot of side quests and collectibles.The mediocre:1. Building textures look pretty bad.2. This game is very taxing on PC's.  It's the only game where my FPS drops to the 30's here and there.   3. Hunting becomes completely obsolete after you acquire certain upgrades, which can be very early depending on how you play.4. Save system absolutely sucks.  You can lose a lot of progress if you forget to "save" by buying or selling an item in a store.5. Most of the side quests are unneccesary.  I only did the supply runs, hunter quests, and the trials of the rakyat.  I still managed to get all the money and experience for all skills.6. Animals and humans don't look that great.  Except the main characters during cut-scenes.  7. Taking over outposts is fun... for a while.  Once you see one, you've seen them all.8. Some folks criticize the main story, and it's nothing we haven't seen before.  I don't expect much out of the story in a FPS anyways.  I mean, this isn't Mass Effect.  Both endings are kind of crappy I must say.Overall it's a good, fun game.  But for all the hype it got, I expected a little more depth and less repetitiveness.  It's very similar to Just Cause 2, but with added hunting and stealth.  A good experience while it lasts, but I wouldn't play through it multiple times.*EDIT: If you want to read up on the game or on whether to get the game or not, don't bother with the Steam forums.  All you'll read are posts about how bad Uplay is.  Uplay runs fine on my end, in games including FC 3, Blood Dragon, and Assassin's Creed 2/Brotherhood/Revelations*

content:
Posted: February 17
 Far Cry 3  According to me this is the best game from the entire series. The plot tells the story of Jason Brody, who together with friends is kidnapped by pirates during the holidays. Unfortunately, our hero escapes and decides to save his friends and brother. Location which will visit are two very large size islands on which we will have free access to travel through using a variety of vehicles. The game is split into a very interesting story missions and side quests which are designed to help us improve our character. One of the most important secondary thing is to climb on a towers those actions unlock new side missions, cases with loot and items to the collection like letters and other things. Another important thing is the bases that we have to liberate, either silently or a loud. The game offers a good amount of fun and exploration, a great story and characters, brilliant soundtrack, interesting side missions in the dlc and a large amount of diffrent weapons. There is also a multiplayer mode which is cool but no one is playing and there is cooperative campaign up to 4 people which is fun to play together with friends. In my opinion Far Cry 3 is a brilliant production and sincerely I can recommend it to everyone.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
												I definitely had a pretty good ride with this game. I was introduced into this series with Far Cry 4, with this being the second game I've played in the series. I've noticed a lot of similarites between the two games, in terms of gameplay and such. Regardless, I still had a lot of fun with the game as I loved Far Cry 4, so was bound to like this one as well. Solid graphics and gameplay. I don't really have much to complain about them. You have good combat as there are various ways to go with any situation, whether stealth or head on. Lots of stuff to explore and collect, side missions to do, and more. In terms of story, it serves the setting and game well. It kept me interested and wanting more. Setting is pretty good as well, taking place on an island with lots of mountains, forests, vegatation, caves, ocean, lakes, and much more. Lots to explore on this island. To be honest, I did have some mixed feelings with the last few events at the ending of the story, but overall, was satisfied and happy with the ending I chose and how it turned out. It took me about 36 hours to get 99% completion, for those wondering. I enjoyed the music of the game as well. A fair amount of times during the game's story where I thought it choice of music was quite suited and pretty cool. Overall, there's a lot to do in this game, from hunting, to racing, to assassination missions, to liberating villages, and much more. I was left pretty happy, impressed, and satisfied with this game. Would have no problem playing this game again, as I think of it to be a really great game that I'd definitely recommend to anyone. Two thumbs up from me!

content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												*** This review is "NOT" about the game, but Uplay, as this is the fundamental cause of all problems. And stop complaining without reading my review. Or if you think I have something against the game, then by all means, stay ignorant. This negative review is about Ubisoft, and Uplay, NOT Far Cry 3. ***First of all, I have loved Ubisoft back in the old days, and I thought they were one of the best game companies.Now? I think it is one of the worst. First of all, let me ask, what the hell is Uplay? And how am I supposed to make this god-awful client even work? I start Far Cry 3 from desktop, by clicking on the icon and nothing happens. But on Steam, it says the game is running. So I have to shut down the game manually....which is not really running in reality. And then I try starting the game from Uplay and I see where it says "Play", but it doesn't look like it is highlighted and not really clickable. In fact, it is not clickable. So then why is it there? So....I downloaded the Uplay client itself and tried to play it from Uplay directly. Oh, now "Play" button is clickable there, Yay! Click! It says the game is running on Steam, but I do not see anything again. I actually installed it once, removed, and re-installed and still nothing is happening. Let's see, Ubisoft, uh, THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR MAKING ONE OF THE WORST CLIENTS MANKIND HAS EVER SEEN. And guess what, it doesn't seem like I am the only person here. Google "farcry 3 uplay not working" and see for yourself how many people are having problems with this garbage-like client. Or you need even more proof? Go to the store page of Far Cry 3. And check out the negative reviews on this game. They are mostly about UPLAY.I have found a few solutions for this, and well, some of the suggestions are to remove certain files, install some new driver, go into some folder and change something........uh....I bought the game, and I have to put up with all this garbage? They might as well put up a warning sign that reads "This game has one of the worst clients that will drive you nuts, so if you don't think you are sure about your PC being able to run the game because of Uplay, then you might want to reconsider purchasing."GFWL was not that good, but not as bad as this. EA Origin is not bad, but it's actually pretty good. Steam, is definitely one of the best. Uplay? Pure garbage, in fact, it really proves the whole point of Ubisoft being one of the worst companies in the world. May I ask why Uplay is necessary? Is it necessary? Ubisoft has the history of screwing up the PC ports of Devil May Cry 3 and Resident Evil 4, the old PC version. If this is how they are going to do business, well, then I think their games are not worth full price, at all. I am glad I got this POS when it was on a sale. How is the game? How the HELL am I supposed to know? Uplay is not letting me play, so well, I wish I could tell you? But I can tell you how the client was. A complete piece of GARBAGE. Will NEVER pay more than 10 dollars to an Ubisoft game, ever again. They obviously have NO CLUE how to do business. Even though Activision sells the same stuff Call of Duty every friggin year, they at least NEVER make a stupid-♥♥♥ garbage client like this.Oh, I'm sure the game is good. It really looks fun. But if I can NOT EVEN LAUNCH IT...then what? ZERO (0) out of 10 for Uplay. UBISOFT = UPLAY = COMPLETE FAIL.For the game Far Cry 3, I give "?" out of 10. Well, I can't rate a game that I can not play?

number of helpful: 92 of 157 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
Disney's Pocahontas With An M-RatingThe ending is enough to justify a negative review but I'll go more in depth...It's a Taken/Pocahontas story we've heard before: bunch of bored, spoiled, rich, white kids travel to a deserted island where they get jumped by Spanish-speaking pirates and are held for ransom. One of them runs away (the player) and the story somehow turns into a heroic epic to save Pocahontas, her people, and the friends the player character is slowly caring less and less about. Pocahontas and her people grant him powers that they possess but can't use the way he does (or at all) because he's American and they're incompetent and he's special and blah blah blah. Then it turns out, the people who've been helping you are actually evil all along. Wow, plot twist!This may just be me but the constant notifications bugged me. A lot. The game doesn't stop pestering you until you check every notification even though you've been notified of the same thing a billion times before that. I know I got a relic, game. I chose to pick it up! I know I can craft a medical syringe; that's why I got the green leaves to begin with! Hell, this game notified me so much that, after the first 15 minutes, I already knew how to craft all of the basic pouches and syringes. If I needed to remember, I could just look in the menu. I don't need constant notifications pestering me.It's a simpler version of Assassin's Creed mechanics in FPS mode. Don't get me wrong, the developers should be able to recycle their mechanics—it's their game. The gameplay was entertaining and the graphics were absolutely breathtaking but there were still too many similarities between Ezio's game and FC3 that I couldn't keep separate. Liberating Borgia towers outposts, climbing to the highest point and synchronizing getting radio towers working, and doing the Leap of Faith ziplining down became a tedious chore after the 3rd time. I found it more fun to attempt a Leap of Faith and send Jason Brody awkwardly stumbling down the tower to his untimely death. "Stealthing", or more accurately crouching right under your enemy's noses (sometimes literally) and hobbling about, is a joke that made me laugh several times. I'm sure that was unintentional.The story felt as uninspired as the protagonist—who is the most boring player character I've ever had the misfortune of controlling. In Assassin's Creed, Ubisoft made me want to do the mini-missions and care about the people just as much as the awesome main missions we chose to do. Whereas in FC3, I tended to skip every single mini-mission because I just couldn't care. Sometimes the main missions were just as mind-numbing as the side missions. As someone else said, the game felt more linear because it forced me to go certain directions and do certain things rather than being the promised open world it should have been. I'd get notifications throughout the game saying that if I stepped out of indistinguishable bounds, I'd forfeit a mission I didn't even know I accepted. With some near-identical mechanics, I couldn't help but constantly think about how much I missed playing Assassin's Creed, especially with its superior storytelling and better sandbox gameplay.Last but not least, cultural appropriation[swanblood.tumblr.com] + antiblackness[en.wikipedia.org] + noble savages[en.wikipedia.org] trope = not cool. The cultural inaccuracies were played out and the racial fetishism made everything feel skeevy. Maori people and Pakatan Rakyat leaders would not be happy to see the defiling of their history, culture, and traditions. Not cool, Ubisoft.TLDR: This game's an unoriginal, hot mess that stinks like moist butts basking in fresh, warm urine with gameplay that reminds me too much of Assassin's Creed. They had so much originality with Assassin's Creed that they failed to do the same with the latest Far Cry entry. Even more debilitating is Ubisoft's blatant disrespect for indigenous people and black people. You might as well watch an episode of Rugrats where they dress up in racist tribal regalia because you'd be getting the same disgusting result. Skip this and play Blood Dragon instead.2/10

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												After completing Far Cry 3 on normal difficulty, I am now playing through once more on the hardest difficulty and am trying to complete all of the missions this time. I usually don't play through a game twice, but this game is worth it. There are so many things I like about this game, where to start...Open World: Far Cry 3 offers a massive, beautiful open world and allows the player to choose one's pace. You can explore the island, do missions, build up skills, build up gear, and follow the story all on your own time. The world is full of goodies like treasures, relics, wildlife (useful and some dangerous), plants, missions, vehicles, and more. Story: A very simplistic summary would be that you play as a guy who was on a nice trip with his brothers and friends, but then things go downhill and you wakeup in a cage with your brother. You must then escape and save your friends all while building new skills and learning about the island. Of course, it is a rather intricate and enticing storyline that keeps you on the edge of your seat, especially when things heat up.Gameplay: Unlike most first person shooters, there are so many ways you can choose to play. You can do the traditional guns-a-blazin, you can be like Hitman and stealth your way through, you can be like James Bond and use your surroundings to unleash hell on your enemies, or you can do what I did which is all of the above. Characters: I thought the characters were very well done. One of the main antagonists in the game, Vaas, is personally my favorite video game villain I have encountered. A very interesting character indeed, though I won't say more than that, you will have to play it and find out for yourself. Besides Vaas, the other characters were also very well designed.Weapons: This game has a weapon for everyone. Pistols, SMGs, LMGs, Snipers, Assault Riffles, Flame Thrower, RPG, Grenade Launcher, Bow, Flare Gun, Explosives, etc. When your weapon holster is maxed out you can carry four weapons. They are all very well balanced, nothing is too underpowered and nothing too overpowered. Very well done. Vehicles: A fair variety of vehicles. Everything you would expect on an island like the one in Far Cry 3. Once again, nothing is too under or overpowered when it comes to vehicles. My favorite would have to be the glider, quite unique and very fun to use.I could go on, but I'll just add one more thing because I think it was incorporated quite well. There are a few instances throughout the game where you are giving some type of drug that sends your character on hallucinogenic, soul searching journeys. They were quite entertaining and really added to the whole storyline. This is definitely a stoner-friendly game, however I haven't smoked while playing (yet anyway), though it would be fun. Overall I would give this a 95/100. Not a perfect game, but very captivating. I'm also not a big fan of the Uplay launcher, but my rating didn't reflect on the launcher, just the single player game.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												EDIT: I'm playing the game through a second time, trying to go for 100% completion. I'll make another reviewI do not know where to start, to be honest. This game was simply, one of the best games I have ever played, for years. When I was little my dad bought me FarCry, and I played it, but it didn't interest me as much, because I was more of an arena gamer. But this game here, man, simply blew my mind. The campaign got me stuck to the characters, and the missions actually gave a challenge. I never bought any thing or used skill points because I never really payed attention to those, but when I started using them, it made the game alot more fun. The campaign has tons of plot-twists and made the game more exciting, and for the choices you choose, it creates a more diverse story.As an improvement for the game, it would be better if the "Boss battles" or combat battles would be more realistic, because I feel like I am in a dream whilst dueling Vaas/Hoyt. One Hole in the story though, its a slight hole though. IN the beginning, you see a guy in a beanie wearing glasses: THat ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is Vincent Salas. Who is he? Is he the friend Vaas mentions in the beginning, "DO YOU WANT ME TO CUT YOU OPEN LIKE I DID YOUR FRIEND(Topkek he forgot to say no homo)" Anyways, this character was supposed to be in the game where you accidentally shoot him in the game when you are with Vaas. His name isnt even in the intro, yet you still see him and you are with him. And he was never in any part of the game besides the intro, and none of the characters even mentioned him. But if none of the characters mentioned him, that would mean he never existed; then who was Vaas mentioning in the beginning? Anyways, Vincent was just cut from the game for some reason, but he is presumed dead.Overall this game was pretty damn amazing. 10/10 With badass approval.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is a great game. The island is really a living place and you can spend a good amount of time by traveling in some car or hunting some animals. By the way, this is the best game to use a bow, I really enjoyed use it during all the game, the gameplay is fantastic.It has some great music, sound effects and voice acting but the story could be much better, but it is almost ok. You start trying to save your friends but after some point later in the game I completely forgot about them (and I feel bad for saying it, LOL), but I was having too much fun playing around in the island, going to new towers and hunting new animals between the missions... Well, what can I do?On the other hand, Vaas is a great and unique character, unfortunatelly the others aren't that interesting as him (except one soldier in later game...), every time you encounter him is very cool (and crazy).After all that I went to co-op, which is a very linear and short storyline, but is fun and works great. In every mission you will face some sort of competition with your friends (sniper, jet ski, rpgs, buggies, ...) and that makes it even more fun and a lot less repetitive. You should play it.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												If you're crashing on Windows 10 after ~15min playing try this out, this is the only thing that fixed it for me> Click on Windows Start button> Type "Services"; it'll automatically begin doing a search as you type> Click on the thing that comes up and says, "Services"> Scroll aaaall the way until you get to "Touch Input and Handwriting Panel Service"> Right click, click "Stop"> Enjoy the game!If in game, it takes forever to "Log in" to Ubisoft's Fary Cry 3 servers, then fails, and then it does this every time you go to the menu while in game, try either or both of the following:1. Windows Firewall> Click on Windows Start button> Type in "Firewall"> Click on Windows Firewall with Advanced Security> On the left column/window, click on "Inbound Rules"> Scroll on down to the area with a bunch of stuff that says "Far Cry 3", Far Cry D3D11, etc> Enable all dat jazz2. Change compatibility of farcry3.exe> Go to whatever hard drive location you store all your Steam games (Folder is called SteamLibrary)> Once in SteamLibrary go to SteamApps,> then common, > then Far Cry 3,> then bin> For example on my computer the final path looks like this "E:\SteamLibrary\SteamApps\common\Far Cry 3\bin"> Right click on "farcry3.exe" > MAKE SURE its farcry3.exe, not farcry3_d3d11.exe, game will crash on startup if you mess with it> Click "properties"> A window should pop up with a bunch of tabs on top; click on the "Compatibility" tab> about 1/4 way down the window it says "Compatibility Mode" with a little checkbox that says "Run this program in compatibility mod for:"> Check the checkbox> Select "Windows 8" from the dropdown menu> Click OK at the bottom of the window> Finally enjoy your god damn game> Oh no wait you have to go through like 10 hoops with Uplay's Google Authentication bullsh!t, where you have to download an app ON YOUR PHONE. You can only have fun after that.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												What a massive game this is. Huge islands to explore with just too many sidequests. You can just run/drive/fly around and do nothing or you can; hunt animals, craft items, free settlements, find relics and other secrets, take over radio towers, do some trials and a whole lot of other activities and (side)quests. It's seemingly endless and completing the entire game will take you probably well over 50 hours. Now that's some value right there.The graphics are just gorgeous, no matter what settings you use. You can't make this game look bad, you just can't. The animations and models are some of the best I've seen in a game. Wow. The same thing applies to the sounds and voice acting, which is brilliant and truly convincing.While doing the story and sidequests you'll earn XP to upgrade your skills. There are 3 skilltrees in total and the way you play the game is entirely up to you. The Shark skilltree will let you upgrade your assault and healing skills, while the Heron tree will help you with your sniper skills and speed and finally, the Spider tree will let you focus on your stealth and survival skills. There's no right way to play this. There are many ways to complete an objective. And that's what makes Far Cry 3 fun, but not necessarily unique.However, there aren't many FPS that give you this much freedom, while telling a realistic, focused, story at the same time. So I take my hat off to Ubisoft for creating this masterpiece. The commercial and critical success for this game is well deserved.Let this be a lesson - and example - for future first person shooters. Hooray for Far Cry 3 !

												This is the first Far Cry game I have played, and I am quite impressed. The main plot line has great characters and the shooting and hunting/crafting mechanics are solid.I know this is somewhat polarizing, but I happen to love the writing and general theme of spoiled california kid gets jungle fever. In the end of the game I was only using the bow and trying to melee combo everything.It has crashed quite a few times for me, but only after several hours of play time, usually in load screens, but the auto saving mechanism is quite good so I have never lost progress.I immediately see why Far Cry Primal is a thing, which may be my next Far Cry (perhaps after blood dragon?)

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												[Please Note This Is Only A Partial Review Having Played 1/4 Of The Game Thus Far!]So this game is amazing, no doubt about it, and a full review will soon follow, but I ABSOLUTELY cannot recommend this based on the fact that its uPlay implementation is PATHETIC!I've put in over 15 hours of gameplay only to discover to my horror that the saves it was meant to save (by default to the cloud) somehow failed, and I lost over 10 hours of gameplay! All my hunting for upgrades, over 20 outposts, I'm gutted, truly. But as I said, this game is indeed amazing and I'll take this one on the chin and trod along, making doubly sure my games are being saved (have we not come so far into the gaming world where this is inate?).To add insult to injury, uPlay is EXTREMELY intrusive, and one can't even get to the Main Menu without it wanting to download this and download that, download profiles, download stats, it takes a whole couple of minutes EACH TIME before you get into the game! You wanna do trials? Oh ho ho, lets sync (think) first. I've had to force myself to play in offline mode (once again PATHETIC!) just to be able to run the game like the hundreds of other games I have in my library. And the first time uPlay install? Let me just say it kept looping with one of its "infamous" updates...But this is the last time I EVER support Ubisoft, I'm sorry, but they are appalling. If I wanted to play a Ubisoft game, I'd buy the game and play it via uPlay, but I have STEAM for a reason and it’s just really silly that I have to play a uPlay game THROUGH STEAM. Origin and uPlay need to come to an agreement to release games to STEAM (aka individual keys). They can certainly count on me never buying one of their products again. Hopefully they learn from the giant how to do things right.

number of helpful: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												Where do I start? I loved FC 2, I loved its mature story, its realism, immersion and many other things (hated the respawn mechanics tho and hate ubi till this day for ignoring this issue like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s they are).But FC3?? its like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ little brother of FC2 and 1, It threats you like a little kid, basically saying " here, shoot something, cut some tigers and drive around with speed of light while you are basically invincible"Three main sins of FC3 that break the spell for me are:- Its incredibly dull- it lack any immersion whatsoever- its easy, very very easy1. DULL, everything is the same and repetitive,  weapons are only FEW and all are similar really, hunting is fun for like 30 minutes and then gets annoying and unnecessary ( you get the holster and ammo pack upgraded in about 30 minutes and anything else you don't need, especially the wallet which I do not understand why even exist since you unlock weapons which are free for ever and everything else u can pick up), fighting is dull as hell mainly due to the easiness. AI is just apes with firearms.  Stealth is ridiculous, enemy must be blind, I can clear out all camps with just a knife. Dont get me started on unlocking the radio towers which is just atrocious, and pointless.2. Immersion. There is non. Everything feels staged and unrealistic, the story is ok but the main character is a joke. I couldn't get into the story from the very first few minutes. I mean how some random dude from rich family is all of the sudden an expert commando killing machine just cose some doc told him hes a warrior, and what do u know, he suddenly is, climbing, diving, sniping, killing, sneaking and god knows what else he can do. What really hit me was that he's brother actually would be a MUCH better main character knowing he was a military and all, at least I could understand why he handles guns and knife so well, but no, he dies almost immediately. For comparison, in FC2, you are an experienced mercenary/military/hitman with a clear task given, much more immersive and that I can understand, this is my job to eliminate and thus being an ace sniper and firearms master suddenly feels completely not out of place unlike FC3. World is meh, Graphic is meh too, everything feels like its made of plastic.3. Easy mode all the way. I played the hardest setting, and it was a walk in the park, I can kill the camps in any way there is, name it, knife, sniper rifle, zerg rush with machine gun, rpg barrage, anything really.  But since I really like stealthy strategic approach with sniper rifle, I got to say it was just laughable, I yawned as I was picking enemies off with no problem, and when I got silenced sniper rifle with better zoom? haha I couldn't even be bothered to kill anyone with it, it just felt unfair to the poor AI.Conclusion, to me, this game is a one big bore and the difficulty is insulting. However I can see how  people  like it, its easy to pick up and just shoot away,not what I personally look in fps tho hence that is the reason for me disliking it. And thats why Im not recommending it. It's just not worth of the Far Cry title, its not Far Cry, it resembles Just Cause much more than FC1&2, it is not serious, it is easy and childish, not what I was expecting from FC series.

												First 3 hours experince:*My laptop Nvidia GT650M SLI run 60fps with medium setting in 1920x1080!After 3 hours experince:*Hunting animal is satisfied!After 6 hours experince:*Wow, character animation also not bad!After 9 hours experince:*Ok, have to explore more area now!After 12 hours experince:*The story is being drag longer & longer...After 15 hours experince:*Coming more stealth gameplay to continue...After 19 hours experince:*Beat the game in medium diffcult! Enjoyment: 9/10+Super high quality graphic (2013 tech)+Very natural atmosphere+Realistic caves+Nice weapon,sound, particle effects+Attachment available for gun+Very easy to find items+Very easy to craft items+Fun to go hunting animal skin+Inventory limit is expandable+Fire is dangerous in this game+Many fast travel location+Various transportation available +Many side quest+Mini game features+Sexy dance+Half nudity, but not exactly+Long campaign+Camera is useful for tracking enemy position+Poker card gambling features+New story in coop mode+Replayable after ending+Map editor-Some checkpoint is too long ago-Can't save game during a mission, i believe is reasonable-Bullet impact on body is not satisfy-Architecture is similar-Aggressive animal is too few-Require to login Uplay to start-Require Uplay friends to play coop-Uplay cannot import friend list from steam-Achievement is inside Uplay-Require a high-end graphic computer to enjoy the bestGAME MODE:*Campaign Mode: (6 Chapters)= 2 endings (save game before accept the mission)= Coop mode (separate from the Singleplayer storyline)*Multiplayer Mode: (10 Maps)=Team deathmatch=Firestorm=Trasmission=DominationWorth buying?*Yes, for normal price; Or wait for sale, there will be 75% off*No, don't buy if you don't have enough money.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												7/10 -What a trip. I enjoyed hunting animals to craft items, Looting, finding relics and completing side missions to get money to upgrade and buy weapons, stealth killing, sniping from a long distance to shoot a cage to let a tiger out of it and watch it maul everyone nearby, taking over enemy posts so I can fast travel to them, fixing towers to show the map and unlock new weapons, running people and animals over with my car, upgrading my character with xp to unlock new moves, starting things on fire and watching it spread and last but not least the story missions. You can craft plants but I ended up not crafting any except green ones which give you health because the rest of the plants you can craft are basically useless. Who wants to craft a plant to allow you to be flame retardant for 15 secs? I didn't care anyway. Unlike plants crafting animals is useful since you can carry more weapons at a time among other things by collecting their skins. I had fun hunting these animals in the wild and checking my list of how many I needed of a certain breed to create whatever it was. However it was pointless hunting animals anymore after you craft everything unless you want to gain barely any money in doing so or just for the hell of it. Looting dead bodies got really annoying because you have to wait and see the same animation over and over again. There is no way to skip it. Another annoying problem was if their weapon is nearby you have to hover over a certain spot on their body to loot them since you use the same key press to pick up their weapon...why couldn't I just hover over their body and get the loot automatically without pressing anything and press a key if I wanted their weapon? I ended up all the time swapping my weapon accidently because of it. There is really no death animations just ragdoll physics. Which is disappointing since I liked how in Far Cry 2 you can snipe someones leg and they start yelling in pain from it and if one of their friends is nearby they could pick them up and carry them to safety. You shoot anyone in the leg in this game they just die and fall over. The story was a let down to me. It's really a big lame excuse to kill people on an island. You go to the extremes to save your friends in any situation. I didn't like the main characters voice it was annoying and laughable at the sametime. It doesn't help that your character is a real ♥♥♥♥♥ and makes very poor decisions you have to watch unfold that you don't like. The ending wasn't satisfying at all. Don't get me wrong though I did enjoy alot of the story missions. The co-op is alright but can be frustrating due to waves of overwhelming odds and connection issues. The motion blur in this game gave me headaches and there is no way to turn it off. I am only nitpicking here but you can't blow up a car or truck by sniping it's fuel tank. You can't cut down trees. You can't blow up a building having it's walls collapse in. You can't fly a helicopter. You can't even see your own feet. It's no Crysis that's for sure but I did have fun and I spent alot of time just wrecking havoc.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												So I don't normally review games, mostly because I don't feel the need to, but Farcry 3 is a different case. I've played my fair share of games, RPGs, MMOs, FPS'. But none of them have ever given me the same adrenaline rush that this game offers. Now don't get me wrong I'm sure there are better games out there, but Farcry 3s enticing story (I'm about halfway through atm) and deep character progression are something to behold. (Not to mention the incredible voice acting).This game offer many different ways to play and there are multiple ways to complete a mission. When you're not off killing pirates and blowing s##t up, you can kick back and go out hunting (surprisingly therapeutic) or play some mini games that the villagers offer. There is an unbelievable amount to be done is this game and the whole map feels like a playground, where you do things your way.I would go into the story, but I'd get carried away and probably spoil something, so all I'll say is that Vaas is possibly my favourite villian of all time be it in a book, movie and of course game. So I'm not saying everyone will love this game, but if you like the freedom to do whatever the hell you want and also don't mind a pretty brilliant story (in my opinion) then just buy it! I nearly didn't because of all the complaints about a so called Uplay, but trust me its not that bad! A little unesscary, but once in game you forget all about it.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Might not be a bad game, if Uplay wasnt so brutal. The game constantly crashes. Why is this game so buggy? When I attempt to load it will get stuck in an endless loop. If I try to buy a gun, it crashes. If I try to update my skill tree, it crashes.When the game gets going, I have a lot of fun. I love the open world aspect. I can explore what I want and go where I want. I can take out enemies stealthy with a knife or go in guns blazing. The world is beautiful and fun to explore.Unfortunately, I found this game can get repetitive within the first island. Rather than create new challenges, it seems like take another base (with the same enemies). Yes, you can attempt to stealth it, or go full on combat, but eventually it loses its flare. Looking for relics gets boring fast. The game designers made some interesting puzzles to solve, but it feels like bad version of Tomb Raider. Relics lose novelty fast, after 60 of them, if you arn't completely bored of them, you still have another 60 more to go. Its fun to watch the world get reinhabited by the island folk, but their animations, or scripted events get boring fast. It almost seems meaningless to take a base from the enemies and where do the good villagers come from? It would be fun to find villagers hiding and occupying little outlying huts. Am I happy that I purchased this game? ... Yes, but because it was on sale.

content:

												Elements from Far Cry 1 & 2 that didn't work are gone, things that did work stayed.  Skyrim with guns, Assassin's Creed with guns, Borderlands done without the campiness.As awful as the Far Cry 1 story was, I can actually see a connection between that & 3.  Even though each game is considered a spiritual successor and has no connection to one another, I can tell 1 & 3 have a lot of similarities in story.  The difference is, 3 isn't a hackjob story with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ voice acting.Beautiful graphics, great gameplay, great story, memorable characters and one thing Ubisoft does great: amazing intros to their games.  This is definitely a good 20 hour playthrough, highly recommended if you like FPS with open world questing, skills to level up, hostile outposts to clear into friendly outposts, driving, flying, shooting, hunting.  Oh yeah, the hunting is actually fun, sometimes hard and actually useful.Great game, worth the price on sale.

number of helpful: 21 of 34 people (62%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												No. Just no.The game is a big step-up from its predecessor and it is really good when you're free roaming the island taking out pirate camps, exploring the monotonous but beautiful landscape. And it looks pretty nice. But that's about it.There are a lot of problems with the pacing. Half an hour in the game and I was carrying a modern french assault rifle and a silenced sniper rifle with free access to unlimited ammo if visiting the right places. The crafting mechanics are completely contrived (why do I need tiger-skin to make bigger pouches?) and there is a lot of dissonance between gameplay and story. The protagonist lies in doubt about his actions, about killing other people while ingame recklessly slitting throats of pirates like there is no tomorrow.The story itself is very unengaging and the characters in it are just as boring. The supporting cast ranges from "meh" (the friends) to "completely braindead and annoying" (everyone else).The big shaman girl is just a ♥♥♥♥♥, calling the main character "no warrior" after he single-handedly defeated a dozen pirate camps while her so-called warriors did nothing at all.The half-enemy strange guy that kidnapped your best friend attacks you with a knife. And for some contrived reason your player character pulls out his knife instead of just shooting him with the MACHINEGUN IN HIS HAND. Argh.Vaas, the big-bad from the beginning of the game waits around corners to punch you like... fifty times. It gets old VERY fast.Lots of setpieces don't make the slightest sense. I have a clear shot at the big-bad-evil-guy and am carrying around a Remington sniper rifle. Can I take the shot? Nope. Because cutscene.I escape the pirates and decide to steal a helicopter instead of just slipping into the jungle... why exactly? Oh right, because Vaas needs to recapture the player.I finally get the opportunity to attack Vaas' hideout and decide to kick in his front door and go in guns blazing. Alone. Not to mention the combat in this game works best if you rely on stealth and hit&run attacks. Riiiight.This level design belongs in a Micheal-Bay-Style FPS like Call of Duty and not in something with this kind of survival-vibe.Also the kills on the antagonists aren't even satisfying because they're just boring QTEs. In conclusion: If you want a free-world action game get GTA or Just Cause 2. If you want a spectacle shooter get CoD. If you want a shooter with an engaging anti-war story get Spec Ops: The Line. If you want a first-person survival game.. uhm.. Metro? Stalker?  But not this.

number of helpful: 14 of 21 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Amazing.This game is an absolute masterpiece, and in this review, I'm gonna stick by Yahtzee's rule of: "A game must be able to stand on singleplayer alone." and, wow, this game really does stand out. The summary of this is that you (the protagonist) and your friends has been kidnapped by pirates and you've escaped. The rest of the game you are trying to get them back. Venturing throughout the game, you battle amongst different species of animals, depending on the food chain. This includes sharks, snakes, komodo dragons, crocodiles, tigers, panthers, and bears. Majority of a lot of the predators on the island include intense quicktime events when they attack by suprise. One sticking out would be a crocodile attack. If you fail to complete the quicktime event, the animal kills you. If you finish it, you either kill the animal, or damage it. You need to also kill animals to craft larger objects (bigger bandolier, more space in wallet). A situation which I found hilarious was where I was hunting for tapir to gather their pelt. I was interrupted by a tiger, who literally left my health at the lowest point. To which I retreat to the river where I was instantly attacked by a crocodile. The game realistically shows all the different situations in the jungle and proves Vaas as he said: "if the jungle doesn't eat you up alive, I will.".Going onto characters, Vaas is one of the best villians I have ever had the pleasure of laying my eyes against. True fact, Vaas wasn't even supposed to be in the game, Michael Mondo's(Vaas' voice actor) audition pleased Ubisoft so much, that they decided to create the character Vaas for him. As you saw the summary above, which is quite bland, Vaas introduces the story of insanity. To which it makes you think, what if all of this isn't happening and you're sedated or on drugs? What if this is all a dream? I may be sounding completly irrelevant and random, but the theme of insanity really does make you wonder what is actually going on throughout. Not to mention there are even more villians than Vaas.While you battle pirates and animals, you have a wide range of weapons to choose from. There are RPGs, bows, SMGs, rifles, shotguns, flamethrowers, flare guns and machetes. Not to mention you get to customize your weapons, for instance, you can add a red dot sight to your bow to help accuracy or add a extended mag to your rifle to stop running out of ammo quicker. Your character also gets tattoos from the Rakyat which improve your fighting and stealth skills. The tattoos you get to pick from are the heron, the shark and the spider. Tattoos that would be an example would be moving faster while crouching, the throwing knife takedown and the added health bars.If you are thinking "tl;dr", then my summary of this review is that this game is one of my favorites I have ever played along with other great games like Red Dead Redemption, Skyrim, and Fallout. There are a few problems with the UPlay, which ruins it a bit. But all in all, a great game.10/10 GG Ubisoft.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2013
												Far Cry 3 é simplesmente ÉPICO! Caçar, sobreviver, matar.. coisas constantes nesse jogo que vai te deixar em suspense do início ao fim. Não é a toa que recebeu ótimas notas nas Review's mundiais. Uma ilha gigantesca, lotada de animais selvagens para se caçar e diversos piratas lunáticos espalhados por todos os cantos da Ilha comandados por um dos vilões mais épicos da história dos games, o Vaas. No game, você acaba sendo raptado pelo Vaas junto com seus amigos e também seus dois irmãos, e no fim acaba lutando para conseguir salvar a todos e sair vivo dessa Ilha do Terror. Eu geralmente não curto muito os jogos da Ubisoft, ainda mais pela Uplay existir, mas esse jogo aqui é diferente.. É um jogo incrível que me fez ficar bastante tempo viciado nele!Se você tem dinheiro pra gastar, esse jogo é indispensável! Coop divertidíssimo e um Multiplayer de certa forma viciante, achei até melhor que o Multiplayer de CoD. Jogabilidade excelente e gráficos de primeiro mundo. Um dos melhores jogos que já joguei na vida, e que recomendo a todos jogarem sem pensar duas vezes ;D------------------------------~ NOTA: 9,8------------------------------

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												What can I say about Far Cry 3?  The game is pretty.  That is the only good thing I have to say about this game.The following review may contain spoilers!!!  You've been warned!!!You start Far cry 3 and the first thing you notice is how great everything looks and you think to yourself "This is gonna be great".  Since this is a game that lets you free roam you do the first storyline mission, maybe two and then you just go explore.  The problem with exploring is there really isn't anything to explore.  You have to liberate the radio tower in an area to unlock the map and then you get 2-3 camps to liberate to remove enemy soldiers from the area.  The only other thing to do is find all the collectible crap that might unlock signature weapons but mostly is just there to keep the OCD people playing until they complete 100%.  Everything that was fun or interesting about the game was over by the time I finished the first island.  The second island in the game was not fun at all and contains pretty much every crappy gimmick that has been put into video games in the past decade.  Seriously timed button presses, mini games,  and poorly made rail shooters.  I only completed the storyline missions on the second island just so I could finish the game.  It wasn't fun, interesting, or engaging.  It seems like they knew their game was bad so they decided to make you have to jump through hoops to unlock literally everything in the game.  You have to unlock the map, the weapons, extra weapon slots, extra ammo slots, all the skills, literally everything.  Nothing in this game happens without you performing some kind of grind.  This isn’t fun, what happened to the days when games were fun?

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is the king of aesthetics. The jungles scattered throughout the island are overflowing with detail, wildlife, etc. The game does a great job at having you feel immersed as you try to save your friends from an unforgiving warlord, and his henchmen. The first few hours of the game are bliss. You're just killing things, and getting tatt'ed up. The game then becomes stale. You start killing the same enemies, start recieving the same missions, and you are even forced to travel halfway across the map between missions.     Then there's the protagonist. His profile indicated he is a grown man- but his voice actor makes him sound like a disney-channel sitcom teen. This shattered it for me. His expressions even made me cringe well into the game. Though he grows, the more you learn about him, the less you want to be playing as him. In short, 6/10 , expected something more.

content:
Posted: January 3
												Let me just start off by saying that there is very few games out there that can keep my attention and get me so drawn into the story that I don't want to stop playing. Now that being said here's my pros and cons of this game(and trust me when I say the pro's heavily outweigh the cons)Pros:Awesome storylineStreamline gameplayWide variety of guns for every type of playerWingsuit..because who doesn't love to "soar like an eagle"?Parachute because crashing to the ground is never funA lot of character depthLots of side things to do from missions to upgrading gear and unlocking new skills even after the main story is overTons of replayability(BIG BIG BIG plus in my book)Crazy plot twist after crazy plot twist keeps you on your feet throughout the main storylineCons:Vehicles are a little wonky on the controls and sometimes impossible to controlSemi-Short storyline(this is my only big complaint about this game)*this is a personal opinion for me* I wish using the Parachute to Wingsuit combo makes your glide longer in the wingsuitBow controls are a little hard to get used to but can be mastered if you stick to it, not as easy to use as the guns are in this game making it almost obsolete compared to the rifles.Overall this game is a definite suggestion for anyone who loves games that play like Tomb Raider(2013+), Just Cause, or the other Far Cry games.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												I tried to like this game.I really tried.That's not to say Far Cry 3 is a bad game. It has some very interesting features and there are a lot of improvements over the previous game (Far Cry 2), for example:- Better stealth. Enemies can no longer spot you from miles away and snipe you with a pistol.- No more infinite vehicle chase. If you come across an enemy patrol, you can outrun them instead of having them follow you till the end of Earth.- More animals. Far Cry 2 had animals (Zebras!), but thtey were extremely rare.- No more weapon deterioation. F*** the gun jamming mechanics in Far Cry 2. All it did was to force the player to visit a gun warehouse in between mission.- Weapon customisation - horray for red-dot sights- Stealth take down - in Far Cry 2 if you sneak up to someone and stab them in the back you will alert everyone nearby, but in Far Cry 3 you can actually perform a stealth kill with a melee weapon and even hide their body.- Better fast travel - I can't remember how many bus rides I took during Far Cry 2.- Crocodiles. I will never forget the first time I see an unsuspecting NPC get dragged into the river by a crocodile.However, this game also has a lot of flaws, some I found critical, other annoying enough to put me off the game:- You can't save during a mission. Sure you can quick save (which btw isn't mentioned in the game manual) to keep the loot you have found, but you will lose any other progress if you don't complete the mission in one sitting. Far Cry is supposed to be an open world game, so why the heck do I have to go to the menu to abandon quest if I change my mind half way through?- Too bloody many tigers. More than once I have seen an outpost (that I am supposed to conquer) get slaughtered by some wild tiger/komodo dragon. While it's funny to watch the first time, it rapidly gets less interesting after that.- NPCs keep repeating the same line. It's as if they only know 20 words in total.- Immersion break. If the locals have formed a resistance group against the pirates, aside from the occansion patrols, why is is that I seem to be the only one fighting?- Terrible health system that forces you to choose a stealthy approach. Even with a bullet proof vest, you can only last for a few seconds in a gun fight before you health is completely depleted. You pretty much have to thin the enemy out from a distance using a silenced weapon in order to survive.- Odd graphics. This game has some very weird shading that reminds me of cell-shaded games. It is as if the developers can't make up their mind on whether to make the game look realistic or cartoonish.I know that a lot of people will disagree with my opinion and there are a lot of positive reviews out there regarding this game. However, I feel that I have given this game a fair chance and I just cannot get around to enjoying myself playing it.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Don't buy this game. The story is terribly written in my opinion and doesnt fit at all in the far cry series. the gameplay is very repetetive, with each outpost having the same structure. it comes too predicable that even at the hardest difficulty you can easily do well at the game just using a pistol. In the story (Both co-op and single player) it's just cliche after cliche after cliche. It happens so often that it just gets annoying and it just feels awful. You get no connection to the protagonist at all, you won't llike him, you don't even want to be him and wish he'd just jump off a cliff, break his ankles and left there for no one to be found ever. Neither do you feel connected to the world. In most games you get a sense of where you are, roads feel familiar, certain parts feel like home. In this game it is just jungle after beach after dirt road and they all just seem the same.The story is full of spiritual nonsense that could fit in a setting centuries ago or in a different kind of world (where magic and unicorns exist), but not in the 21-st century on a tropical island where everybody has 17 guns. If you have a gun, you don't need some pretentious spiritual power to kill just another thug with a group of his guards. Honestly, the only way the game is fun is to just avoid all storyline missions, not using the map and running around blindly shooting people. Basically what FarCry 2 consisted of.The co-op is kind of alright in the game. The campaign doesnt really have that much story (this doesn't really matter though, it's about shooting things with your friends). It consists of multiple chapters which can be played chronologically. It's fun to do a few times, but the problem is that all these chapters are so repetetive and contain the same things, you never get a nice surprise. The worst part is the extreme glitchiness in Co-op. Anybody has a ping over 60? Fat chance that when you respawn after everyone dies, somebody on your team will just randomly drop dead and has to wait for the next checkpoint. Or he seems to appear on top of a building, while you're standing inside it. Good luck saving him when he gets incapacitated. Furthermore it is impossible to play with 2 players, as random kicks without a visible reason happen very often. if you play it with 2, and one gets kicked, you automatically get booted because 'there aren't enough players.' Say goodbye to your progress.All in all, get off the store page, and spend your money on a better game. But not this, don't do this to yourself.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												So this game, has an interesting enough concept, you get to roleplay a white whiney teenager who goes for a holiday then gets captured by a much more interesting villain who has some great dialogue and presence.It breaks down into an Ubisoft favourite, capture X area Y times with slight variances with upgrades in weapons inbetween and a forest of trouble between the areas (like the very linear and constrained Assassin's Creed).The much more improved part of this are the great NPCs and the environment of the jungle, you will end up getting surprise attacked by a tiger, crocodile or shark rather than getting killed by any human characters since they are quite predictable and even on ultra hard mode they are easy to sneak up on.The game has XP and money barriers for progression but there is an interesting hunting and gathering requirement which requires you to gather animal and plant products for consumables and how much ammo or how many guns and consumables  can be carried.Littered throughout the open world are various racing and shooting mini games in addition to hunting, searching and assassinaitng quests.  This is all great and fun indeed.The graphics are quite great especially with everything turned up.You're probably asking why I don't recommend this game.Ubisoft seems to have trouble programming and supporting its titles beyond console release.Thsi game is littered with gamebreaking bugs, glitches and will make your machine regardless of if it is top of the line 2 years ago or top of the line today to crash or hang.Sometimes you'll be able to play the game for 4 or 5 hours straight no problems other times you'll have difficulty having it running for 15 minutes.It seems to be a theme with Ubisoft every PC port they make has an unexcusable number of problems.In addition to this there is the extra layer of trashware implemented - Uplay.  Which is basically a massive Ubisoft advertisment which requires administrative access to run and is morethan likely one of the causes for autosave points to crash your machine.If you would like your machine to crash more times in the one playthrough of a game than over the last 3 years, by all means buy this game.  If you want ot keep your sanity and send a message to Ubisoft that PC gamers will not put up with a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥job then do not buy this game.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												Like skyrim with guns. Needs mods to make the gameplay more fun, but it never gets its core problems fixed.Lacks depth, exploration is only fun for the first 2 hours. Very repetitive gameplay, in the first hour of the game you've seen 90% of the content the game has to offer. Weapons are very unsatisfying, they lack a punch and don't feel unique. Driving is awkward and you'll never drive too long before crashing your car. "RPG" mechanics are very, very shallow, there's only a "perk" tree in wich you unlock some abilities you'll rarely use, and you can unlock them all anyway. Stealth mechanics are simply bad. It's not even worth mentioning the "survival" mechanics and the gathering wich is just a chore to make the game feel longer instead of just letting you buy more ammo space and such.And don't get me started on the story.If you are looking for an open-world FPS with some RPG mechanics play S.T.A.L.K.E.R. instead.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												This game is actually rather shallow. You have a wide open world with alot to explore and... well thats it. There is virtually NOTHING else to do in this game beyond the story. You can do super TINY lil missions like "Go kill a lion with this bow" and capture little camps so that your buddies can take it over and even then the fight is easy on account of it being a simple "kill 8 dudes" kinda deal. The story is pretty bad in my opinion. You play a total wimp rich white boy with less hair on his chest than a newborn. There is no choice in the majority  story at all which would not be so bad if the story was good. The supporting cast is relatively bland and fail to be interesting or even create any sort of bond between you and them. I only like one on your friends because he looks like Nick from L4D2. Your character (besides being a limp-weenie) is an utter retard. CHECK YOUR CORNERS DANGIT! The story of the game also involves a large amount of tribal ritual mumbo jumbo that I find utterly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. There are alot of drug-related sequences you go into in this game to the point where I just know my guy is going to have a serious addiction. The combat is just pathetic. Its not interesting due to a lack of enemy intelligence and overall difficulty. The game is so easy and I played it on the 2nd hardest difficulty. I could have pushed it to the max with little difference. The AI are so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and present no challenge. They all act as independent units with no teamwork at all other then random chance bringing them together. Stealth in this game is alright in of itself, but feels entirely hallow due to knowing that you can breeze through the enemy 12x as fast if you just ran in. Stealth killing the enemy loses its pleasure when you know the enemy are all ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. The crafting is weak as all it results in is you becoming MORE overpowered and giving you even LESS of a challenge. The story is crap.The combat is crap.The story is MEGA crap.The main character is ULTRA crap.Buuuuuut the game is very pretty. The visual design is by far the strongest part of this game.Is it a bad game? No. I dislike it because I value characters and story very highly and this game utterly fails in this department destroying my attempt at an un-biased view.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												I stuck it through to the end of the campaign, but this is the first game in a while that I was happy to delete.  This game is a “far cry” from the Trigens that I loved in the original Farcry, and it’s turned me off the series now for good.  There’s a reason why the game is so cheap. Visuals are incredible.  Sound is awesome.  The characters, voice acting, and animation are top-notch.  At its core, the FPS gameplay is superlative!  This game is BEAUTIFUL and provides movie-quality experience.  The best advice I can give if you already own it but haven’t tried it, is to play it free-form and enjoy the open-world experience.  But if you want a better FPS story experience that looks just as good, try the Crysis titles instead. As for co-op, I didn't try it, but I’m sure it’s good, as the FPS mechanics in this game are very good.However the campaign content in Farcry3 is so RAW that I cannot in good conscience recommend anyone playing this game.  I like my meat medium-rare, but this one is still on a living animal.  I am VERY concerned that underage people are experiencing it.  Now, don’t peg me off as some religious bible-thumper that is pro-censorship; you should hear me swearing and cursing at slow drivers while I tear down the roads cutting people off in my gas-guzzling tweaked-out car.  In the end, with FarCry 3, I just was not ENTERTAINED by “playing through” the actions you are required to take to progress in the game.The game is plastered with EXTREME profanity, there was no hope of me playing it with the volume up without offending anybody nearby.   The pirates are constantly swearing at you, taunting you, calling you a mutha*cker, the main character swears as he skins animals or nearly dies, and the cut scenes are so full of offensive language that it seems they had to fill a quota and fill in as many sh!t’s and fu*k’s as they could.  The single-player campaign has you hunting animals (boars, pigs, deer, goats, sharks, komodo dragons, dogs, leopards, tigers, bears) with all sorts of weapons, including bows, shotguns, assault rifles, and flamethrowers.  Yes, there ACTUALLY is a mission that requires you hunt down and kill eight dogs with a flamethrower.  Now, to be fair, they were advertised as “rabid dogs that need to be put down.”  But as I approached with my flamethrower in hand, and walked right up to the pack of 8, not one attacked me.  And as I started to flame them, all they did was run away whining.  NOT a fun gaming experience.  I have a dog, she’s an important member of our family.  THIS was in no way fun.And then, the premise is, you skin each of the animals.  On the screen, as you do this, you get a gory visual of the main character inserting his knife into the dead animal, ripping the skin off, and putting the lump of flesh into his rucksack (usually with a “f*ck!” while he does it).  This is REQUIRED so that you can “craft” larger containers to carry your crap in.  Otherwise you can only carry one weapon, with little ammo, and very little money.  F@ck, if I want do that crap I will go play deer hunter.  And CRAFTING?  Why, since MineCraft came out, does everyone think they need to have it too?!   If I want to mix sh!t together, I’ll go try to cook something in the kitchen and fail miserably.  Why can’t I just pick up med kits or buy them in stores like all the other FPS games out there?  No, I have to search for green leaves to CRAFT syringes (where does the syringe come from???)Anyway, back to the story.  It is a mystical tale of human trafficking, drug trade, overcoming all odds, and saving (or betraying) your friends, who are being held hostage on the tropical paradise by pirates.  The bad guy characters are all way too over-the-top insane.  Hilarious at times, mind you, I did laugh, but Vass is simply too much, and he sure screams a lot.  Oh, and did I mention he swears?  Hoyt is a bit better for language, and funny too, but you actually see him for less of the game than Vass.  You spend half of the key plot sequences in (apparently) a drug or mushroom-induced hallucinogenic state, fighting fiery demons with a bow and arrows or knives.  At the end of these sequences, I found out that, apparently, I succeeded in killing the bad guy.  What the hell?  Why can’t I just put a bullet through his head?  Oh, was that a bit too gory for mainstream gaming perhaps?At various points, the game has you holding space bar down to TORTURE people.  It includes first-person sex scenes with a crazy jungle girl.  There are themes of r@pe (including homosexual – you are asked to pucker up your a$$ up on several occasions).  There are people that are burned to death in cages in movie-like experience.  If I want to see all of that, I’ll fire up an old copy of Amistad.  This is NOT entertaining.All in all, it’s just too much.  I just want to run and gun and save the hot chick so she can suggestively tell me that I should come over later with a smile and a wink.  Happy ending.Back to the good in this sh!t sandwich – the guns are done very well, with a good selection and interesting attachment options.  The vehicles in the game are lots of fun, all sorts of road and water craft to try, albeit with some questionable physics.  The islands themselves are beautifully constructed, with beaches, caves, hidden pathways, old temples – everything you loved from Tomb Raider, and more.  The open-world concept is very nice, “freeing” the radio towers is an interesting side quest for the first 10 towers, and then it gets tedious afterwards (though the puzzle aspect of it was fun).  At least it unlocked new guns and opened up your map, otherwise I wouldn’t have bothered.  I have the same feelings about re-taking outposts, it was fun the first 20 times.  However the game requires you to do it in order to open up new “hunter quests” so that you can craft the very best equipment.  By the end of my ~25-hour experience, I simply had enough and powered through the rest of the campaign so I could delete it from my hard drive.  Unfortunately for me, once I start something, I usually have to finish it.  Notice I didn’t have to mention uPlay to complain about this game.  But that part sucks too.ANYWAY, there was one memorable and awesome part of the game that I want to mention – you are required to take your newfound flamethrower and burn up some drug fields on a plantation to set back the local warlord.  As you arrive at the mission site, the soundtrack switches over to gangsta rap (a good track actually!) while you run and spray all of the drug fields.  It was very well orchestrated and reminded me of the epic fax machine scene in Office Space.  If there’s one reason I’d start up Far Cry 3 again, it would be to do that mission.  If it was available as a separate $2 mission, I’d buy it and play it.Don’t do it kids, go enjoy real life or a more encouraging game instead of wasting your time with this overly-negative story experience.EDIT:  Steam Censorship
