content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												Date of review: 10.24.2014Platform: PC  Released in 2012, Far Cry 3 became a huge success, considered by many the game of the year (or at least the FPS of the year), something which I also believe it fully deserves. An open world FPS experience has never felt so polished before.Story:In the third installment of the Far Cry series you take over the role of Jason Brody, a 25 year old american daredevil who is currently on a holiday with his friends and brothers in Thailand. Everything is party and fun until the group goes skydiving over the supposedly uninhabited Rook Islands, only to land on a world occupied by pirates who deal with kidnapping and human trafficking…While the plot is not as mature and meaningful as the one of Far Cry 2, it’s more than first meets the eye, being a carefully built satire.Characters are very deep, and Vaas Montenegro is one of the coolest antagonists ever to show up in a game.Though not directly related to the main plot/story line, the detailed history of Rook Islands (going back all the way to ancient China), the Rakyat (the native people of the islands) the Japanese occupation during the second world war, etc. adds a lot to the game and to the immersion.9/10 Visuals:Far Cry 3 looks absolutely stunning. Colorful yet wild, the tropical world has never looked so good and alive before, with breath taking landscapes and dozens of animals roaming/flying around. This is definitely one of those games you just enjoy by looking at. The variety is also impressive, from the lush jungles to the sandy beaches, from ancient temples to small villages, it’s simply a pleasure to roam around, and explore, and the small details really make it feel rewarding.Combat also looks and thus feels great, with brutal animations and beautiful explosions, making firefights incredibly fun.The day-night cycle (although somewhat short) is present as well and adds a lot to the visuals, creating sights which will easily take your breath away.Of course, such visuals will require a decent system in order to run smoothly on High and/or Ultra detail settings. On the test rig (for reference see test system specifications at the bottom of the review), I could run Far Cry 3 at 1080p Ultra details and 2xMSAA with very good frame rates. I did get some rare fps drops in very intense fight scenes, but even then the game was more than smooth enough to be played. Turning MSSA over 2x however, pretty much killed my frames, but this is absolutely acceptable considering the visual quality. All in all, you will need something like an Intel Core i5 3570K or an AMD FX-8350 CPU paired with a GeForce GTX 770 (GTX 680) or an AMD Radeon R9 280X (HD 7970 Ghz Edition) GPU to be able to play on Ultra settings with 2-4xMSAA at 1080p resolution. However, I also know people who play Far Cry 3 on low end PC's or laptops and they were still able to get decent fps rates on low to medium detail settings, so the game seems to be quite well optimized... thumbs up for Ubisoft (for a more in depth analysis on system requirements I advise you to check the "Far Cry 3 Performance Test: Graphics & CPU" on Techspot).10/10Gameplay:If you thought visuals were the game’s greatest strength, you were wrong… the gameplay is simply fantastic. Far Cry 3 takes over where Far Cry 2 left off, but delivers so much more in a significantly more polished way.The main plot is long, with varied and fun to play missions. The secondary missions/quests may not be as meaningful as in Far Cry 2 for example, but the game more than makes up for them with the unbelievably fun exploration, hunting, gathering, collectibles, etc. Really, collecting stuff and exploring has never felt as rewarding and as fun, whether you are searching for relics or letters from the Japanese soldiers (who occupied the islands during the Second World War), or whether you are hunting a rare white tiger or gathering herbs, you will have fun. You could probably rush through the main plot in 15-20 or so hours, but if you allow yourself sucked into the world of Rook Islands you can spend 75+ hours and you will still have plenty of stuff to do. Simply awesome.Of course this is an FPS, so one of the main questions here is, how are the guns? Short answer: great! There are well over 20 weapons to choose from, pistols, sub machine guns, assault rifles, sniper rifles, light machine guns and even exotics like the flame thrower or the re-curving bow. Also, almost all weapons are customizable, you can attach sound suppressors, scopes, extended magazines, etc. providing a truly varied arsenal which you can configure to perfectly fit your play style.Long range and close quarter combat is usually viable in every FPS, but Far Cry 3 will also be completely playable using stealth tactics, even more, you will be rewarded for stealthy kills and takedowns (which are awesome by the way), or carefully and tactically liberating outposts without getting detected. Oh and do you remember the outpost re-spawn problem from Far Cry 2? It's gone! In Far Cry 3 a libreated outpost is taken over by the Rakyat, and will serve as a safe house.As in the previous Far Cry installments, vehicles are also available. And I have to say (at least for me personally), the cars handle better and are more fun to drive than in many racing games… which is not something we are used to from an FPS.But Far Cry 3 is so much more than a simple open world FPS… the introduction of RPG elements might sound scary for some hardcore FPS fans, but Far Cry 3 nailed it. During your adventures you gain experience and eventually level up, which is rewarded with skill points which you can use to unlock some incredibly cool and brutal takedown moves and other bonuses. The skills feel balanced, you’ll never become a Terminator, but they are also rewarding enough to make you want to unlock them.And we are still not done, Far Cry 3 also has crafting! Now don't imagine a complex gathering/crafting system. You can gather skins and furrs from animals to create ammo bags and pouches, and different plants for different syringes which can heal you or provide different short term bonuses. Not much but it perfectly fits the game and the setting.10/10Sound:While the previous Far Cry games were ok when it came to sounds, they never really managed to impress me. Far Cry 3 is different, the soundtrack finally contains some memorable tunes, the ambient sounds are great, the guns, the explosions and combat in general sounds brutal, and the voiceovers are some of the best I heard in a long time, again with Vaas stealing the show.10/10Replay value:Far Cry 3’s plot is linear, and there aren't many choices you can take, you won’t replay the game for the different endings, but for everything else, because Far Cry 3 is pure fun. And... for Vaas!9/10Conclusion:The third Far Cry game really managed to put an incredibly polished and fun gameplay onto the table. It would be nice if developers finally understood that visuals and content are important, but in the end, it’s the gameplay that will really make a game fun to play… because a good game is fun to play.Great games however, are not only fun to play, but also look great and also have tons of content, and Far Cry 3 is one of these, it simply delivers in everything. Definitely a must have!9.5/10Test system specifications: AMD FX-8350 (OC @ 4.6 GHz); 8 GB DDR3 RAM @ 1866 MHz; AMD Radeon R9 280X (AMD Catalyst 14.4 and 14.9), Windows 8.1 64 Bit Pro.

												I am rewriting my review, leaving previosu thoughts but i have now made a final decision. I can no longer recommend this game because:1. The game is in a constant state of requiring to connect to "far cry 3 services" which is just nonsense. So apparently when I launched the game,  I was greated with "failed to connect to far cry 3 services". Cryptic, for sure. Basically an issue on ubisoft's end.     While playing, every time I access the menu or map (and in this game, you do it a LOT) I was forced to set for about 15-30 seconds after, everytime, interrupted by an immergency message saying the game needed to connect to "far cry 3 services". It failed, every time. After this attempt, I was "allowed" to keep playing as long as I didn't use the map or inventory/crafting screen because then it would try again.2. The map is beyond glitchy and buggy, its broken and in many instances, preventing the use of fast travel or even basic viewing. Game itself is fine, the method of delivery is♥♥♥♥♥♥poor. Avoid. BELOW IS MY PREVIOUS REVIEW TAKE ON THE GAME INITIALLY. I really like this game ! But I'm reviewing the steam digital version here. And unfortunately, compared to what Steam offers, it's downright idiotic that their entire opportunity to use TRADING CARDS or  ACHIEVEMENTS       is GONE because of U PLAY.  U PLAY is like a steam wanna be except it doesn't do what steam does , it just tries to do what xbox live does, and I was never interested in either. I really don't mind U play that much, but its pointless since nobody is going to see your account because nobody uses U PLAY apart from when they are forced to for a few select games of their choosing. GREAT game ! A little silly stupid sometimes with how inept a character can be until you suddenly gain control and they turn into Rambo's dad.          Hindered by being forced to use a second DRM game launcher that is essentially a second Steam..... that prevents Steam from doing what it does best.  And nobody needs two different online platform accounts for the same game.

content:
Posted: January 10
												You are Jason. Normal dude, with a 7/10 model qt girlfriend (her butt is 10/10 though). A sudden turn of events change you in to a tattoo loving, native boning, acid tripping badboy. You walk, you run, you drive (poorly), occasionally you jump from helicopters with some kind of gliding suit. You kill and harvest the meat of a number of animals. It’d be much too convenient to simply buy things you need when you can just kill boars, tigers, … and sharks. How do you kill a shark? Just stand on land and shoot it, duh! You also have a weird fetish for radio towers, but people give you free stuff for going to the top of them, so why not? Oh yeah there are a bunch of bad guys constantly trying to kill you too.Yup, just another day in paradise.The good:+ A shooter pretty much anyone can pick up and play. The easiest difficulty I didn’t have a problem playing with a steam controller.+ Impressive visuals. Can still challenge even a GTX 1080.+ A sizable world that I never really felt bored in.+ Decent story, but the game is not that story heavy. Think GTA V not the Witcher 3.+ Great voice acting with very interesting characters.+ A decent mix of missions.+ A satisfying kind of bad♥♥♥♥♥ending.+ Trippy drug induced sequences add some artistic flair.The bad:- Weird technical glitches, at least 2 missions I had to replay because I was unable to loot an important body.- Crappy save system. Can only save outside of mission. Event then some times when you save you don’t end up where you think you will on load.- Occasional crash, this will cost you some time because of the save system.- Weird performance deterioration between save points / transitions.- Bad driving controls. Driving is overly challenging on a controller.- Couldn’t get it to recognize the steam controller. There is a controller mode but had to map controller to keyboard / mouse. Less desirable because you have to remember what everything is mapped to.-Uplay. Need I say more?TLDR;A pretty good looking shooting romp around a paradise island that I think most people would be able to play. Story is OK if not a little weird. A few technical glitches hold this game back from being highly recommend, but if you can overlook that it’s still a decent game. I’ve played much worse so I say give it a shot.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
Singleplayer:Campaign:I played the campaign on it's hardest difficulty and it took me somewhere around 15 hours. The story is about Jason Brody having a vacation on an island. And wakes up in a cage realising that his vacation is over and he has to save all his friends so they can get back home. This sounds and also felt generic. But as you continue through the game the story gets more and more interesting, due to well voiced characters and the inspiring monologues. The game also felt like some kind of total recall to me, because the character has many drug trips. So even when I was playing the normal sp missions I was asking myself if it wasn't just a drug trip. Because if the bulk of the story was a drug trip the story would make a lot more sense. The campaign story was mostly the reason that kept me playing. Gameplay:The gameplay other hand was good and entertaining, but nothing special for me. Some early missions could be annoying, because you were forced to play stealthily. Also the sp missions can sometimes feel as a narrow route.  The power of the gameplay itself is that you can choose how you want to play. stealthily or guns blazing. Both can be fun but both also have some issues. The stealth problem is that the ai can be annoying. And for guns blazing you can easily run out of ammo and have to break your arm to revive yourself many times if you play guns blazing.(Atleast on my difficulty. I would maybe recommend to play 1 difficulty below or first do a lot of side missions to unlock more health, weapons etc.) Also if you have no ammo you mostly have to camp until you can easily knife someone, without getting hit. Sadly every endboss fight from the game showed the definition of insanity in gameplay. The game was also a bit overwhelming in the beginning because of the many menus with upgrades. At first I ignored them, but later I really saw the benefit of it. Otherwise you will easily die.  The graphics of the game still look nice, I especially liked the lighting. And how much effort there had been put into the building. Open World:I have to be honest I haven't done that much in it. Because I wasn't really interested in it. Still I can say if you are interested in exploring the world there is alot to do! There are enough side-missions, which is mostly killing enemies/animals in a certain way, missions where you have to go from A to B as fast as you can etc and, of course, collecting stuff. Really the only thing that made me stop fast-traveling from mission to missions was the tower climbing and the animal/flower hunt to unlock stuff. They were more rewarding to me than the side missions that just give you money and xp that I already had enough of. Online:Multiplayer:In my opinion the mp isn't that special. It has 4 standard game modes. Of course they are varied with some nice ideas. But to me it just feels like a cod-clone. The multiplayer also has a strong map editor. Probably at the time there were many great mods made. (I found some interesting ones on youtube. ) But now that the game isn't as active anymore, I couldn't find a modded map to play.-Co-op:I played the co-op with someone many months before continuing my singleplayer campaign. It was pretty long at 6-8 hours. But still the co-op was pretty generic and forgetable. The only thing that I liked were the mini-games. What is strange is that the multiplayer and the co-op leveling system are combined. So if I had only played Co-Op, I would have all the unlocked loadouts for the multiplayer. Overall:I can say Farcry 3 is a great game, but you can ignore the multiplayer and co-op, because they aren't that special and that active anymore. I think for the people who only own FarCry 4, FarCry 3 is still a great game to play, especially for the campaign, that makes it something special.

												Booooo uPlay.This game requires a uPlay signin to play. In some cases, uPlay activation is either unobtrusive or not required, but for this game, it is. You will launch the game in Steam, which launches uPlay, which launches the actual game. My actual time played is about 8 hours, but Steam isn't reflecting it for that very reason.That being said:+Big world!+Shooting/stealth is fun and for the most part, enjoyable.+One of the few games with a satisfying flamethrower that catches huge patches of jungle on fire.-Pretty unoptimized, but I can't tell if it's because I have to run uPlay as well.-Skill trees suck. They do that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t "Lock certain abilities until you're further in the story" thing. Just give me a skill list instead of a tree then!-Hunting is a neat idea, but terrible in execution. I GUESS I'M CARRYING ONE GUN FOR THE REST OF THE GAME BECAUSE I CAN'T FIND A GOAT TO CRAFT ANOTHER HOLSTER! It just ends up feeling like filler, since there isn't much reason to explore the world besides crafting supplies.-Garbage interface. Feels really slow and clunky, like I'm playing the game with boxing gloves on.-The story starts out pretty interesting, but is spread thin and really makes you ask "Who cares?" about halfway through.So between all that AND a terrible uPlay implimentation, I'd say avoid.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Far Cry 3 is an interesting return to form for Ubisoft. What is it? Well it's adventure to put it bluntly, and it seems like they geared the whole game around it. Adventure, action, survival. It's plot bares very interesting similarities to 19th century adventure stories like Treasure Island, with the protagonist having to face pirates and psychologically grow stronger as a character.In terms of gameplay the game is fundamentally very similar to Far Cry 2, but at the same time very different. The plot structure is more cinematic and focused on story. Adding to that, animals are much more heavily focused upon. The game introduces a crafting system and inorder to carry more guns and ammunition you must skin specific animals. This actually makes the game very interesting with how you hunt animals in the overworld and breaks up the monotony of killing pirates fairly effectively.That's not to say the game is without flaws. While the protagonist is portrayed as an everyman, even on the hardest difficulty you are death incarnate outside of cutscenes. Adding to that the game's sidequests are more or less just "Kill this particular enemy with a specific weapon" or "find this particular animal".Ubisoft designed the world very effectively. Overall it's kill pirates, get money, ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥es. Not necessarily in that order.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Where to start. IMO This game overall is nothing special. Even playing on the hardest difficulty this game was easy. Tank your way through and inject enough medical needles to turn yourself into a walking testosterone infused pot head, and you will be fine. Stealthing made it a little more challenging, but not by much. The story is nothing to right home about, most of the characters are just boring, the script for most of them was like somthing out of a bad modern action movie, opened world with not much to do, money is freaking EVERYWHERE, obtaining new weapons is as easy as climbing a tower, upgrading all of your varius storage packs are as simple as killing a few animals, and this game is repetitive AS HELL! Find artifacts and letters (it's as easy as an easter egg hunt), liberate outposts by killing about 6 to 8 guards, climb towers to get free stuff, damsel in distress, medical runs, hunt animals and bandets, and the main story (about 8 hours). Thats it, there is nothing that makes this game stand out from the rest. The story didn't have a stong start and just feels like poorly writen action movie. It doesn't become interesting until a character named vaas tells you the definition of insanity. But once he dies the story goes down hill again faster than lemmings. It's not all bad though, a few of the characters are interesting along with some dialogue, and it tries to spice things up. But it's not enough to backlash all of the♥♥♥♥♥♥Over all if you are a FPS junky and don't mind doing the same thing over and over and over again go for this game. But if you want games with outstanding sotries, interesting gameplay, new and different ideas, and memorable characters. look elsewhere.Also, note how i never metioned the graphics and multiplayer? Thats because almost every ♥♥♥♥ING FPS does nothing but that now.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Quite a memorable game with memorable characters. Despite being mostly a free-roam game, with plenty of distractions and activities, like hunting, killing, swimming, gliding etc. it has a decent story.As I mentioned in the beginning, the characters are one of the strongest points in this game, every character with their own strong personalities, each one with their own insanity, great voice acting and motion track. The motivation and choice freedom of the protagonist feel a bit wooden and not quite dynamic, but the diversity in the activities, making it feel not quite so linearity dependent, compensates for the lack of story control.The story can be easily completed with minimum of effort, since difficulty doesn't really represent an impediment (if you play shooters often, you can aim for the highest difficulties), but making the side activities do help in certain cases, especially for the traveling part.The vehicle control is quite fluent, reminds me of the car from Half-Life 2. The weapons can be customized in a variety of ways, from adding attachments to adding a camo, quite easy to use, they have ironsight, so for any Call of Duty player they should be a no-brainer.It has a sort of RPG-like skill tree, which allows you to get new abilities and features, supporting your gameplay as well as your herb/animal crafting system.The co-op is average, not much of a story, really linear levels, it's basically a cooperative competition, since each level contains a sort of mini-game with ranking, so you will be able to beat your friends and brag about it. It's sometimes bugged, you may be spawning dead, fall through the ground.The multiplayer is quite...empty...not many people play it, it has basic game modes like team deathmatch and domination like modes, feels a lot like a "Call of Duty" style. You also have a multiplayer leveling system (not the same with the one from single player), which will unlock new weapons/skills etc. I also happened to encounter some cheaters and some bugs.Also wanted to add that this game's antagonist (the cool one), Vaas, was a source of inspiration for one of my cosplay projects, feel free to check it out.

By: Steven Cojo

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Let's start by talking about why Assassin's Creed 3 is pish. It's a game obsessed with making you play exactly how the designers had intended. Those rewards you get for full synchronisation aren't rewards for playing well; in fact, withholding them is a punishment for playing a mission any way the designers didn't intend. Assassin's Creed 3 wants you to hit certain beats to look stylish and will end the game if you don't dance to its tune.Back in Assassin's Creed 2 the series valued emergence - the kind of crazy nonsense that might or might not happen depending on how you did or didn't play. You'd get a target and more often than not you'd do your thing and the game was happy for you to do it the way you want. Far Cry 3 loves emergence, and that makes it a more authentic Assassin's Creed than Assassin's Creed 3.It's not an unfair comparison. They were mostly developed at the same studio in Montreal, they both begin with the same old quote from Alice in Wonderland and then they both proceed to share the same ideas all over the place - similar towers to climb, similar minigames to play, a similar focus on hunting endangered critters, and a similar structure - with one critical difference: Far Cry 3 lets you do most things your way. It's a thirty-hour anecdote generator and some of the year's best gaming moments have been emergent madness spawned by Far Cry 3's checkpoint assaults.Now, there's a lot I dislike about Far Cry 3. The campaign has all your Game Design Favourites like Forced Stealth, Escort Missions, and First Person Platforming is terrible. I don't want to have to keep leaving the game to see my map or craft items and I don't see why Far Cry 2's magical cardboard in-game map couldn't have carried over to Far Cry 3.I once grumbled about Far Cry 2's respawning checkpoints but 3's alternative has you gradually stripping the world of content until there's nothing left to fight but a bunch of tapirs. And I'm not keen on the - to lapse into sociology-speak - "othering" of the Rakyat, the white dude restoring order to a disorderly "ethnic" land via the hot end of his assault rifle, or the implied♥♥♥♥♥♥and QTE disco stabfest stuff either.That's not to say I want Far Cry to be a PG-rated no-chairshots-to-the-head cuddlefest, because I miss the sheer brutality of Far Cry 2 - a game where your bestest buddy deforests acres of jungle with Agent Orange just so you can have a clear line of fire at the guys farming there, never mind the damage it does to the ecosystem or to your face.In Far Cry 2 even your friends weren't your friends and it all felt like a proper descent into madness - mad characters, mad game design, one final mad moral choice, the lot. Cut to Far Cry 3 and you're punching your brother until he cries, doing the whole "look at my hands... what have I become?" thing and then getting straight back to jumping off a cliff with a hang glider and dive-bombing guys for phat XP. Thematic consistency is the all I'm after - Far Cry 2 had it; Far Cry 3 doesn't. But Far Cry 2 also had bad guys who could spot the golf ball Alan Shepard teed off the Moon just as it's passing Jupiter so every mission became a shoot-'em-up killing spree where everyone and everything caught fire. Four years on, Far Cry 3 has bad guys with all the observational powers of a referee in the WWE, so stealth works and works well. You get to hide and feel powerful right up to the moment you make a silly mistake and then you get to fight off a small army with the obscene firepower you're given within minutes of starting the campaign.You have fantastic tools with which to scout out an area and so many ways to know when enemies are nearby - the radar, Brody's X-Ray vision, their constant chatter - that you master the environment. Games have become sorta obsessed with "empowering" players - apparently ignoring the important lessons taught by games like Resident Evil and Dark Souls on the way.But in stealth games every system needs to be transparent or else you end up shouting "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T" at the screen when a brown man standing in front of a brown tree in a brown forest filled with brown grass on the other side of the universe puts a bullet between your eyes when you were hiding behind a rock. Far Cry 3 understands stealth like Mark of the Ninja does and it means you have the tools to play the game how you like.When he's not making games badder in badder Andy Kelly likes to take out outposts with a couple of neat sniper shots to the alarm system, then pick everyone off from afar. Me? I like to get in the camp and get up close with knife and bow. And we've both had fun with it. Something goes wrong so you hide and relocate, or you Rambo everyone to death with explosive arrows, maybe.I carry a grenade launcher everywhere like Mask De Smith and go explodey the very second a pirate or a Cassowary gives me an excuse. I once had a grenade launcher joust with pirates on a bridge until I'd dumped five truckfuls of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s into the river. Weird things happen in far Cry 3 and it's brilliant.When Ubisoft are trying to force Uncharted-style scripting into Assassin's Creed's massive open world it's clear game design is headed down a dark rabbit hole. And at the bottom of that hole isn't a magical wonderland filled with whimsical characters and adventure; nope, it's just a regular hole filled with rabbit poo. Far Cry 3 is good because it lets you tell your own stories within the neat boundaries Ubisoft give you. Mad emergent things happen and you're forced to deal with them using whatever comes to mind - stealth, fire, missiles, running away and hiding - Far Cry 3 doesn't care what you do, so long as you're having fun.And then you go away and tell your friends about what happened in your tropical adventure and they tell you what happened in theirs, and the stories you tell are different. That's what videogames are supposed to be. Any idiot can tell you a story, but only a videogame can give you enough flexibility to be creative and tell your own. Far Cry 3 is a proper videogame and I have the stories to prove it.If you like it, make a "Yes"Thank you for your time!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I wish I could recommend this game. It's moderately fun for the majority of it - aside from the annoying dream sequences - but the main story ground to a halt when I was suddenly forced to go on a stealth mission that automatically fails if you're ever detected. The fact that this restriction had not previously existed in any mission beforehand coupled with an imperfect AI detection screen (they saw me through a solid door once) and it made for an impasse in the game and - ultimately - left me unable to recommend this game.In an era of games like Dishonored, artificial stealth requirements - especially when I'm carrying more than enough ammunition to kill everyone in the base - just ruin the gameplay. There are too many other games that don't suddenly manufacture artificial requirements in missions to play to waste time on this one.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Far Cry 3 seems promising, at first.  I think.  To be honest, no.  There was always a glimmer of this being Just Cause 2 meets Tomb Raider reboot meets maybe a dash of Spec Ops crazy, but it takes these good ingredients and pops out a mediocre product.   It's also full of rather game-ruining bugs, which were promised to be patched up by Uplay and Steam but ultimately cut many hours of progress to shreds (the camera/rocks could not be accessed, all my guns and ammo were stripped for no reason at all.)Maybe it's better on consoles, but it's ultimately a very, very generic product (Hope you like recapturing the same little outpost 32 times) outdone by its predecessors and JC2.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Formulaic and honestly quite boring, it forces you to play as a stealthy player whether you want to or not. The main missions are filled with escort quests, not since Goldeneye have I been so utterly enraged by a stupid NPC that I have to protect. I hate the protagonist and I hate his friends. I actually hate the islanders even more and started killing them wholesale. Hunting and skinning animals and gathering plants is a meaningless grind the same can be said abouit the letter's relics, and climbing radio towers. All of these things seem to be inserted into the game to artificially inflate the legnth of the game.  I don't know how the hell this game got rated so highly because one word comes to mind Boring. Disclaimer, as a whole I would give this game a 6.5/10 based on how beautiful it is, and how mechanically strong it is, these things however are only half the battle.  The story, character interection, and other activities take away from what is otherwise a mechanically strong/ aethetically pleasing game.  Because I believe it is in poor form to criticise a game without Justifying the reasons for my opion's I'll break it down for you here.Stealth play: I firmly hate stealth play in FPS as a matter of forced enjoyment, all the assassinate pirate quests and taking of compounds plus  several story missions make you employ stealth or you fail/ Get killed by endless waves of reinforcements. Terrible mechanic is terrible, the frontal assault option needs to be just as viable, I mean this isn't splinter cell, once your equipped correctly yyou should be able to run and gun not sneak and stab.Escort Missions: I get it my friends and I all got kidnapped and now I have to rescue them / get them to safety, However, after I've mowed down an entire batalion of pirates, why the hell do I have to get ino a boat/ jeep and do an on rails turret section until we are in safety? (another thing I hate seriously screw turret sections and screw game designers for putting this crap into a game.Why the hell can't I save my "Friend" and tell them to run "That way" and then pick off the pirates as they try to persue us on foot in the jungle. I mean one of the biggest theme's in this game is you unlocking your inner hunter/ Jungle fighting badass, not unlocking your inner turret working door gunner.The Protagonist: Jason is easily my most hated protagonist, the words Whiney, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ come to mind. I mean the whining would be acceptable right up until you meet a certain island lady and unlock your inner badass hunter. (Citra I am talking about Citra) After you embrace your inner hunter you should no longer whine when gutting animal's you should no longer be brooding you should be a badass predator in the making. Instead what we get is the same kid getting more and more tatted out and mainting the same attitude.His Friends: There is not a single one that I like, If it were up to me and I could make the morale choice earlier in the game I would have made the choice to let them stay kidnapped and instead concentrated my Vendetta against Hoyt and Vaas. From the movie star to the goophy "Stoner" not a singe one of them is an NPC that I feel for, I don't want to save them because I honestly don't care about them.The Islander's: Why the hell are the indiginous "Maori" (Quoted because they are not Maori although they are likely very much so modelled after them. Or atleast I believe so, I honestly stopped paying attention after I had to fetch someones medicine and wanted to punch my monitor.) so damned helpless to solve their own most basic problems. Actually I am not going to fault this game too heavily for helpless NPC's giving me stupid fetch quests that they should be able to do on their own, as its indemic with almost ALL modern games. I'll give this example, One NPC begged me to go bully another NPC to stop him from digging up her daughters grave. The player is supposed to be this mythical great warrior, "Read stealth prison shanker" why would you rationally bother such a person with that sort of task? That would be like if I was in a huge war zone, and a Spec Op's soldier showed up to save me and I then asked him if he could deliver a love letter to my girlfriend. I would be told to **** off and probably be pistol whipped for suggesting something so stupid and you know what? I'd deserve it. These people are supposed to be badass warrior's what we get is a group of bumbling idiot's that after a few, "Spy on my boyfriend, and Fetch my daughter" quests will make you just want to outright shoot them  instead of helping them.Further if your their savior, they should be helping you (by providing valuable information not in a direct manner) not begging you for help with trivial tasks..The Time Wasters: Skinning animal's and processing plant's started out as fun but soon became quite a trivial chore, I equate them with kill 5 boars (this time literally" and other such quests in MMO's. Climbing radio tower's is another example of forced enjoyment this time via jumping puzzles. What you have is a person running up flights of stairs and circling their way up a tower. This wouldn't be bad if their wasn't almost 30 of the stupid things in the game. (why the hell are there so many of these things on such a small group of islands in the first place?) And this brings us to the absolute joyus Memory cards, Relic's and Letters. 120 relics,  20 Letters, and I think 30 memory cards. Why? Do you really need to inlfate your game by adding so many of these things? I have a thought for the game developers on this one; Less is more when it comes to trivial tasks. Imagine what you could have had your game designers doing if you removed say half of all of those items, 60 relics, 10 letters and 15 memory cards. What amazing thing could they have done instead of designing a complex labarynth of undergound tunnels for the express purpose of putting a  Boar/ Shark Relic in there, Dittor for the jumping puzzles for the Heron relics. Could have probably designed a whole other Island, or given **********SPOILERS SPOILERS******* Vaas a decent showdown / death scene instead of that dream sequence off camera death.***********SPOILERS OVER********* instead you had them designing the aforementioned cave systems instead. As a player I don't feel that Boar relic #24 added anything special to my game experience other then making me think I really wish I had some bacon right now.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												Far Cry 3 spits the naive, arrogant and entitled Jason Brody into a spiralling world of violence, anarchy and survival, beset in a jungle, where survival by whatever means necessary is the norm as he restores order to the islands by takling over pirate camps and towers to reveal a map of the islands. This is what a first-shooter, open-world game ought to be. Sure, it lacks character development in some scenes, such as Jason's thrust into the island without seeing his emotions unfold as he loses his brother to Vaas. And the main villain: He was really top-notch. Vaas played his role perfectly, though the game mechanics downplayed his role as a vilain. Taking down bosses in choreographed button mashes and simplistic scenes is no way to end a boss. Same went for Hoyt Voyker and Buck Hughes.All in all, its' many hours of exploration, take-downs, gliding, sky-diving, killing and blowing up things. A journey you'll be begging to return to over and over again.Second part: Co-Op. That is some awesome stuff. Adds many, many hours of hilarious gameplay and challenge-based system that add up XP , a'la Trials of the Rakyat in Single Player.Multi-player: Well, this is probably my favorite so far. You can't play it once. Custom maps can also be built and be featured here too.Notes: Mature content. Everywhere. Overall rating: 9.5 out of 10.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Endless world FPS... Only if you like these. Continuing straight from FC2 (game char') you fight on a far away island to release your friends. While there's obviously a lot to do, single player can be over after 8 hours or less if you choose not to play any mission outside the plot. Some mission are fun, some get boring (actually, most of them are kind of repetitive in one way or the other after you play them a few times). Graphics are marvelous, and the sound is great too, but after finishing the game you feel some parts of the plot are weak, f.e. the parts where you fight bosses - you black out, all other enemies disappear... weak.The multi player was disappointing, but I really liked the Co-op (left4dead play style, with pirates instead of zombies). There are 8 missions to be played for hours, with a ladder to abilities and experience, as in any other shooter today. The Bad things in the MP are many sever disconnections, and visual bugs (like floating dead people, etc...).It's not as good as the gaming media shouted, but if you explore the whole island, buying it today for 7.49$ (in sales) , it is a money well spent.BTW, there is no reason to buy the Deluxe edition - unless you want the whole thing. It's main addition is 2 Island side missions, nothing more.7.5/10

content:
Posted: April 19, 2013
												I'm not sure what to think about this one. I haven't played much because, quite frankly, the game just got very boring. I thought this game would be a lot like Fallout 3 with such a large open world and hunting down and finishing quests when, in all honesty, after the long opening (which you can't save and continue later without having to start half of it all over <annoying>) I found myself mostly wandering around (or driving, which is a nice addition) killing a few people here and there or hunting animals and plants to create things which is just clumsy. Quests are one thing, but looking for radio towers to activate just seems ridiculous. Nobody on the island would have done that yet?? On the plus side, the graphics are great and the weapons (when you can get them) are awesome plus, finding vehicles (land, sea, AND air) and driving (or gliding) them is fun and necessary to explore such a massive open world. I plan to revisit the island soon and see if there is more I just haven't seen yet. I'll update this when I do.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												FarCry 3. One of the BEST games I’ve ever played in my years of gaming.There’s so much to talk about, I guess I’ll divide this game into multiple categories to talk about.– The storyline 10/10Words literally how amazingly amazing it felt to play this game. The story mode was well thought out and executed perfectly, an original story with everything else was amazing. I do not wish to spoil the story too much because you NEED to play this game. Basically you are a tourist visiting an island when suddenly something goes wrong…– The graphics 10/10Graphic-wise the game is beautiful and detailed, when you’re playing it, it feels like skyrim but with better graphics and more realistic weapons. Sure some computers may not be able to run the game, but the majority of the people who can run the game on the best graphics will admit it you can feel a simple breeze from the wind. The weather system can’t be talked bad about at all because the rain wasn’t too annoying, but was made just perfect.– The A.I 8/10The A.I is the only element in the game I could complain about, yet it was marvelous. In times during the game I noticed some A.I glitching in the wall or just auto-noticing me behind a wall. In other times the A.I were just surprisingly professional by avoiding all walls and hiding behind baricades while shooting me only when I stand up to shoot them! Also the A.I of animals was made so they act like they do in real life, from turtles crouching in their shell to sharks slowly getting closer and going in for the kill.– The Controls 10/10Everything was designed wisely, starting from the basic-in-every-game controls like WASD and Shift to sprint to smaller details like switching items in your inventory around the way you like.– The gameplay 10/10This is the main element of the game which is most essential. The possibilities are infinite, you can play the game as vanilla as you want by using weapons you pick up from the enemy but you can’t taste the game truly unless you’ve tried the RPG’s or the Flamethrower. The leveling up system in the game is not like any other but a very original concept. You unlock new weapons and get them free in shops by claiming land from the enemy or climbing radio towers which noticeably become harder to get on top of with every new one. You can also convert to be a better warrior for the sake of the island by leveling up and getting “Tatau” aka Tattoo’s on your arm which give you abilities like holding your breath underwater longer or decreasing the damage you take from animal bites.– The Ending 10/10 I really can’t talk much about the ending to not spoil it, but the way you want the game to end is all up to you. There are 2 endings so it’s all up to you how you end the game.– Final Verdict 10/10The Game as a whole is a 10/10. A First person survival which has more then 30+ Realistic animals. I recommend everyone to play it.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
"You kissed the girl, now you have to pay!"I recommend this enjoyable open world FPS. You loved your trip to Thailand and happen to like Apocalypse, now? Pros and cons in order:Positive: Absolutely amazing optics and level design. It is worth getting all the collectibles & loot, just because of some amazing caves and scenery. Vehicles are fun. Controls are easy and understandable. The main story is set right from the beginning. Some characters are done nicely; specially Buck and Vaas are great. The game had it's fun moments, including the side quests.Sometimes offers the choice between the Run & Gun or the stealth approach. Only minor bugs on Win7. (Some Dollar bills couldn't be picked up) The Co-Op mode is lotsa fun. As well, it got four great characters and good missions!Neutral:Liberating Outposts has absolutely no impact to the main story.Hunting was cool, but there were too many predators in the game for my liking, in case you have been idle for too long. You can bypass certain hard bits with Godmode-Syringes.Negative:The boss fights are all scripted and mostly alike.In general your main character as well as your friends are highly unlikeable. The first half of the story is fast paced and pretty good as well. After that, it looses steam quickly (Ubisoft, isn't it?) and barely crawls over the finish line. Did I mention the "boss fights" are non-events?The weapon's menu and the whole economic system are unbalanced. Weapons are tons of the same. With "Signature Weapons" each class has a weapon which maxes all peers out. The main story missions are very unimaginative and too much alike: Sneak somewhere in to kill someone or blow things up, exit in a rush.Not sure if owed to my minor difficulty level, but there weren't any helicopter battles except for a brief moment in the main story and the Rakiyat trials - and well, yes the last outpost. As well, I missed any navy battles or hang glider escapes built into the main story.Enemy AI seems to "tag" you even through bushes from miles and it is quite hard to loose the line of view, theras close to you, they start stumbling around and make easy targets. The loot button is the same as the weapon's switch button. This is extremely annoying.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												It all began when I read Swiss Family Robinson as a kid and watched Gilligan's Island reruns on television. It probably continued while watching Fantasy Island, (and Herve Villichaize in the belltower shouting "de plane! de plane!") during a harsh Indiana winter. I'm referring to my love for the South Pacific Ocean. My love for that place was finally requited when I spent two and a half years there in the US Navy on a forward deployed Fast Frigate. I left the Navy, and those cherished waters never to return again save for my dreams and memories. And that's the sucky part about aging. Each passing year makes the details a little more fuzzy, a little more distant. Sometimes I feel as if they're the memories of an entirely different person. And then I played Far Cry 3. Guam, Diego Garcia, The Indian Ocean. It was all there for me, revisited on my computer screen. It was like an odd sense of coming home. Not only did the game's protagonist, Jason Brody, share the same adventurous locales as I did at his age, we also went through a deflowering of innocence all men take the path of, albeit mine occurred over years. Poor Brody's innocence was shattered the moment his brother and friends were accosted by the villians, Vaas and Hoyt, drug and slave traders who inhabit the gameworld like monsters. As I lead Brody through a dark passage of rites in rescuing his friends and a preciptious push into manhood I've gotten to know the island like my own backyard. I've not been affected by a game like this in ages. When I haven't been playing I've been listening to the game soundtrack so efficiently and appropriately helmed by Brian Tyler (e.g. Constantine, Iron Man 3.) Driving down the Indiana countryside looking up at these gray autumn skies and listening to this music, it just makes me yearn so much to go back to the island. It's a desire only fulfilled when I can sit in front of my computer again and lose myself entirely in the gameworld. The game will soon end for me. I'm on the last long downhill leg of the roller coaster. And it's been an ecstatic ride. Watching the end credits will be bittersweet, I'm sure, because I'm going to be reacquainted with that old feeling of leaving home once again.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is like your favourite action movie. It has snipers, exploding vehicles, and a maniacal villain named Vaas. Already this may sound like a clichéd shooter, but Far Cry 3 does so many things well, that it’s hard not to dive back into its world again. Along your perilous journey, you will climb up a radio tower, cover yourself in magical tattoos, and drive a quad-bike into a river. All of these elements, while definitely daredevilish, don’t feel out of place in Far Cry 3. The map is vast, and allows you to explore to your heart’s content. Hunt wild animals to collect their skin, or liberate enemy outposts to gain respect amongst the civilians. In Far Cry 3, it’s completely up to your how you approach situations. Beneath the crazy guise that Ubisoft paints with Far Cry 3, lies a character that actually cares. Jason Brody, along with his other twentysomething friends, travel to the remote Rook Islands, for a holiday. But all is not what it seems. Vaas, a psychopathic leader of Rook Island, captures Jason and his friends. Jason escapes, but his other friends are not with him. Jason must meet with local islanders to find his friends and go home. Playing Far Cry 3, I thought Jason was an excellent character with a determined, hard-working spirit, who wants nothing but to keep his friends safe. Vaas is a wonderful villain, with humour, but also a sort of finess on how he handles situations. The strange calmness he portrays is intimidating, but at the same time, left me uneasy. He is definitely a unique character, and one that I welcomed into the game. The only this is, Vaas seemed to swear a lot, often too much. This took away from his character slightly, and was one of the only disappointments I had with this game. Far Cry 3’s gameplay is diverse, entertaining and never gets old. One moment, you will be fighting for your life setting pirates on fire, and the next you will be jumping out of a plane in a wingsuit. All of these never felt nuanced or out of place, and whether you are using a keyboard and mouse or a controller, the controls are easy to pick up, and similar to other games of its genre.The game’s campaign mode is quite long, and lasted me around twelve to fourteen hours. While it is definitely the main aspect of Far Cry 3, after you finish your missions on Rook Island, there are still so many other places to explore and new things to discover. Loot is found everywhere throughout the vast map, hidden in crates. Bodies can also contain money and trinkets, which can be sold for money at stores. Plants are also found on the minimap, each a different colour. I found the Green Leaves especially useful for crafting important medical syringe kits, which have saved me from death countless times.The customization of weapons in Far Cry 3 is amazing. If you really want to, you can add a Red Dot Sight to a .44 Magnum handgun, or an extended magazine to an ACE assault rifle. All of these can also be customized with decals and camos, letting you find the weapons that are more suited to your play style. You can equip an M249 SAW, an LMG, and a LPO-50 Flamethrower and torch the lot, or go in silently with a silenced Z93 and a Recurve Bow with a Reflex Sight. In Far Cry 3, it’s completely your choice.Vehicles in Far Cry 3 could have been much improved. There were only three “classes” of vehicles, like the army-like 4WDs or the sedans and quad bikes. These all handle basically the same, and I personally am not a fan of first-person driving and was disappointed you couldn’t change this. Also, vehicles are scarce around Rook Island, and I was often without a ride and sprinting for ages to get to a destination in time.Overall, Far Cry 3 is an amazingly diverse, creative and humongous first-person adventure, and one that will keep you glued to your monitor in excitement and anticipation as it shows you a fantastically good time.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Far Cry 3 is a sum of many ubisoft games, they have taken many features from their other IPs and successfully combined it with the tropical setting of far cry 1 the end result is a brilliant open world fps that is exciting to play till the end.There is coop and competetive multiplayer in FC3, the PvP is decent fun you level up fairly quickly and have battle cries and can customize a lot, you can spend a decent amount of hours in it before getting bored, the PvE is really fleshed out and the characters are well written and is objective based you will have better luck finding a game in the competitive mp rather than the coop mp.The single player is a very diverse,really fleshed out levels and thoroughly exciting until the end. The best part i loved about FC3 was that it rewarded stealth play example if you take out an outpost you get 500 xp take out the outpost but without triggering the alarm and you get 550 xp and if you take out the outpost without being detected you get 1500 xp. This is the reason why i almost always used stealth to take out outposts and you can do the same in most of the missions. The wildlife makes it feel like a real world where you can skin animals and sell it for cash or use for crafting, the herbivores will run away scared of you the carnivores will actively attack you and try to kill you, you can also set animals like bears,tigers and lions on the enemies by luring the animal to them or by shooting the caged animals which is a lot of fun.Traversing through FC3 is a blast you can use the outposts you captured as fast travel, the cars are decent to use the water vehicles are very fun to use espically the jetski, the most fun you can have traveling is when you ziplines and the glider, later during the late game you will have access to wingsuit and paracute which makes traveling from one point to the other even more exhillariting and fun to do. FC3 is a looker it looks really good and the vistas change from region to region some of the segments are breathtaking, the level of detail if you can run it on very high/ultra is mindblowing, the lighting the shadows and the particle effects are really well done, the facial animation doesnt look that well but it is a 4 year old game now so cant complain too much. The jungle truly comes alive as the meshes of the trees grass and plants make it feel really life-like.I feel FC3's villian characters are really interesting with backstories and are well developed especially Vaas whose voice actor really brings the character to life but the hero characters espcially the main hero J.Brody is not intersting nor convincing the character will blurt out stupid puns and make fun or everything and sometimes acts all serious making him feel like a man-child. The story is simple and the game has two endings, i only wish they made the "bad" ending somewhat better but i guess then it wouldnt be the bad ending but overall the story is servicable and the characters for the most part are good.There is a lot to do in FC3 from unlocking towers to view segments of the maps, free outposts to fast travel and access new items, complete side quests in which you are required to eliminate enmies or animals using speific wepons, looting is very fun and the game actively encourages you to do so the chalice ones are hard to do and fun since it makes you explore, apart from these you have races,gambling,knives throws, etc, so yeah a lot to do. FC3 tropical setting really helps the mood of the game and the nigh and day cycle really bring out the jungle vibe. The game doesnt have too many  bugs or glitches, i did run into a few popups and stutters but mostly its looks good and runs well. The problem sometimes occues in mp when uplay decided to disconnect you automatically during game and its quite annoying but thanfully thats just on the mp side of the things. You can crafy syringes to enhance your abilites and skin animals to upgrade carrrying ammo, extra guns and special bows.There are also some dlc missions which are quite good if you have them, blowing stuff up feels really rewarding and the enemy AI is really nice, they will try to flank you into the open they actively use grandes to make you go into open areas to kill you easily.The tagging system in FC3 really makes the stealth aspect very intriguing as you can tag the enemies observe their pattern to quitely assassinate them or set animals on them. The takedown feature is probably the best feature ive seen in video games reason being the variety of takedown you can perform, from the simplet takedown to chain,gunslinger,death from above/below, heavy and grande, each does something differnet and feels really satisfying.Lastly the audio is really crispy and on point, some of the soundtracks are spot on the one instance where you light a weed farm on fire with flamethrower has skillrex's ft. damien marely make it bun dem is brilliant and become my faveourite track, you can hear the hissle of snakes and the roars of the tigers from a distance giving you audio feedback as how to approach your immediate surronding.Overall an excellent open world game by ubisoft and truly back to the Far Cry roots and a step in the right direction since i considered FC2 a failure, FC3 is a game anyone can easily love and sink hours into you can spend anywhere between 20-40 hours doing all kinds of things, I completed all outposts and towers and many of the missions and still wanted to play for an hour or so coz travelling with the wingsuit was so darn fun.Easily recommeded to anyone at any price point.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is a hugely enjoyable open world FPS set on a beautiful tropical island.Game-play is great, providing many alternate methods of completing your objectives. This offers players the chance to use stealth and silent weapons to pick off their enemies one-by-one while remaining undetected. Alternatively you can run in and gun everyone down, which is slightly less fun and not as rewarding. Many games boast this feature of choice and always seem to be lacking in either the stealth system or just general combat. I'm glad to say that Far Cry 3 delivers on both fronts. The game offers a huge array of things to do aside from the main campaign. There are around 30 outposts, 20 radio towers and tons of extra side missions sprawled around the game map. Completing all of these side activites is bound to give you numerous benefits, but not without a challenge. Far Cry 3 also contains one of the best hunting system I've seen in gaming. While not forcing you to have to hunt for survival or anything, hunting will give you many materials to help craft items to make you character carry more items, weapons and money.Now, the story. At first the story of Far Cry 3 doesn't seem like much, you're an American tourist on holiday with your friends to an exotic Indonesian island. But what lives on this island is much more sinister than you expect. A huge group of pirates, lead by Vaas Montenegro, a once good man driven to insanity by the temptations of evil. You are Jason Brody, a typical American who has a desire for adventure. The character arch of Brody is great, showing how much a man can change when something is taken from him. The story is one of madness, strength and discovering the darkness of human nature.The visuals are pretty excellent. The world is colourful, vibrant and perfectly lit, the island and all of the characters on it look spectacular, even on the medium settings my PC was forced to run it at.The soundtrack is overall pretty great, especially a track which appears toward the end of the main campaign.I highly recommend picking this up if you're a fan of FPSs and/or open-world games. It's worth it at full price but this game is no stranger to sales so it might be best to wait until the time is right and pick it up for less. uPlay also seems to be bearable with this.

Posted: November 23, 2015
												Well just completed it....aaaand well I dont think its nearly as good as people make it out to be.The main story is imo extremely short, and too much out of your hands.In the end you get a choice, but honestly it barely is a choice from the perspective of the player, we only kinda know about our main characters background but what we play and thus experience is the complete other side of the coin.So this choice in the end is some stuff we get told apperently happened....vs the stuff we ACTUALLY experienced in the game....so yeah, not much of a choice really.And what is with the Hype around Vaas? Dude is seriously barely in teh game, hell everyone is barely there because the core story is so damn short but man, Vaas is in like what, 3 scenes?Whoop di♥♥♥♥♥♥ and nothing about those were remarkable or memorable, hardly the Bane from Dark Knight Rises now is he?Story falls apart in many places anyway, like the bs reason as to why I cannot instandly kill main baddy,♥♥♥♥♥♥was also so damn predictable urhhhggggg.The Island is huge and the game looks good and places are recognisable, soon you will know you way around just like you do after playing a while of GTA, thats all pretty cool.What is not is the actual content, or lack there off.Sure tons of stuff to collect....but that I find hardly constitutes of content.Skyrim for example as a lot of big stuff going on next to the main story, this game could learn from that because it has nothing of the sorts.All in all I think if I would have to express the experience in a rating, I would be inclined to say maybe a 7/10 but that would be generous.Its not bad, but its most def not the rating it has on several websites, really need to up our standards yo.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is a hugely enjoyable open world FPS set on a beautiful tropical island.Game-play is great, providing many alternate methods of completing your objectives. This offers players the chance to use stealth and silent weapons to pick off their enemies one-by-one while remaining undetected. Alternatively you can run in and gun everyone down, which is slightly less fun and not as rewarding. Many games boast this feature of choice and always seem to be lacking in either the stealth system or just general combat. I'm glad to say that Far Cry 3 delivers on both fronts. The game offers a huge array of things to do aside from the main campaign. There are around 30 outposts, 20 radio towers and tons of extra side missions sprawled around the game map. Completing all of these side activites is bound to give you numerous benefits, but not without a challenge. Far Cry 3 also contains one of the best hunting system I've seen in gaming. While not forcing you to have to hunt for survival or anything, hunting will give you many materials to help craft items to make you character carry more items, weapons and money.Now, the story. At first the story of Far Cry 3 doesn't seem like much, you're an American tourist on holiday with your friends to an exotic Indonesian island. But what lives on this island is much more sinister than you expect. A huge group of pirates, lead by Vaas Montenegro, a once good man driven to insanity by the temptations of evil. You are Jason Brody, a typical American who has a desire for adventure. The character arch of Brody is great, showing how much a man can change when something is taken from him. The story is one of madness, strength and discovering the darkness of human nature.The visuals are pretty excellent. The world is colourful, vibrant and perfectly lit, the island and all of the characters on it look spectacular, even on the medium settings my PC was forced to run it at.The soundtrack is overall pretty great, especially a track which appears toward the end of the main campaign.I highly recommend picking this up if you're a fan of FPSs and/or open-world games. It's worth it at full price but this game is no stranger to sales so it might be best to wait until the time is right and pick it up for less. uPlay also seems to be bearable with this.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Kui sa oled FPS Shooterite fänn, siis tegemist on MUST PLAY mänguga. Imeline graafika, story ja gamepaly on super combo. Täiesti prefektne. Muidugi oli ka paar asja mis häirisid, nimelt oli loot cheste väga palju ja nendest sai vähe kraami. Mõtekam oli sidequeste teha. Ütlen siis ära, mängu lõpus on valik, ehk saad lõpetada mängu kahte erinevat viisi. Mina ise valisin selle "inimlikuma". Selliseid valikuid oleks võinud olla rohkem mängus. Osad cutscened olid minule vastutahtmist. Näiteks ütles karakter, et ta tahab saarele elama jääda, kuigi mulle see üldse ei meeldinud. Kui tagasi tulla story juurde, siis asi on väga deep. Mida kaugemale jõuad, seda rohkem tahad kätte maksta. Selles mängus soovitan palju eeltööd teha enne main questide juurde asumist. Kindlasti oleks vaja võtta kõik radio towerid ja outpostid ära. Mängu alsutades oli plaanis ka kõik relicid, messaged ja memory cardid ära koguda. Hiljem sain aru, et see oli praktiliselt võimatu. Memory cardid (tegin ära) ja messaged olid mõleldavad, aga 120 relici on natuke üle piiri. Lõpetamiseks kulus 25 tundi, mis on open world mängu kohta täiesti paras. Kindlasti kui oleks teinud veel side queste ja chillinud oleks 30 tundi ka ära tulnud. Mängus on ka veits rpg elemente, ehk sul on võimalus enda karakterit leveldada ja asju craftida, et paremini metsikus looduses ja sõjas toime tulla. Kindlasti soovitan mängu, see on igat senti väärt!

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												I'm going to try and make this short, but it will be hard since this is one of the absolutely freaking best games I've ever played.Okay, here we go.This game includes: Jetskis, boats (some with guns mounted on them) , ATVs, lots of different cars (some with guns mounted on them), cargo trucks (my favourite), hanggliders, wingsuits, weapons in general, flamethrowers, RPGs, lots of wild animals, a enourmus beautiful landscape to explore, lots of minigames, and of course, a deep and totally amazing story. A deep and totally amazing story for both the singeplayer mode and the 4 player co op mode. And of course, there is the ordinary multiplayer mode aswell.The game itself is pretty much a sandbox, so you can rund around in a open world and do whatever you want.But a couple of things you should know if you are planning to buy this game: This game requires Uplay to work (at least it did for me), the game might be a bit laggy (mine was, but changing from DirectX 11 to DirectX 9 helped a lot), and the saving system is a bit complicated (you can only have one saved game at a time, the game doesn't always save when you hit "save game" even if it says it does, etc.)Anyhow, I would give this game a 9.5/10. It's absolutely fantastic.That pretty much sums it up.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Far Cry 3. FAR CRY 3! Ubisoft must be proud of this game. Far Cry 3 takes the open-world action onto a completely new level. You can either spend your time completing missions, overtaking enemy outposts or hunt animals. Hunting animals isn't there just so the jungle feels alive, it actually has a huge purpouse. You can skin animals and craft wallets to store more money, craft better weapon holsters, or craft potions to, for example, see all enemies, all animals, regenerate health etc. Upgrade and customize your weapons exactly the way you want. You can even fight SHARKS in the game, which feels absolutely INSANE. That was only the Singleplayer. But no. Ubisoft doesn't stop there. Far Cry 3's multiplayer is AMAZING. You can level up, make new weapon loadouts, customize your weapons like in the singleplayer, decode data from flash drives and disks to unlock new weapons modifications. When your team wins a match, the person who has gathered the most experience can either kill the enemy with the most experience with a unique death move, or free him.  This game does everything perfect. I cannot say anything bad about it. Anything.Final Rating : 10 / 10BADASS

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Note: to see this review in it't true form go to: http://wildwoodgeek2.blogspot.com/2014/03/game-review-far-cry-3.htmlFarcry 3, "like skyrim with guns!"  that is not true in the least, Farcry 3 is a fun game and a good game but it is not a shooter skyrim. because the marketing for FC3 decided to compare it to skyrim i'm gonna compare it to skyrim too. First: Open World. Farcry 3 is more of an "Open Map" granted the Map is big but parts are locked off until you do certain things, also there are a lot of invisible walls on the island itself. i don't mind that, in fact i understand why they did it. but Skyrim doesn't have that. Next: Side quest. Farcry 3 has actives like racing,shooting,hunting, and kill missions. but they don't call them side quest, the ones that they do call side quests are pitiful and worthless. most of them you have to go "Spy" on someone across the town and then report back to who gave you the quest, or you go here and kill 15 of this or that and "save" a poor civie. In the end the actives are way more fun then the side "quests".  and third: Customization, you can't make your own character in FC3, you can't even change your outfit. once again i under stand why they did that, but they are the ones who started compering the two.Ok now that is out of the way lets focus on the Single player story line. The Story of Far Cry 3 is that you and your friends are vacationing on a remote island, but what you don't know is that it is controlled by a cruel gang of Pirates and Drug lords, you start off captured and locked away in the Pirate base, and you have to escape. Now i don't want to spoil anything about the story line so i'll stop there. Story Wise the game is epic there are some times where the other characters appear to be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but most of the time the story was fun and exciting. The villain of the game is like a more gory Joker and it really is insane. most of the time you won't even now who is your friend and who is your enemy. The main villain does stay around for a while but you never will think that he shouldn't have survived your attack or feel like he is god-like in some areas because the script writers didn't want to kill him off. (*hint COD Ghost hint*) The game has tons of the stuff for you to do and the skill and perk tree is large and helpful, you can craft meds and other helpful things, and hunt animals for their meat/skin. the Single Player story line took me 9 hours on Normal. keep in mind however it took me longer because i didn't rush to do the main quests.The Co-op mode of Farcry centers around a band of travelers who are left for dead by their greedy captain who works for the pirates, the Co-op gameplay is all on a different island from the Single player one. the Co-op itself is fun but compared to the Single player island the co-op one feels like a hallway shooter, also there are few players playing co-op and even fewer who will stick with you to go through it. when the Host leaves a Co-op game (and VS games) the game takes a ridicules amount of time to "Migrate" and when it starts most players leave meaning it migrates to other players each time taking longer, in fact once this lead to every one on my server to leave. The VS mode in Farcry is as you expect two teams fight each other to the death and who ever loses all their points first is the loser. the high set scorer and the wining team gets to to choice to spare or kill the highest scorer on the the team that lost. all in all the MP in Far Cry 3 is fun and enjoyable but because of their crappy Net code you might not be able to play very long.in the end i would say buy the game for the single player experience and if you have some buddies with the game maybe you can actually get through a Co-op game.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is all about adventure, carnage, the jungle aspect and getting the best guns for your assault type. There are a lot of areas where FarCry succeeds but many more where it simply falls through the floor. Far Cry 3 offers a compelling storyline through the singleplayer campaign. It is almost unrivaled and allows you to take hold of a person and watch them grow from a normal friend-loving schoolboy to a psuedo-psycho badass of the jungle. Multiplayer is completely broken as there a lot of bugs and hiccups along the way. The loadout option is pretty much useless as there is currently one build that destroys anything else that you put against it. Coop is a very welcomed theme within the Far Cry series, it's just a shame it wasn't implemented into the overall storyline. Or atleast contained within it's own world. Rather than you and a friend playing within the island sandbox, you are forced to go through objective-based and competition-based tasks that follow a very crappy storyline of 4 people just wanting to get rich and get out. ++ Singleplay, Multiplayer and COOP modes. + Guns and tools are nice+ Great scenery +++Buy this game for the singleplayer- Multiple bugs- Uplay requirements/overlay- Game-breaking bugs- Overpowered SMG class- Graphics are similar to FC2 but..worse? I would only recommend this game for the singleplayer and nothing else. The coop is fun if you're with the right people and playing on INSANE mode.

content:
Posted: March 24
												Welcome to my review of Far Cry 3.I will discuss all the negatives and possitives you need to know,if you are interested to buy the game.The game requires Uplay – and you have to have Steam and Uplay active to play the game.If you don't mind this,we will continue to the positives.I will not compare this game to the others of the franchise because is different in many ways.First the story in the game is more serious and you will want to know what happens next,see how the story unfolds – but there is one big problem …And that's that wonderful open world that they have created.You can get lost, doing side missions,activities and collectibles.You can/and will hunt animals so you can craft better gear,to expand your inventory.And most of the events get your worth of time spending passing them. For example – if you go and unlock all the Radio towers not only you will have the complete map – but also free weapons in vendors.The gunplay is awesome,it's easy to get used to,and you will be having fun everytime you have to go to combat.The gameplay is varied,most of the mission you can go gun-blazing but you can go stealth also.I passed the main story + some side activities in more than 20 hours,but I kinda want to go back to finish what I have left behind.The story is great,the voice acting and music really shines – and show how good they wanted you to immerse yourself in the role of the main character,how you want to save your friends like him,how you would want for him to finish his journey.Far Cry 3 showed us,that not only open worlds can be immersive and fun – but also can give a good story driven experience.If you like a open world in which everything you do,you will have fun doing buy the game.If you want to play a open world game,in which not only the content is much larger and you have hours of activities to do,but also you will want to do them – you will want to finish the story.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												I consider this game having three acts, the first starting out on the island and hunting down Vaas, the second having you reach the second island, and the third having you complete the game.It has 38 story missions total, so about 12-13 missions for each act. The game is also split between two islands, the first two acts take place on the first island with the final act taking place on the second. The game starts off great, I was really enjoying the first act, and the side missions were fun enough to keep me doing them. However, after a while the side missions just get boring, as unfortunately they fall into the Ubisoft formula of "Go here, kill this, come back." that plagues their games. I completed about 2/3 of the side missions before I just started ignoring them, and strangely all of the side missions you can do to get special animal skins to craft the best upgrades are all on the first island, so you'll have every upgrade before you finish the first act. Also for the first act you talk a lot with your new buddy, Dennis, and he helps you through learning the ropes of the island. I really liked Dennis, and by the end of the game I really felt bad for him.The second act is where I found the game really fell flat. I quite enjoyed Vaas and his role in the game, but unfortunately he doesn't stick around until even the end of the second act. After him you have to deal with his boss, Hoyt, who has hardly even been mentioned until this point in the game and isn't nearly as interesting. Along with losing interest in the side missions, I was also losing interest with the story. There wasn't really much keeping me going at this point, even Jason was starting to irk me, as I just couldn't understand a lot of his decisions and most of what was even coming out of his mouth anymore.However, I feel the third act is where the game really shines. The last 10 missions are fantastic, and your new new buddy, Sam, is a really fun character and adds a lot of spice back to the game. I definitely like Sam more than Dennis, and the story missions with him are by far the best. Fortunately Jason was getting a little better in my eyes and I was liking him again, and a lot of the stupid things he was saying in the second act have passed. The final few missions were amazing and I finished the game with a significantly higher opinion of it than I had by the end of the second act.Meanwhile, there are lots of collectibles, as is to be expected from a Ubisoft game. This game seems to try and one-up Assassin's Creed by having at least a thousand chests scattered around the two islands (this is probably an exaggeration, but good lord there has got to be at least 500), not to mention 120 relics, 20 Japanese WWII letters, and 20 drug dealer memory cards to collect. As with all Assassin's Creed games, you can purchase maps to show you where everything is, then you just have to collect them.Overall, the game is very fun despite the weak middle part. Though keep in mind that it will be a test of endurance if you plan on achieving 100% completion as the collectibles and side missions are an exercise in tedium.
