												Far Cry 3 is the best/worst game you will ever play. It gives you a wide open world to explore at your pace, but only when it suits the gameIt gives you plenty of side missions to complete in your own way, but they all have arbitrary rules that you need to follow.It gives you a gripping story of a dudebro trapped on an island who lets go and makes his own way, losing his sanity in the process.At the same time you will lose your sanity because while your free to do whatever you want, you can only be as free as the game lets you.For examply, for arbitrary reasons the game restricts your progression until you've completed certain missions. Theres no real reason listed in the plot. Theres no gameplay stability that is disrupted in the gameplay that letting you level up however you want. The game has no reason to restrict you.But it does.Though I might sound a bit critical of the game, it really is fun. Its just also really stupid. REALLY stupid. I highly recomend it, but it has its quirks that don't make any sense.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is a good game, a great game even. You could even say it's an excellent game. No game is without fault however I'll talk about some of the good things and some of the bad. First: the guns; the core part of any FPS. They're so fun to use in this game simply because they all feel different and it's very easy to recognize the differences between all the weapons. Stealth is also a big part of the combat, stealth takedowns and silenced weapons eventually become your best friend as rushing in is generally a bad idea (especially once you've reached the later half of the game) even on normal difficulty. Optional objectives are spread throughout the game which include: side quests, hunting challenges, sniper challenges and poker. Most of them are purely optional offering nothing more than something to do while you're playing others are higly incentivized (Radio towers, hunting, liberating camps + supply drops) as they offer XP, money and lead to unlocking better equipment and guns! Getting around isn't that hard either (provided you aren't getting shot at) and you'll find that once you have access to more fast travel points you'll reach your destinations really quickly!Now I'll touch on the story for a bit before I get to the cons! The story... not so great! That is to say it's not amazing, but it feels a lot like an action movie and those don't really require great stories either! I did find, however, that across the story there were a few memorable characters and sequences that I really liked but the ending leaves a lot to be desired. Also worth noting, several instances of nudity!And now the final part of this lengthy review, the cons! There were quite a few bugs, mostly visual and none of them game-breaking definitely a slight on the game but they can be over-looked! I found that when I was exploring or hunting for collectibles whenever I had a waypoint on my map there was no clear indication as to whther or not the thing I had waypointed was above me or below me. By the time I realized this this I had usually gone too far off to find the actual path to the thing I was looking for. And finally, the major offender... UPlay! I have nothing against the platform itself but not having it installed prior to playing this game lead to me waiting a good 45 mins before I could actually play the game. It also requires you to be connected to the internet for a enjoyable experience, meaning if you've got a dodgy connection or are simply having issues you should probably just play something else.To wrap things up, like I said in the beginning, this game's great. If you have any interest in shooters or open world games then you have to give this game a spin, as there's tons to do and you'll probably have a good time doin' it!

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												I was really looking forward to a CryTek-powered open world shooter.  What I got was a dirty needle and some pig entrails.  This is a disgusting game in more than one way.  Obviously, there's a crafting system that involves gutting and skinning animals that you hunt.  It's gross and I can get past that.  That's not the disgusting that bothers me.  The enemies are pretty rough characters -- drug runners, kidnappers and mercenaries.  Looting them will yield an assortment of colorful vendor fodder like dirty needles, crackpipes and the sort.  This bothers me a bit...but I can get past it.  The game, however, seems to pride itself in what an ugly world and situation it places you in.  Loading screens treat you with random, stream-of-consciousness words, a few of which are obscenities.  Of course the in-game dialog is repleat with obscenities.  I guess you can't have a modern "gritty" game without them.  At this point, I'm swallowing a lot of ugly for the sake of the game play, which holds up pretty well until you start hitting certain progression walls.Like many games claiming to be open worlds, the world is gradually revealed or unlocked through progression in the story.  Character skills and crafting recipes are similarly locked to your storyline.  In the end, it was these restrictions that put me off to the game entirely.  I hated the storyline for the game's ugliness I described above.  I just didn't want to run through it.  However, with at least half of the game world locked away behind irritating game content, I lost my will to play the game at all.  And cheat codes don't help you much in escort missions in which NPCs will gladly take cover in front of enemy gunfire.All of that said, I laud CryTek for what they tried to do here -- open world shooting with crafting and skill systems that feel lifted from the latest MMO.  I loved that concept.  I just wish it weren't tied to content that made me feel worse for playing the game.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Jumped from rooftop. Landed a knife on an enemy's back. Grabbed his knife and threw at other enemy.      RAMBO/10     Now, seriously,this is the best game that I have played in a long time. The story is very captivating and the gameplay is very adictive. You are completely free to choose what to do next, like: you can continue your story completing missions, or you can try sidequests around the island, or you can just hunt some animals and craft your gear, or you can explore the island and loot some cash, or you can free some outposts... In short, you can do pretty much everything you want in that island.     The graffics are excellent, I played the game at ultra and the lightning effects, combined with foliage and water reflection are so beatiful sometimes you'll just stare at the landscape and enjoy it.     The background music is great, the sound effects are very immersive and realistic. The radio that plays at cars is OK, but after 10 or 15 hours of gameplay it will get repetitive (I guess there is 3 or 4 playlists, and they start at the same part of the same music everytime you enter in a car by the first time) but that is just a detail.      The worst thing about this game is Uplay. Really, this thing is very annoying. I always open my games through GeForce Experience, so in order to open and play FarCry 3, I open GeForce Experience, that opens Steam, that opens Uplay, that finally opens the game. I hope this is not a new trend, because I already have Steam, Origin, Rockstar Social and now Uplay. What will happen if every game company creates a digital store/ social hub-like program like Steam? Hell, that's what will happen. A quick tip for every company in the world: USE STEAM.      If you aren't sure whether you buy this game or not, try the following: type "The Far Cry Experience" at Youtube and click play (I recommend Machinima's playlist) YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT      Obs.: If you already played this game and doesn't know what "The Far Cry Experience" is, GO WATCH IT NOW, as I said before, you will not regret it.Never played Far Cry 1 or 2 before. I only bought this game because it was R$ 20 and came with a bundle. The truth is: this game is so good it is forcing me to pay R$ 100 for Far Cry 4. I hate you, Steam sales! Gimme back my money!!

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Far Cry 3 is a solid game. I recommend it to everyone who enjoys FPS or sandbox genres. It had surprisingly well designed game play which made the game feel fresh for the whole time I played it. Graphics looked good on my 5 year old pc and sounds were even better apart from music. Voice acting was nice and sounds of the jungle felt good if not great. So it is definately a better game than FC2 or first Far cry. What surprised me most is the fact that this game really feels like both of those games thought they were nothing alike when compared to each other.Sneaking is decently done, and variety of weapons and different missions kept the game going for around 30 hours. Although the jungle looked good, it never really felt in any way threatening and was kinda like walking in a zoo or something. I hope we'll see more dense, darker and frightening jungles in the future. And more varied landscapes, these islands felt a bit too dull in a way that it all looked pretty much the same apart from some swamps. As I realised that the Island looks pretty much the same all around, I kinda stopped looking after the chests and relics. Didn't bother looking for them from the south island at all compared to the fact that around 60 % of the chests in top island was gathered and all the relics.That being said, I still didn't think this was a GOTY or even 9/10 game. I would give it 8.5/10. Main flaws of the game is the story and the characters. Story is thin and empty: about rescuing your brothers and friends and becoming a "warrior" for the local tribe. The story makes little sense and feels very weird time to time, especially towards the end. The atmosphere changes drastically between characters that are meant to be funny and the few minute drops of serious conversations with your friends. Combined to the fact that between missions the protagonist is running around picking flowers, hunting, flying, playing cards and doing whatever, the story feels disconnected from the world. I got the same feeling that I got from Far Cry 2; Someone wanted to make a serious game with serious plot about insanity, but at some point someone wanted to water it down and make it more relaxed and funny. The result is mish mash that's neither funny nor serious. Then again I felt that I played the game wrong. I should've just went straight for the main missions and totally ignore about everything else the environment offered me.I didn't know much about the game before I played it but I definately knew about Vaas. He was the biggest disappointment. He had maybe 10-20 mins of screen time and barely made any sense at all. And no, it's not a testimony for his insanity, it's testimony for directors lack of will to make this game a whole instead of gathering of pieces. There were no other characters that were in any way memorable, except for the main protagonist which turned out to be decent. And the ending, oh dear what the hell.All in all, I will most likely return to this game at some point, although I think I completed everything worth doing in the game, only some relics from south island and few hunting and Wanted missions got left over. Maybe I try to complete the game as fast as possible just to see if the main plot would be more coherent instead of what it turned out to be in my first play.This opinion is based on single player experience only, didn't play multiplayer or co-op.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												If you’re deciding whether to buy Far Cry 3 for Uplay or for Steam, I’d recommend you just get it for Uplay. Sure the Uplay client is inferior, but you’ll have fewer problems getting the game to work (took a long time to get the game to run). Also, when you start the game in Steam, it just launches Uplay anyway so it’s basically just a shortcut. I had kind of a unique situation so I can’t say for certain that you’ll encounter the same problems playing the Steam versionFirst off, the game is very hardware intensive. It probably stressed my system more than anything other than Watch Dogs, which I just gave up on running due to low frame rate. I had to turn down the graphics a bit to get a nice 40 fps for Far Cry 3. If you have better than a GTX 460 video card you should be fine.For gameplay, the game is very similar to Far Cry 2 (big surprise). It’s a first person shooter with 4 gun slots (you unlock them through crafting). Similar to many other modern shooters, when you kill a gun wielding enemy, they usually drop that weapon for you to pick up, or just scavenge the ammo. There’s a stealth component to combat where you are rewarded (with extra exp) for sneaking up and using takedowns on enemies rather than just running in shooting. Various styles of takedown are unlocked through skill points as you progress through the game (such as dropping down on enemies or pulling the pin on an enemy’s grenade and kicking him toward his buddies. I mentioned crafting earlier and the crafting system is very simple, if somewhat time consuming. You hunt animals for their skins and use the skins to unlock equipment upgrades. For example 2 goat skins might increase the number of grenades you can carry or 2 flowers can be turned into a healing item. I spent about 3 hours just hunting all the animals to upgrade my gear before tackling the main story quests. Similar to Tomb Raider and Deus Ex: Human Revolution, “leveling up” doesn’t make you stronger with more HP or damage. It just gives you a skill point to spend.The game story is very well written and executed (completely new protagonist and story from the previous Far Cry games). I won’t spoil it for you but you start as a non-combatant and end up as a badass. There’s a ton of collectible items strewn across the game map telling the history of the island (kind of like Tomb Raider) and you’re rewarded for finding them with more exp.Overall the game is fantastic and a definite thumbs up. I only have the basic version so I can’t tell you if the “deluxe edition” is worth getting. I kind of doubt it though. By the way, I thought Far Cry 3 Blood Dragon was a DLC for Far Cry 3. Blood Dragon is actually a total conversion and you don’t need Far Cry 3 installed (or even owned) to play it.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												Far Cry 3 was an interesting experience. The core game mechanics were very fun and responsive but the problem of the game turned out to be the story. The game went the usual GTA sandbox route where you can just roam the game world doing various activities or engage in the story missions. Those story missions just weren’t very fun. The thing is that instead of building over the existing fun gameplay they seemed to constantly take away from it by constraining the ways the player could play the missions and filling them with quick time events. To top it all off the characters and script of the game were just ridiculously clichéd and uninspired outside of barely few fun exceptions. Even the missions themselves quickly boiled down to just following markers and watching cutscenes. The main character in particular was just not convincing at all and made me question if anyone in Ubisoft knew anything about human beings. As I said the core game mechanics were very good (if you don’t count the driving sections) and at best made me think of games like Fallout 3 and Just Cause 2. Lastly, I need to point out that people making Far Cry games seem to have an endless fascination with tropics and paradise islands. I happen to hate them. Here’s for hoping that the next Far Cry game will take place in some sort of Twin Peaks inspired setting.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												!!! Far Cry 3 !!!Hmmm...Game Of The Year 2012? Yeah, I'm 2 years behind on this game and i cant believe i let this one slide me by. Let me start by saying it's refreshing to meet a game where it's strongest point is singleplayer, usually current games stash all of their real content into multiplayer then hack on some half-witted single player just to have it there.First off, just to get it out of the way, you have to deal with the horrible abomination that we all call Uplay...I'm glad i could finally play the game in offline mode, but still, it's a dumb program in the way of your gaming experience. There were also alot of server issues galore when i tried and i have yet to be able to play a single CO-OP game. so as of this review, ive stuck to singleplayer.Most people pass this off as an average console port, but i don't really think so. as far as graphical options, this game truly delivers. Full DX11 support and even offers a dam FOV slider, when was the last time you saw one of those beautiful things? Mouse smoothing also isn't a problem since you can just turn it off. The amount of sheer detail found in this game is outstanding, but moreover, its consistent. Most games of this scale will throw in the occasional bland texture, but ive yet to see ANY.I'll start with the story, it is really quite interesting as you progress and experience Jason, a town-raised ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, changing as a person; lowering himself to Vaas's level. Becoming a warrior himself.  Vaas, is very Heath Ledger (joker) like, the way he talks and his fast paced personality. you can clearly see the amount of effort that Micheal Mando (Vaas voice actor) but into him. The game is even matched with little tid bits of "Alice in wonderland" quotes thrown here and there between the chapters, they fit perfectly.Supporting Far Cry 3's story is a pretty large arsenal of side quests; ranging from hunting special animals to races to mini games. There always seems to be something to do. There is even a very robust crafting system in place, at times it feel very lackluster but as my progress in the game grew deeper, i found myself liking it's simplistic style more and more. Crafting in this game is essential and really makes you want to go hunt or gather ingredients for syringes that besides healing you can grant you some neat abilities (the ability to sense the animals around you or repel predators,etc). Now this is a Free Roam RPG shooter, so as well as crafting and side missions, your hit with 3 character advancement skill trees that as you unlock the skills in them, tattoos appear on your forearm *or tataus like they are called here* i feel the skill system could have been a little better, but i think that was just me remembering FFX oh well.The huge focus of this game is its amazing amount of freedom in anything and everything you do. Sure there are a couple of story missions that are kind of linear or restrictive, but other than that it's all up to you. Do you like to make a noisy entrance into the enemy base, without knowing where the enemies are, spray-and-praying Call of Duty style? Go ahead.Do you like to stalk your prey and make a plan and try to keep to it as you silently pick them off with your silenced sniper or trusty bow? You can do that. Or maybe baiting your enemies while you sneak into their base, plant amine near every alarm and next time they see you BOOM! Or maybe let that leopard trapped in that cage do the job for you. Done! You have so many options it can be overwhelming at times. Most AAA RPGs that are released now and boast with their freedom of choice don't even come close to this game.As for the animals, this is where the game does a VERY good job. There are two types of animals: carnivores and herbivores. Predators and prey. Wherever you go chances are you will see leopards chasing deer, tigers hunting buffalos, sharks eating tortoises, bears assaulting villagers etc. It feels very organic, natural and chaotic as well. These animals can make your life very hard - like surveying an enemy outpost only to find yourself attacked by a tiger, thus drawing enemy attention and realizing there are 4 times more enemy troops now. Or making a run for it and having to cross a river only to be assaulted by a crocodile and dragged underwater as soon you dive into the river. Splendid!well, i think i made you read for quite long enough. all in all i would highly recommend this game, especially if you like first person shooters. im sad to say my review was based only on the singleplayer, but ive heard from many people that Far Cry 3 has a very solid multiplayer and an extremely fun and engaging CO-OP, matched with a high singleplayer replay value. this is defiantly a game ill be playing a few times over-XeroSyphon

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												When I picked this game up in the sales for a few pounds, there was no way I expected it to be as brilliant as it actually is. Farcry3 follows Jason, a slightly wimpy American teenager who gets into trouble with some bad guys on an island. In essence, they kidnap some of his friends and he goes to get them back. Firstly, let's get the characters out of the way. Lots of people hate Jason and his friends, and although they are very 1 dimensional, I have to say I grew fond of Jason. His transition from cowardly white boy to tattooed warrior was a great development throughout the game. The other characters are brilliant; The unstable and unpredictable Vaas, in particular, I absolutely adored. And Sam. BLITZKRIIIIEG! I love the fact that you hear them referring to you as 'Snow White' as your legendary status increases, it makes you feel like a badass.The game is just so much fun! I felt genuine fear as I ran and hid behind bushes from the enemies, having heard their trucks driving closer and closer. I nearly had a heart attack the first time a tiger jumped on me, and laughed out loud as a herd of cows chased me. I adored having to go to certain areas on the island to hunt for different animals to make things. The skill development trees are great, and the skills built up perfectly in sync with the difficulty progression of the game. The open world feature is brilliant - it makes the game less linear and a lot more interesting. I absolutely loved the idea of having to turn on the pylons to unlock sections of the map, and the turquoise water, sandy beaches and lush tropical vegetation make the game look stunning.The tasks are varied and a lot of them are so much  fun  (the drug fields task was probaby my favourite task in any game, ever). From having to drive a quad bike against the clock, to sneaking into camps to take things, to shooting a gun and making everything explode from a helicopter, to torturing somebody, the tasks are endlessly entertaining. At no point in this game did I think 'oh great, another one of  these  tasks'. And that's another thing: you have a lot of choice. No, you don't have to keep taking out all the enemy camps, you can sneak around them. No, you don't have to do lots of vehicle driving if you don't want to. Aside from the main storyline, you can play the game how the hell you want. The difficulty increases throughout the game so perfectly, you have to take your hat off to Ubisoft. Towards the end, the tasks got really quite demanding, and there were several instances where I 'ragequitted' and sulked for half an hour, before having to go back for more punishment. And to me, that is the sign of an incredible game - I had to finish it, I needed to know what happened. The storyline is probably the best storyline I have seen in a game for a long time, it flows well and you genuinely care about what happens. Of course, there are a few bugs and general irritants in the game. The enemies are very 1 dimensional and often a bit daft, as Jason's friends are. Some of the later tasks are ridiculously difficult (constantly spawning enemies). Having to pat down dead bodies to steal stuff means you'e continuously having to hold E, and the character feels a little bit clunky when you're climbing around. Having said that, these are very minor issues that took absolutely nothing out of the game, I'm just trying to balance it out a bit. I wish I could go back to the time before I played FarCry3 and start all over again. I absolutely recommend this game, and for the sale price of less than £5 you would be absolutely crazy not to have this on your list.

												When this game first came out, someone said that it is like Skyrim with guns.  I think that's generally a fair assessment.It was a bit frustrating that some of the missions required stealth since I don't think this game was trying to be a stealth game. The injections system by which you crafted stuff like health vials and a few other buffs was a bit awkward and I don't think it added much to the game (although it was a necessary thing to do in order to play successfully).I had fun playing it.  I don't expect to play it again, though.   I'm a bit excited to give the previous FC games a try, though, once I work through my backlog a bit.

												Welcome to beautiful, massive and entertaining open world of Far Cry 3.Storyline is awesome and deep, will take you a long time to finish if you are very bad at stealth gameplay.A lot of additional Mini Games such as: hunting challenges, poker, land and sea races, deadly warrior and much more.Big weapon arsenal: from a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 1911 to AMR anti vehicle sniper rifle. A big choise of skins and attachments for your weaponry. Tons of collectables which unlock more missions and equipment. Multiplayer servers are still active and still has players, a lot of bonus weapons like type 10 ( a mini shotgun) and Tanto blade. CO OP is really fun with or without friends. Has its own storyline. (notice that leveling up in CO OP levels you up in Multiplayer too). The game is really brutal- contains partial nudity and gore (SPOILER ALERT! : THEY CHOP YOUR ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ FINGER OFF!)Do not recommend buying this game to  less than 14 year old teenagers. In conclusion: one of the best games i have ever played 9.9999/10!Really reccomend it!

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Let me start by saying I'm not usually someone who enjoys FPS games but I think to call FC3 simply an FPS would be wrong. Although the storyline and setting is pretty typical of FPS games (bad guys/terrorists vs you/the little guy) the gameplay its self isn't typical. Infact, the game rewards you for trying outlandish, improvised or tactical approaches to seemingly ordinary objectives. You'd think all this freedom means it's just another one of those titles that you derp about blowing yourself and everything else up till you get bored and leave the game to rot in your library, but the storyline and characters within FC3 do enough to make you want to actually finish or at least progress through the game. The map itself, teamed with the crafting mechanics and ecosystem, is great fun to explore. The little relics and hidden locations mean getting sidetracked can be worthwhile. I personally also really enjoy the patrols of bad guys and having to hide or engage, which is just another way the game has of reminding you not to relax for too long.  There are a few things that annoy me however. Firstly, you need a Uplay account to run this. I bought through Steam because of the convienience and achievements and all that cool stuff, but Uplay wipes that out. There are a few UI/Navigational annoyances in this game too, menus mainly. Some of the flavour texts I feel are a little overdone, or repeated too often to be funny. These are however more preferential things than a straight up issue.In short, even if you don't play FPS games, you'll still probably enjoy this enough to warrant picking it up through a sale. Good fun.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												Good, but somewhat overratedAfter all the praise I’ve heard and read about Far Cry 3 I approached the game with some high expectations.I had played – and enjoyed - the original Far Cry. About the second Far Cry I read a lot of rather lukewarm comments and only purchased it on a Steam Sale  a year  or two later. As expected it was a mixed bag of an interesting open world gameplay (with an entirely different feel than FC1), but somewhat underdeveloped and riddled with annoying elements and a completely uninteresting storyline. Still I have to admit that somehow the game managed to keep my attention and I played it through to the end.When I read about FC3 it seemed like once again a different kind of game than FC1 or 2. But once I started playing I found that FC3 is very much a continuation of FC2, but thankfully much better developed and with a lot of smart improvements.The storyline is more interesting, the world is richer and more diverse and there’s a nice mix of gameplay elements to offer diversified gameplay experience. For the most part you can set your own pace, alternating between storyline missions and the various side missions to stretch gameplay and broaden up the experience.  Some elements, like the radio towers, were obviously adopted from Assassins Creed, but it’s a nice change of pace. The basic concept works quite well and gameplay all in all is enjoyable.But while I thoroughly enjoyed the game some flaws and strange design choices kept FC3 from being a great game. Let’s ignore some of the weak spots in the storyline (and  skip over the pretentiousness of the “Alice in Wonderland”-quotes suggesting a depth the storyline simply didn’t have, and ignore the unsatisfying conclusion) and just look at the gameplay:Crafting was basically an interesting idea, but I found it not all that useful and basically pointless in the second half of the game (Perhaps more useful on more difficult settings, but I played medium and don’t think I collected a single plant on the southern island). Money also is an important point in the beginning, but loses importance in the second half (most of the time I had more stuff to sell than my wallet could handle). I have the strong suspicion that shops originally should be spread scarcely across the map (as it was in FC2), but the integration of autoshops in most spawnpoints made shops pointless and gave gameplay a strange rhythm. That goes along with the quicktravel option, something I liked on one hand (especially later, when I hunted for relics), but it robbed the game some of its immediacy, since you could hop around the map (at least between unlocked points) and resupply as much as your wallet allowed. That’s the other extreme to FC2’s four travelpoints, which forced the player to travel long distances to missions. I would have wished for something in between: Less travel points, less (or even no) autoshops, no free weapons after radio tower missions.And to be honest I found many gameplay elements repetitive after a while. Freeing enemies camp was fun most of the time, but many of the additional missions overstayed their welcome during the second half. IMHO it would have been smarter to introduce entirely new gameplay elements on the south island (if done smartly motivated by the different environment and enemy group). As it was the second half felt like “more of the same” and I found myself rushing through the missions.Another missed opportunity was to integrate real sidequests. While inhabitants all over the map offer the player little sidequests, those have to be worked through immediately. How much more interesting it would have been to have quests, which can be accepted but finished either later, or might even have to be dealt with on a different spot on the map. All in all FC3 was a definite improvement over its predecessor, but I can’t help but feel that some compromises and design flaws kept it from being even better. We will see if FC4 will correct some of those mistakes, but frankly as much as I enjoyed FC3 I’m not compelled to purchase FC4 immediately.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												This is a very difficult game to review, I'd like to note before we begin that this is my opinion with my OWN experiences... you may think the problems I found with it to be nothing or you may just not like me bashing your wonderful game but I'm speaking or in this case typing from the heart, any stupid comments will be ignored including those that wish totell me how gay I am or how much of a♥♥♥♥♥♥my mom is.Now onto the review shall we? This is a very fun game... I stayed up 2 and a half days straight to complete it but there is really nothing to do but the story and that lacks so much...This is not a game like GTA, it offers a wide variety of extra tasks to do but there is no need to do them other than to feel the grind, one extra is the ability to hunt to craft upgrades and the ability to find flowers to create medicine or buffs but I completed the game without upgrading any of my gear and I never had to create buffs... the only thing worth while creating was medkits and once you unlock the ability to heal yourself without medkits(much slower) you will not find the need for them... I also never really ran out of ammo and if I did I just picked up another gun off an enemy.. easy!That is another thing I find lacking.. there is so many weapons but for the entire game I stuck with the AK47 from one of the first people I killed at the start... I don't even know what other weapons there was.. was no need..The Graphics are nice but of course a little dated now and with my settup appeared very cartoony.. the people that is had thick black borders around them.. the world however was beautiful!Now the story.. jeeze.. it was amazing BUT.. I found a lot of flaws with it.. to start with the story restarts 3 times.. 3 times you complete it and it takes everything away from you and sends you back to the start only this time something is a little different... I also hated the weird magical mystical scenes.. granted when I'd smoked some weed or had hallucigenic powder blown in my face? great! but then you reach say a boss battle and your transported to some made up magical place where the fight consists of button bashing (really.. you have to mash keys when it tells you to win) at first I did not even know I had killed the first boss.. I thought I was somehow on drugs in fact I still believe I was on drugs.. I swear I killed him while on drugs and he never actually died but after i came around apparently I killed him so you know? ok?Towards the end I felt this was a pebble compared to Farcry on my old Xbox (the original) and I felt that though the story was good it was very very short akin to DLC (as i said they restarted it 3 times to make it appear longer) I like te premise for the story I just don't like how it was executed.. Now I had great fun with this game but I don't know I'm sort of half for recommending it and half for not... right now it feels a cross between original farcry but done as a point and click adventure game.. I've decided after a small break to decide that I'm NOT going to OFFICIALLY recommend this game however I'd like you to be well aware that this is a magnificent game even though there was to many flaws for me to recommend it.. you should buy it if it's affordable to you.. (IE you're mega friggen rich or it's on sale)I recommend this game but I don't, 5/10 (meet you half way) BONUS PET PEEVE: There are enemies on it that wear about 40 body packs and can take about 6 rounds of my assault rifle to put down, I thought they were going realistic here? get them to carry a riot shield next time and leave fantasy alone.. it's clear you guys cannot grasp reality/make pretend anyway! (you're suppose to aim for the head, aim for the head and you'll do great!)

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Far Cry 3 was one of my favorite games of 2013.As with the previous Far Cry games, we have always expected them to be a PC gaming benchmark graphically and this game is no exception. The graphics are excellent, and can bring high end gaming machines to their knees! However, even with a mid range graphics card you could easily manage some playable settings and enjoy the game to the end.The characters are quite easily the best part of this game. Vaas is possibly the greatest villain ever portrayed in a game, largly down to immaculate voice acting & believable animations. Even the side characters you meet on the way are believable and help immerse you in the story.Controls are easy to get to grips with whether you use keyboard or control pad. I played through with an Xbox 360 controller and it was an enjoyable experience start to finish. The feeling of the guns is realistic and they feel different whether using a pistol of LMG, the weight and control is spot on.Overall the game is immaculate and shouldnt be missed. It's a shame the PC multiplayer seemed quiet because I thought it was brilliant, some nice game modes, excellent maps, and the graphics are still on point. Better than the typical CoD games. Did not get a chance to try Co-op but from what i've seen it seems fun.I would give the game 9/10 for single player alone, could have been 10/10 if the multiplayer had been able to extend my time with this game!

Posted: June 15, 2015
												At first i felt like this game was trying to hard to make this game Open World. Dont get me wrong i loved this game, but i bought it for open world and side quests. Far Cry 3 had "side quests" but these quests would mess up the story line and often mess up the main story line. The open world aspect to it wasnt open world at all really just a large world filled with nothing in particular. In my opinion i would recommend it to people who like a game that sticks to the storyline and just that. I would not recommend this to people who like games like "skyrim" or "fallout". I do know its bad to compare these games to this, but if thats what your looking for, dont get this game.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												You play Jason Brody, some rich kid from California, who goes on a trip with some friends and ends up as a hostage of the local pirates. After he barely manages to escape he is recruited by Tribals who call themselves the Rakyat, and goes on a long and erotic journey to self-discovery. While the initial Idea is pretty good, it is not executed very well. Jason never killed anybody nor skinned an animal, but after the cut scenes end and you can finally go out and explore, you can happily murder half of the Island´s population without hearing a whimper ever again. Well, except when skinning animals; Jason never gets used to that, even though you have to kill the whole fauna twice over to craft a wallet and a rucksack. This is something Tomb Raider pulled off better. Another problem is that the faction you are working for (and you have no choice here) is not really likeable. Even though YOU are supposed to help THEM, you rarely see them fighting the pirates. There are several occasions where, after "liberating" one of the pirate outposts, I´d hear some Rakyat proudly proclaiming: "WHO`S THE MAN?! ME!" Yeah buddy, you sure are. This goes on and on, and after a while you ask yourself why you would even help them in the first place; your goal is to rescue your friends. But because some black guy who fished you out of the river, put some tattoos on your arm and sent you to the local drug king told you to, you´ll happily oblige. BECAUSE YOU ARE A WARRIOR, JASON. AND YOU NEED DA TATAU TO BECOME STRONGER. This part of the story is just unnecessary.The game also has an obsession with drugs; on several occasions Jason ends up getting drugged, whether willingly, by accident, or per force. These dream-like sequences may be fancy for the first time, but are outright annoying the second time around. This is the part where you can guess what Ubisoft´s Target Demographic must have been. The Far Cry series has always been known for graphical fidelity; this one is a slight exception in my opinion. While the game DOES look good overall, there are some things that are worse than in the previous games, if not♥♥♥♥♥♥in general. I can´t understand how a game that runs essentially on the same engine as the previous game looks worse, even though they even upgraded it to the second version. When you compare the two games side by side, several things just stand out negatively: the LOD and view distance are handled way better in Far Cry 2. I have never experienced such severe pop ins like I did in Far Cry 3, especially since it uses a rather obvious effect to do so. Secondly, Far Cry 3 uses way too much SSAO, to the point where objects have black halos surrounding them. Unfortunately you can´t disable this effect in game without switching to DX9; you have to edit the config file if you want to get rid of it. Another thing I really can´t understand is a weird graphical glitch that happens when you are inside caves. Sometimes the walls appear all shiny, like somebody spent two weeks smearing oil on random cave walls. The sound is generally pretty good, the weapons all sound quite alright. Only problem here is that all suppressed weapons use the same sound, no matter if you are using an assault rifle or a shotgun. This can be kind of annoying when you tend to use more than one suppressed weapon. But this is nothing compared to the sound quality of EVERYBODY except the main characters. Every single civilian, pirate and rebel sounds like his voice was recorded with a microphone wrapped in a plastic bag; the sound quality is just awful at times. Couple this with repetitive voice lines á la "FOCK. DIS. HEAT" or "BURNS LIKE A MOTHER WHEN I♥♥♥♥♥♥ SHOULDA USED A RUBBER." and the problem will become really obvious. The gameplay itself is what really saves this title. The gameplay is mostly fluid, rewarding and well, fun, that you can forget most of these annoyances when you get the chance to play undisturbed for more than half an hour. It is way more fun to ambush pirates with mines, surprise them with C4 or just stab everybody with your knife than playing the main missions, which sometimes severely limit how you can approach the situation. Maybe this is why I liked the southern Island more; the whole tribal hero ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t is cast aside, and there is only the mission and how you want to approach it, just like the previous games. Unfortunately the game is almost over when you reach the second island, leaving you with such a low amount of missions that I wonder why they even bothered making another island.The weapons are fairly standard, ranging from pistols to rocket launchers. But for some reason some weapons have their attachments disabled, something which really sucks in the beginning. This is strange because all weapons HAVE attachments, which you can use in coop and multiplayer. A simple mod can unlock all attachments for the weapons, which makes me wonder why they chose to disable them in the first place. There is also a problem with the game´s difficulty. First of all, the AI is not that great. Even though your enemies can take cover and try to flank you sometimes, they just charge towards you most of the time. Couple this with aimbot like accuracy on the higher difficulties and bugged fire that you can´t put out because the QTE prompt does not show up and you know what to expect. Because of that, a stealthy approach is easier most of the time. If you do get spotted, you can abuse the takedown system by shooting even the armored guys until they stagger, walk around them and stab them in the back to kill them instantly. Things like that make some encounters ridiculously easy.  After all I have criticized, you´d think that I don´t like this game. But here comes the funny part: I can´t deny that Far Cry 3 is a fun game. It has some major flaws and annoyances, but at least this time the gameplay is decent. Stabbing people, blowing up convoys and hunting the local fauna just has a certain charm. While it is not a bad game per se, it is not a good Far Cry. Despite this, pick it up when it is on sale, it will keep you occupied for a while.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												I just can't put this game down. It is just too immensely rich and fun to play. There is always a cave you haven't explored, a secret you didn't find, a nice place you didn't see, a way of fighting you didn't try before... Rook Island always makes you come back for more.Gameplay--- I have to place this statement in a proper context though. My first playthrough on the vanilla version of the game only lasted about 25 hours, full of high-tempo combat, mad driving, killing pirates by the dozens, completing missions in a hush-hush way. This is because the original game can feel a little FPS-mainstream (damn you, COD, for what you have done to the genre). The emphasis is a little too much on the action, and less on the open world and side missions, as is the case with Far Cry 2. However, where game-dev's fail in order to satisfy the producers and the company, the game community comes to the rescue. With proper modding (Ziggys Mod!), this game becomes what it had to be all along. The pace is slowed down, the difficulty has gone way up, making run-and-gun console-type approaches impossible. Instead, you have to resort to guerilla-warfare and the use of stealth and your natural surroundings. The over-guidance of the vanilla game is gone; you have to rely on your own noodle now. Sometimes you'll be the hunter, sometimes you'll be the prey, and that is what makes this game an exciting experience. Also, you will notice that this game is much richer in content than you noticed at first, since you spend too much time running and gunning in the vanilla version. Now, you can just ignore the missions and go hiking the amazingly beautiful island on your own.Storyline--- Although I get the feeling that it is a little too cliché-ridden, the storyline is quite decent. No big plot twists or big schemes, but enough to keep the game going, and to give you a sense of urgency. Also, it does a good job in letting you question your morality and sanity by the end of the game, a nice break from the justified-violence themes in other games in the FPS-genre (yep, looking at you, COD). The most credit has to go to the voice-actors, who did an incredible job in giving the characters some depth (Vaas already is a classic). Technical aspects--- The graphics of this game are just insane (keep your finger on the print-screen button!). Then again, so are the system specs, even for current standards. Bear this in mind when you buy this game!Multiplayer and coop--- Not really worth the trouble. The multiplayer is COD-clone without depth (sorry for the fanboys that I keep mentioning this franchise in a negative way). The coop, however, is quite fun and easily accesible, since it uses a sort of 4-player drop-in format like L4D. But honestly, who cares? This is the best single-player experience I had!Conclusion--- Buy it, mod it, fall in love with it. Once you set a foot on Rook Island, you'll never want to leave.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2013
												So I recently bought Resident Evil 6 and since the download is so slow I could send my dog run to China, swin across the Pacific ocean and come back, and my download would still be at 50%!While it's making the download, I figured why not review Far Cry 3, Ubisoft's 2012 best game and one of my personal Games of the Year of 2012 (like I said before I have 4 "winners").Graphically, the game is stunning, everything is high-res, attention to detail is ludicrously high! The color pallet is incredibly varied! I can actually see greens (true greens, not f*cking brown-grey-ish greens, Skyrim!!!!), the water is actually blue! I was shellshocked the first time I saw it, it's truly amazing and a sight to be seen ASAP!Story wise is where I can safely say the game shines (since every single side quest is as repetitive as a CoD game. Side quests are basically: kill this super holy♥♥♥♥♥♥huge beast animal! OR it's: This pirate is really badass and only you can save us! Kill him! But with a knife because it's our ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ will-get-you-killed-some-day tradition!),  one of the antagonists (of course, Mr. Insanity himself: Vaas!) is the best villain of all time! Movie-wise, book-wise, game-wise, whatever-wise. Vaas is the perfect Villain I've been expecting to see somewhere for years!! The story tells the personal story of Jason Brody, who is trapped along with his girlfriend, brother and friends in a circle of human traffic, lead by Vaas and other amazingly written villains (not as good as Vaas, but they are still some of the best I've ever seen anywhere!). The story is really good, character development EXISTS! It's amazing! One of the best storylines of all time! Although it's annoying the cliché at the start where Jason is a lonely boy who doesn't know how to do anything and 5 seconds later he's Jason Brody, the son of Rambo + Chuck Norris in the womb of John Connor! It's not very believable, but with that aside, the story is stellar and it's the steal of the show along with the graphics!Gameplay is pretty standard, you have guns n' sh*t and you have to kill some animals to create bigger bags to create bigger ammo pouches, bigger rucksacks (for loot), bigger wallets (it's pretty obvious...) and carry more guns (up to 4 guns, yes you can carry 4 LMG's if you want to do so). The is an RPG like system where you gain XP for stuff that you do and get skill point with then you spend in 3 different skill trees, which allows you to have more health, takedown heavier enemies (this game has stealth and actually does it WELL! F*ck me finally!), among other amazing traits!Gunplay is pretty good, guns have a very nice handling and feel. Most of them sound very powerful. However in the demo shown at E3 2011 (I think it was E3 2011, not sure) the guns, like the AK (the one shown) looked and seemed to feel much better in that demo than in the actual game, but those are small complaints since the AK still feels amazing in this version.SOund design is amazing as well, you can hear jungle noises, tigers roaring, gun fire at the distance. The Island is alive and it's great! It really really is! I love the game and everything about it! The game also has a FULL Co-Op campaign up to 4 players and a FULL Multiplayer component (with perks, attachment for guns, clan support, so much, just so much to cover in this game, you can easily put over 40 hours out of it!)Get it at any price, even 49,99€ it would still be worth it! On Steam is now 29,99€ buy it now or wait for a sale, you won't regret it (unless you're not a tropical island/FPS fan, but who isn't? Nobody, that's who!) :D

Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam groupFew words about the gamePlaying this game was a really good, even suprising experience, something new and different from most of games i play. I don't always finish this kind of games, as it's often gets farmy or too boring but this game simply made me stay around for moreAdvantages - Amazing looks and variety of surroundings - Movement system is realistic what in my opinion makes it really, really good - Diversity of armament, there is more than enough to match your equipment to your personal style of gameplay - Entertaining storyline that makes you want to play more and more - Authenticity of characters, especially Vaas, i loved his personalityDisadvantages - Taking over camps is required to progress the story and it's a bit monotonous - Modding of games is simplified to choosing few colors and sights, nothing really useful - Uplay.If you find my review helpful or funny be sure to follow Opium Pulses curator page right here for more reviewed games!

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Far Cry 3 is a solid, albeit formulaic game in every aspect. You won't find very many "flaws" (for those whom aren't having problems with Uplay anyway) once the game is up and running. Solid gameplay, solid story, great looking world, excellent music score, memorable characters...you've heard as much already I'm sure. So what's there to dislike?The only real problem was how there wasn't any 'heart' in the game. By following a formula they never left any room for the creativity and innovation to fully unleash the world of the island. It's difficult to explain but easy to spot the places where they focused on following formula instead of improving user experience/immersion. For such a high production game this lack of going the extra mile somehow ends up being the only thing that prevents it from being perfect.If you don't own it you should really buy it during a sale. Not my GOTY (I enjoyed The Darkness 2 significantly more), but definitely worth a playthrough. The low to no replayability shouldn't matter with Far Cry 4 out now anyway.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Far Cry 3, for me, is what Far Cry 2 should have been. In its predecessor the game lacked a proper story and also the game was very difficult. I remember the creators explaining it with the story, i.e. in order to really grasp the reality of the harsh African environment the game had to be hard even on a normal difficulty level.Far Cry 3 finally has a story and a more interesting protagonist. Also, the antagonist is memorable - his attitude, the voice acting, everything related to his personality stands out. The game gradually gets more difficult and you have a sense of progress here - there are no respawning enemies at the outposts any more: once you capture an outpost the local natives will take full control over it. They later on send patrols to further explore the island so it is now common to see them fighting with the enemies. I liked this approach as you could truly feel you were part of a story here and the fate of an entire people was dependent upon you. Oh, you want to clear an outpost in a much better way? (e.g. following the stealth approach) No worries, the game lets you reset all outposts so that you can complete these again earning some extra achievements.Proper fauna was also missing in the predecessor. Here you have all kinds of animals you can hunt. Hunting is important as by obtaining the skin / hide of your prey you can apply upgrades to your gear. You can have greater pouches to have more money with you or store more ammunition. I liked how you can even pick up herbs so that you can craft syringes that grant you an extra ability for a short period of time to make battles easier.And of course we have an enormous amount of collectible items scattered throughout the island. They are atop mountains or deep within in hidden caves. You need to swim in from the outside only to suddenly be attacked by a crocodile. Far Cry 3 is an exceptionally good game. If you don't mind signing up for UPlay (achievements are logged via that instead of Steam) you should not have a problem with this game. It is beautiful, it is entertaining, it has a good story and an amazing wildlife (e.g. a tiger can easily attack a deer in front of your eyes). And what's more in order to gather all collectibles and complete all side missions the game will hold you captive for at least 50 hours. And this is only the single player campaign as you still have coop mission and multiplayer.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												8/10Awesome gameplay, open world fps with gun customization, stealth, cars/boats, crafting, etc. Combat is really enjoyable and doesn't feel repetitive. The story, however, feels a little bit weak. The plot progression feels counterintuitive, especially the end of first island and the start of second island. Since it is an open world game, it is not story oriented at all and there are only a handful of main missions. Furthermore, side missions are somewhat rewarding, so I did only a few side missions. The story is also relatively short for an open world  game. However, I think the game has a powerful ending.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
 Far Cry 3 You've been captured by pirates, and it's up to you, Jason Brody, to rescue your friends and get the hell off the island. As action heroes go, Brody is an unlikely one. While Far Cry and Far Cry 2's protagonists had military or mercenary backgrounds, which at least explained their ability to reload an assault rifle in three seconds, you're just an over-privileged Californian bro in his early twenties stuck in a nightmare situation.Far Cry 3 is one of the best open world games ever. This game offers a wide variety of different things to do, From Liberating Outposts to even hunting animals for their skins! Far Cry 3 is a delightful and harsh tropical wonderland, crawling with wildlife and threatened by the pirates and drug runners that disrupt its peace. Furthermore Far Cry 3 also has multiplayer, co-op so you can play online with friends or just play a game of deathmatch , Far Cry 3 also has a map editor where you decide what you want in your map, from where you want the animals etc...When i got Far Cry 3, i thought it was going to be another typical First Person Shooter game but i was wrong, Far Cry 3 adds realism to the game which actually makes you feel as if you are Jason Brody yourself. Far Cry 3 is a game i would definitely recommend to people who love fps games but  WARNING: THIS GAME HAS ANIMAL ABUSE SO IF YOU ARE A ANIMAL LOVER THEN THIS GAME IS NOT FOR YOU . I would give Far Cry 3 a 10/10 for many reasons, one of them being the graphics which is just out of this world and the characters are well created especially Vaas who is my favourite character in the game simply because of his humour. To the people who do not own this game or don't have the sufficient funds for it, wait for the sales to come around then Far Cry 3 will drop prices massively and that's when you can get it but if you do not own this game, you are really missing out.What i don't like about this game are the constant notifications and reminders. These are so frequent, and so annoying, like if i am roaming around, nearly every 10 seconds a notification pops up on the top corner of the screen about the objective which can get a bit annoying but that is all that i have against this beautiful open world fps game.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2013
												This game can be defined with three words. Open world immersion! Crafting, hunting, exploration, side games, challenges, optional quests, lively characters, and amazing weapon design -- this game has it all! Not many games live up to the given price tag, and this is one of them. I spent fifty hours on my first play though. That is an extensive single player fps.Cut off the music and turn off all of the "hud" options that can be toggled, (I left the grenade indicator on) and this island will come to life. When hunting, the player will need to stand still and listen for the growls and other noises made by the animals. The items obtained from the wild life give the player options to craft new weapon, ammo, and consumable slots. The open world feel will often send the player face to face with tigers, bears, or enemy patrols when least expecting it.The ONLY thing I didn't like about the game.... Is the main character! I wanted to smack my guy in the face way to many times =/ But that is a small price to pay for a full and complete game that has been polished into a guided, open world thrill ride that is sure to please. The first time you light an enemy base on fire then slide down a steep mountain side for a quick and slick escape from the guard dogs like a serious BA, just to land on a pack of frickin' grizzly bears -- you'll be hooked!


Far Cry® 3 
A Screenshot of Far Cry® 3
By: Vash(88)

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												I've played about 30+ hours of Far Cry 3 on PC and another 40+ hours back on Xbox 360, meaning I've had quite some experience with the game. That being said, Far Cry 3 is probably Ubisoft's prime example of advertising and hyping without fully delivering, hence my negative review: it's far from as great as people claim it to be.The Good:· Michael Mando's performance as Vaas Montenegro is very well done, simply one of the best motion capture in any game.· The huge island allows for hours of exploring, hunting, and doing sidemissions. The Bad:· First I'm going to list what bothers me the most, and it also happens to be the thing I liked the most... Vaas. Ubisoft promoted Far Cry 3 with Vaas from the get-go; putting him in the early demo, placing him on the boxart, including a wahini-figure in the Collector's Edition... his insanity was basically the center of the game. Unfortunately, those promises weren't met. Slight spoiler warning ahead so please skip to the next point if you don't want any bits of the story given away, but Ubisoft's oh so glorious Vaas Montenegro had a combined total screentime of 15 minutes. Yep. Durning your 30+ hours, only 15 minutes will be spent looking at or listening to Vaas. It's like buying a movie ticket to go and see Fight Club just to end up watching A Good Day to Die Hard.· The missions are repetetive beyond believe. Save this person, do this for that guy, kill these guys. The sidemissions exist largely of racing- and huntingmissions, both equally boring after the first time. The only enjoyable mission -- spoiler warning, again -- was the one where you had to burn marijuanafield with a flamethrower to a raggae-dubstep beat. If only there were more original missions like those.· The character development is so unbelievable it feels parodic at times. You go from a party-going teenager to a hipster Rambo that is able to murder hundreds of experienced soldiers in a few hours.· There's no real reason to craft anything. Health syringes are useless if you have upgraded your manual healing skill that'll automatically heal you when you're out of syringes (by bandaging your scratched arm when you fall or pulling out a bullet when a tiger attacks you. Yeah...) Your wallet can only hold a certain amount of money, so maybe crafting a larger wallet would be usefull. But why do so if climbing all the radio towers will basically get you all the weapons for free?The Visuals:· The overal graphics are very nice, from detailed textures to great lighting, but the shadows were so overdone it almost felt cartoonish.Final verdict:· High expectations, even higher promises, and ultimately you get an avarage repetetive shooter. Far Cry 3 is the best example of how Ubisoft spends more time hyping and advertising than polishing what could have been a much better product. 6/10

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2013
												What a massive game this is. Huge islands to explore with just too many sidequests. You can just run/drive/fly around and do nothing or you can; hunt animals, craft items, free settlements, find relics and other secrets, take over radio towers, do some trials and a whole lot of other activities and (side)quests. It's seemingly endless and completing the entire game will take you probably well over 50 hours. Now that's some value right there.The graphics are just gorgeous, no matter what settings you use. You can't make this game look bad, you just can't. The animations and models are some of the best I've seen in a game. Wow. The same thing applies to the sounds and voice acting, which is brilliant and truly convincing.While doing the story and sidequests you'll earn XP to upgrade your skills. There are 3 skilltrees in total and the way you play the game is entirely up to you. The Shark skilltree will let you upgrade your assault and healing skills, while the Heron tree will help you with your sniper skills and speed and finally, the Spider tree will let you focus on your stealth and survival skills. There's no right way to play this. There are many ways to complete an objective. And that's what makes Far Cry 3 fun, but not necessarily unique.However, there aren't many FPS that give you this much freedom, while telling a realistic, focused, story at the same time. So I take my hat off to Ubisoft for creating this masterpiece. The commercial and critical success for this game is well deserved.Let this be a lesson - and example - for future first person shooters. Hooray for Far Cry 3 ![Rating: 92/100]

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												This game is amazing with a great story, amazing visuals and really good shooting mechanics.Gameplay-The shooting mechanics in this game are brilliant. The guns feel very nice to use and there are a lot of different types to use. Enemies can shoot through thin walls which is both realistic and amazing, and cover is done really well too. If you hide behind something you can aim down the sights and you will lean out or fire over the top. Scattered across the map are radio towers and enemy strongholds. Radio towers are useld like veiwpoints in Assassins Creed, where you have to go to the top and trigger an animation to be able to veiw that area on the map. Another bonus to these is that you get some really nice veiws from the top. Unlocking radio towers unlocks free weapons in stores, so you never have to pay a large amount for a gun. Enemy Strongholds can be taken out by lots of different ways, stealthily stabbing everyone, sniping all the pirates or just running in all guns blazing (which is likely to get you killed).There are several different vehicles in the game to get you from A to B. They are really fun and feel nice to drive with a keyboard and the handling is very arcade-y. There are also 3 types of boat and handgliders scattered across the map for fun transport. Enemies and friendlies will patrol in these as well and some really fun situations can emerge where you find an enemy roadblock and try to run from it, only to be pursued by two cars filled with pirates.The first part of the game is very survivaly as you are unequipped and have low health. Hunting and crafting are used to improve your equipment and skills are used to improve yourself, such as adding more health, not running out of stamina and being able to hold your breath under water for a lot longer.I would reccomend playing on hard or very hard difficulty otherwise the game just becomes too easy within about an hour.The Map-The first half of the story takes place on an absolutely stunning jungle island. It is absolutely huge and is covered with stuff to find. Temples, outposts and caves dill the map with stuff to do. The second half of the game is located on an island about a kilometre south that is made up of mountains and to me, wasn't as impressive. It was still very good but there just wasn't as much stuff on it to do but the outposts and enemies there are a lot more challenging, so that's fun.Story/Missions-The story missions ranged form burning fields of weed with a flamethrower to shooting pirates to exploring ancient tombs in search of a treasure. The characters are really well written and the voice acting is brilliant. After completing the game there are still many side missions to do aswell as hunting activities and bounty quests. However, one of the biggest problems with the game becomes apparent during the missions, the checkpointing. Sometimes it is fine but other times you will die and be reset to 5 minutes earlier, that becomes annoying.AI-The AI is very good, especially on the higher difficulties. They react to sounds and their dead bodies and don't just look for you for ten seconds and then stop, they will keep on searching. Also, they don't just follow paths, their movement seems very dynamic and don't patrol a small area on a repeated loop.Graphics and Sound-On a GTX 760, intel i5 4690 3.5GHz and 8GB RAM, I get about 60FPS in 1080p and everything at ultra, apart from a few things which are at high. The game is beautiful and colourful and the FOV goes all the way up to 110, which is better than most games (ahem Skyrim). The sound is brilliant aswell and the way enemies react to sounds feels real. If htey hear a gunshot they will search in the direction it came from to find it. All weapons have a unique sound that is very luad, like a gun should be, unlike other games where an assualt rifle sounds like a cough.Overall-The game is amazing and really fun. The checkpointing is the only real issue I have with it but otherwise it is brilliant.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2013
												This game can be defined with three words. Open world immersion! Crafting, hunting, exploration, side games, challenges, optional quests, lively characters, and amazing weapon design -- this game has it all! Not many games live up to the given price tag, and this is one of them. I spent fifty hours on my first play though. That is an extensive single player fps.Cut off the music and turn off all of the "hud" options that can be toggled, (I left the grenade indicator on) and this island will come to life. When hunting, the player will need to stand still and listen for the growls and other noises made by the animals. The items obtained from the wild life give the player options to craft new weapon, ammo, and consumable slots. The open world feel will often send the player face to face with tigers, bears, or enemy patrols when least expecting it.The ONLY thing I didn't like about the game.... Is the main character! I wanted to smack my guy in the face way to many times =/ But that is a small price to pay for a full and complete game that has been polished into a guided, open world thrill ride that is sure to please. The first time you light an enemy base on fire then slide down a steep mountain side for a quick and slick escape from the guard dogs like a serious BA, just to land on a pack of frickin' grizzly bears -- you'll be hooked!


Far Cry® 3 
A Screenshot of Far Cry® 3
By: Vash(88)

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
 Far Cry 3 You've been captured by pirates, and it's up to you, Jason Brody, to rescue your friends and get the hell off the island. As action heroes go, Brody is an unlikely one. While Far Cry and Far Cry 2's protagonists had military or mercenary backgrounds, which at least explained their ability to reload an assault rifle in three seconds, you're just an over-privileged Californian bro in his early twenties stuck in a nightmare situation.Far Cry 3 is one of the best open world games ever. This game offers a wide variety of different things to do, From Liberating Outposts to even hunting animals for their skins! Far Cry 3 is a delightful and harsh tropical wonderland, crawling with wildlife and threatened by the pirates and drug runners that disrupt its peace. Furthermore Far Cry 3 also has multiplayer, co-op so you can play online with friends or just play a game of deathmatch , Far Cry 3 also has a map editor where you decide what you want in your map, from where you want the animals etc...When i got Far Cry 3, i thought it was going to be another typical First Person Shooter game but i was wrong, Far Cry 3 adds realism to the game which actually makes you feel as if you are Jason Brody yourself. Far Cry 3 is a game i would definitely recommend to people who love fps games but  WARNING: THIS GAME HAS ANIMAL ABUSE SO IF YOU ARE A ANIMAL LOVER THEN THIS GAME IS NOT FOR YOU . I would give Far Cry 3 a 10/10 for many reasons, one of them being the graphics which is just out of this world and the characters are well created especially Vaas who is my favourite character in the game simply because of his humour. To the people who do not own this game or don't have the sufficient funds for it, wait for the sales to come around then Far Cry 3 will drop prices massively and that's when you can get it but if you do not own this game, you are really missing out.What i don't like about this game are the constant notifications and reminders. These are so frequent, and so annoying, like if i am roaming around, nearly every 10 seconds a notification pops up on the top corner of the screen about the objective which can get a bit annoying but that is all that i have against this beautiful open world fps game.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												(Scroll down for Pros and Cons) 82 hours and one of my most played games on Steam (I have over 220), it is amazing. Far Cry 4 will be similar, and I know everything about it so far. If you like FPS, adventure, open-world, fun, b00bs, guns, parties, Co-Op (unfortunately not open-world, but WILL be in 4), and games worth your money, you found the right one!Pros:-The enviroment. A huge map and probably my favorite open-world game, ever! The second part of the map opens after half way through the game. While the enviroment isn't as detailed as Far Cry 4's will be, it's still an amazing treat.-The graphics. They look the best for 2012. 'Nuf said.-The characters. Interesting and awesome (especially Vaas, in my top 3 favorite villians of all time) and a story that will keep you interested even after the game is over!-The weapons and cars. While there is no flyable helicopters (Which there will be one in Far Cry 4 called the Gyrocopter), the cars are varied with random encounters with Pirates (Grunts) down the street. The boats are awesome and that comes to our next pro.-Hunting and Scavenging. In Far Cry 3 you can hunt animals (don't worry, they're virtual and not real) and pick flowers. With animals, you can make upgrades, like more holsters for guns, ammo pouches, and sick stuff. With picking flowers, you can make "medicene" (drugs) which boost things in combat, hunting, and health.-Co-op and Multiplayer. They didn't stop with the Singleplayer, and it still would have been an amazing game, just look at my hours! (86+ hours) Unfortunately, the Co-op is linear but a nice touch, and the Multiplayer isn't just stapled on. They have a cool decoding system and Battle Cries, which are very helpful. It gives a lot more teamwork than Call of Duty ever would.-B00bs. You probably say Nudity on the Rating, but how could I not put this in? Seriously?-$30.00. You've got to pick up this game for that price, no matter what kind of gamer you are!-Mini-games. From Throwing Knives to hunting Legendary Animals, there is some Minigame for you!Cons:-No Open-World Co-op. There will be Open-World Co-op in Far Cry 4, which I can't wait for. My biggest con.-The enviroments are a little empty in some places, which it will be fixed in Far Cry 4.-No Elephants or the Gyrocopter, until Far Cry 4.-No worth-while DLC. (Besides Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon, and for $15.00 you should pick up if you like this game!)-When it ends. Great choices at the end you can pick from and I loved the game.Rating (Non-Bias):9.5/10-Bad-A$$ Seal of Approval (Even Angry Joe gave it one and a 9/10!)Rating for Hardcore Far Cry Fans:9.8/10-Bad-A$$ Seal of Approval (Even Angry Joe gave it one and a 9/10!)They're just missing the Open-World Co-op with a friend.P.S: You might recognize me, that's because I currently have the 8th most Top Rated Guide of Far Cry 3 (It's called "Far Cry 3 Ultimate Guide")! I'm so glad the community could be there all these years to meet that goal! I am accepting requests to add things to the Ultimate guide.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Amazing open world first person shooter with survival elements implemented.The vegetation is dense and well-detailed. The vehicles are varied and feel satisfying to drive.The Co-op multiplayer, however, is completely different to the hunting-survival-like single player.Co-op gameplay reminds me of Left 4 Dead (but without the zombies). You and 3 friends run and gun your way through set paths blasting and shooting absolutely everything in your way. There are even mini-games where you compete against your friends to get the most points.It's a bit different from the single player, and can provide a breath of fresh air if you are bored of sneaking around in the bushes stalking a tiger in order to craft a larger wallet or whatever.The Versus multiplayer is like any other first person multiplayer game- not much to say here apart from there are some playlists which include custom maps made by the community which is a nice addition. (did I forget to mention there's a level editor included with the game?!)Overall, a brilliant game that can fill all your first-person shooter desires.There are some mods online which can tweak your single-player experience to make it more realistic and emphasise the survival aspect of the game, as well as make the weapons more realistic (ie: more deadly).
