number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is a game that takes place in Rook Island, which is divided into North Island and South Island. You begin the game as Jason Brody, an American tourist who is vacationing with his friends looking for fun on this tropical paradise. Things go wrong when pirates kidnap them for the purpose of selling them into slavery. You encounter a leader named Vaas Montenegro, who makes life a living hell for you and your friends. Later you’ll run into another nasty guy in the name of Hoyt Volker, who lives in the South Island has more powerful pirates protecting him.Jason may seem like an ordinary guy, but you can make him quite powerful using the skill tree system. There is plenty to explore, including the plant life, the animal life, and the numerous outposts controlled by the pirates. You will also get to know the Rakyat, the natives of the island and you will learn their traditions as you progress through the story. The story missions are interesting and well-scripted, but the most exciting part of the game is being able to freely explore the island when not working on a story mission. The world has plenty of randomness such as shootouts between the Rakyat and the pirates. Other times you will see animals attacking the Rakyat. On some occasions you will see animals like bears, tigers, and leopards attacking the Rakyat tribe. On other occasions you will see tigers or bears stalking boars. Sometimes the predatory animals will come after you and you will have to kill them in order to survive. Other times you see a pack of dogs with one howling like a wolf. You look around to see if these animals are stalking you.There can be benefits to killing animals in the game. After killing them you can skin them in order to craft bigger wallets to hold more cash and craft loot rucksacks to carry more leaves and loot recovered from containers and dead bodies. Liberating outposts requires you to kill all pirates guarding them so that they can be your safehouse. The game rewards you more for using stealth than for going all out on a shootout against the pirates. Each outpost contains alarm panels near the flags representing the outposts that pirates can use to call reinforcements should they find you. But you can shoot out the alarm panels to eliminate the possibility of reinforcements. The sniper rifle comes in very handy when trying to liberate outposts. I would shoot a few pirates and find a place to hide by hiding behind rocks and in the foliage. The XP gained from liberating outposts is used to develop Jason in different ways. This is the RPG element of Far Cry 3. There really no wrong skill to learn because all the skills are useful in some way. You can learn to take down an enemy from behind using the brutally effective machete. Then you can learn to take down an enemy by taking one down from behind and throwing the machete immediately to take down a nearby enemy without alerting others. Liberated outposts offer side missions such as assassinations and hunting animals both common and rare. You have to complete assassinations by using your brutal knife, so using any other weapon will result in mission failure. This is in line with Rakyat tradition that you will learn to respect in Rook Island. The hunting of animals requires you to first stop by a site to pick up a weapon designated for hunting the animals. Using any other weapon will result in mission failure. The hunting of rare animals is rather interesting because the skinning of these animals will help you craft larger wallets, larger ammo pouches, larger loot rucksacks, larger syringe kits, etc. So hunting and crafting go hand in hand and will help you throughout your exploration of the island.Whether you’re hunting, crafting, searching for relics or lost letters from dead WWII Japanese soldiers or progressing through the main story, Far Cry 3 is rarely boring. You can unscramble radio towers throughout the island to make your map clearer to read and to help Rakyat supply lines. As soon as you kill deactivate a radio tower, you will have a supply drop side mission available. Supply drops require you to drop medical supplies within a certain time limit. This type of side mission lets you know how treacherous driving can be in Rook Island. It also can get a little repetitive. In my opinion, the supply drops side missions are the most tedious in the game.There are many vehicles that you can drive, but driving on the roads can feel a bit awkward. Driving boats and watercraft can be a lot of fun while exploring the gameworld by sea. You can navigate from one place to another by ziplining, which is more fun from a first-person view than I expected. It’s cool to zipline, get to drop down on a pirate, and brutally stab him at the same time. There are hang gliders scattered throughout the island that you can use to reach faraway places or hard to reach areas.In the original Far Cry you could use binoculars to tag enemies you see in the distance. Far Cry 2 removed that feature to make it more realistic. Far Cry 3 has brought back the ability to tag enemies in the distance, so you will be able to see enemies through walls after tagging them. Weapons would eventually wear down in Far Cry 2, so you had to replace them. In Far Cry 3 weapons never wear down from use and you can upgrade them using the built-in store in each safehouse for a price. Some weapons can be upgraded by using attachments such as a sniper scope, a laser sight, or a silencer. Some weapons can also be customized by painting them in a variety of colors that are available in the built-in store.The AI in the game is very good, as you will see enemies react to dead bodies. They will automatically go into search mode in an attempt to find you. They will try to flank you if they detect you or they can hide behind objects such as rocks and shacks. They enemies work as a team when trying to find you and kill you.The graphics of Far Cry 3 have very impressive textures and make Rook Island look alive. The animals are incredibly detailed and so are the skies whether it’s sunny or raining. The details of the faces of the Vaas and Hoyt look amazingly realistic as do the faces of the pirates.Without trying to spoil the end of the game, I will only say that there are two endings. Each ending leaves you with moral choices to contemplate. The story missions are somewhat linear, but having two possible endings for the game makes it more entertaining.In my opinion, Far Cry 3 is the best in the Far Cry series. The other two Far Cry games emphasized an open gameworld, but Far Cry 3 is the most open gameworld and the random encounters really help this game. The randomness ensures that the result of approaching an outpost will never be the same each time. You may infiltrate an outpost on your own only to be interrupted by a predatory animal such as a bear, tiger, or leopard. Sometimes, your attempt to liberate an outpost is thwarted by a jeep filled with pirates. Far Cry 3 is a classic action game that I highly recommend to anyone.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is another incredible game in its series. With stunning graphics and an immersive story which really makes you feel one with the game.It's also very well optimized, meaning random FPS drops are almost never if not at all.The multiplayer is rather empty now, and the Co-op doesn't live up to the single player campaign. But the games you do find are always fun and guarnteed to be worth it.The campaign's pure length is more than enough to make up for the lacking multiplayer...And is easily replayable and enjoyanle.Moving on. Some none essential characters during cutscenes have slightly poor sound and animation. But it really should not be something to put you off the game.I would more than recommend this game to people with a good gaming rig. My nVidia GTX 660 plays Far Cry 3 on ultra very well, and the regions of a 640-650 should be able to run it on medium-high settings at decent framerates.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
+ Mapa gigantesco que oferece infinitas possibilidades de abordagem.+ Atuação e dublagem impressionante do vilão (Vaas).+ Mecânica de tiro muito boa, com armas realistas e divertidas de usar, e um sistema de cobertura intuitivo e eficiente.+ Arco e flecha <3+ Visual bonito, oferecendo algumas paisagens impressionantes.+ Ótima integração da IA com os outros elementos do ambiente, em especial com facções inimigas e vida selvagem, faz o jogo parecer vivo.+ Consertou vários erros irritantes presentes no Far Cry 2.- Não se deixe enganar pelo menu gráfico detalhado: Far Cry 3 pra PC é um port desleixado muito bem disfarçado. Tem uma das piores implementações do DirectX 11 que eu já vi. Torrei quase 1/3 do tempo de jogo fazendo tweaks gráficos, numa tentativa desesperada de fazer o jogo rodar de forma estável, mesmo usando num sistema que supera os requisitos RECOMENDADOS.- História monótona que toma uma direção ridícula na metade do jogo.- Missões da mainquest são lineares e restringem muito as ações do jogador.- Inimigos com sensor ninja destroçam a imersão em alguns momentos.- Excesso de recompensas e evolução desbalanceada tornam o jogo fácil demais e acabam desestimulando a exploração do mapa.- Caçar animais e plantas pra craftar itens é divertido no começo, mas se torna um pé no saco depois.- Sidequests repetitivas e um grinding insuportável de fazer inveja a Assassin's Creed I.7,8/10.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												SPOILER ALERT!I have to grudgingly recommend this because of the excellent stealth gameplay and realistic level design, despite uplay and one of the stupidest plots ever written for a video game. Some highlights:Our protagonist meets his friend, who has an escape plan:"How will we escape?""We found a boat!""Awesome!""A broken boat.""I... uh... guess you could fix it...""A broken boat in a cave at the top of a mountain.""What?""A cave with no boat-sized exits...""Seriously?""...or any nearby water."(long pause)"How many of those pills did you take?""Eleventy?""Yeah, that's what I thought..."Our protagonist meets up with Buck, who has been sending him to uncover ancient lost tombs:"Listen, Buck. The last two times you sent me to a 'lost' tomb, it was filled with pirates. Not centuries-old ghost pirates - the normal kind. And when I got there, you were already there waiting for me. I'd guess that both you and every pirate on the island already knows where the stupid tomb is. So instead of using this magic stone compass thing, why don't we try looking for the tomb on a tourist map first?"Our protagonist meets up with Buck one last time:"Hey Buck""Hey, Snow White. I'm here to betray you.""That was incredibly obvious. Do you realize that I'm holding a small arsenal?""Yep.""...and that I killed like 200 dudes on the way here?""Yep.""...and that all you have is a dull antique knife, and you're standing on the other side of the room?""Yep.""Then why tell me?""Because you can't shoot me during a cutscene.""Touche."Our protagonist meets a deep cover agent:"Hey I've got a plan to kill Hoyt.""Hit me.""First we'll bring you to his private office and introduce you to him. You'll try to get a job working for him, and after we've earned his trust we'll get you an invitation to one of his poker games. You can kill him when you're alone with him at the game.""Wait... this plan starts with meeting Hoyt alone, then follows an elaborate set of steps so we can... uh... meet with Hoyt alone?""Exactly.""I can't think of a problem with that. Let's go."Our protagonist is presented with a moral choice at the end of the game:"Jason, you must choose to leave the island with your friends, or kill them and stay here with me.""You want me to do what to my friends?""Kill them.""Sorry, I thought you said kill them.""I did.""Not even if you weren't obviously a psychopath. Nobody would kill their friend for no reason. Actually, nobody would even have lifted the knife to her throat unless a cutscene made them do it. Why would you even include this as an option? Seriously, who thought this ending was worthy of occupying space on my hard disk? Hold on a second. Let me Google this."Jason puts down the knife and pulls out his phone."Wait..." he giggles "the main writer thought this plot was clever? Oh my goodness." he starts laughing "the guy thinks that he's subverting video game cliches by just retelling them in the most literal way? Hahaha. Oh this is good. He said in an interview that he thinks we should be looking for deeper meanings rather than just saying 'I get it. That was dumb.' That would be like looking for deeper meanings in Earnest Goes to Camp. He honestly thinks critics hate this plot because we only half-listened to it, not because we understood it and think it's idiotic."Jason ghasps for breath and wipes a tear from his eye.Citra stares at him for a moment. "So... uh... are you going to kill your friends?""No, but thanks for the laughs.""Wait! What will you do now?""Steal some cars and sneak into a bunch more heavily armed compounds because - honestly? That's a riot."Subscribe to my curator page hereView my other reviews here

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												There are some different angles to look at this game. It's not a brilliant, that's for sure, but I can't tell exactly, is it good or bad.Certainly, pros overcome cons, but cons aren't that small issue to negate them completely, as I do with games I'm really in love with.I start from good side: Far Cry 3 is a complete adventure at some tropical islands, where you have to (and have might to) overcome cluster♥♥♥♥, and take a life under control. Dream of so many people. Great story plot, quite comparable with Cameron's "Avatar" movie.As a game, first-player-view shooter with some "gaining new abilities with experience" (RPG-elements)... It looks good, it allows to move as you please on large and full of life archipelago, and, most needed, it allows you to shoot people (and other things) when and how you want to - which is much clever, than usual "narrow corridor bang-bang run" ala Call of Duty series.As an inheritor of Far Cry 2, it washed away bigger part of boredom, reason, why so many people turned predecessor down. Far Cry 3 is an open-world game, where you may actually like sub-quests and spend "a little more" time than you have to beat story line.But... there are cons part.First of all, oh precious realism, makers of Far Cry 3 most definetely casted it away. Some American boy found himself trigger-happy - that is one thing. But, that boy, cutting throats and sneaking to clear an avanpost silently all by himself... "Ne veriy" (Don't believe it) - Stanislavsky would say. Secondly, I don't like Jason Brody (protagonist) for one bit. Not a golden boy from prologue, not a rambo-like gut-cutter he evolved. All that story 'bout "insanity" make me sick. So, if I'd believe my "nature instincts", like game asks me to at start, I'd through it away. It's way Hollywood-and-plush, "Hunger games" on good bones of "Battle Royale".For game itself (gameplay process). It looks nice, but Just Cause 2 (released 3 years ago) looks greater and sharper, in terms of visual quality. As for game balance, in sandbox conditions - they have to lock key characters in buildings and scripts. Othervise, everyone will end up killed by varans and cassowary. About rambo-ing. Sure, I can silently clean an outpost, spend time to look for patrol routine, calculate lines-of-sight for every soldier on it... But why do that? Without any reconnaissance I can rush forward, and kill all of them (armed with AK's, SVD's and probably some machine-guns and RPG-7) face-to-face, with my machete and shotgun. On hardiest setting possible. On quarter or less time than silent approach. Talking 'bout realism again.Finally, for comparison with Far Cry 2, I'd say, yeah, they cut boring parts with respawnable avanposts, replace some of "dogs of war" realistic stuff with more hollywood-like decorations, very dramatic, of course, but edged teeth of action-stuff-fans up to zero.There are other lesser flaws, like stupid bow and driving-worse-than-in-farcry2, but I don't want to dig deeper.Overall, game is big, sometimes even fun and clever, game have catchy moments, but even then it has that "seen it before" scratch of second-hand cloth. Definetely NOT a must-buy. Take it at some discount, if you up to FPS games and don't fall to all that marketing crap already - or don't bother at all, it's not all that good. Total mark - 6,66/10PS: multiplayer and co-op features could have been a bigger win, but they are too glitchy, too narrow-viewed. Look at Battlefield, for much better online experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is a first person shooter that takes its inspiration from movies like The Beach. You are an adventurer stranded on an island of criminals, corporate mercenaries, pirates, profiteers, tribal folk and misfits.A huge sandbox map with a variety of challenges: from hunting animals and finding treasure, to side missions and of course the main mission. The islands offers plenty of land to explore, great missions and colourful environments. The character handles nicely and has some enjoyable abilities, like stealth, hang-gliding, swimming and sliding across the dirt. It has an adequate multi-player aspect and the element of stealth makes this rather enjoyable.One of the things I love about this game is the locale: the NPCs look great, conveying a Pacific Islander culture in a way that is virtually unseen in video games - their tattoos, their look and their New Zealand(ish) / Moari-flavoured accents are a rare thing in a culture dominated by US flavoured action adventure (there is a strong feeling of authenticity about the islander culture, even though it's explored through the filter of Western assumptions). I'd like to see more of this cultural diversity in games - we have a great diversity of humanity and it is not explored often enough in games. The culture represented in this game is a refreshing change from the Americana or Americana as viewed through a sci-fi / aliens / African American criminals lens. Far Cry 3 could probably have been improved by making the protagonist a non-US citizen. This issue of cultural adventuring alone has  me currently savouring every moment of awesomeness that is the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. universe. Just the cultural setting alone makes Far Cry 3 an outstanding adventure. But it is also highly playable, which is the bottom line in gaming.I really like this game, the variety of weapons and vehicles, the tropical locale, the characters... although the treasure hunting gets a little tedious. So near to completion, and I've stalled because of the small amount of treasure left that I still have to get to. I look forward to finishing the game all the same, and highly recommend it to anyone looking for an exciting and pacy adventure.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												I've been a Far Cry fan since the first one came out for the PC and I consider that one to be one of best shooters of all time. The Xbox versions were also great so I was really stoked for Far Cry 2. I have to say I was very dissapointed with that entry in the franchise. The idea for it was great but it suffered from some minor but crucial flaws mainly due to the whole open world scheme, which didn't work so well in my opinion, in a franchise that established itself as being a great straightforward (but strategic) FPS.So, as you would guess, when I heard Far Cry 3 was keeping the same formula was the previous one, I didn't get very excited for it. I tried it out for just thirty minutes and thank god I was wrong. Everything about this game is great. Puts together the over the top action of the first games with a more refined open world aproach of Far Cry 2. This game works well in so many ways. Even when you finish all the main and secundary missions you will be wanting for more. And the game will definitely give you more of what you want. As you can tell, I didn't go alot into detail on this review, but there's no need for it. Trust me, play it. It goes down for as one of the best, if not the best, games of 2012.

In future, more Vaas, less Hoyt (Whose name I had to google, he's quite forgettable.)Edit: Uplay is terrible. That is all.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is beyond any doubt an amazing game and an experience that mustn't be missed, even with it's flaws.The graphics, ambience and voice acting are all amazing and makes this game one of the most asthetically pleasing titles in recent years, however as a result Far Cry 3 is pretty demanding in the hardware department. So make sure your gear is up to speed and optimize it for maximum performance. The gameplay has been referred to in the past as "Skyrim with guns". This is true, Far Cry 3 puts the player in the heart of a tropical paradise plagued with drug-running pirates and gives them the opportunity to go about as they please: Exploring areas, fighting off skirmishes and collecting items. However unlike Skyrim the primary story isn't completely optional, with constant reminders appearing on your screen to go here or do that while out experiencing the island for yourself makes you feel like a dog in an off-lease park; yes you are free in a sense but you're still not in total control of your experience.To further add the sensation of "freedom with boundaries", Far Cry 3's story is very restrictive in comparison with the exploration. During a mission you are forced to use this one specific weapon, drive this one specific vehicle, do this objective in precisely this particular way, go here within the alloted time; the list goes on. Adding unpredictable restrictions to the story makes the player feel like a ball and chain has been shackled to their ankle, which does no favors to the overall experience of the game. However, when you are allowed to play your way, Far Cry 3 really shines through. Plotting out ambushes on fortified outposts or joyriding across the island running over whatever gets in your way is a blast through-and-through, made even better by a large variety of destructive weaponry ranging from grenade launchers, RPGs and even flamethrowers. The story of Far Cry 3 is simple, you take on the role of Jason Brody, a rich white boy who loves hair product. While you and your friends are on a drunken binge in exotic places you're all kidnapped by a band of pirates looking to ransom you and then sell you off to slavery. Jason manages to escape and begins his adventure to rescue his friends and kill the bad guy and get the girl. To be frank, the story isn't all that great. Jason Brody and all his friends are shallow and dislikeable, and I'd much rather shoot them all in the mouth than risk my life to save them. In contrast, antagonists in the game are interesting and imaginative and save Far Cry 3's story from being dullard. Vaas Montenegro, the most well established villian is similar to the Joker from Batman: Arkham Asylum, he's psychotic, unpredictable, imaginative and fun to watch. Far Cry 3's combat is split into two categories: Stealth and shoot-em-up, and both are well-made and flow well into eachother as the situation requires. Jumping into foliage when not in combat makes it so enemies cannot see you, allowing you to plan out your attacks or to play venus fly trap and lure them to you by throwing rocks before jumping out and puncturing them with a knife takedown. The takedowns are a very satisfying insta-kill against unarmored enemies (and can be used against heavy foes later in the game after acquiring a perk) so long as you take them by suprise, and with unlockable perks takedowns become even more versatile and deadly by either pulling the pin off a grenade of the freshly deceased or going for multi chain stabs. On the other side of the combat spectrum the guns and shooting mechanics are satisfying and have a good healthy punch to them. Unfortunately the combat indulges in one of video game design's bad habits, Quick-Time Events, prominently when fighting carniferous wildlife like aligators and sharks. You're swimming across a river when SURPRISE GATOR SEX comes up, then you're given half a second to mash a specific button before you die. QTEs are a bad mechanic in video games and while they're not too prominent in Far Cry 3 they still feel unecessary on the whole. Finally the worst part of the combat is the battles against the main antagonists like Vaas or Buck, both of them being such hostile albeit savourably enjoyable characters you'd think the fight would be memorable, right? Wrong. When fighting them the game designers decide to put you and your foe into a sort of drug-trip combat sequence that makes no sense and is incongruious to the rest of the game, followed by a series of QTEs taking control away from you for the sake of trying to make the encounter more cinematic. This resulted in final struggles that were disappointing and left a very sour aftertaste. So in all, Far Cry 3 is a game with flaws, but they don't drag it all the way down. Far Cry 3 is fun, addicting and worth the time (especially if you got it while it's on sale). I suggest you look past it's flaws and let the overall experience take you in.Also before I close off I need to mention: Far Cry 3 also has an online multiplayer, which only exists for the purpose of having an online multiplayer. It's unimaginative deathmatch and is not anything special.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												+/+ Great sense of progression.+/+ Excellent gameplay.+/+ Fun environment.+/+ Nice graphics/sound.+/+ Nice choice for upgrades.+/+ Hunting wildlife for upgrades is an excellent and immersive feature.+/+ Solid enemy and animal A.I.+/- Mediocre story.+/- Voice acting varies from good to poor.+/- Gameplay outlasts the sense of progression and leveling.  In other words, it could use additional upgrades for character and guns for the late game.+/- Hunting is mostly finished by mid-game.  Would have been nice to see the feature continued (such as having some required animals on the second island.)-/- UPlay required to play.-/- Weak protagonist.-/- Not a very difficult game.-/- Missing steam features such as achievements or cloud.Overall: 9/10.  While not perfect, Far Cry 3 is still a great game that I would highly recommend.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Great FPS, decent and interesting story (hard to come by these days), great realism.  Has an AK that feels as powerful as the one in real life. Lots of sandbox aspects that make the replayability pretty good.  Choose your own approach to your enemies. Lots of mini-games and mini-quests to spice things up and keep it interesting.  Same as far-cry 1 and 2 really, big island with lots of uncharted territory that you seek to destroy and control.  Unlike facry2, guard posts do not respawn and once you control a zone of the map your allies patrol it instead of the enemy. Read in a review that you can't save the game manually, that it only autosaves, but this isn't true, you can press ESC>Save to save at any time. Don't know what all the complaining is about with Uplay, it hasn't given me any problems whatsoever.  Yes you have to register and log in with Uplay but that's pretty much all you have to do.  Then it's just play and don't worry about it.  It gave me some concern about this purchase but I suspected it was just trendy little sheeple regurgitating things that they say to one another, and I was right. Good deal, especially at $8.  Would recommend.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Far Cry 3 succeeds like its predecessors in providing an open world action / thriller set in a tropical climate.  Like similar games such as GTA and Batman: AC, the current objective is shown on the map... there are side missions and mini-games that can be unlocked and played at will.  Portions of the map details are hidden until radio towers are "unlocked" by scaling them and sabotaging the fuse box.  Weapons and skills are steadily unlocked as progress is made in both the main story line, collecting hidden treasures, and completing various other tasks.  Thrown in for good measure are hunting and crafting, and a completely separate and very challenging co-op campaign.On the plus side:> The world is beautiful and nicely detailed.> The story is quite good and features one of the best antagonists in any video game I have ever played.> The weapons look, feel, and sound excellent.> The stronghold raids and "kill nasty dude x" side missions are the meat of the game and very entertaining, with many ways to approach them> The takedown skills are challenging to apply and fun when they work.> An excellent PC port with all the graphical and control flourish we expect.On the negative side:> The game ramps up too quickly... I found myself proceeding at a reasonable pace, and by act 2 I was becoming overpowered... this along with another mechanic in act 2 makes the second act seem anti-climactic.> On the same vein, the first act Boss feels more threatening than the second.  He also was such a good character I was disappointed that he was dead.  Can he have his own game, please?> The native peoples character models are too similar.> The world does not feel "lived in"... it feels more like an action game set piece.  There is also very little variation in the game world.> There is very little incentive to continue exploring after the game ends.The co-op campaign is very difficult... you will want at least 3 players for that.  I bought the game on sale on steam for $5... was it worth it? Yes absolutely.  I would say $20 is reasonable for this since I got nearly 40 hours of entertainment out of it.8/10

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												Beautiful graphics are just not enough to turn this game around. These are the positives: responsive controls with customizable keyboard configuration that actually works (funny that I have to call that out, but many games execute this poorly), good graphics, and a large, often interesting area to explore. If that's enough for your gaming experience, then this is the game for you. If you like multiplayer, also, this is a great setting. However...If you want a good single-player game, unfortunately, Far Cry 3 also has these things that I have to put in the negative column: really, really annoying major and minor characters (including the main character Jason, who must be the all-time worst ever created for a shooter - bad, whiny voice acting combined with no redeeming values), an awkward game interface for controlling inventory and crafting (obviously designed entirely for clunky consoles), endless messages popping up on the screen to tell you things that you already know or don't care about, poorly executed "big game hunting" that is both cartoonish and annoying, and worst of all: every major villain must be dealt with in some kind of "alternate-reality" setting that seems to be happening in the unlit hallways at Ubisoft. Note to game designers: every time you move someone abruptly out of the game world you have been carefully creating for them for the last dozen hours, you ruin the immersive experience. Boss fight with Vaas? Lame. Boss fight with the weird Australian guy? Lame. Boss fight with Hoyt? Lame. Boss fight with the giant island demon thingy? WTF? Lame. Half-way into this game I absolutely lost any interest at all in how it would turn out and finished it entirely so I could expunge my disappointment by shooting a few more pirates. I give this game a 5 out of 10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is beyond any doubt an amazing game and an experience that mustn't be missed, even with it's flaws.The graphics, ambience and voice acting are all amazing and makes this game one of the most asthetically pleasing titles in recent years, however as a result Far Cry 3 is pretty demanding in the hardware department. So make sure your gear is up to speed and optimize it for maximum performance. The gameplay has been referred to in the past as "Skyrim with guns". This is true, Far Cry 3 puts the player in the heart of a tropical paradise plagued with drug-running pirates and gives them the opportunity to go about as they please: Exploring areas, fighting off skirmishes and collecting items. However unlike Skyrim the primary story isn't completely optional, with constant reminders appearing on your screen to go here or do that while out experiencing the island for yourself makes you feel like a dog in an off-lease park; yes you are free in a sense but you're still not in total control of your experience.To further add the sensation of "freedom with boundaries", Far Cry 3's story is very restrictive in comparison with the exploration. During a mission you are forced to use this one specific weapon, drive this one specific vehicle, do this objective in precisely this particular way, go here within the alloted time; the list goes on. Adding unpredictable restrictions to the story makes the player feel like a ball and chain has been shackled to their ankle, which does no favors to the overall experience of the game. However, when you are allowed to play your way, Far Cry 3 really shines through. Plotting out ambushes on fortified outposts or joyriding across the island running over whatever gets in your way is a blast through-and-through, made even better by a large variety of destructive weaponry ranging from grenade launchers, RPGs and even flamethrowers. The story of Far Cry 3 is simple, you take on the role of Jason Brody, a rich white boy who loves hair product. While you and your friends are on a drunken binge in exotic places you're all kidnapped by a band of pirates looking to ransom you and then sell you off to slavery. Jason manages to escape and begins his adventure to rescue his friends and kill the bad guy and get the girl. To be frank, the story isn't all that great. Jason Brody and all his friends are shallow and dislikeable, and I'd much rather shoot them all in the mouth than risk my life to save them. In contrast, antagonists in the game are interesting and imaginative and save Far Cry 3's story from being dullard. Vaas Montenegro, the most well established villian is similar to the Joker from Batman: Arkham Asylum, he's psychotic, unpredictable, imaginative and fun to watch. Far Cry 3's combat is split into two categories: Stealth and shoot-em-up, and both are well-made and flow well into eachother as the situation requires. Jumping into foliage when not in combat makes it so enemies cannot see you, allowing you to plan out your attacks or to play venus fly trap and lure them to you by throwing rocks before jumping out and puncturing them with a knife takedown. The takedowns are a very satisfying insta-kill against unarmored enemies (and can be used against heavy foes later in the game after acquiring a perk) so long as you take them by suprise, and with unlockable perks takedowns become even more versatile and deadly by either pulling the pin off a grenade of the freshly deceased or going for multi chain stabs. On the other side of the combat spectrum the guns and shooting mechanics are satisfying and have a good healthy punch to them. Unfortunately the combat indulges in one of video game design's bad habits, Quick-Time Events, prominently when fighting carniferous wildlife like aligators and sharks. You're swimming across a river when SURPRISE GATOR SEX comes up, then you're given half a second to mash a specific button before you die. QTEs are a bad mechanic in video games and while they're not too prominent in Far Cry 3 they still feel unecessary on the whole. Finally the worst part of the combat is the battles against the main antagonists like Vaas or Buck, both of them being such hostile albeit savourably enjoyable characters you'd think the fight would be memorable, right? Wrong. When fighting them the game designers decide to put you and your foe into a sort of drug-trip combat sequence that makes no sense and is incongruious to the rest of the game, followed by a series of QTEs taking control away from you for the sake of trying to make the encounter more cinematic. This resulted in final struggles that were disappointing and left a very sour aftertaste. So in all, Far Cry 3 is a game with flaws, but they don't drag it all the way down. Far Cry 3 is fun, addicting and worth the time (especially if you got it while it's on sale). I suggest you look past it's flaws and let the overall experience take you in.Also before I close off I need to mention: Far Cry 3 also has an online multiplayer, which only exists for the purpose of having an online multiplayer. It's unimaginative deathmatch and is not anything special.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Heard very good things. Played first mission. Exploration restriction made me question open world. Got bored. Thought FC3 kinda sucked. Stopped playing.-Months later-Friends bashed me for hating and assured me open world after first mission, so I gave FC3 a second chance, and god thank goodness that I did. I've put in over 50 hours in the past month playing this damn game every day until late at night.The character development is outstanding. Far Cry 3 will mess with your mind as you play as Jason Brody, losing yourself to the wilderness and insanity of the jungle that has one rule and one rule only - kill or be killed.Gameplay is smooth, interactions with the wildlife is vast and extensive (hunting, crafting, climbing vines and towers, harvesting plants, etc.), stealth is amazing, weapons are super fun (knife throwing, flamethrowers, recurve bow, snipers, etc.), additions are wonderful (hang gliding, exploring ruins, collecting artifacts, playing poker, sharpshooting, rakyat challenges, etc.), and so so much more asldkfj The main storyline is stunning and intense, and the side missions indulge you in the stories of the local villages. God, this game. I've never played a game quite like FC3. It's like Skyrim and Fallout 3/NV with a more involved story that will trip you up and make you question your own life. This game has got everything. Even strippers. This game has strippers. 10/10But seriously, this game is as fun, astounding, and riveting as the trailer makes it to be.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												A gorgeous game, sandbox-ish game where you are a jungle warrior instead of just having a vacation.I say sandbox-ish, because while you can do other missions and activities than the main story, it feels like it's not that much that you can do and half of it feels the same. That said, this game is certainly not bad. Actually, it's really good.The story goes where your friends, brothers and you go on an exotic, adventurous vacation. What they didn't saw coming was that you all would be captured by swashbuckling pirates who want to sell you for ransom money. That is certainly not what the brochure said...You manage to escape and you have to find and safe your friends and brother.All in all, it's pretty good but it has some flaws of which mostly: Character Progression.The game starts as you, scared and unexperienced. Never killed a man before but the moment you get a weapon in your hands, the main character goes pretty much berserk. While it is understandable that you can't limit the skills of the player, the story doesn't make this progression better and soon you will be the Berserker Warlord of the Jungle.It has potential but it goes just a bit too fast to believe it.Gameplay feels smooth and feels right. From the firefights to the stealth, nothing to really complain there.There really is a bunch to do and terrain to see and it looks damn good.The biggest problem I had with Far Cry 3 is that the Field of View returns to default in cutscenes, making it look like every character is invading your personal space.All in all, a beautiful game with a name story and lots of things to do!

Far Cry 3 was by far my favorite Far Cry game to dateI Played through Far Cry 1, 2 times and loved it, I haven't played much of Far Cry 2 yet.Though I was hoping for a sequal to Far Cry 1 but there was no Trigens to be found but oh well cant have everything right :( StoryThe Storyline was very engaging and the pacing was good. There are some moments when it can start to feel repetitive like getting to the top of each Radio Tower but that's a small detail that can be overlooked. There's lots of side missions to do some unlockable some DLC but all are well worth it and help to extend the gameplay for a few extra hours. If your only interested in the campaign you can just play through it and move on but if you prefer the open world exploration element theres TONS of chests, locations, artifacts, tasks and missions to do to get extra cash and provide you with more play time. CO-OPThere's also a 4 player Co-op campaign which though its not as good as the main campaign its good fun with friends and has some head to head challenges to add a bit of competitiveness to the mix. MultplayerMultiplayer is nothing special, try it out maybe but.... eh9.2/10- My Favorite Far Cry game. 91 hours well spent

Good variety of weapons and ways to play. 8/10

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Great FPS, decent and interesting story (hard to come by these days), great realism.  Has an AK that feels as powerful as the one in real life. Lots of sandbox aspects that make the replayability pretty good.  Choose your own approach to your enemies. Lots of mini-games and mini-quests to spice things up and keep it interesting.  Same as far-cry 1 and 2 really, big island with lots of uncharted territory that you seek to destroy and control.  Unlike facry2, guard posts do not respawn and once you control a zone of the map your allies patrol it instead of the enemy. Read in a review that you can't save the game manually, that it only autosaves, but this isn't true, you can press ESC>Save to save at any time. Don't know what all the complaining is about with Uplay, it hasn't given me any problems whatsoever.  Yes you have to register and log in with Uplay but that's pretty much all you have to do.  Then it's just play and don't worry about it.  It gave me some concern about this purchase but I suspected it was just trendy little sheeple regurgitating things that they say to one another, and I was right. Good deal, especially at $8.  Would recommend.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
Far Cry 3 was by far my favorite Far Cry game to dateI Played through Far Cry 1, 2 times and loved it, I haven't played much of Far Cry 2 yet.Though I was hoping for a sequal to Far Cry 1 but there was no Trigens to be found but oh well cant have everything right :( StoryThe Storyline was very engaging and the pacing was good. There are some moments when it can start to feel repetitive like getting to the top of each Radio Tower but that's a small detail that can be overlooked. There's lots of side missions to do some unlockable some DLC but all are well worth it and help to extend the gameplay for a few extra hours. If your only interested in the campaign you can just play through it and move on but if you prefer the open world exploration element theres TONS of chests, locations, artifacts, tasks and missions to do to get extra cash and provide you with more play time. CO-OPThere's also a 4 player Co-op campaign which though its not as good as the main campaign its good fun with friends and has some head to head challenges to add a bit of competitiveness to the mix. MultplayerMultiplayer is nothing special, try it out maybe but.... eh9.2/10- My Favorite Far Cry game. 91 hours well spent

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												I'd highly recommend getting this game. Especially if you're a lover of action and surprises, because that's what Far Cry 3 is all about.Throughout the game you can choose to either be a stealthy killer by adding suppressors, laser sights to your guns or even using a bow. Or you be like a tank and just shoot everything that gets in your way with every big, powerful gun you can get your hands on. The map is really big and has so many new places and things to discover. Invade enemy bases and take them out to claim it to yourself and your people or just go hunting and collect animal skin to craft new weapon holsters or backpacks. And then there's the story line. I'll try not to spoil anything on this one. It has many plots and twists in it, many unexpected scenes which you may wish didn't happen but sometimes you could've prevented it to happen, because at some points you can choose your own destiny. The story also shows us how adrenaline and power changes people.. Or should I say, person? The main character encounters so many new experiences that he has never even thought of before, which leaves a great impact on his mind and makes him want to stay where he is instead of trying to get back home with his friends and family, because he believes that he belongs there now and he needs to finish what he started.All in all, I'd say it's definitely on my Top20 best games list, not to mention the awesome, atmospherical graphics.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Far Cry 3 is an entirely open world FPS that offers massive amounts of exploration, collectibles, missions and other features like weapons. The single player campaign is great although the main protagonist is entirely hit or miss as far as personality will go. The side missions in the main game are unfortunately quite emotionless, although the DLC side missions are actually good. The multiplayer was glitchy at launch and never picked up and is mostly an afterthought now. The game also has a following on the nexus modding community so be sure to check out the interesting mods!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												This is a great open world FPS with an engaging story and fantastic visuals. I found playing this with the controller to be a more enjoyable experience as a lot of the controls are clearly designed for use with the 360 pad. Especially the jumping stealth kills. Unlike many FPS games your character actually speaks and engages with the NPC's and environment which I find makes the game much more immersive. The game features a light RPG element with skill levelling, inventory management and crafting. All of which are done very well and don't feel tacked on or an afterthought.I have played this game through to completion, my only gripe would be that towards the end taking the final few enemy encampments and towers did feel like a bit of a chore. Early in the game it was all great fun but 30+ hours it does feel a bit like... not another flippin outpost!Overall I would class this game as a must play for FPS fans, it's a corker!

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
Far Cry 3Assassin's Creed with gunsSo is it good? Yes. Is it great? Well, that depends on what you want. I enjoyed the "story" or rather the awesome characters, acting and voice acting in this game A LOT. It is simply really well made, I cannot remember a "better" antagonist in any recent or even not so recent game that I have played.The gunplay and graphics are awesome, the game feels very smooth.But there are downsides. The beautiful landscape is not filled as well as it could be in my opinion. Sidequest and especially collectibles are repetitive and grindy to the point that they are annoying and boring.Another part of the game - namely liberating outposts - is immense fun, while other freeroaming aspects did not quite entertain me as much. Especially hunting. Fun for a short while, but after that it is just a grind and then it is suddenly useless.I am not a huge fan of sandbox games and unlike Assassin's Creed with the nice fighting system, there is simply a lack of challenge when shooting the mildly insane AI. What I also missed was decent music. Especially in a caribean setting like this I would like to hear some more reggae outside of missions (don't get me started on the car radios).All in all I enjoyed this game a lot, but I would suggest focusing on the main story line and stealthily liberating outposts (for fun).#Ghost

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Heard very good things. Played first mission. Exploration restriction made me question open world. Got bored. Thought FC3 kinda sucked. Stopped playing.-Months later-Friends bashed me for hating and assured me open world after first mission, so I gave FC3 a second chance, and god thank goodness that I did. I've put in over 50 hours in the past month playing this damn game every day until late at night.The character development is outstanding. Far Cry 3 will mess with your mind as you play as Jason Brody, losing yourself to the wilderness and insanity of the jungle that has one rule and one rule only - kill or be killed.Gameplay is smooth, interactions with the wildlife is vast and extensive (hunting, crafting, climbing vines and towers, harvesting plants, etc.), stealth is amazing, weapons are super fun (knife throwing, flamethrowers, recurve bow, snipers, etc.), additions are wonderful (hang gliding, exploring ruins, collecting artifacts, playing poker, sharpshooting, rakyat challenges, etc.), and so so much more asldkfj The main storyline is stunning and intense, and the side missions indulge you in the stories of the local villages. God, this game. I've never played a game quite like FC3. It's like Skyrim and Fallout 3/NV with a more involved story that will trip you up and make you question your own life. This game has got everything. Even strippers. This game has strippers. 10/10But seriously, this game is as fun, astounding, and riveting as the trailer makes it to be.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Worth it. Bought this one on sale, usually the only time I can afford games, but starting to see that original price still would have been worth it. Gameplay is solid, the open environment opens up several playing styles for you to complete different missions, or just explore the map slaughtering endangered wildlife at every turn purely for the sake of more useful attire (really, I just murdered two sharks for a wallet). The game incorporates most successful traits from most of the sandbox genre, roaming wildlife, dangerous vistas, strangly hard to kill tigers, vehicles to make getting around the map easier and for the truly lazy; fast travel. Now that it's been out a while and the price has come down, definitely a title for anyone interested in shooters but hates being restricted to linear map progression.All that said, ♥♥♥♥ Uplay. The game demands to be run through a different platform called Uplay. On first opening the game you are required to create a new accound and verify the key, not so bad. Unfortunatly the game continuously syncs online files, and promts in game menu new from the developers. I don't know if its the platform itself or the game but it seems to crash 1/5 times using fast travel, which is rather inconvenient if you just spent twenty minutes hunting bears and fighting off komodo dragons. Still the game is fun. The developers put in a good effort and as far as core gameplay, this has some of the best.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												+/+ Great sense of progression.+/+ Excellent gameplay.+/+ Fun environment.+/+ Nice graphics/sound.+/+ Nice choice for upgrades.+/+ Hunting wildlife for upgrades is an excellent and immersive feature.+/+ Solid enemy and animal A.I.+/- Mediocre story.+/- Voice acting varies from good to poor.+/- Gameplay outlasts the sense of progression and leveling.  In other words, it could use additional upgrades for character and guns for the late game.+/- Hunting is mostly finished by mid-game.  Would have been nice to see the feature continued (such as having some required animals on the second island.)-/- UPlay required to play.-/- Weak protagonist.-/- Not a very difficult game.-/- Missing steam features such as achievements or cloud.Overall: 9/10.  While not perfect, Far Cry 3 is still a great game that I would highly recommend.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Kinda bummed about all of these bad reviews....I am so far enjoying this game.....I really enjoy the crafting/open world/and combat elements. Pretty amazing graphics. Love the different kinds of combat def doesn't make you stick to just stealth mode or agressive (enjoy having the choice). Tons of side missions to do but the story line is pretty great in general. I enjoy the survival aspect of it with the wild animals too.  So much fun loot and weapons!! And an insane amount of vehicles. Makes me feel like a kid in a candy shop. :) A lot of the negative feedback prevented me from paying any interest but I am glad I finally bought it. content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												Of all my 72 hours and 4 complete playthroughs so far - not one has been boring, dull, or not played to its full. Seriously, other open-world games do not even come close to this, yeah, GTA is the most popular because of its diversity and gameplay, but the survival and adventure feel of Far Cry 3 tops most other gaming experiences I've ever had. In my opinion with the gameplay and emotion that comes with this game, I can totally forgive every single one of its small bugs and occasional mishaps. If you have the money, don't hesitate for a second to buy this game. And if you don't, save your money, this is an experience you'll never forget.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												I stayed up until 5 AM liberating the top half of the map from pirates, weaving in and out of the jungle like a Navy Seal gone AWOL. That is fun. Pure adrenaline-pumping fun. The best story mission in the game is where you have to destroy pirate-controlled drug fields with a flamethrower. I felt like a kid on Christmas morning as I set pirates and plants ablaze, in a maniacal frenzy.Hunting is pretty easy when animals regularly pop out of Jason's anal cavity. Watching the same looting / harvesting / skinning animations play hundreds of times is not fun. Neither is playing pointless minigames, like poker (cash is easy to come by, don't waste your time). The supply drop missions were fun for the first couple of times, but they ultimately didn't stand up to repetition.The story is a loose deconstruction of Hollywood action flicks and club culture. Jason is a funny and sympathetic character, and so is the rest of the cast, especially Vaas. I got from start to finish without any complaint about the story, so that's an achievement.I won't be returning to Rook Island for quite some time due to the game's repetitive nature, but there are a handful of brilliant moments among the monotony. Just make sure to use a mouse and keyboard.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Far Cry 3 succeeds like its predecessors in providing an open world action / thriller set in a tropical climate.  Like similar games such as GTA and Batman: AC, the current objective is shown on the map... there are side missions and mini-games that can be unlocked and played at will.  Portions of the map details are hidden until radio towers are "unlocked" by scaling them and sabotaging the fuse box.  Weapons and skills are steadily unlocked as progress is made in both the main story line, collecting hidden treasures, and completing various other tasks.  Thrown in for good measure are hunting and crafting, and a completely separate and very challenging co-op campaign.On the plus side:> The world is beautiful and nicely detailed.> The story is quite good and features one of the best antagonists in any video game I have ever played.> The weapons look, feel, and sound excellent.> The stronghold raids and "kill nasty dude x" side missions are the meat of the game and very entertaining, with many ways to approach them> The takedown skills are challenging to apply and fun when they work.> An excellent PC port with all the graphical and control flourish we expect.On the negative side:> The game ramps up too quickly... I found myself proceeding at a reasonable pace, and by act 2 I was becoming overpowered... this along with another mechanic in act 2 makes the second act seem anti-climactic.> On the same vein, the first act Boss feels more threatening than the second.  He also was such a good character I was disappointed that he was dead.  Can he have his own game, please?> The native peoples character models are too similar.> The world does not feel "lived in"... it feels more like an action game set piece.  There is also very little variation in the game world.> There is very little incentive to continue exploring after the game ends.The co-op campaign is very difficult... you will want at least 3 players for that.  I bought the game on sale on steam for $5... was it worth it? Yes absolutely.  I would say $20 is reasonable for this since I got nearly 40 hours of entertainment out of it.8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												I finally bought this during the 2014 holiday sale. I'm playing the hell out of Far Cry 3 and really enjoying it, but holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ it's completely indefensible. A real shame, because the game is really fun and well designed.Problematic themes and depictions include:A raging case of Last Samurai Syndrome. A white man comes to an exotic foreign world and is quickly adopted by the oppressed natives not only into their culture but as their savior, despite the fact that he knows nothing about their environment and has no applicable skills. We're supposedly a tribe of island warriors who've been living here since time immemorial but only you can save us, scrawny Californian douchebro who's never handled a gun before!As such, the Rakyat can't do anything for themselves. Only Whitey Samurai has any kind of power in deciding how the Rakyat fight for freedom. After the heroic white boy singlehandedly liberates an enemy outpost, a half dozen Rakyat warriors show up in jeeps to secure his conquest, AK47s at the ready, but they're only there for atmosphere. They're unable to take outposts themselves or even help the hero out. I know that having the player be the only being in the world with agency is a convention of open world games going back farther than GTA, but it's pretty ♥♥♥♥ed that these people literally have to wait around for the white hero to save them.Citra. The spiritual leader of the Rakyat is a colonial fantasy straight out of Victorian pulp fiction, the hypersexual female native drawn to the white savior, despite being surrounded at all times by hunky warriors from her own culture. Weirdly, she doesn't even look like she's the same ethnicity as the other Rakyat, who are supposedly... Polynesian? (The game never says exactly where Rook Island is.) Citra is ethnically unplaceable, and definitely has more "caucasian" features than the rest of her people, presumably to maximize her sexual appeal to the game's target demographic. Also, the warrior initiation ceremony of the Rakyat involves Citra straddling you while topless and grinding on your junk. Whoops, that was a spoiler, sorry.Dennis. At the beginning of the story, the white hero is rescued and guided by a magical negro witch doctor. Dennis has been adopted by the Rakyat years before, but is not worthy to be their savior himself. He can only assist our white hero, despite being depicted as much more competent and experienced.There are two enemy factions, the savage bloodthirsty "Pirates" and the professional mercenary "Privateers". The disorganized and drug-addled Pirates are all Afro-Caribbean, while the much more competent Privateers are (mostly white) Americans.The main bad guy is a white South African who is of course depicted as a genocidal monster. Poor Afrikaners, no other ethnic group is so easy to demonize in video games and action movies. It's not their fault that their accent makes them all sound like Bond villains.In conclusion, buy it cheap during a Steam sale, enjoy exploring the gorgeous world, the awesome stealth killing mechanics, and the wide variety of customizable guns, and shake your head at the tone-deaf racism.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												I enjoyed Far Cry 3 more than I've enjoyed almost any game for a long, long time.I don't care how dumb the story is (it's not, but that was apparently a fluke), it's internally consistent enough to be coherent and convincing while being vague and last minute enough in other places to be totally compelling and mysterious, like Lost was before Damon Lindelof realised viewers were way smarter than he'd ever given them credit for and his insistence that this wasn't a case painted him into a cringe-inducing corner.I digress.Far Cry 3 is really, really good and interesting and fun. The island is beautiful, the wildlife is interesting, the fire system is more or less intact from the otherwise terrible Far Cry 2 SO THAT'S GOOD and the music is some of my favourite in a long, long time. There's an overwhelming amount of things to see and do, thanks to the scattershot 'world map full of activity markers' Ubisoft school of design, and almost all of it is really fun and usually quite a diversion from the 'routine' gameplay.But nothing in Far Cry 3 is routine. Everything kind of feels special and exciting. If you liked Far Cry or The Beach or Lost or Arrow then you should definitely give Far Cry 3 a try. You probably should anyway.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Overall Far Cry 3 is a very solid First Person Shooter game. It has a very intense story that makes you want to finish the game from start to end without stopping. To note this is the first Far Cry game I have FINISHED. I could never finish the previous Far Cry games for many reasons. That being said this game in the series was very enjoyable to me. As you can see the game took me no more than 13ish hours to beat, doing some side missions and other little challenges in the game. It is a fairly easy game to get through compared to the other Far Cry games. One gameplay mechanic I really enjoyed was the stealth. It was top notch fun sneaking around taking people down with brutal machete kills. The skill system works very well with the game too. I never once felt underpowered in fact the way the game progresses you feel weak at the beginning, but towards the end of the game you are a bonafide killing machine. The story like I said was very entertaining, playing out like a classic hollywood revenge film. You play as Jason Brody a man who decides to go on a getaway vacation to a mysterious island. Things go south and your friends get captured, leaving it up to you to save them. The game has great character development showing how Jason must learn to adapt to the situation at hand and become a ruthless killer in order to save his friends. The game does feature 2 different endings each one being very different from the other. The endings were the only thing that made the game a little negative for me. Without spoiling much one of the endings is very empty meaning it feels as if it was rushed and things needed to be futher explained. Other than that it is a great single player experience. I have yet to play multiplayer. As far as technical aspects the game ran very smoothly never dropping its frame rate or crashing. I had a good experience with UPlay too. This is definitely the right step in the Far Cry series and I am now looking forward to Far Cry 4.9/10- TLDR Great game with awesome gameplay mechanics and a solid story. Looking forward to Far Cry 4!

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Far Cry 3 is an open world, first person shooter game that takes FPS games to the next level. For quite an old game it doesnt look half bad, bright coloured grass and wildlife give the area a sense of tropicality and the textures, models and sounds are amazing. Three of Far Cry 3's biggest and best features are the range of weapons, the choices you can make while completing normal tasks and the characters. On rook Island there are a massive range of weapons, including Rifles, Snipers, Bows, Rocket Launchers, Grenade Launchers, Flame Throwers and many, many more. These weapons each have the normal upgrades like bigger magazine, silencer and many more. These attachments let you be creative in killing; when overtaking outposts you can be sneaky with a bow and a silenced AK-47 taking out enemies with these weapons and skills, including creative takedowns, or you can go in guns-blazing with a grenade launcher, Machine Gun and explosive arrows. And Finally, despite the main characters weak and funny (in a bad way) personality, the other characters are really entreging. Sadly these characters seem to disapeer, or get taken out of the spotlight as soon as you meet them and start to like them. Thank Fully that is the only downside, your stuck with annoying characters and sadly your favourite characters are even killed or not seen a lot after an hour or two.Overall this is one of the best pc games I have ever played and I recomend it to anyone who has a pc and £15.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												I finally bought this during the 2014 holiday sale. I'm playing the hell out of Far Cry 3 and really enjoying it, but holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ it's completely indefensible. A real shame, because the game is really fun and well designed.Problematic themes and depictions include:A raging case of Last Samurai Syndrome. A white man comes to an exotic foreign world and is quickly adopted by the oppressed natives not only into their culture but as their savior, despite the fact that he knows nothing about their environment and has no applicable skills. We're supposedly a tribe of island warriors who've been living here since time immemorial but only you can save us, scrawny Californian douchebro who's never handled a gun before!As such, the Rakyat can't do anything for themselves. Only Whitey Samurai has any kind of power in deciding how the Rakyat fight for freedom. After the heroic white boy singlehandedly liberates an enemy outpost, a half dozen Rakyat warriors show up in jeeps to secure his conquest, AK47s at the ready, but they're only there for atmosphere. They're unable to take outposts themselves or even help the hero out. I know that having the player be the only being in the world with agency is a convention of open world games going back farther than GTA, but it's pretty ♥♥♥♥ed that these people literally have to wait around for the white hero to save them.Citra. The spiritual leader of the Rakyat is a colonial fantasy straight out of Victorian pulp fiction, the hypersexual female native drawn to the white savior, despite being surrounded at all times by hunky warriors from her own culture. Weirdly, she doesn't even look like she's the same ethnicity as the other Rakyat, who are supposedly... Polynesian? (The game never says exactly where Rook Island is.) Citra is ethnically unplaceable, and definitely has more "caucasian" features than the rest of her people, presumably to maximize her sexual appeal to the game's target demographic. Also, the warrior initiation ceremony of the Rakyat involves Citra straddling you while topless and grinding on your junk. Whoops, that was a spoiler, sorry.Dennis. At the beginning of the story, the white hero is rescued and guided by a magical negro witch doctor. Dennis has been adopted by the Rakyat years before, but is not worthy to be their savior himself. He can only assist our white hero, despite being depicted as much more competent and experienced.There are two enemy factions, the savage bloodthirsty "Pirates" and the professional mercenary "Privateers". The disorganized and drug-addled Pirates are all Afro-Caribbean, while the much more competent Privateers are (mostly white) Americans.The main bad guy is a white South African who is of course depicted as a genocidal monster. Poor Afrikaners, no other ethnic group is so easy to demonize in video games and action movies. It's not their fault that their accent makes them all sound like Bond villains.In conclusion, buy it cheap during a Steam sale, enjoy exploring the gorgeous world, the awesome stealth killing mechanics, and the wide variety of customizable guns, and shake your head at the tone-deaf racism.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Got to say Far Cry 3 is a brilliant package. Visually it's one of the most gorgeous games I've played so far. The tropical island is lush, appropriately has wild life here and there but not oversaturating the islands. Shooting and the hide and stabbing work satisfyingly well. Compared to Far Cry 2 the game has much more substance. There's much more to do in the open world and it doesn't feel so empty. Plus the driving, which actually in 3 is much more optional than in 2, has much more weight and is through that more enjoyable. There's a lot of good writing in characters, especially in the "evil" ones. But I suppose like with every open world game there comes the sense of repetition eventually. Focusing doing too many side quests and other side activities might make you a little bored after a while.I really didn't have any problems technically despite maybe a crash that happened once during the 18-hour playthrough but that's just really minor. If you've got the specs on your machine to run this game and you do enjoy a bit of open world FPS, can't say you're going wrong by buying and playing Far Cry 3. Unlike Far Cry 2 it's totally worth your time. It's a sweet piece of... smooth jungle beauty.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												+/+ Great sense of progression.+/+ Excellent gameplay.+/+ Fun environment.+/+ Nice graphics/sound.+/+ Nice choice for upgrades.+/+ Hunting wildlife for upgrades is an excellent and immersive feature.+/+ Solid enemy and animal A.I.+/- Mediocre story.+/- Voice acting varies from good to poor.+/- Gameplay outlasts the sense of progression and leveling.  In other words, it could use additional upgrades for character and guns for the late game.+/- Hunting is mostly finished by mid-game.  Would have been nice to see the feature continued (such as having some required animals on the second island.)-/- UPlay required to play.-/- Weak protagonist.-/- Not a very difficult game.-/- Missing steam features such as achievements or cloud.Overall: 9/10.  While not perfect, Far Cry 3 is still a great game that I would highly recommend.

It is very much Skyrim with guns. It was very much an enjoyable use of my time.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Overall Far Cry 3 is a very solid First Person Shooter game. It has a very intense story that makes you want to finish the game from start to end without stopping. To note this is the first Far Cry game I have FINISHED. I could never finish the previous Far Cry games for many reasons. That being said this game in the series was very enjoyable to me. As you can see the game took me no more than 13ish hours to beat, doing some side missions and other little challenges in the game. It is a fairly easy game to get through compared to the other Far Cry games. One gameplay mechanic I really enjoyed was the stealth. It was top notch fun sneaking around taking people down with brutal machete kills. The skill system works very well with the game too. I never once felt underpowered in fact the way the game progresses you feel weak at the beginning, but towards the end of the game you are a bonafide killing machine. The story like I said was very entertaining, playing out like a classic hollywood revenge film. You play as Jason Brody a man who decides to go on a getaway vacation to a mysterious island. Things go south and your friends get captured, leaving it up to you to save them. The game has great character development showing how Jason must learn to adapt to the situation at hand and become a ruthless killer in order to save his friends. The game does feature 2 different endings each one being very different from the other. The endings were the only thing that made the game a little negative for me. Without spoiling much one of the endings is very empty meaning it feels as if it was rushed and things needed to be futher explained. Other than that it is a great single player experience. I have yet to play multiplayer. As far as technical aspects the game ran very smoothly never dropping its frame rate or crashing. I had a good experience with UPlay too. This is definitely the right step in the Far Cry series and I am now looking forward to Far Cry 4.9/10- TLDR Great game with awesome gameplay mechanics and a solid story. Looking forward to Far Cry 4!

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												I've been a Far Cry fan since the first one came out for the PC and I consider that one to be one of best shooters of all time. The Xbox versions were also great so I was really stoked for Far Cry 2. I have to say I was very dissapointed with that entry in the franchise. The idea for it was great but it suffered from some minor but crucial flaws mainly due to the whole open world scheme, which didn't work so well in my opinion, in a franchise that established itself as being a great straightforward (but strategic) FPS.So, as you would guess, when I heard Far Cry 3 was keeping the same formula was the previous one, I didn't get very excited for it. I tried it out for just thirty minutes and thank god I was wrong. Everything about this game is great. Puts together the over the top action of the first games with a more refined open world aproach of Far Cry 2. This game works well in so many ways. Even when you finish all the main and secundary missions you will be wanting for more. And the game will definitely give you more of what you want. As you can tell, I didn't go alot into detail on this review, but there's no need for it. Trust me, play it. It goes down for as one of the best, if not the best, games of 2012.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2013
												Far Cry 3 is two games.The first 2/3 of it is an open world first person shooter that lets you control the pace. You can go hunting for wild animals, attack enemy bases, and tackle the vast majority of the missions in any way you want, whether that's via stealth or dudebroing it up, or whatever. It really is exceptionally good fun!The last 1/3 is just... well... it's linear, it's boring, it's Call of Duty-esque gunsplosions, i.e. gameplay is driven by linear environments with checkpoints, and progress is through attrition rather than player ingenuity. All of these are symptoms of a game that has lost its way towards the end, or christ, even had another team entirely working on it.Sure you *can* still explore the open world in the last third, but the impetus and momentum at this point is on beating the game rather than unlocking♥♥♥♥♥♥ since doing it is for its own sake at that point (earlier on in the game, side missions are to get XP to strengthen your character in order to tackle the tough story missions). The game even acknowledges this by raining ammo packs and body armour down on you at the end of each story mission at this point so you don't have to spend time going to restock.Couple this with a predictable plot, lame characters and a rather binary sense of morality, and Far Cry 3 is an okay, if not amazing, product. I can recommend it, since I felt compelled to finish it, but be warned: the last third of the game is really lame whereas the first two thirds are really quite good. Just be sure to get the game when it's cheap.6/10

content:

												Far Cry 3 is another incredible game in its series. With stunning graphics and an immersive story which really makes you feel one with the game.It's also very well optimized, meaning random FPS drops are almost never if not at all.The multiplayer is rather empty now, and the Co-op doesn't live up to the single player campaign. But the games you do find are always fun and guarnteed to be worth it.The campaign's pure length is more than enough to make up for the lacking multiplayer...And is easily replayable and enjoyanle.Moving on. Some none essential characters during cutscenes have slightly poor sound and animation. But it really should not be something to put you off the game.I would more than recommend this game to people with a good gaming rig. My nVidia GTX 660 plays Far Cry 3 on ultra very well, and the regions of a 640-650 should be able to run it on medium-high settings at decent framerates.

												Far Cry 3 is a great game. The island is really a living place and you can spend a good amount of time by traveling in some car or hunting some animals. By the way, this is the best game to use a bow, I really enjoyed use it during all the game, the gameplay is fantastic.It has some great music, sound effects and voice acting but the story could be much better, but it is almost ok. You start trying to save your friends but after some point later in the game I completely forgot about them (and I feel bad for saying it, LOL), but I was having too much fun playing around in the island, going to new towers and hunting new animals between the missions... Well, what can I do?On the other hand, Vaas is a great and unique character, unfortunatelly the others aren't that interesting as him (except one soldier in later game...), every time you encounter him is very cool (and crazy).After all that I went to co-op, which is a very linear and short storyline, but is fun and works great. In every mission you will face some sort of competition with your friends (sniper, jet ski, rpgs, buggies, ...) and that makes it even more fun and a lot less repetitive.
