content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												I finished the game and after some time reflecting this is my review:Pros:- Gameplay was fun overall;- Nice graphics;- Hunting was intense, fun and rewarding (without potions);- If you are the type of player that likes to play stealth  you'll get rewarded (with extra XP);- The characters were in "place", they represent well what they were suppose to do;- Charismatic Villain ( Vaas);- Some fun side quests;- Large area to explore;- Treasure/ cards hunting ( they reward you with gold, lore and special weapons);- Mini puzzles to get to the top of the towers;- Nice Co-op;- Took me 25 hours to complete on normal and i didn't collect all the stuff and neither unlocked all the outpost/ towers.Cons:- Boring protagonist, pretty clichê (if you ask me);- The characters speak in combat therefore you'll miss what they are saying because you're focusing on the combat and you can't even "replay" or have a "quest jornal";- The story is confusing, and doesn't give much answers ( there is a interesting "Symmetry Theory" on youtube that can help you out), but still we dont know if thats the truth;- You can get all the upgrates from hunting on the first island;- After Vaas died the story became pretty boring and a "standard shooting game".- Hoyt was pretty hyped at the beggining of the game but we saw pretty much nothing of him;- On the second island you can just fast travel next to the main missions without unlocking any outpost/tower;- The missions were harder as the game goes on but even if you died you came back with the progress that you had unlocked, like that mission that you and Sam had to destroy 5 fuel depots, you destroyed 2 and died and came back with 2 already destroyed instead of totaly restarted;  - Uplay can be a pain for some players;I  give it an 8,5/10I liked the experience of the game and I think you wont regreat buying it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												A well produced and beautiful piece of work, made by ubisoft. As far as thee other far crys go, i think this one is way better then previous far cry's. this game is one that takes beauty and action and merges it into one that creates a world like no other. This game makes the player feel immersed, like they are actually there themself, hence with astonishing animations for whatever you do, whether it be climbing into a car, or even diving into the sea, with every action there is a animation. Thus with factors such as that, it makes the game even more fun to play and addiciting. i know this because i always smile when i do something within the game, from flying wingsuits(spoiler) to ziplining and shooting komodo dragons, this game makes me wanna play it more and more until my eyes are bloodshot(not that i would actually do that). And in terms of graphics, i am comepletly speechless. When i first left the camp, i immediatley ran and climbed the first hill i saw, and just watched in astonishment, of how beautful the island was and everything on and around it, everything was detailed, from trees to buildings, to even 1 leaf that was on the ground beside me. The whole world was just immaculate, and i just couldn't get enough it, most of my time on the game was just exploring and staring at the beauty of the islands lush nature and jungles. Plus don't get me started the water, as that was definitley a highlight in this game(for me anyway). but anyways, if you're wanting to know what te rest of the game is like, then i can assure you(well most of you) that this game is a must see for yourself to believe. the campaign was great, there were some parts that were abit confusing and dissapointing, but however that did not stop me from continueing on. This game is fun filled with lots of action, drama, comedy, and even some emotional and loving scenes(talking about the campaign and the world mostly). But yes, enough of me blabbing about my thoughts, just get the game and be prepared to be amazed. :DDDDDD peace guys x

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
Far Cry 3Assassin's Creed with gunsSo is it good? Yes. Is it great? Well, that depends on what you want. I enjoyed the "story" or rather the awesome characters, acting and voice acting in this game A LOT. It is simply really well made, I cannot remember a "better" antagonist in any recent or even not so recent game that I have played.The gunplay and graphics are awesome, the game feels very smooth.But there are downsides. The beautiful landscape is not filled as well as it could be in my opinion. Sidequest and especially collectibles are repetitive and grindy to the point that they are annoying and boring.Another part of the game - namely liberating outposts - is immense fun, while other freeroaming aspects did not quite entertain me as much. Especially hunting. Fun for a short while, but after that it is just a grind and then it is suddenly useless.I am not a huge fan of sandbox games and unlike Assassin's Creed with the nice fighting system, there is simply a lack of challenge when shooting the mildly insane AI. What I also missed was decent music. Especially in a caribean setting like this I would like to hear some more reggae outside of missions (don't get me started on the car radios).All in all I enjoyed this game a lot, but I would suggest focusing on the main story line and stealthily liberating outposts (for fun).#Ghost

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
Far Cry 3 ReviewStory: 17/20At all, the story of Far Cry 3 is pretty nice and you can have a lot of fun over the time. It's a long and well developed Story. You will take something like 25-30 Hours to play the whole Story and you won't get bored. Characters: 17/20I really like the Characters of the Game, the attributes of them are really well developed and i like them pretty much. World: 20/20The game has a huge open world, that offers a lot of things around the story: Extra-missions, taking over outposts & collecting relics, to name a few. So it can't get boringControls + Gameplay: 17/20The controls are just like in the other games, but the weapon selection layout is not really great. The gameplay is very open, you can do whatever you want, as long as you complete your Mission. You can either shot everything down or go stealth and kill them one by one, without getting noticed.Graphics: 19/20The Graphics are great. They really fit into the game and you can take a few nice Screenshots, if you want to.Overall: 89/100In my opinion, it's a must have for FPS/Adventure fans.Cheers!

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												With the (at the time of writing) recent release of Far Cry 4 I think the best way to sum up Far Cry 3 is “Still entirely relevant”Far Cry 3 is a beautiful game and an absolute joy to play. The atmosphere and the vibrancy of the island you have at your disposal is such a wonderful contrast to most games with the First-Person Shooter classification. One of the most compelling parts of the Far Cry formula is the freedom to approach a situation in whatever way you can dream up. As a fan of stealth games, my mindset was to wipe out an entire enemy force and either make it look like a tragic accident or a nightmarish ninja slaughter. Another aspect that oddly sticks out in my mind is the guns; they all sound unbelievably real and deadly. I’m not sure how they crafted the sound effects for gun fire but they nailed it in Far Cry 3.So again, my best summary of Far Cry 3 is still “very relevant”. It is a fantastic open world, first-person, sandbox shooter with light RPG elements and I highly recommend everyone pick it up while it’s cheap!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												Far Cry 3 is framed as a shooter, and in that vein, there are plenty of guns, grenades, rocket-propelled grenade launchers and more. But there’s more to Jason’s skill set, which makes for a more sophisticated game. The ability to sneak and to throw rocks to distract enemies might seem like small factors, but combined with instant-kill maneuvers and AI that reacts to the environment, the result is a game that swings back and forth comfortably between action and stealth. Hunting in Far Cry 3 serves a purpose beyond errant urges to destroy something beautiful. Animal skins are used to create new pouches, loot sacks, holsters and more, each of which increases your various carrying capacities. It encourages exploration, as different animals live on different parts of the island, and some game is more dangerous than others. And tying crafting back into the main game, the best gear can only be crafted by hunting legendary animals tied to specific hunting missions.There’s so much to do in Far Cry 3 that it can be intimidating. You can climb a radio tower, which is a platforming puzzle of sorts, which in turn will reveal more information about the area of the island surrounding it. You can storm an outpost like an avenging angel or sweep through it like a ninja drawing off enemies with thrown rocks to pick off with a machete or bow — my weapons of choice — which in turn reveals new side missions. These include special hunts that yield rare skins that can be used to craft the best gear, or can yield contract missions with financial rewards to expand and upgrade your armory.That’s Far Cry 3’s greatest strength — every action has a result that ties into other actions and new rewards. Even from a strictly moment-to-moment mechanical perspective, quickly made decisions have very visible, immediate consequences. An idly thrown grenade might cause a chain reaction of explosions. An errant Molotov cocktail could take out your enemies, but might also surround you with killing flames. That first takedown kill might be perfectly safe, but if you get greedy and, say, use your new ability to chain a second takedown by throwing your first victim’s knife into a second, a sniper you didn’t see might watch it all go down and trigger an alarm, calling in even more enemies.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Needs more definition of insanity.  Far Cry games are pretty much the same: simple but entertaining gameplay that goes on for far too long.  Some of the characters are pretty interesting though, such as Sam and Vaas.  The in-game menu isn't particularly good, and, to make matters worse, Uplay is constantly in your face with meta-gaming.  I'm still not fond of needing another service, complete with high scores and friend tracking, just to play through the story.  If you're willing to put up with Uplay and this game is on sale, Far Cry 3 is worth checking out, but it's a fairly mediocre game overall.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												Price Aquired: $7:49 during Winter sale 2014I picked up this game after playing Far Cry 4 on the PS4. I was impressed with that game and wanted to see what else the series had to offer. I was very very surprised because in my opinion - Far Cry 3 blows Far Cry 4 out of the water. Since I've purchased Far Cry 3, I haven't played 4 at all because 3 just...feels better. The game does a great job of setting up the story in the opening, and I became invested in the characters very quickly. The main character, Jason Brody, is on a mission to rescue his captive friends after they became stranded on a jungle island following a skydiving accident. This is a really compelling mission, and I, as the player, felt really motivated to save them. I'm not good at starting and finishing Single-Player campaigns (the last one I finished was The Last Of Us Remastered over the summer), but I was hooked into this one from beginning to end. The gameplay is very fun and feels very responsive. Seeing how many guards you can silenty snipe before they alert the rest of the outpost is intense and rewards smart playing. There are plenty of customizable weapons and I always felt like I had options. There are many fun weapons as well (namely the Flamethrower).Gunfights are fun and feel fair. I was rarely frustrated (except for the damn heavy soldiers). Anyone who is worried about missing elephants and other improvements from FC4, don't be. I didn't miss them at all.  The ONLY negative thing I have to say about this game is the occasional overuse of "trippy" drugs. The island natives occasionally give drugs to Jason to make him realize things from their perspective, and they lead to many many cool hallucination sequences. However they end up using this effect in a boss encounter or two and it takes away from the satisfaction of the fight. I would have preferred if they stuck to the realism a bit more in the boss sequences.I highly recommend this game if you like FPS games, games with a good storyline, or wanna see what the Far Cry franchise is all about for a good price.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Great game!9/10 in the BlacKy scale.The good:* Story starts great (no spoiler): A group of rich kids went for a vacation on an exotic island (or a group of islands if u'd like) to have fun, but then gets kidnapped by pirates. You free yourself and get help from local villagers to free your friends and take the kidnappers down.* Island looks amazing. Overall graphics is very up to date.* Exploring the island is very fun (whoever liked Red Faction Guerrilla's enviroment will like this aswell). Many side quests to do. Having a bunch of items to find (just like the classic hidden boxes from the GTA series). Driving a vehicle makes you feel as you're inside the game. You can actually feel bumps on the road.* The wildlife is very nice. Many exotic animals to encounter. Animal's AI is well done overall.* The more you advance in the game, enemies get thougher.* Customizable weapons. Need i say more?* Co-op is pretty fun when its not crashing. * You get to cheat on your gf with an amazonian nympho.The bad:* Story ends bad, in my opinion: I'll do my best not to spoil - When having the chance to get out of the island with all your friends, you take the other option, revenge, staying behind and killing those who have kidnapped you and your friends.* Enemies AI is a bit poor. They sometimes suspect that something is wrong but they dont tend to do much about it, even if they're defending an outpost, etc.* I've found all the syringes except health syringes to be unnecessary to use. No need to dive too much underwater so water syringe is irrelevant. The camera's ability to tag enemies and animals makes the hunter syringe to be irrelevant aswell. You can extinguish fire when you're on fire so fireproof syringes are, again, irrelevant.* Your health is too OP. You can make up to 10 health packs while also carrying impossible amount of crafting materials to make even more health syringes if you'll need to use later. After getting enough progressed in the game, you have constantly infinite amount of health which makes everything boring and less exciting.* The skill tree isn't as good as other games, E.G Borderlands franchise. You will eventually unlock all the skills in the game, which makes it unnecessary to think 'which skill am i going to unlock next?'. Some of the skills have absolutely no value in the game so you may think that even if you have free skill points to spare, you wouldn't pick that specific skill.* While the crafting option itself is very well made. Everything craftable in the game gets unlocked after ~50% of game time (finishing the north island), so you wont be needing to kill animals for hides at the second island at all if you have explored the first island effectively enough.* Activating radio towers makes the game very easy. Too easy i might say. Weapons will become free in weapon shops, ammo gets very cheap, and you get the sense that money isnt a factor anymore. If you like a bit of a challenge, dont do what i did, which was unlocking most of the radio towers before making the quests. Try exploring everything at once:- Do a few missions.- Do a few side missions.- Explore the island as you can: Find some artifacts / SD cards / letters / etc.- Unlock some radio towers and outposts.- Repeat* uPlay - Sadly this game runs by uPlay, which means constantly-crashing servers in multiplayer and co-op, no Steam achievements, and no real option to search for specific servers like in normal Valve servers via Steam.Multiplayer and co-op have no skill filter. A level 1 noob will often join a group of level 75's (highest level). The ugly:* VaasOverall:I admit i was 'letting myself go' on the bad stuff. But when you play the game, you will realize the good compensates the bad in many ways. Very enjoyable game. Open world FTW!Just dont count on the MP / Co-op to be enjoyable. Because of the above circumstances, its not.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
COMPLETED 100%A decent FPS by today's standards. The story is fairly linear, to say the least. The much publicized antagonist Vaas isn't actually showcased that much, only appearing in a few cutscenes before being long forgotten by the second half of the game. Not really a bad thing, since this gives way for further delving into new scenery when the game later branches out into another part, allowing for different new enemies and paving the way for other interesting characters. The open world of Rook Island is a large place to explore, though it's mostly repetitive in environment and landscape, even on the South Island. On a good note, the world is realistically put together and scaled in size. Possibly, it may very well be just as large as a real-life tropical island. Collectibles are spread across the entire islands, but the myriad of treasure chests scattered literally everywhere you go can be a game-breaker, and slight annoyance. With so many laying about, I could say the game is literally throwing money at you till the point where it is common to run out of things to buy at the store, leaving you full of unused cash and having to tolerate the incessant "Your wallet is full" messages that will be popping up constantly. But a minor downsight to the game nonetheless. For gameplay: the enemy AI is rather impressive and well-done, with reactionary actions like knowing when to take cover and losing sight of you. They can also be pretty dumb at times, whether acting logically or not. Weapons are, unfortunately, quite unbalanced, where the simple order of having guns later in the game being in every way superior to the earlier guns. This makes your choice of weapons pretty much straightforward. I'd rather prefer the wep stats spread out across the chart to give more chances for decision-making but that's my take.Some weps...or gear, are pretty useless as well, such as the repair tool that was so useful in Far Cry 2 has become a complete unnecessity and "specials" like the bow and flamethrower don't really have much benefits apart from being unique. The bow, especially, is essentially a pointless waste, given a silenced sniper rifle already does the same job better. Seriously, why does everyone love the bow as much? There's nothing greater about it.Overall the game is pretty much a stripped down version of its predecessor, improving in some ways, lacking in others; with its silly implementations like being able to heal yourself literally anywhere with a magical green syringe, enemies being marked for you and loot chests and plant herbs lying everywhere you go.Ubisoft clearly "casualized" it for the masses, removing the hardcore features from its predecessors while at least retaining its core features. This, at the cost of the game being too easy in comparison. And so the verdict... this game mostly great in quality, despite poor game design choices dragging it down, I'd say it's still worth the play.

												This game is one of the, if not THE best game in the I have ever played. The story, the graphics, the weapons, the overall gameplay were just amazing. So much detailed, high paced action that will get you hooked onto this game in a flash. They spent a lot of time while making, and it really payed off. As you progress throughout the game, you unlock more and more powerful and fun to use weapons which you can customize to your liking. This game also has a lot of skills and abilities that you can unlock that really pay off in some of the harder missions. Overall, this intense, detailed, addicting game has a lot of choices that can make or break your ease throughout the story line, but really can pay off. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who likes a thriller, heart-stopping action packed game, 10/10.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2013
												Words cannot describe the sheer epicness of this game.The campaign's story is centered around Jason Brody and his friends who get lost and then kidnapped in the fictional Rook Island between the Indian and Pacific oceans. The story is well-done and the scope of the islands is amazing. There are many collectibles to collect such as relics and memory cards and they will surely add up more gameplay hours.Gameplay is smooth and can be split into 2 parts: stealth, and utter chaos of great guns and 'splotions :)The soundtrack and music in this game are very fitting and energetic; they breathe life into the world. As many reviewers and sites suggest, both the multiplayer and co-op modes feel tacked on and therefore are forgettable.If you want to experience a great open world game with tight first-person combat and platforming in a survival-themed story, then this game is for you. 9.4/10

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												TL;DR- Far Cry 3 manages to improve on its predecessor without abandoning most of its basic mechanics. Does have a ridiculous plot that is terribly handled at the end. I had a love/hate relationship with Far Cry 2. I loved the weapons, the world, and the combat. But I hated the way the place was populated only by people who wanted to kill you on sight (except for in the closed cities). I didn't like the way enemies respawned automatically and the beautiful world was somewhat marred when I couldn't enjoy a senic boat ride without getting sniper fire, even though I'd crushed that outpost five minutes earlier. Unlocking weapons tended to be a bit tedious as well, though it was worth it to get some of the best ones. The mortar in FC2 is one of my favorite weapons in ANY game. It took patience to figure out, but once mastered it could be used to desolate an enemy encampment in dramatic fashion.FC3 keeps the nice variety of weapons, with the facepalming exception of the above-mentioned mortar. I guess it was unbalancing because of how useful it could be against outposts, but I still wish they had left it in somewhere. Vehicles are still fun, as are boats, plus handgliding is actually a bit more doable in this game- even useful when the game doesn't cheat and turn on the invisible walls for missions. Best of all, not everyone is out to kill you at all times. There are different factions in the game and only MOST want to kill you at any one time! You can actually see battles between the different factions where you can help one over the other. When you take out an enemy outpost, it stays down... unless you decide to revert them back to enemy control so you can have fun blowing them up again- a neat option by the devs to placate both sides of the 'respawning enemies' argument. Plus they've added carnivors. If you remember in FC2 they made some kind of hand-waving statement that they couldn't do that because it would wreck the simulation... or something. Well this time they said "screw it, add more tigers!" Bravo. There are a lot of gimmicks in the game. You can blow open the cages of conveniently placed animals to screw with enemies, use hand-gliders or zip lines that just happen to be near enemy outposts, or... all sorts of other stuff that sometimes gets a little old. But there's enough variety that the fun makes up for the head-scratching about why the redshirts don't learn not to leave a man-eating tiger around the middle of their base. There are plenty of unscripted surprises (the first time a croc tries to eat you, for example... happens to everyone) and the whole thing is just a fun romp. The plot... well, I don't really care much about the plot. They botched it a bit by having the sub-enemy be more interesting than anyone else in the game, and there's a lot of trippy psycadelic fight scenes. The free-form part of the game is the draw. There are some RPG elements that really don't need to be there and don't serve much purpose, other than to seemingly check off a box on the list of things every game is supposed to have... but it's not a big deal.Also a shame is the lack of a day-night cycle as in FC2. It worked so nicely and could have been used to great effect here with easier stealth at night and movement by day, or some other trade-off mechanic. Much of the plot is also nonsensical and a QTE torture scene is so hamfisted I had to roll my eyes when the protagonist looks at his hands afterwards. The whole plotlineis a contrived piece of garbage that could have been solved by your character or his combat-knife equipped buddy just killing the Big Bad who is sitting three feet away and jumping out a window... the same kind of thing you can do at every other part of the game that isn't a cutscene. But instead you have to wait until another QTE-ridden dream sequence... or something... to finish him off. Then have an awful on-rails sequence that, again, makes no sense and seems to be there just to annoy the player. Oh, and combine that with an escort mission. And the escorted person is a moron who seems to purposely get you shot down. The plot is a necessary evil. The way its handled is... well, an unnecesary evil. Frankly the entire last mission arc is crap. But FC3's island is worth the price of admission... maybe be smarter than I was and just ignore everything after the second island gets unlocked, plot-wise.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
FAR CRY 3: HORY SHETIt's been a while since I've really gotten into a game. The last case of that was probably Half-Life 2, which we got our last bite of nearly 10 years ago. {insert obligatory half life 3 joke here}But having now finished Far Cry 3, with one of the toughest end-of-game desicions ever, one of the most amazing soundtracks I've ever heard, spot on gameplay, graphics to make even the toughest console bigot consider switching platforms and characters that, while zany and in character insane at times (Yaas, vaas) seem real.Far Cry 3 is a Survival Adventure Exploration Collect-Em-Up First Person Mission Based Open Word Stealth Shooter based on a fictional archipelago overtaken by pirates and trafficers, forcing the natives into timid hiding. You play as Jason Brody, a rich tw@t who has a rich tw@t brother with a pilot's license who goes skydiving over said archipelago with his friends only to be captured by the pirates and sent to Vaas's camp. After a monologue from Vaas himself, which exists purely to set the plot and show how insane he really is, you manage to escape into the jungle, after Vaas kills one of your friends (Shut up, it's hardly a spoiler. It happens in the first five bloody minutes) You then find yourself in a hut with the Tatau, the game's major mechanic. As you gain XP throughout the game for progressing in the story, harvesting plants, gathering leathers, hunting, and taking over enemy territory you get Skill Points which you can then use to get upgrades for yourself, which ranges from things such as moving a bit faster when sneaking with CTRL to perfoming chained silent kills on groups of enemies in a few seconds like it's Arkham Night (but it isn't because nobody cares about that game anymore)You can craft equipment for yourself too, such as larger backpacks, larger wallets (because ♥♥♥♥ putting your money in, like, your bag or your pockets amirite) or questionably HIV-free health syringes from literally any plant as long as it's green. You can also claim enemy territory by liberating it's camp, which awards you with more XP for not being detected and not having the alarm sounded, and you can climb radio towers and activate them, clearing the map and unlocking/making free some of the weapons in the stores. You can buy weapons, equip certain loadouts and combinations for your play style, get upgrades such as larger magazines and sights, as well as camo for the discerning rebellius californian murderer.You can go looking for relics, treasures, ruins, tombs, and much more. The archipelago and it's inhabitants have a rich history, and the plot itself becomes immersive and deep, with more plot twists than M. Night Shyamalan with a cloning machine. Boss fights take place in what I often refer to as the Weed Sphere (weird psycadellic environments that are really hard to explain with text and text alone) and missions are sometimes addmittidley a little broken, buggy, or outright boring, but most of the time action packed, fun, and intuitive.Far Cry 3 gets a BUY THIS GAME ALREADY / 10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												This is a long overdue review that I should have published last year after playing the game:I pre-purchased and pre-loaded this game at full price. I was so disappointed in the game that I felt like I wasted the $60 I paid. The game itself seemed to be quite buggy and it even prevented me from playing it at full quality. Due to the fact that I have ATI drivers and not Nvidia, the game itself would not go over 15-25 frames at a resolution of 1600x900 on low quality. When this game came out I was playing BF3 and Max Payne 3 at ultra settings getting 45-60 frames. There was no reason that this game should have been performing as terribly as it was. I even contacted Ubisoft customer support to resolve the issue I was having. All they told me was the typical stuff such as update drivers etc. I had already done the basics and they couldn't offer more help except to casually claim there would be an update soon. It was an update that never came. The game was s*** and you guys obviously didn't care. All you cared about was raking in the cash while you could. ATI users were screwed and it was plain to see that it was just an overall bad port to PC. Just like the recent Watch_Dogs, lots of PC users were left sitting with a game that didn't operate up to the specs they claimed originally. Now let's talk about the multiplayer. What was that trash? Attempting to create a fun or at least competitive multiplayer seemed none existant. The multiplayer probably should have been left out of this shiny gem. The map editor was fun, thanks for allowing me to make maps for a terrible multiplayer. Far Cry 2 wasn't the greatest but at least it was broken like the multiplayer and coop was for 3. And coop was not necessary at all. Again it was attempted to make a competitive/fun coop by allowing up to 4 players to run amuk. The only problem was the coop was close to being a rail shooter due to how linear it was setup. Making an "open world" game closed for coop was probably one of the dumber decisions you could have made in this game.[Spoilers ahead]So the story you guys made, it was okay I guess. It had some merits but some of it seemed quite childish and silly mostly. You play a typical white guy who despite his stupid rich friends seems to be able to pick up any gun and just blow away the baddies like it's no big deal at all. Later some how you become the leader of a bunch of islanders and start a revolution, while also tripping major balls on drugs and fighting weird tiki monsters that look absolutely ridiculous. Oh and let's not forget all the while this story is happening you are killing hundreds of endangered species and taking their hides to make a bigger wallet to store the money you take off the bodies of the hundreds of mercs you laid waste to. If you weren't busy skinning a giant helpless tortoise or gliding around oddly placed japanese bunkers you were likely blowing up outpost after outpost slowly boring yourself to death. Overall the story seemed way far fetched and just ridiculous. Who will you choose at the end? Your stupid rich friends, or your new crazy islander wackos. The choice is up to you bucko! Oh boy it's over, thank you!So to conclude my review of this game. Thank you for a bad port to PC, again. Thank you for not catering to all drivers in the PC gaming world, again. And lastly thank you for wasting $60 of my hard earned money, again.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Far Cry 3 provides an epic story about a friendly vacation gone wrong. Jason Brody is your typical youngster who's only care is to party hard, but circumstance force him into a situation where this boy must jump on the fast path to manhood.The graphics of Far Cry 3 are simply stunning. This latest edition goes back to its original roots of lush island landscapes. The scenery is fantastic. As day changes to night and the rain starts pouring down, it provides a sense of realism that is rarely accomplished in many games today. Characters are amazingly detailed and the interaction with them add to that sense of realism. Vaas and Hoyt are two sick son of a ♥♥♥♥♥es that keep tensions high and continually throw unexpected twists your way. The different variety of vehicles like hang gliders, jet skis, and dune buggies make exploration fun, while sprinting is fast enough that it provides a reasonable alternative to using vehicles at all. The large variety of weapons allow for a full range of games styles, from stealth play to I'm here to blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up. I actually played very stealthily in the early parts of the game as the bow and arrow was probably hands down my favorite overall weapon, but later on I just overpowered my opponents with sheer firepower. I found both methods equally satisfying.Side missions are initially fun, but ultimately become repetitious after a while because they don't offer enough differences. Liberate enemy camps, expand your overall field of vision by claiming back radio towers, assassinate key figures, and hunt wild game. Hunting and skinning animals is necessary to upgrade your standard equipment. It goes well with the island paradise and doesn't heavily disrupt from the primary story.Three categories of character skills are available to promote stealth, firepower, and survival. Missions reward stealth gameplay with more XP which I don't necessarily agree with because it tends to steer your gameplay in that direction. I was able to unlock all available skills by the story's end. There's also crafting of drugs using flowers collected which can increase various attributes for a limited time.I found the menu system to be the weakest part of the game. It feels overly cumbersome since you have to escape out of the game to craft syringes or use skill points. It just doesn't feel like it was integrated well overall.All-in-all, Far Cry 3 represents a really fun open world first person shooter. Single player is genuinely fun, but I have yet to play the co-op or multiplayer elements.

Jason starts off as a cowardly whimpering baby who can't stand even an evil person dying, which I liked, but later on becomes insane and likes killing, which I don't. He starts out saying, "Oh ♥♥♥♥! Posted: February 9, 2016
												I finished the game. I bought the game during a Steam sale. I definitely got a bargain and I highly recommend this game.I was pleasantly surprised that Far Cry 3 drew me into the story and sandbox game features. Although the "trippy" stuff was annoying, I could see the need for these "trips" to add to the story development.Some spoilers:- The radar towers were like jumping puzzles. Each unique, but not too crazy.- The safari hunts were interesting, albeit annoying. Bow and arrow to hunt down 1-shot kill tigers was irritating. At least rare animals could help build your character carrying capacity.- The combat was flexible and kept me interested. All of the camps/compounds were different in their own way. The takedown sequences were difficult to navitate due to guards no cooperating with my rock throwing. But overall, one of the best tactical semi-stealth combat games I played in a while.- Driving is fun and the terrain challenging. - The weapons were good, although I would have liked more silencer-type weapons near end-game.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												TL;DR- Far Cry 3 manages to improve on its predecessor without abandoning most of its basic mechanics. Does have a ridiculous plot that is terribly handled at the end. I had a love/hate relationship with Far Cry 2. I loved the weapons, the world, and the combat. But I hated the way the place was populated only by people who wanted to kill you on sight (except for in the closed cities). I didn't like the way enemies respawned automatically and the beautiful world was somewhat marred when I couldn't enjoy a senic boat ride without getting sniper fire, even though I'd crushed that outpost five minutes earlier. Unlocking weapons tended to be a bit tedious as well, though it was worth it to get some of the best ones. The mortar in FC2 is one of my favorite weapons in ANY game. It took patience to figure out, but once mastered it could be used to desolate an enemy encampment in dramatic fashion.FC3 keeps the nice variety of weapons, with the facepalming exception of the above-mentioned mortar. I guess it was unbalancing because of how useful it could be against outposts, but I still wish they had left it in somewhere. Vehicles are still fun, as are boats, plus handgliding is actually a bit more doable in this game- even useful when the game doesn't cheat and turn on the invisible walls for missions. Best of all, not everyone is out to kill you at all times. There are different factions in the game and only MOST want to kill you at any one time! You can actually see battles between the different factions where you can help one over the other. When you take out an enemy outpost, it stays down... unless you decide to revert them back to enemy control so you can have fun blowing them up again- a neat option by the devs to placate both sides of the 'respawning enemies' argument. Plus they've added carnivors. If you remember in FC2 they made some kind of hand-waving statement that they couldn't do that because it would wreck the simulation... or something. Well this time they said "screw it, add more tigers!" Bravo. There are a lot of gimmicks in the game. You can blow open the cages of conveniently placed animals to screw with enemies, use hand-gliders or zip lines that just happen to be near enemy outposts, or... all sorts of other stuff that sometimes gets a little old. But there's enough variety that the fun makes up for the head-scratching about why the redshirts don't learn not to leave a man-eating tiger around the middle of their base. There are plenty of unscripted surprises (the first time a croc tries to eat you, for example... happens to everyone) and the whole thing is just a fun romp. The plot... well, I don't really care much about the plot. They botched it a bit by having the sub-enemy be more interesting than anyone else in the game, and there's a lot of trippy psycadelic fight scenes. The free-form part of the game is the draw. There are some RPG elements that really don't need to be there and don't serve much purpose, other than to seemingly check off a box on the list of things every game is supposed to have... but it's not a big deal.Also a shame is the lack of a day-night cycle as in FC2. It worked so nicely and could have been used to great effect here with easier stealth at night and movement by day, or some other trade-off mechanic. Much of the plot is also nonsensical and a QTE torture scene is so hamfisted I had to roll my eyes when the protagonist looks at his hands afterwards. The whole plotlineis a contrived piece of garbage that could have been solved by your character or his combat-knife equipped buddy just killing the Big Bad who is sitting three feet away and jumping out a window... the same kind of thing you can do at every other part of the game that isn't a cutscene. But instead you have to wait until another QTE-ridden dream sequence... or something... to finish him off. Then have an awful on-rails sequence that, again, makes no sense and seems to be there just to annoy the player. Oh, and combine that with an escort mission. And the escorted person is a moron who seems to purposely get you shot down. The plot is a necessary evil. The way its handled is... well, an unnecesary evil. Frankly the entire last mission arc is crap. But FC3's island is worth the price of admission... maybe be smarter than I was and just ignore everything after the second island gets unlocked, plot-wise.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
FAR CRY 3: HORY SHETIt's been a while since I've really gotten into a game. The last case of that was probably Half-Life 2, which we got our last bite of nearly 10 years ago. {insert obligatory half life 3 joke here}But having now finished Far Cry 3, with one of the toughest end-of-game desicions ever, one of the most amazing soundtracks I've ever heard, spot on gameplay, graphics to make even the toughest console bigot consider switching platforms and characters that, while zany and in character insane at times (Yaas, vaas) seem real.Far Cry 3 is a Survival Adventure Exploration Collect-Em-Up First Person Mission Based Open Word Stealth Shooter based on a fictional archipelago overtaken by pirates and trafficers, forcing the natives into timid hiding. You play as Jason Brody, a rich tw@t who has a rich tw@t brother with a pilot's license who goes skydiving over said archipelago with his friends only to be captured by the pirates and sent to Vaas's camp. After a monologue from Vaas himself, which exists purely to set the plot and show how insane he really is, you manage to escape into the jungle, after Vaas kills one of your friends (Shut up, it's hardly a spoiler. It happens in the first five bloody minutes) You then find yourself in a hut with the Tatau, the game's major mechanic. As you gain XP throughout the game for progressing in the story, harvesting plants, gathering leathers, hunting, and taking over enemy territory you get Skill Points which you can then use to get upgrades for yourself, which ranges from things such as moving a bit faster when sneaking with CTRL to perfoming chained silent kills on groups of enemies in a few seconds like it's Arkham Night (but it isn't because nobody cares about that game anymore)You can craft equipment for yourself too, such as larger backpacks, larger wallets (because ♥♥♥♥ putting your money in, like, your bag or your pockets amirite) or questionably HIV-free health syringes from literally any plant as long as it's green. You can also claim enemy territory by liberating it's camp, which awards you with more XP for not being detected and not having the alarm sounded, and you can climb radio towers and activate them, clearing the map and unlocking/making free some of the weapons in the stores. You can buy weapons, equip certain loadouts and combinations for your play style, get upgrades such as larger magazines and sights, as well as camo for the discerning rebellius californian murderer.You can go looking for relics, treasures, ruins, tombs, and much more. The archipelago and it's inhabitants have a rich history, and the plot itself becomes immersive and deep, with more plot twists than M. Night Shyamalan with a cloning machine. Boss fights take place in what I often refer to as the Weed Sphere (weird psycadellic environments that are really hard to explain with text and text alone) and missions are sometimes addmittidley a little broken, buggy, or outright boring, but most of the time action packed, fun, and intuitive.Far Cry 3 gets a BUY THIS GAME ALREADY / 10.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												Far cry 3 is a very good game in general and you can visibly see all the good game design decisions. Its setting is a strong point- showing off just how well the developers worked to create a living-breathing environment that you can become completely immersed in. Graphically, it is very aesthetically pleasing but can be very taxing on older machines.Gameplay-wise it mostly fluid and intuitive, with a good, solid movement system and shooting mechanics designed for fast paced but skillful shooting. However it came become a pain to quickly move in and out of vehicles and healing yourself can become a serious pain.Few games can claim to have a story I've given 2 half-baked waffles about but Far Cry 3 has quite a good story. With engaging charater arcs and plot twists that twist the plot for once. The story is all very tight and works well with the rest of the game.However, while I don't want to spoil the ending too much, it's one of the only parts where the game lets itself down.The final mission of the game is split two ways - Flying from the enemy base in a helicopter to 'Ride of the valkyries' in an epic mounted turret section- then going through some boring tibal love drama nonsence. Then you pick if you want to be with your friends and escape or with Citra- the tribe leader. Its a sort of moral choice sequence with no moral choice. The 'friend end' is the only real end as the other one just ruins most of the stories believeability.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												  Far Cry 3 definitely had some good things going for it, but it still was not without its faults.  Combat was fun, stealth play was done well enough for those that enjoy it, and I loved the open world.  Oh, and of course, the RPG elements were a welcome addition, even though choice is limited to unlock order and I reached the level cap well before the end of the game.  Unfortunately, enemy A.I. was mediocre, and when it came to stealth, enemies seemed either virturally blind or able to see through cover, depending on their type (pirates (red) v. privateers (yellow)).  Oh, and the boss fights kind of sucked.  My biggest complaint, however, would be that the game had a lot of filler content (Trials of the Rakyat, Tower Unlocks, Outpost Cleared, Supply Drops, Path of the Hunter Missions, Wanted Dead Missions, Letters Found, and Relics Found).  It was fun at first, but by about half way through, I was just doing that stuff to get the unlocks & experience (and because I'm kind of OCD about that kind of stuff).  It just started to get old by the time you've hunted down the 120th relic or did the 23rd Path of the Hunter.  I guess that's better than a short game or an empty world, but I would have like to have seen more variety with this content -well, assuming it was done well, of course; most of the side missions, were already rather forgettable.  Story missions, on the other hand, were varied and quite fun.  Overall, I'd recommend the game, especially if you can pick it up for cheap during a sale.  Combat is satisfying, the story missions are fun, and unlocking new weapons and abilities changes things up and helps to make you feel like a badass.  The a.i. could have been better and the filler content gets a little old after a while, but then again, you can always do as little or as much as you like.  I also had a few other minor gripes (like the ease at which to take fall damage, crappy inventory system, many npc's looking the same, etcetera), but I don't think they detract enough from the game to warrant getting into.  7 out of 10 stars.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												This game is one of the true cases of real freedom. Not just because it's open world. Not just because ther's lots of things to shoot. And not just because if you get bored you can hurl yourself off a cliff. No, the devs of this game really went the extra mile.For example, the hunting. Yes, you can slowly sneak up on deer before blasting it with a shotgun (if you're boring), or you can grab a flamethrower and molotov cocktails, light a section of forest on fire, and when a bear or pig runs past you trying to escape, you can stab it multiple times in the back.Also, there's a lot of side quests. From finding a missing suicidal teen to seeing how many komodo dragons you can kill with one clip of pistol ammo, there's always something to keep you busy. Also, certain non-essential tasks can help you in the long run. Sure, it may seem boring to climb various towers to reactivate old cell phone beacons, but it'll all pay off when the air fills with smoke and you can still see every one of the dudes you are about to terminate.Which brings me, yes, to the combat. The combat in this game is fantastic, and filled with variety. You can rip a dude's neck out and leave him out to be discovered by already terrified pirates; you can lure over a pack of wild dogs and let Mother Nature do the work. Hell, you can just run up to a guy and beat him over and over with a blowtorch, until he either dies of trauma or lights on fire.A personal favourite of mine was to kill a helicopter pilot while he hovered over an enemy outpost, causing the vehicle to spiral out of control, crushing both the pirates and presumably two or three tigers.Overall, this game gets a solid plus. It's Rambo, Terminator and Tomb Raider squished into one, and I love it.God help me, I love it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8
												'Do you know the defenition of insanity?'You won't have until you play this game. It's honestly incredible. At the moment of writing this review, it's my favourite game. In my opinion, it's better than the entire Just Cause, Assassin's Creed, Halo, Call of Duty, HITMAN and the rest of the Far Crys' franchises.Characters: 9/10The Characters in this game are truly stunning. Vaas and Hoyt are terryfying villians who you won't forget any time soon. They both do thinks to you and their men which will make you wince. Jason Brody is also an intresting charcters who progresses throughout the game. Citra, Buck and Denis have great voice actors and intresting characteristics, even if they are not as fleshed out as tthe main villians and heroes. Plot and Story: 9/10The plot is pretty straight forward. It's a revenege thriller focused around a character who ,at the beginning of the game, couldn't even fire a gun. However, the story takes the plot and mixes it with great missions and intresting stories. Even though the game is a FPS, Action shooter, it's very much based around choices and philoshpy. The story is what takes Far Cry 3 to great heights.Combat: 8.5/10Combat may not be the best aspect of FC3, but it's still really fun. Liberating bases with a sniper rifle will never get old. However, combat becomes difficult with different guns. Assult Rifles do little to no damage, while a handgun kills the man instantly. Also, Headshots sometimes don't insta-kill, which is a big nusiance. Open World and Side-Missions: 9/10The Open World of FC3 is amazing. It's so vast and detailed it makes it feel like a 2015 game, not a 2012. There are so many things to do after completing the main campain; Radio Towers, Bases, Wanted: Dead, Path of the hunter, Trials of the Rakyat, Story missions, Relics, Letters of the lost, Memory Cards, Skills, etc.. And they are all really funDLC: 7/10Read my review here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/dank_coder/recommended/226459/Soundtrack: 10/10Just listen to this song from a mission where you get to burn down a Weed Field (yes a Weed Field!): Make it Bun - SkrillexYeah, it's great, right???Price: 9/10The Price is quite good considering how excellent the game is. Normal Pice: £15.99 ($20.00-ish)Sale Price: £5.59 ($8.00-ish)Overall: 61.5/70 - 88%Overall: 8.7/10Just get this game. It's amazingFavourite Quotes: 'Do you know what is the best way of keeping employees in check: Fear''His name is Buck, and he lkes to f-'''You are me. And I am you.'Are you F***ING DEAF? I SAID, GET THE F**K OUT OF HERE, YOU CHICKEN F**K! RUN, FORREST! RUN!'

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												At one point I thought I would never actually finish this game because of how huge the world was.  I’m really glad I’ve changed my mind and decided to continue playing. The story is great and game-play is solid and versatile. I took me a while to finish every side-mission, to find all of the collectables and complete all achievements. It was worth it. I really enjoyed exploring the world and learning its history. Finding out what is happening around me, what I have been dragged in to - was the most satisfying part of the game.In addition to the single-player, Ubisoft have added a multiplayer and a co-op. I have really enjoyed them both. The co-op has its own characters and a brand new story. The multiplayer is fun a fast paced - the more you play the more weapons/upgrades you unlock.My verdict - Get it on one of the steam sales - you will not regret it. I haven’t.

Posted: November 12, 2014
												Having never played any prior games in the Far Cry series, I wasn't sure what to expect when I first opened up this game and got stuck into it. My lack of experience with other games in the series probably made it difficult for me to begin with as  I wasn't sure what to do or the direction I was meant to head and hence after a few hours accumulated, I put the game away and tried something else.However, upon returning to the game I stuck with it and what followed was an exciting story line and great game play.If you like FPS, a solid and lengthy story line, good character progression and an open world experience that gives you the ability to do as you wish, I suggest you buy this game.I was pleasently surprised with this game and wouldn't hesitate to buy others in the series. You can rush the story line or you can complete other missions and mini games that the open world experience offers you. Rather than give a score out of 10, I merely suggest you try this game and decide for yourself. One of my favourite games to have played and indulged in.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												Far Cry 3 has many glaring issues. The most immediate is the horrific and broken Uplay DRM that is forced, despite this being the steam version of the game. The only upgrades in this game compared to it's predecessor are the graphics, voice acting, and general production values. The writing is simply laughable, quite possibly one of the worst stories I have experienced, the fact that Jeffrey Yohalem got nominated for a BAFTA for this game goes to show that becoming a writer in the modern video game industry requires only the bare minimum of credentials. I'm not even going to go into the plot because it's basically non existent beyond "Uh hey he's bad, let's get em'! *takes shrooms*" The only character that has even marginally interesting writing is Vaas, and they hyped him up so much prerelease that practically every single one of his lines can be found in a trailer, and without his VA's fantastic performance it would probably not be half as interesting. Jason Brody & Co. are so obnoxious, that they are for all intents and purposes, a parody of themselves. Jason Brody, whose name itself is cringeworthy, goes from sheltered rich junkie ♥♥♥♥♥boy to a v-neck and tribal tattoo-clad hard "killer" within the space of one mission and an overall story mode that lasts about two weeks in game time that is divided up into chapters, which we are greeted by with loading screens with forced "Alice in Wonderland" excerpts that aren't actually relevant to the story beyond "Woohoo I'm wacky, crazy, and insane Haha!". The game's theme of insanity is not explored or expounded upon, just stated over and over again, no really, they just keep telling you the webster-merriam definition of the word. The irony is almost next level.  The shooting mechanics are vastly improved in this iteration with a few exceptions. 1. There is virtually no recoil on any of the weapons 2. Most if not all of the gun sounds, are in fact, not gun shots. Which in this day and age for a AAA game with a massive budget, is simply not acceptable, the PKM sound is like a note from a skrillex song. Despite Far Cry 2's "Heart of Darkness" derivative story, and cheap voice acting, the choose-able silent protagonists of varying backgrounds including ex-KLA members and IRA insurgents is able to be taken much, much more seriously in it's African setting that is reflective of the varying local wars and conflicts fueled by ethnic and religious tensions, blood minerals, and separatist sentiments that are and have been occuring for the past 50 or so years in Africa. So basically unless you just really, really like playing as a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ druggie ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with tribal tats that changes personality traits more often than my insane bipolar grandmother, and having the NPCs color coded for you to Red = Bad and Blue = Good, pick up Far Cry 2 instead, it has many flaws of its own, but they are acceptable given the context that they are symptoms of its age and budget. Far Cry 3 does everything it does in the most pedestrian and shallow approach the devs could have taken from the UI to the story.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												Farcry Review in a nutshell - Spoiled 1%'er rich kid and his friends get captured on an island. Kid (player) gets a magical tattoo "Aztec sleeves" from a crazy Bob Marley fan (Shortly after having escaped a lunatic with a mohawk). Overnight he learns how to skin animals and make crafting gear along with throwing knives and shooting multiple weapon types. Suddenly he becomes the islands first ever Rambo in Penny Loafers out to save his friends.Pro's: Excellent graphics and single play shooter. Semi-interesting storyline.Con's: Mature content with a very teenage style gameplay that takes, what could be an awesome boss fight, and turns it into a dance dance revolution button masher. ( I suppose it's to cater to people with consoles that need clear definition on how to win).I give it a 7/10

content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												Where do I start? To move forward, we'll have to go back to the beginning. I bought this game when it was first released in 2012 and played it on my PS3. I loved every second of it, and I'm not exaggerating. The most interesting thing about Far Cry 3 is that it puts the player in life or death situations, which, in turn, throw you down a deep rabbit hole of insanity. It's a really, really good game, if you can even get it to work. We all know the horror stories centred around Ubisoft's relentlessy game-breaking service, Uplay (cue the screams). I, originally being a console player who just recently got a PC powerful enough to run games like these, thought it would be good idea to buy this game again. It was on sale after all, and I thought I would be spending countless hours rediscovering the gritty, violent, and chaotic land of Rakyat. But, UPLAY GOT ME ♥♥♥♥ED UP. WHO THE ♥♥♥♥ ASKED FOR UPLAY? HOW WAS IT EVEN CONCEIVED? WHO IN ♥♥♥♥'S NAME THOUGHT IT WOULD BE A GOOD ♥♥♥♥ING IDEA TO ATTACH A GREAT GAME TO SUCH A ♥♥♥♥♥♥ SERVICE? WHO IN ♥♥♥♥'S NAME EVEN THOUGHT IT WOULD BE A GOOD IDEA TO CREATE THE DAMN THING?! SO MANY QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS AND I NOW WISH TO BE KILLED.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												This game... This game is one of the best games I have ever played.  I always find myself wanting to play this game.  The story in Far Cry 3 is one of the best stories that I have experienced in a first person shooter, ever.  It is very deep and well done and it requires you to make game changing decisions.  As you progress through the game, secrets of Rook Island are revealed and you can even find notes from World War II.  The graphics in this game are outstanding.  They still manage to compete with modern day titles, such as CoD and more of the less graphics intensive games of the modern era.  The controls are easy to use and very responsive.  The free roam in this game is extremely enjoyable.  There are so many activities you can do such as side missions, hunting, and even time trial racing.  On top of that you can reclaim the island by re activationg the radio towers and claiming pirate outposts.  The crafting system is pretty well made, allowing you to make syringes that enhance your skill in hunting, mobility, and swimming.  The multiplayer is not so great.  It kind of sucks lol.  It is dead and overall not very well made.  I look forward to Far Cry 4's co op campaign feature.  Overall this is a great game and I would reccomend it to anyone.10/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												An almost perfect Open World FPS with crafting and RPG elements. The story is amazing and the acting/voiceover work is probably the best I've ever seen in a game (the guy who plays Vaas is incredible. Best villain EVER). The thing that impressed me most about this game is, you don't have to spend hours of your time crafting an sorting through piles of junk, trying to determine what to keep and what to sell or discard. Junk is easily "quick sold" and is explicitly marked as junk so there's no need to feel like you should hold onto it until later in the game when it may come in handy. The only real items of importance when it comes to crafting are animal skins for capacity upgrades (i.e., how much stuff you can carry) and plants for crafting medicines and buffs.Leveling and stat trees are balanced and easily managed. It's possible to gain every skill in the game in a single run through so you don't have to feel like you missed out or ruined your game by taking one skill point over another. Just simply farm up some more XP and get that skill as well.Finally, the graphics are beautiful, even if a bit aged. It's very easy to get totally submersed in the game with the wonderful graphics and beautiful locations, especially considering how great the story is and how amazing the voice and acting talent are (did I mention that Vaas is incredible? Because if there were ever Oscars given to video game actors, he should be the first to receive one). The options menu is deep and extremely configurable, from key layouts to graphics and sound settings. I have a pretty basic bargain-bin laptop (Acer Aspire E 15) with no modifications running the integrated intel HD 4400 with 1792 VM and can get the game to run with a bit of lag at full settings. I run mostly on medium with a few settings set to high, however, and get a constant frame rate of ~30fps (which is great for my non-gaming computer).My only gripe with this game is the soundtrack. It's pretty bland and bear-bones and neither adds nor subtracts from the game. It's just kind of "there". It doesn't hinder the experience in any way but I feel with a stronger score or maybe even the addition of some licensed music added during key scenes, it could have added that much more to the submersive experience.Overall, this game is a 9.5 out of 10 which by my grading standards, is practically a 10. I save 10s for the absolute best of the best. Games that not only are damn near perfectly designed and executed and fun to play, but which have also changed the landscape of gaming in general and paved the way for others to follow. The only "10"s I've played I can count on 2 hands (Super Mario 3 and Super Mario World, The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past and Ocarina of Time, Half-Life II, Tetris, Mrs. Pac-Man and maybe a few more I'm forgetting). Far Cry 3 is almost there but, there isn't much here that hasn't already been done before. That said, everything about the game that came from other games, Far Cry 3 put it all together and made it better as a whole than anyone else in it's genre. They took the best parts of games like Borderlands and Fallout and improved upon them in a way that's damn near perfect.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2013
												A fun, exciting, and utterly stupid game. Firstly the story barely makes any sense. As a group of preppy rich kids go on an island filled with pirates, which is apparently also a getaway vacationing island, they skydive right into our lovable villian's lap, Vaas. I feel like when they were marketting this game, they made a right call on never showing the main character or his friends and all the advertisements were about the criminally insane Vaas. Everytime I play this game I always think to myself about how much I want to kill the irritating main character, Jason. What really makes no sense to me about this game is how the hell does Jason learn all of these para-military tactics within a minute, after his armed forces brother dies 5 minutes into the game, when he clearly admits that he has never done anything like this or taken a life before. And the whole concept behind a "magical tattoo" that gives you strange and mystical powers is just plain stupidity. However, I somehow still really enjoyed this game. The gameplay behind Farcry 3 is amazing. It's a sandbox sort of game filled with so many hostiles, including animals that you're able to hunt for materials. I like the concept of skinning the animals to further your carrying capacities, however I feel that it could've been a bit better. I really did enjoy the fact that there were multiple vehicles whever you went, such as Jeeps, Quads, MG mounted boats,  Jet skis, and sky gliders. Overall the gameplay is superb, but the main character and his story could've used way more help. Vaas is the only saving grace story-wise. Also, the CO-OP mode is essentially a Left 4 Dead copy, where there are 4 players connected to one server, and you get swarmed with hordes of enemies while completing petty objectives.I would've liked to see a better story, but this game easily gets 7/10.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Lots of people are downvoting this because of uplay. Ignore these people. You can still use steam chat and community stuff in-game, like anything on steam, and especially after you've launched it the first time, it actually just takes you right into the game in all subsequent times. A little annoying? Sure. Reprehensible that a company would release on steam but force the use of a clunkier, in-house client? Definitely. Does it devalue the game experience? Absolutely not. Far Cry 3 is one of the most incredible games I've played in recent memory - it's right up there with Skyrim for me. The net impact of uplay is essentially closing one additional window upon exiting the game; if you let that stop you from enjoying such a phenominal achievement in game development, you frankly deserve to miss out.And trust me - you will be missing out.

Posted: July 11, 2014
No more buying Ubisoft games for PCGreat graphics, Great gameplay, Great story...Overall a great game. You might wonder why I do not recommend the game... The reason is Uplay.I purchased the game during the Steam summer sale. I installed the game, and launched it. I was told to copy a CD key to the clipboard, and I did. When the you click play here, it opens Uplay, (Ubisoft's stupid DRM) making Steam look like a glorified CD key retailer. It prompts you to enter the CD key. When I did, it said my key was already in use. I didn't freak out, I thought it was just a bug. So I tried again, but it still did not work. I was not able to launch the game, so I contacted Ubisoft support, they were not helpful, saying that the code was already redeemed to someone else's account. They suggested I contact Steam instead. I did. Steam told me to contact Ubisoft. None of them helped me. None.I ended up pirating the game to finish it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Far Cry 3 was one of the top selling games of 2013, and for good reason.  Solid game play, gorgeous open world atmospheres, and beautiful graphics provide a strong base for some of the best acting gaming has ever seen.  There's one reason above all the enjoy this game, and thats for the solid 30 minutes of cutscenes with Michael Mando playing the fantastically insane villian. Game Play  - 9Pros: Fantastic open world, great combat, decent weapon selection, decently competent AI, RPG-like exploratory experience that almost never feels "grindy". Hunting big game is awesome, and actually feels like...hunting. Stealth game play is even solid, which tends to feel gimicky and slapped on in these types of games. Generic missions have enough variety to stay fresh. Although I'm focusing on other aspects of the game, this list can go on and there's no denying that the game play in of itself is stellar.Cons:  A few annoying features in terms of design (for example, sometimes picking up items is mixed with weapons switch out since they use the same hotkey). Occasionally weird physics can ruin some immersive moments (why is that giant dead bear rolling and bouncing down a realatively flat surface?). Some seemingly easy to add features were completely unavailable (why can I only move bodies on a special kill?  Why not after they have already dropped to the ground?)Story: 7While much of the story itself wasn't particularly revolutionary, the fact that simply playing the storyline alone can last over twenty hours without feeling repetitive, grindy, or contrived is a feat unto itself.  The motivation feels vague at times, but the clear conflict between the need for violence to save himself and his friends and the consuming negative nature of said violence becomes starkly clear by the final act.Mood/Atmosphere - 9Fantastic jungle renderings, gorgeous mountain ranges, and beautiful lagoons.  The soundtrack compliments the emotion of the landscapes. Certainly a memorable experience. Graphics - 8Solid facial and body animations. While the detail itself wasn't the best I've seen, the motion tracking worked well for creating believable body movements, which complemented the acting. Environments looks great , and the weather effects look stunning even on low settings. The grass effects are simple but effective for stealth game play and hiding the animals in the grass. Sound Design - 7One of my biggest pet peeves of Farcry 2 was the obnoxious looping soundtrack. Farcry 3's score was substantially stronger, and after the game I found myself relistening to the opening theme days later. The rest of the sound design erred on the side of subtlety, to the point that sometimes I didn't even noticed I had been injured because the character didn't make the usual borderline-sexual grunting noises when hurt.  While maybe detracting from some supposed "realism", it removed a lot of the audio repetitiveness of the last game which for me was a plus. Acting (special category): 10Few games deserve this as a category seperate from story, but this is where the game really shines. Particularly in the case of Michael Mando, there are arguably few better performances in gaming history. While the story may not be revolutionary, the implemtation of motion capture and performance certainly plays out in an incredible way.  That alone is enough to carry the game.  As a side note, a live action youtube video series was released with Christopher Mintz Plasse and Michael Mando.  You should check it out, its hilarious.Should I play this game?There are few FPS or RPG players who won't enjoy this gaming experience. There's a little bit for everybody, and it's worth the 20 hour play through on the incredible acting and cut scenes alone.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												Where do I start? To move forward, we'll have to go back to the beginning. I bought this game when it was first released in 2012 and played it on my PS3. I loved every second of it, and I'm not exaggerating. The most interesting thing about Far Cry 3 is that it puts the player in life or death situations, which, in turn, throw you down a deep rabbit hole of insanity. It's a really, really good game, if you can even get it to work. We all know the horror stories centred around Ubisoft's relentlessy game-breaking service, Uplay (cue the screams). I, originally being a console player who just recently got a PC powerful enough to run games like these, thought it would be good idea to buy this game again. It was on sale after all, and I thought I would be spending countless hours rediscovering the gritty, violent, and chaotic land of Rakyat. But, UPLAY GOT ME ♥♥♥♥ED UP. WHO THE ♥♥♥♥ ASKED FOR UPLAY? HOW WAS IT EVEN CONCEIVED? WHO IN ♥♥♥♥'S NAME THOUGHT IT WOULD BE A GOOD ♥♥♥♥ING IDEA TO ATTACH A GREAT GAME TO SUCH A ♥♥♥♥♥♥ SERVICE? WHO IN ♥♥♥♥'S NAME EVEN THOUGHT IT WOULD BE A GOOD IDEA TO CREATE THE DAMN THING?! SO MANY QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS AND I NOW WISH TO BE KILLED.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												This game... This game is one of the best games I have ever played.  I always find myself wanting to play this game.  The story in Far Cry 3 is one of the best stories that I have experienced in a first person shooter, ever.  It is very deep and well done and it requires you to make game changing decisions.  As you progress through the game, secrets of Rook Island are revealed and you can even find notes from World War II.  The graphics in this game are outstanding.  They still manage to compete with modern day titles, such as CoD and more of the less graphics intensive games of the modern era.  The controls are easy to use and very responsive.  The free roam in this game is extremely enjoyable.  There are so many activities you can do such as side missions, hunting, and even time trial racing.  On top of that you can reclaim the island by re activationg the radio towers and claiming pirate outposts.  The crafting system is pretty well made, allowing you to make syringes that enhance your skill in hunting, mobility, and swimming.  The multiplayer is not so great.  It kind of sucks lol.  It is dead and overall not very well made.  I look forward to Far Cry 4's co op campaign feature.  Overall this is a great game and I would reccomend it to anyone.10/10

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												I love this game. Awesome graphics and a decent storyline. Plenty of hours worth of playing. Lots of side missions to do if you want, or not, though some side missions help you max out your lootsack, wallet, ammo sizes etc so they're worth doing. This game ♥♥♥♥♥ all over Far Cry 2; it would be hard to go back to #2 after playing #3. FC3 has lots of fast travels so there's less driving around, and the enemies don't respawn in locations where you've captured the outpost. Also, no malaria tablets to worry about!!The co-op missions are fun too, though what would make this game massivly awesome would be a co-op version of it. Let's hope Far Cry 4 has the co-op we all love. Big thumbs up for FC3.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												Far Cry 3 has by far reigned among my top 5 open world games, every aspect of this game is great; from the story; to the gameplay; the action, world and its mechanics. You are Jason Brody, a young man looking for an adventure while vacationing on a remote island with your closest friends. Yet you get more than what you bargained for, when your group is kidnapped by drug pedaling pirates to be sold to the underground world of slavery.  Now its up to you to save your friends, bring peace back to this once pristine environment, and inspire hope to its native people. As you diverge from your expected path you become a true product of your new environment. You turn from a scared boy, to a ruthless warrior. Though be careful who you trust, for betrayal is lurking around every corner.This game is like no other, the story missions are long and tough and the side missions are a blast. You must climb to the top of hundred foot radio towers to acquire maps, radar and weapons; liberate pirate outposts; learn the lay of the land; hunt its native creatures, both docile and ferocious; find its most precious and scarce relics; bounty hunt for the islands most wanted; and test your skills through vigorous timed trials. This enormous world has more than enough ways to spend your time. If you feel like taking a break from the fighting, go play some poker, place wagers on your marksmanship, throw knives,  get laid, or race ATVs.As you delve in to this chaotic world, you find all resources at the palm of your hand. Customize your weapons by adding scopes, extended magazines and suppressors. You can pick someone off from a mile away, shoot them in the back with your bow and arrow, slit someone's throat, or blow it all up! Every desirable weapon is available at your disposal; hand guns, shotguns, assault rifles, SMGs, LMGs, RPGs, C4 explosives, knives, even a f**king flamethrower; everything your twisted heart could desire! The question is, how will you save this world? As a silent assassin, or a gun toting  juggernaut?Choose who you wish to become by picking skills from three separate skill trees. You can chose to become a stealthy assassin, a long range killer, an unstoppable killing machine or all three.  Will you learn how to shoot from a zip line, or how to silently ambush numerous enemies from atop and below? These skill will also help you become a better hunter-gatherer. Collect indigenous plants to craft potent remedies and abilities or learn to silently hunt a tiger or shark for its hide.Like any good contemporary game, there is multiplayer along with coop. Fight with or against players across the world to complete objectives, sabotage each other's bases, go on missions, or just shoot each other up in death match. Be careful though, for the losing teams best player is to be made an example of. The winning team can chose to show mercy, or beat him to within an inch of his life. So mount up! This world cannot be saved without your efforts. Just remember, trust no one. Not even yourself...

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												This is a fabulous game. The setting is large, beautiful, and lively. Quite frankly, this is one of the better settings I have seen in a game. With that said, graphically the game is excellent. Everything from the animations to the textures to the models looks great. The game sounds excellent, and the music selection is superb. The weapons all have fairly distinct sounds, and there are no sound issues as far as I can tell.As far as the story goes, it's really engaging. I am not going to spoil anything, but it does get a bit hokey a few times. By the end though, none of this mattered. The story has a way of dragging you in and making you care, as any well written narrative should. To sum it up, this is an excellent game. I almost regret not purchasing it sooner. From the setting to the story, this is most definitely a worthwhile purchase.
