number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												This game is an exact cross between Far Cry and Far Cry 2. For those that don’t remember, Far Cry was the first game (afaik) which allowed players to hide in shrubs on a massive tropical island with luscious green foliage. It used the first Crytek game engine. In Far Cry 2, you couldn’t really hide in shrubs, instead you were placed on a barren African landscape wearing a straw hat and on safari. This time the Dunia game engine was used which I’d personally say is more than just a heavily modified version of the CryEngine.Far Cry 3 uses the Dunia Engine 2. What this means is, the gameplay mechanics and overall feel of the game will be more like Far Cry 2. This is particularly noticeable with the shooting mechanics, the openness of the landscapes with trails/tracks/villages/compounds and even the driving of boats and vehicles will feel pretty much the same. Except the only difference is you’re on a luscious island where you have plenty of shrubs to hide in (or burn lol).What’s different? We get a pretty full on cinematic experience. It almost felt personal with the characters being so close and their faces taking up the entire screen. I thought they all wanted to kiss me. Aside from that, I thought all characters were standup comedians. Vaas in particular, but Buck as well. They have hilariously crazily loveably outrageous personalities.There is also an XP skill system in place. It didn’t bother me (see my Hitman: Absolution review) but after a year I’m now growing to hate seeing this in games. Not only is it a lame way to track progress, I reckon it damages the RPG genre. But like I said, it wasn’t much of a bother in this game.Overall Far Cry 3 in my opinion is for those that seek a very slow-paced game where you complete menial tasks on the island, but with the goal of exploration. Having said that, the island is a work of art, very detailed at every place. Not just a piece of terrain where they plopped buildings and 3D models on randomly.It’s interesting seeing how the land mixes in with the river banks, tree roots, erosion and sediments. Like you’ll see some tin shack on some beach in the middle of nowhere with intricately placed shore rocks, or you may walk through a plain field of grass with some oak-like trees during the night, or a lake in the middle of nowhere, it’s an experience to remember.I can almost certainly guarantee you that you won’t traverse the same spots on the island more than twice. This can be proven by purchasing maps to display the locations of all the loot chests. There’s a crap load of them! And for about 30 hours I was really nitpicky in the beginning opening those chests.The game was a bit buggy for me from time to time, but I always seemed to pull out of it without losing too much progress. Like sometimes you can bypass waypoints with ease which will break the mission. I also didn’t like long unnecessary animations like patting corpses for loot. Sometimes the game would just crash when I sell a lot of loot items in the store. I run an AMD 5000+ overclocked to 3GHz and HD6870. This is a pretty old gaming rig and I was able to play on high settings comfortably enough (felt like 25-30 fps when running).I prefer Far Cry 2, but Far Cry 3 is a very sophisticated game technology-wise. Definitely a step forward that newcomers can jump into without needing to play the predecessors since the stories and characters are all different.*note this review was cut down from 9000+ words.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												I didn't have high expectations of FarCry 3 after playing FarCry 2, and FarCry 1's story was a little far fetched for me. I was immediately engaged by the opening scene of FarCry3 and I had to play it a couple of times because of how the save points work. I was mostly engaged by the story, although there are some points you want to go WTF? But there is a really cool scene that blew my mind. While shooting bad guys is pretty repetitive, I had a lot of fun capturing Radio Towers and Bandit camps for the challenge of not being detected. I didn't spend a whole lot of time searching for relics or loot because it would never end, but the game is just gorgeous. The "upgrades" you can do to yourself are fun and add to the game and most of them I didn't find useless. Another nice feature about the game is the ending. Once you beat the game, you have the option to "leave" or continue on. I opted for continuing on, but all I have left is searching for relics, and there is about 300 in the game. Not really worth the time to me. I don't know about the replayability of the game, but it was worth the discount I paid for it. It's one of three or four games out of 90 or so that I've actually wanted to complete.I would recommend this game, even at the current regular price, but if you can find it on a discount, even better. I do have one complaint. I would consider my computer hardware to be above the norm, but the game sometimes would run great and then go down to 10 or so FPS, which when doing certain tasks (radio tower medical quests), it would make it extremely challenging. You may find other reviews complaining about how the game is not optimized, and I felt the same pain. Didn't detract from the game, but out of 5 stars, I would give it a 4.5 for this reason. If it ran well 100% of the time, I would have given it a 5.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												I’ll probably never finish playing FarCry3.  The game suffered from front-loading all the best content.  The first half of the game was superb.  The second half failed to live up to what preceded it.  On almost every level – villains, objectives, scenery, atmosphere – the second half of the game was like a bad sequel.  But what finally drove me away was utter disgust for the character I was required to play.  Unlike a lot of games that try to implement moral choices and some sort of moral system, FarCry3 seemed utterly uninterested in whether what the character was doing was good or right or heroic, instead choosing to focus on other themes.  This was ultimately to the game’s detriment, as progressing in the game often required acts that were morally unpleasant – just because the game designers don’t particularly care if something is moral or not does not mean that the players won’t.  For example, the opening of the game did a wonderful job setting up the pirates as a force that I could wipe out in good conscience – they were horrible, sadistic and murderous men who made me feel like I was saving lives when I removed them from the gene pool.  Even those who may not have been so downright evil were enemy combatants in a war they had chosen to declare on me.  And the game did a good job reinforcing this with many of the random encounters.  Absolutely none of that can be said for the mercenaries introduced midway through the game.  I expect this was intentional.  The game makes a point of claiming it is about insanity, and this is a fair way of showing the character’s increasingly murky morality and perverted mentality.  But in choosing to do that, the game chose to create a protagonist whom I found progressively less enjoyable to play.   Inevitably, the game’s demand that I mass-murder a huge swath of these guys was more than I was willing to give it.I'll admit, my attitude towards wholesale slaughter of the mercenaries probably had a lot more to do with the game than an objective measure of their comparative evils.  Hoyt himself was certainly as bad or worse than any of the pirates; and the mercenaries were following his orders, right?When the mercenaries first appeared, I had no idea who they were.  It was a mission to provide sniper cover for my allies while they attempted to recover their people whom the pirates had taken prisoner... or so I was told.  Except the people who showed up weren't pirates.  All I knew about them was that they looked military -- for all I knew, they were the armed forces of a sovereign nation, or possibly even people sent in by the United Nations -- and that they decidedly weren't the people I was there to shoot at.  I didn't know these people, I had no grudge against them, I couldn't even be sure that they weren't the good guys, and I had absolutely no reason to declare war on them.  Except that if I didn't the game would not allow me to progress, so it was either murder these people for no good reason or quit the game.I continued playing, despite the really bad taste that left in my mouth, because the game had been amazing up until that point.  Next, I find out that instead of the allies I was told I'd be rescuing, the military men were transporting my enemy.  So either my allies had suffered a catastrophic intelligence failure, or I had been lied to.  Worse, I'd just declared war on an unknown group and murdered a bunch of their people in order to set a horrible, sadistic psychopath free... for all I knew, I'd just launched an attack on the good guys just as they were taking action against the pirates!  To say I was unhappy was an understatement.  I had lost every bit of faith in my "allies" and I really wanted to be given the option to tell them to go ♥♥♥♥ themselves.Of course, it turns out the military men were Hoyt's mercenaries.  But at that point, as much as I hated Hoyt, I was primed to want to give these guys as much of a benefit of the doubt as possible.  The first town was under their control, but they weren't slaughtering the civilians like the pirates would.  The first scenario where I really dealt with them had me sneaking past the first two mercenaries and listening in on their conversation.  One mercenary was reveling in psychopathic bloodlust.  The one with him was reining him in, telling him this was a job not a murder free-for-all, and that he was only to shoot where and when he was told to.  My reaction?  The first guy very clearly was a danger to society and needed to be permanently put down.  But the second guy?  He was working for a very bad person, yes; but he was actively preventing a bad situation from getting much, much worse.  I didn't want to put this guy down, just as badly as I wanted to take out the other one.  The islanders needed people like that in the enemy's camp.  Of course, the game had stripped away my ability to choose what to do in that scene; I couldn't kill either or the scenerio would restart.I ran into those two again in one of the next situations.  Only this time, instead of not being allowed to take out the homicidal psychopath, I wasn't allowed to spare the other guy.  In fact, I was required to abandon all common sense, not to mention my characters skills, stealthy play style, and impressive custom sniper rifle, and make an absurd, bombastic rocket-launcher attack on a bridge and then carve my way out through all the people I had just carefully slipped past.  I was supremely not impressed.Finally, I was taken to see Hoyt.  I was lead into his office fully armed for a private sit-down with the guy.  At which point, I killed him with my silenced SMG, then tried to sneak out the window.  A bit of a mistake -- the place was so crawling with guards that I really didn't have much of a chance the moment the alarm went up... made all the worse by there being only a single exit that I could use: the front gate.  But my brother was in the place, and thanks to my undercover ally, I was able to rescue him.  We got to the gate, and of course that triggered the final cutscene where I had to make a fatal choice... and I chose to make sure my ally got my brother to safety, making a last stand that left me a bullet-riddled corpse.  I have to say, though, a damn good ending......except none of that happened.  Because you can't shoot Hoyt even though you are alone in a room with him and you are fully armed.  But I was allowed (read: required) to ignore that the bad guys had video footage that would have told them who I was, blown my disguise and made (or at least should have made) everything I was told to do afterwords a painfully obvious trap.  Because the second half of FarCry 3 is pretty much awful.I gave FarCry 3 every possible chance.  I played the first island exhaustively, finding every treasure and relic, doing every side quest, exploring every inch of the island... hell, probably spent days worth of game time just having my character hang out and play poker with the guys.  But in the end, the strikes against the game piled up so high that I simply couldn't enjoy it anymore.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												An engrossing open-world FPS, but not without its faults.  Beautiful graphics, intense gunfights, legitimately fun (if simple) stealth gameplay, and tons of content are the good parts. Like most open-world games, however, it becomes samey around the 20 hour mark and I started rushing story missions to get it done with. The not-so-good stuff: a) the storyline tends to pound on the "You are just like the bad guys, GET IT?!" theme in the dumbest ways possible; b) the people you are supposed to care about are aggressively stupid or bland, c) your character has the worst voice actor in the game, and d) the only memorable character (Vaas, who is plastered all over the marketing) is given relatively short shrift, but perhaps that's for the best - he's the best actor in the game and more exposure might have ruined his impact. That said, my gripes pertain mainly to the story missions (the majority of which are legitimately fun and/or exciting) and aren't enough to overcome its strengths; the game is definitely worth checking out and it's the best of the Far Cry games overall (I'm lying, Blood Dragon is the best).

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												I've played the game before, but after spending around an hour I felt bored and quit. Now, after about a year I bought the game again and gave it a second try and to my surprise it's much better than I previously thought.FarCry 3 is an open world first-person-shooter with some RPG and stealth elements developed by Ubisoft. The game is set on a tropical island between the Indian and Pacific Oceans. You are playing as Jason Brody, after a vacation goes wrong, you try to save your kidnapped friends from pirates and escape from the island. While the island itself is huge, it does not offer you much variety if it comes to locations however it is graphically stunning and feels alive, populated by various animals, nothing is comparable if you hear a tiger roaring behind your back. Gameplay wise the game is very good if compared ot other shooters, you are given the choice how to approach the threats you encounter wheather doing it the sneaky way or the more direct one. The story itself is rather simple, yet it feels believable and the characters are amazingly executed, I'm refering to Vaas at this point. Also the soundtrack is beautiful, all in all the game is fantastic and is truly a worthy purchase if you ask me.Also some people may advise you to stay away from this game since it has 2 layers of DRM, one being Uplay, speaking from my own experience I had no difficulties at all. Similar to Origin or GFWL you register the key and just keep it logging you in automatically.

content:
Posted: March 3
												Personal Rating: 5 of 10Its very difficult to review this game. The story and plot is good, the island is vast and combat is satisfying at times. However it falls really short on variety and many things don't gel together.Story is simple and straight foward but the plot did raise my eyebrows several times like the shocking kind which is good. The island is self is split into 2 part with the latter being revealed later in the game. The map is huge but I think mainly its because its empty and repetitive. The island looked the same everywhere with the same encampment, building, random places of small interest, mountain top and temples here and there but beyond that, the island is practically empty. For such a huge island there sure is no jungle. Don't expect different settings like snowy mountain, huge swampy area (there is a small and rather under designed one) or perhaps some remains of previous civilization. The reason I've said this is, there is proof of war bunkers, ancient temples and some large abandon facilities but these just isn't enough of other structures or towns to support it.Towns and encampments are plenty and scattered everywhere but they are really dead is coal. NPCs are decorations mostly that does nothing except for some that gives out quest. Not lively at all.Speaking of side quests, apart from collectibles, none of them span across a few series of repetitive quests like kill 250 of this and collect 50 of that but if you combine all of them together you get your fill series of repetitive nonsense lame side quests. Some side quests may obviously hide some meaning behind which others may find it funny or offensive but to me, I deemed them really unnecessary.Voice acting is alright but some NPCs voice record quality is clearly poor and bad also. Main characters are clearly stands out from unimportant NPCs as they are livelier and some are designed really well. Music is okay but it does gets on my nerve after a while because its so repetitive and some soundtrack clearly kills off the mood. Some main characters are overly done though which can be annoying. Thank heavens the interaction time with them isn't that long.The story mission is not really that long and the developers really hike up the challenge really really fast. Enemy A.I. is alright but once you find a flaw to exploit it seemingly easy. Weapons are plenty to choose from and yes they do have different characteristics which you can clearly feel but I feel they can be a little more hard hitting. You can customize weapons and even apply skin on them but its very limited. What surprises me the most is the animals. There is actually quite a few variety of them but lacked of characteristics.You can earn levels and money doing quests and looting but thats that. Collectibles unlocks written stories and provide nothing more. Each time, I was hoping the next collectible will unveil more location or puzzle but nothing really. Money allows you buy stuff. I was really excited at first but again dissapointed me as fast as it got me hyped up because you can only purchase weapons and customization. Ammos and med kit are practically useless as there are plenty around. Further more most of the weapons can be earned for free. Leveling up earns you a skill point and yeah the skills are quite useful nad gives you a sense of progression.You can also craft items in the game but personally I think it is a cheap gimmick. Imagine this, you needed leather to holster weapon. To carry more weapons you need more holster. But each holster requires different leather to craft. Its like her lets make use of the animals you know since its there but yeah its really redundant. You won't feel any sense of achievement there just finally I get more slots. You can also craft a variety of syringe that boosts/gives you certain ability for a short period of time. I only find 1 or 2 of them useful. In order to craft syringe you need to forage some plants. There are just too many of them lying around which practically makes them worthless.If you ever watched the trailer, it was really good. I thought that finally it went back to its root (Far Cry 1) but the actions you see in the trailer is more like in game ability kind of thing and not the actions you control of feel satisfy when you execute them. You only need to push a button at the right time. The antagonist that appeared on the trailer also sends shiver down one's spine. You hoped to see more of his insanity but no it doesn't really fills the expectation void. The character just don't expand.Overall, the game feels like it was designed by many department. Some did great while others pitched the idea, implement it for the sake of having the feature there in the game but these features don't simply cannot fit into the puzzle together and other aspects of the game cannot fully utilize one another to the fullest.Note that there are also some game breaking bugs too. Collecting collectibles doesn't save the game so if the game crashes (there are no quick save feature as I can't see the key mapping option), you need to repeat the process which is a pain. At times, if you land with the wingsuit you may clip through the ground. Missions contains plenty of unmarked checkpoint. If you somehow managed to bypass them you need to reload as the game won't progress.This game is good for casual open world game that packs some action. There are little things in the game that may surprise you or you may notice some small features that should be there.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												It's More Than Skyrim With GunsI picked up this game recently with the Steam Summer Sale of 2014 and it is well worth a buy. Unlike Skyrim where the real fun of it is with the whole questing main story or side quests but in Farcry surprsingly enough the main story was THE most fun I had through the whole game. The side quests are lacking with the only options being kill this guy, hunt this thing, and a fetch quest style of quest from the natives. However there are parts of the world that make it feel alive and real, a good show of this is if you run around with a repair tool on you then locals will ask for your help reparing their broken down cars and such. The only faults I have with this game is that to me the sidequesting is dull and boring and that the stealth option does work untill near the end the game sky rockets in difficulty and using something like a bow becomes a burden and even before then when you get levels in caves or close quaters stealth gets hindered even more so.TL;DR Version: Game is good, main story is great sidequesting is dull. Doing stealth near the end becomes way to hard and even forces you not to. As of now off sale it is $29.99 USD worth a buy if your into it maybe wait for a sale to make it 20 or less if your on the fence.

												A stereotypical broseph, rich with daddy's money eats some psychedelic plant matter and gets heavily tattooed after his equally fratty friends are captured by modern day pirates while on vacation.  Somehow, this turns him into a perfect hunter and killing machine almost instantly, even if he does sound unsure of himself.  Sort of reminded me of that flick "The Beach", or maybe Lord of the Flies.That being said, it is quite pretty, it has some great action and a pretty good variety of guns and skill-builds.  Finding all of the side-quest-totem-things can be an interesting challenge.If you get it, get it on the cheap.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												My hours should show you my feelings about the game. But I'll expand:Negative points:- Weird glitches get annoying sometimes. I've had this problem where sometimes, completely randomly, my weapon will disappear for a second and then immediately come back. You can't fire during this time. That's one of a number of glitches, although small, that - The hardest difficulty isn't that difficult. I ended up using the Gun Realism mod so the enemies actually hit you with the same damage as you hit them with. It actually makes being faced with a car-mounted machine gun a challenge if you're not armed with an RPG.Amazing points:- Excellent gunplay. It's what I base my ratings of other games' gumplay off of. It's great fun and even more with the Gun Realism mod.- Good story. I don't play games for the story, but FC3's story was pretty good. I don't get the complaints about the fact that Jason acts like he's never fired a gun before in a mission after arriving with an LMG and a grenade launcher. It's a game and unless you wanted to be stuck doing stealth or something for the first few hours of the game that's what you've got to deal with.- For a game from 2012, it doesn't feel that dated. Probably not an issue for many, but for me it would be.Get it while it's on sale. It's so worth $7.48. Heck, I'd go to say that it's worth $29.99. Or the original $80 I paid at the start.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												"Skyrim with Guns" they call it. And how freaking right they are! With this being released just at the end of the year 2012 it easily makes for one of the best games of the year. Having played only Far Cry 2 in the past and having somewhat enjoyed some elements of the game but never actually got round to finishing it, I was in for a ride with Far Cry 3. The main selling point for me to picking up this title was Vaas. Plain and Simple. I loved Michael Mando's role as Vaas, It was absolutely fantastic! When I saw the Character Vaas, I knew this was a game I had to get in on despite my lack of interest from the previous Far Cry games. I absolutely loved every encounter with Vaas and easily one my favorite Antagonist's to date!Let's crack in with the detail. You play as Jason Brody. You, Your Brothers and some Friends go on a vacation in Bangkok as celebration of your Brother Riley as he obtained his Pilot License. Celebration is cut short after a Skydiving trip after having land upon a Pirate Island. You and your group get captured by the Pirate Lord known as Vaas, a Secondary Antagonist to this story. Shortly after your escape, you are aware of what goes on within the Huge open world known as Rook Islands. Slavery. Your friends have been taken captive and only you can save them against Tyranny of Slavery. You must adapt to your new surroundings or be consumed by them.How open world is Rook Islands you may ask? VERY open! The map is huge! Tons of exploration as you wonder through the Island discovering Historic Relics, gazing at Ancient tombs, Shrines and even weapons! Rook Islands is certainly a stunning place to be. With the vast amounts of exploration you will want to be doing deep in the Jungle you are going to be wanting to get around as running simply isnt fast enough to get from point A to B. There are various ways to get around Rook Island. Ground Vechiles consist of Jeeps, Quad Bikes and even Dune Buggies! With Aquatic transportation simply boats or Jet Ski's to get around, though preferably boats. Specially if your hunting a certain predator out in those waters... And last but not least is Air, no not Helicopters or planes but Hang Gliders! What a way to get from Point A to B... Glide to your destination and enjoy the sight bestowed upon you! Ubisoft truly went to town with the detail in Far Cry 3's enviroment and certainly wanted us to enjoy it, with the time spent in the Jungle hunting or in the air gliding across the Island, its hard not to appreciate Rook Islands Beauty and Ubisoft's hard work.Throughout your journey ahead you will require upgrades to make Jason a more efficient Warrior. This is where the Hunting kicks into play. While exploring the Jungle you will be sure to discover plenty of wild animals that you can kill and skin so you can craft new equipment such Weapon Holsters, Increased Lootpacks, Syringe Pouches etc. A very nice feature and certinaly one I enjoyed. Prowling through the jungle with my Sniper Rifle taking out wild beasts before being bested by a Tiger. Dang! Be aware of your surroundings, The hunter is also the Hunted.While exploring the Jungle you will come across Plants you can harvest for which you can make Syringes with to enhance Jason.  Syringes of the likes of Fireproof and the Ability to see Enemies through walls. Given that they are a timed effect but still useful. I havent crafted them all however the more creativity you have with Far Cry 3, the much better experience you will have.Throughout the game as you hunt, complete missions, discover viewpoints (Towers that expand the view of your map, similar to those of seen in AC series) you will earn Experience. The experience will reward you Skill points in which you can use to unlock new talents in three categories. The Heron, Shark and Spider. You are not devoted to one category, you can spend your points across all three Specializations. As you begin to build up your new found traits you will begin to build up whats called "Tatau". Symbolized on your Left arm, this Tattoo represents a Warrior from the Rakyat tribe in which you aid against Vaas and his Pirates. As you progress through the game and spend more well earned skill points, the tattoo will begin to expand along your arm.With alot of the single player aspects, what else is there to do other than explore and discover the collectibles of Rook Island? Far Cry 3 also packs in a multiplayer to boot, personally I have no interest in the multiplayer as I'm interested in the Single player mainly however it may be something to be explored in time of writing of this review however nice to see they had time to implement this in along side their Epic campaign. However it doesnt stop there! Oh no! They went even further and added a Co-op Story mode, seperate to the story of single player mode might I add! The story of the Co-op mode is set a few months prior to the story of the single player campaign and revolves around four characters, scammed out of their money by the pirates and they won't rest easy about it! Again having not played this side just yet, its still nice to see another addition to the package! More content!!!Having spent 25hours to finish the Single Player Campaign alone while doing some hunting, side objectives and sightseeing I still have yet much to accompish. Discovering all the relics, completing the rest of the side missions and fully upgrading my arsenal whether it be my weapons or simply hunting related gear. Theres still much left after your done in Far Cry 3 and then if your curious enough to try out the multiplayer or Co-op mode that will earn you even more hours upon your gametime. Far Cry 3 is worth your time and money! I would give this game a 9/10. A must buy, The single player alone was worth it for me but yet much more to be done with this title!

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												So i yet to complete the game so i can't talk much about it. Here is what i like.Great graphics, yea the game looks really good, even tho the enemies do need more variety and the landscape may get bored to look at after 10 plus hours.The main missions are very good.Lots of things to do.Ecology and unpredictable creatures make the world come alive.Role-playing elements and difficulty curve make u play more than once.Good multiplayer for this type of game.Lots of weapons and ways to enjoy combat.Here is what i don't like about the game.Easy money, yea u get money so fast in this game that just 5 hours into the game u have money to buy the best weapons, money u don't really need since the game gives weapons for FREE.Generic side quests. One word, BORING...Enemy AI is laughable sometimes.Stealth is also not that well implemented which might lead to minor frustrations.Spawns and spawn rates are stupid. Kill all enemies in the area?, wait too long others will spawn and u have to do it all over again.Gunplay is not that good. U will notice this, if u play other FPS games like BF or COD.The wildlife is way too overpower, takes for EVER to kill animals.The main hero who is over sensitive to drops (you could literaly kill yourself by jumping from 3m height!)Also the game may get bored too soon if u get all weapons and done all the crafting upgrades.So, overall Far Cry 3 is a good game, but one that has a lot of things to work before it becomes great. There r just too many flaws for me personally to completely enjoy it, but enough to recommend to people that might like this type of games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2012
												It's time for a super serious review guysA Herd of Cassowaries rampaging through a pirate outpost. Sneaking through the jungle until a tiger decides to try to make you its lunch. Ramming a car bomb into a base and setting it off. A hot pink 1911.If any of those sounded appealing, then you’ll probably like Far Cry 3. To put it simply, Far Cry 3 is what Far Cry 2 should have been. Almost every aspect of it is improved. No more are there infinitely respawning checkpoints or enemies that can spot you out of nowhere. Far Cry 3 takes what was bad about Far Cry 2 out, improves on what it did right, and then sprinkles some komodo dragons and magic mushrooms on top.The plot starts with you, Jason Brody, and your fellow spoiled-white-kid friends getting captured by Vaas Montenegro, leader of the pirates on the unnamed island you have decided to visit. After escaping, you set out to save your friends, and get off the island. While your character, and the slice of the 1% that you came to the island with, are often insufferable, virtually every other character is fantastic. Vaas is a psychopath, and absolutely drips of crazy; Dr. Earndhart is fantastically creepy; and Willis Huntley may very well be my favourite character of 2012.But there’s far more to Far Cry 3 than the story. It’s set in an open world, letting you wander off and ignore the plot completely in favour of hunting animals, taking outposts and climbing radio towers if you’d like. There’s a crafting system, allowing you to upgrade how many guns you can have on hand, how many syringes you can carry, etc. You’ll get most of the upgrades quickly, though, since there’s plenty of animals to hunt and skin, and while the final upgrades for most things are part of hunting sidequests that unlock at conquered outposts, they’re all available on the first island. There’s also a skill system, giving you new abilities and upgrades. XP is easy to come by, but some skills are locked behind missions and won’t be available until a ways into the game.While the gameplay is a lot of fun, I was sometimes left wanting more. The one downside to having outposts not respawn is that you can clear out an entire island of enemies and then have nothing left to do but hunt cassowaries and mop up sidequests. If you’re lucky you’ll run across the occasional firefight between a washed up group of pirates and your native allies, but those are often over before you figure out where the gunfire is coming from.Side missions are a mixed bag, all of them are fun the first few times, but they rarely stray from their formula. Assassination missions make you kill a guy with a knife, supply drop missions make you drive through some checkpoints, et cetera. Fortunately the hunting missions have at least some variety in what kind of weapons and animals you are using or going after. Using an RPG to hunt down a pack of rabid dogs is a lot of fun, I assure you.While there is a finite limit to the content, it’s not like this is a short game. There’s PLENTY to do in the story missions alone, and if you add general island dicking around time to that you have a very substantial experience. Even the formulaic side missions are good for a change of scenery every few hours.Speaking of scenery, this game looks good. Really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ good. and getting a very smooth frame rate with some amazing visuals. The first island is mostly jungles, but there are plenty of beaches, rivers, bunkers and so on and so forth. The game is also really colourful. In a world if grey and brown shooters, it’s great to see a game set on a tropical island that feels, well, tropical. There are bright birds and plants everywhere, and with the wildlife system the game world feels alive.

Ratings:Replayability: 1/5Graphics: 4/5Artificial Intelligence: 3/5Immersion & Gameplay: 4/5Difficulty/Challenge: 3/5Procedural Destruction: 2/5Story: 4/5Multiplayer: Didn't ExperienceCo-op: 4/5Value for money: 5/5 (bought on Steam sale)Community: Didn't ExperienceOverall: 4/5 Tips:  - Hold onto skill points for situational events, you cannot respec. - Clear the additional content as you go to get the white stars (re: Handbook[Signature weapons]),  - Farm skins early for pouches  - Use your potions!  - If you are into Co-op, grab the phone app so you can decode additional content for your weapons.Overall:I really enjoyed this game, weapon selection is great, the sandbox side is a great distraction from the story line.Co-op is pretty fun too, I've been playing it with my partner & it is a hoot, specifically the difficulty and the carrot on a stick unlocks.Notable experiences: Frantically trying to reload when a maneater is coming at you, being rewarded by the phat XP when you capture a fortification undetected, sniping targets in quick succession.Games with similar flavour:  - Just Cause 2.Cons: - Uses Uplay

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This review is for the game ''Far Cry 3'' a single player(co-op and multiplayer enabled),open world action-adventure,video game.The game was developed by ''Ubisoft Montreal'' and published by Ubisoft.Series:''Far Cry''Engine:Dunia Engine 2Platforms:Microsoft Windows,Playstation 3,Xbox 360Release dates:November 30,2012 for EU and December 30,2012 for NA.Genre:First-person shooter,action-adventure.Mode(s):Single-player campaign,Multiplayer,Cooperation (co-op)Distribution:Optical Disc,Download.PlotYou are Jason Brody,a young man in his mid twenties,on vacation with a group of friends in Bangkok.During their vacation the decide to take a skydiving trip.Little did the know that they would land on a pirate-infested island known as Rook Island.The game begins with you and your older brother Grant tied up in a hostage situation by a man name Vaas,the pirate leader.While you manage to break from captivity your brother gets killed by Vaas in the escape.Later,Jason is rescued by Dennis Rogers and the the Rakyat tribe,the island's natives.By that time Jason's adventure to find his friends and to extract revenge begins.Throughout the game Jason will have to complete quests in order to gain the confidence of the Rakyat,Citra(the Rakyat leader,Cia Agent Huntley,Sam Becker and other stakeholders.After gaining their trust and their respect each one of the will assist Jason into rescuing his friends and killing the pirates and the Pirate leader Vaas who later is revealed to be just an employ of slave trader baron Hoyt Volker.After Vaas' death the game's true villain is revealed,the slave baron Hoyt who resides at the southern part of the island.Jason is determined to kill Hoyt and save his little brother from his hand.So,with the help of Cia Agent Huntley and the undercover operative Hoyt's privatee Sam Becker,you manage to infiltrate Hoyt's camp,gain his trust and kill him after a lengthy knife fight.Shortly after Hoyt's death you save your brother Riley and escape from Hoyt's troops back to the Rakyat island.At that point of the game Jason has realised how much he has changed.From a good grade Los Angeles resident to a bloodthirsty,revenge seeking,pirate slayer.From an active athlete and a loving and caring boyfriend to an almost sadistic vigilante who hesitate in anything until justice is met,Hoyt and Vaas is dead,and his friends and family are saved.In the end Jason and Riley arrive at the Rakyat Temple where Jason has to make a tough choice.Either kill his friends and be free from everything in order to lead the Rakyat people alongside with Citra or save his friends and turn his back on Citra and the Rakyat.If you kill your friends you will make love to Citra,impragnate her and die from her after stabbing your chest ,apparently dying like a warrior.If you do not kill your friends and choose to save them Dennis tries to murder Jason who's saved from Citra but dying from the hit.After takign the hit Citra dies in Jason's hands whispering that she loves him.In both cases the ending cinematic is the same showing the ancient knife artifact stuck in the sand at the beach with a boat leaving in the island.GameplayFar cry is an open-world first person shooter with adventure and role-playing game elements.The world of Far Cry 3 is bigger than his predecessor offering more opportunities in terms of exploring.Also as far as for the rpg elements the game utilizes a wide variety of skill trees,a simple crafting system and experience points used to gain levels and points used in the skill trees specializations.In the end you have a wide variety of weapons to use with extended customization to choose from,many vehicles and water travel to use to get to places and lastly besides the main quests,you get to complet side quests,hunting quests,wanted dead,supply drops and gather collectibles like lost letters and artifacts.Co-opThe game also features co-operative mode too for 2 to 4 players.The characters are Callum,Tisha,Leonard and Mikhail who are scammed out of their money by Pirates and later decide to work together in order to pursue them and their Captain for revenge.The plot takes place 6 months before the single player campaign.MultiplayerMultiplayer consists of 10 different maps,incredible weapon and abilities customization options and require skilled players in order to take advantage of the game's full potential.Balanced multiplayer forgiving to the new player but deadly to the lazy cocky veteran.RecapI've finished this game over and over again more times than i can remember.In my list it's my number one game to play and recommend.Consistent plot,wide variety of customization,a jungle to hunt animals,pirates,privatees.What more can you ask for?By the way if you want to experience the island's locations and everythign this game has to offer do not use fast travel.Personally i hate fast travel and i do not use it.Pros+Exploration+Wide variety of customization+Plot+Warfare+Funny and competitive Co op+Active Multiplayer with numbers of players that surpass even modern call of duty and battlefield gamesConsNone that i know of.Well...Uplay is somewhat annoying from times to times but nothing muchSummaryMake sure you have this game in your library and if you don't buy it without second thought.A piece of art for gaming.Thank you Ubisoft Montreal and ubisoft developers,employeesand associates for creating this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2013
												The Far Cry series has done what so few others have in that each game has redefined our perception of what this franchise is. The first game had you blasting through a Island of Dr. Moreau-inspired landscape, the second brought us back to reality with a hunt for an arms dealer in Africa, and now the third installment aims for a more personal experience while drawing inspiration from films like Taken and Turistas.In the game you play as an American 20-something year old named Jason Brody who accompanies his two brothers and wealthy friends on vacation in Thailand. Being thrill seekers and adrenaline junkies the group is told about Rook Island where "anything goes" and they decide to blindly sky dive onto it. Shortly after landing the group is taken captive by pirates led by the clearly sadistic and violently insane Vaas who plans to collect a ransom but sell them into slavery anyway. After narrowly escaping, Jason is taken in by the local natives who inpsire him to take the fight to Vaas and save his friends.The story is beautifully crafted, the characters are vivid (thanks to phenomenal voice acting and animation), and the game's use of insanity as a focal point pays off brilliantly.Like the previous titles, FC3 drops the player in an open environment that's just as big if not bigger than Skyrim and all of it save a smaller island is available to explore from the get-go. Populating the game world are story missions, side missions, and hidden collectibles and transportation including cars, trucks, boats, ATVs, hang gliders, and jet skis. The combat is exciting and tense and a large arsenal of weapons is at the players' disposal covering handguns, SMGs, assault rifles, LMGs, sniper rifles, shotguns, and even a bow and flamethrower.  While the story missions are always varied and great fun the side missions are repetitive and lack luster after awhile. Tracking down hidden collectibles also becomes a chore pretty quickly as the payoff for doing so is limited. Lastly while the environment looks incredibly appealing it does become stale after awhile in its lack of variety. Additionally, some of the more detail oriented players have noticed that the game world lacks some of the awesome physics and destruction features present in the PC version of Far Cry 2.Overall though the pros greatly outweigh the cons. Far Cry 3 is a tense and brilliantly designed game that is totally worth picking up. If you're looking for something that seamlessly blends a fantastic narrative and addictive gameplay look no further. Personally I can't wait to see what they do with the next game and how the franchise will redefine itself again.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												By far the best game in the series, FC3 once again places you in an exotic location where nature becomes a powerful and sometimes frustrating character in the game. A world traveller and thrill seeker, your character is thrust into a struggle for survival when you are forced to free your freinds from local pirates on a tropical island. This time around, you must hunt wild and sometimes dangerous animals for skins and harvets local plant life to craft new holsters, medicines, and temporary stat buffs. With a large aresenal to choose from, enemies are fairly intelligent, and a large series of islands to explore and tons of side quests, FC3 has something for everyone. If you liked the Tomb Raider reboot, you'll enjoy Far Cry 3 as well.

												This game is tons of fun.  First run thru with some sidetracking from main story (side missions/exploring etc.) was roughly 30+ hours. So get this game and go swim with sharks, blow up jeeps/bases/crocodiles? and explore the islands.***9/10***

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												Far Cry 3 is a brilliantly executed open-world First Person Adventure. Many call this an FPS, but that’s only a small facet of this game. I enjoyed the first half of the game, but I had to will myself to cross the finish line.  FC3 has many “tacked-on” elements that don’t really add to the experience. It has “crafting” and a “skill tree” that could have easily been absorbed in to the games progression, as neither really changes your game experience beyond expanding your inventory capacity or adding a new way to take out enemies. A decent player will have both maxed out well before the end-game. The weapon progression was fun; especially the high powered weapons that send enemies flying on impact. The addition of weapon mods was nice, but arbitrary. The mods were only available on the higher tiers of weapons, and limited to an artificial cap. The mod categories are suppression, magazine size, and optics (in some cases you could stack optic choices, like adding night vision to a long range scope); unfortunately the designers chose to artificially limit the number of attachments and only allow them on top tier weapons. The result is a huge number of underused weapons. I might have experimented with more of the lower tier weapons if they were upgradable. This would not have thrown off balance since there was so much redundancy in weapon choices anyway.The story starts with strong conflict which cements you in to the mythos quickly. I enjoy hardboiled tales as much as the next guy, but there was very little foil to the darkness  and grittyness. For a 40+ hour experience, it would have been nice to have some humor and light hearted content mixed in to the hard hitting main quest. There were some likeable characters along the way – Vass was a good “bad-guy”, Sam was a lot of fun, and the deep cover agent straight out of Miami Vice was a nice touch, but I found I was less interested in the main story and more interested in my own exploration. The number of times I got shot, stabbed, drowned, and “left for dead” started to become an in-joke (they even mention it in the game).Overall I would lump this game in to the same family as Skyrim or Fallout 3, both of which far eclipse this game in story and progression. The area that Far Cry shines is in the gameplay mechanics, and the interaction with the world. I felt much more in control of my characters physicality which ultimately sustained my intrest allowing me to play through to the end. (The wingsuit is AWESOME!) I really did get the feeling of being a one-man-army action-hero without it feeling like I was dealing with idiotic AI. It’s worth playing and I look forward to seeing how they improve this franchise going forward.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												I played the original Far Cry and found it to be a game of lackluster storyline and glorious graphics. I player Far Cry 2 and found it to be annoying, repetitive and boring, yet nice-looking. So that's what I expected from Far Cry 3 as well.I was wrong.Far Cry 3 is pretty, that much hasn't changed. In fact the game was so pretty that all the pretty environments, visual effects and bright colours actually made me feel physically ill sometimes, which I guess has to count against the graphics, but other than that Far Cry 3 is a gorgeous game.However, unliked it's predecessors, Far Cry 3 has an interesting premise, that of young adults captured by pirates and struggling to escape with the assistance of native resistance warriors fighting the pirates. It has cool locations, characters and missions, and most importantly: it has an arc. The protagonist, Jason Brody, changes throughout the game. He grows on you in this weird way, and I found it unusually easy to relate to him.The voice actors are solid, the game uses original and lifted music effectively and most of the sound effects seem top-notch.And then there is the positive surprise! While most modern games give you something between 6-10 hours of gameplay, Far Cry 3 got me up to 22 hours, with easily 90% of the side missions untouched and much of the map still left to properly explore. If you are that kind of a person, you can easily get lost in this game and just roam the land, hunting prey, be it man or animal, and taking in the glorious scenery.I didn't expect to, but I truly recommend this game.Playtime: 22+ hours (single playthrough)Ratings (1-10)Visual: 8Audio: 9Story: 8Gameplay: 9Overall: 8

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Much better than Far Cry 2. This was a pretty good shooter all around, guns sounded great and the bigger and more powerful guns had a satisfying feel to them. The survival aspect was done nicely, you can use pretty much everything in your environment to craft useful support items or gear which you can upgrade over time. For example, you can upgrade your holsters with animal hides to increase the number of guns you can carry at once. One big improvement over Far Cry 2 is that there is tons to do in the game becides the main quest. Far Cry 2 sported a large open world map, but had very little to do in between missions. This one has camps you can take over, kill missions, hunting missions, challanges, and collectable items that encourage exploration. It also has a fairly interesting plot that keeps you engaged and has some pretty cool characters you meet throughout. I highly recommend this one, especially if Far Cry 2 left a bad taste in your mouth.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												Considering this game was hyped to all hell, I figured that I would at least kind of enjoy the experience. And to an extent, I did, but some horribly glaring issues with the game just ruined it all for me.Now the first thing I want to note before I go into any of this is that I played through Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon before this, and I loved the experience. That game was silly and marvelous, and I would recommend it in a heartbeat. This game, however, manages to be worse than the game that was done on a significantly lower budget running on the same engine. Here's why:First, the mission design is repetitive as all hell. For the most part your missions boil down to "Go into restricted zone X to find/kill/blow up Y and then leave restricted zone X". Practically every story mission is like this. And practically every side mission is like this as well, even the hunting missions. It turned into kind of a chore to do everything, and that's bad. It worked better in Blood Dragon because even though it had the same problem, it was on a much, MUCH smaller scale. You were a badass supersoldier who could zoom over to your objective in less than 10 seconds and it'd be done even faster. In Far Cry 3 it takes more time to get where you're going, and then more time to do what you're doing, which makes what used to be a niggling complaint a gigantic complaint.Second, too many turret sections. I should not have to explain this, but I will: game developers and designers, nobody wants to sit in the same spot holding down LMB for fifteen minutes while you scroll a background for us. It's not fun, it's not satisfying, it's boring, and it's tedious, and Far Cry 3 has turret sections out the♥♥♥♥♥ This is a crime against game design, and whoever's smart idea this was should be hanged upside down by their pinkie toes for even suggesting it.Third, crafting and RPG elements are super underutilized and feel utterly tacked on. If you're going to put crafting or RPG mechanics into your game, make it INTERESTING. Make it so you have to actually BUILD A CHARACTER, so you actually have to DISCOVER IMPORTANT CRAFTING RECIPES, not this. Far Cry 3's leveling system comes down to this: kill everyone in sight until you ding, get the next linear upgrade, rinse, lather, repeat. The skills you perk into hardly ever have an effect on gameplay, and when they do, all they are is another canned animation for your takedown that is hardly ever useful. I never used the grenade takedown, I never used the hanging takedown, I hardly used the double takedown, when I did it wasn't useful, I didn't use the chained takedown, I didn't use the knife takedown, and I didn't use the gun takedown. All I used were the vanilla takedown, the heavy takedown (which is just the vanilla takedown on big enemies), and the death from above takedown. Everything else was stupid and pointless. And the other skills were dumb things like "Reload faster" or "Get more money from looting" or "Reload when aimed down sights".Part deux of point three, the crafting is terrible. All you do is farm out animals to get bigger bags and then just get all the green plants for nonstop healing items. There is no reason to get anything except green plants after you acquire all the bag upgrades, and it could have been used for something interesting. Let me make special weapons, or traps, let me use all this stuff, let me fashion some jerryrigged armor SOMETHING, ANYTHING. Instead it's "Got all the bags? Okay now all the animals are walking money go nuts." Horrible crafting system, they should have just left it out altogether.And finally, the story is just absolutely pathetic. Now, before you jump down my throat about it let me make this perfectly clear: I loved Vaas and Hoyt. They were excellently written characters. Unfortunately, this game does not star either one of those characters, it stars Jason Brody, a moron who claims to have never shot a gun, yet guns down armies of pirates and privateers like he's been doing it since he came out of the womb, and is "super serious" about saving his friends, but can't keep himself from making stupid pop culture references every thirty seconds. This character ruined literally the entire story. The game can't decide if it wants to be silly or serious, so it tries to do both and it fails utterly. The ludonarrative dissonance in this game is just insane levels of bad, and you just want to murder Jason by the end of it all. I'll go so far as to say that this is probably the worst story I've seen in a game, not because the concept of the story is bad, but because the execution is just awful.All in all, I would say skip this game and just get Blood Dragon. Blood Dragon doesn't have any of these problems, even the turret sections are more toned down, and frankly they're actually well executed. Blood Dragon succeeds in everything Far Cry 3 fails in and more, and it's cheaper as well. So, yeah, just get Blood Dragon. Just get Blood Dragon. What I'm saying is buy Blood Dragon.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												The first half of this game is a masterpiece.  The second half is terrible.  But overall, I am very glad I got it, and I will always remember it.The first half of the game has very enjoyable gameplay, and I like that you can choose whether you want to be stealthy or just go full-on Rambo with guns ablaze.  Taking over strongholds were definitely the best part of the game for this reason - it's you, a bunch of bad guys, and it's all up to you how you deal with it.The missions throw this tactic out the window.  For the first half of the game, you are pretty much forced to use stealth tactics, and for the second half, it's basically Call of Duty type shooting.  Speaking of which...The second half of the game throws all tactics out the window, and in my opinion, it was thoroughly unenjoyable.  Whereas with any other part of the game, you can approach the enemies however you want, in several of the missions in the second half, they don't even spawn until you are about ten feet away, meaning if you were relying on the bow or the sniper (like I was), tough luck ya ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  If you insist upon playing the second part of the game, my advice would be to carry: a large machine gun, a shotgun, a rocket launcher, and one type of long range weapon.  Stealth matters no more.Obviously, Vaas is the best character in the game.  But after he's gone (don't think I'm spoiling anything there), the game just felt empty - you're only halfway done after that point, and Hoyt is not the same, not by a long shot.  I kept playing just to see the ending that everyone was talking about, and even that was pretty disappointing.So to sum it up: if you get this game, my advice would be to play the first half of the game and enjoy it to its fullest, then either go full-on sandbox and forget the story or drop the game altogether and just watch the ending on Youtube.  You're missing nothing between the two.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Part of an already well-known franchise, Far Cry 3 holds no 'surprises': visual extravaganza combined with fast-paced gameplay. You and your group of friends are taken for ransom by a druglord. After your successful escape, you need to get yourself and your friends off the island... alive. I'll let you discover the rest of the story yourself.The open world is very large and offers hours of gameplay. Different mission types are available: story progress, scavenging, hunting (both human & animal), time racing, ... During the first hours of gameplay, this will surely keep you entertained. However, half-way through the game these missions become very repetitive. Especially if you like to explore everything and do all the missions before progressing to the next zone. There is also an abundance of money you can find to spend on weapons, ammo, ... You basically never run out of money.Only played a few multiplayer matches, so can't really comment on it: they were fun and fast-paced. Large maps, so only fun with lots of players online. Co-op uses a seperate storyline involving 4 people trying to escape a cruise ship hijacked by pirates. It was very hard to find online co-op matches, so I only did this twice. Would be fun to do this with friends.I got the base game during a Steam sale, together with all the DLC. I would advise to do the same, as the DLC holds little value if you start playing it after you complete the game. Both mission DLCs bring some diversity to the missions of the base game. Monkey Business was entertaining due to Hurk, who seems to pop up in Far Cry 4 as well.  Lost Expedition is also very nice as it provides some variety next to the base game missions. But the top reason for the DLC is the Predator weapon, a silenced sniper, which is available right at the start.Score: 8.5/10Pro:+ appealing visuals & sound+ massive open world environment with hours of gameplay+ nice DLCContra:- standard missions become repetitive halfway through- low replayability

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												I loved this game.  However, the glitches created by Uplay have devastated my gaming experience.  When the game first came on sale, I had to deal with glitches that completely break not only single player, but multi player as well as coop.  Not only that, I have kept crashing for a while, even on a computer I have reformatted several times just to get Far Cry 3 to work, and then later realize that the game crashes at a certain point only during Full screen mode.  Other than these major problems that have kept me from playing the game, I will continue to finish this game and of course, I'll recommend it to those who will buy the game when it is on a sale.What are the good parts of Far Cry 3?-Amazing story with an amazing villain.  More than one ending, no spoilers though...-Craft several things, hunt down animals.-Amazing multiplayer with an amazingly detailed killcam.-Build your own maps... why not? FC3 has a map editor for you to create and share with others.-Single player story and coop story are totally different.What are the bad parts of Far Cry 3?-Once you start a mission, you can't free roam anymore.  If you try to, you will encounter a waring message to go back or else you will be automatically killed.-You can't explore the whole map, even if you are not in a mission.  If you try to, you will encounter a warning message to go back or else you will be automatically killed.-Multiplayer can be dead at times.-Uplay issues... game crashes as I mentioned above.  I couldn't play FC3 for months because of Uplay and their unnecessary updates.-Many multiplayer glitches especially when FC3 goes on sale and Uplay servers overload. Get rid of Uplay... NO ONE WANTS IT!My final verdict: 79/100Uplay really ♥♥♥♥ed up the awesome experience of this game. Stop using uplay... Just use steam servers. Then this game would've had a higher score from me.

												Really enjoyed playing through this.  The open-world island is beautiful and fun to explore, there's lots to unlock, and the guns feel great. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												The theme of a descent into insanity is nothing new to video gaming. But few games manage to properly juxtapose the senseless and euphoric ultraviolence of the standard gaming experience and the psychological decomposition that happens to real people in such situations. Far Cry 3 is one of them.You are just a regular college student by the name of Jason Brody who's on a tour of east Asia with a few of your upper-crust friends and your two brothers. On a whim, you make an excursion to an all but uncharted island seeking some easy, anarchistic thrills, and quickly find yourself in the lowest pit of hell.Your friends are taken hostage by drug-farming, slave-trading pirates, from whom you barely escape at a terrible cost. From there, you meet a whole host of world-class characters brought to life by brilliant voice-acting (Vaas and Buck especially) as you fight to survive and manipulate the living, open-world jungle.There's a small degree of collecting and crafting, but when it comes to upgrading it's very straight-forward. You gain experience from combat (more from stealth takedowns) through an arcade-like point system, and you gain weapons by looting them off dead foes. The combat is fluid and dynamic, as planted explosives, freely roaming animals, random NPC patrols, and your own mistakes can aid or hinder you in your quest to save your friends.Kills and gunplay are especially satisfying. Melee kills make your heart pound with their hectic but smooth animations and audio, making every strike feel personal. The gun porn is ramped up and though recoil isn't a major concern, the ballistics are very effective, and the animations match the beauty of the open world of the islands.As you progress the story, however, Jason Brody will have moments of recess where he confides in others who are justly becoming concerned about his having gone tribal. And you might need a little genre awareness to realize that the horrible things you watch your first and even your second major adversaries do are no worse than what you've been wrecking upon their hapless subordinates. Alongside the main story are some side-quests with a couple more hilarious and unique characters, as well as small missions for hunting, gathering, assassinations, deliveries, and so on. Or, you could just give in to your inner demons and prowl the jungle seeking out the poor souls who wander its depths.10/10 - Became what I ate, ate what I killed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Far Cry 3 Good Points:-Compelling story- Lots of activities to do- Stealth is an option- Destructable jungle- Variety of weapons- Lighting and surrounds- All main characters are beautifully voiced and you truly feel how they feel- Multiple transport options (Car/Buggy, Paraglider/Wingsuit, Jetski/Boat)- Sick, twisted tyrants that are unique and unlike any other bosses in games- Soundtrack is just.. Beautiful- Skill tree has varietyFar Cry 3 Bad Points- Poor sound quality from lesser important characters- Repetition of speech from enemies-  Depending on style of play, earning money CAN be an issue- Various bugs (Classic Ubisoft) But none that are too game breaking- When set on fire, you take a lot of damage before you can put out the fire, this can be annoying- Hills that seem like you can climb them, cannot be climed, this can make exploring a bit of a drag at certain pointsIn total, out of 10 I would rate it a solid 9. I have played this game more times than I care to remember when I played it on Xbox. On PC, it is even better. I would recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a unique story that will keep you coming back for more, the main character is one of a kind, as are the sick tyrants that inhabit the island. I cannot stress how brilliant and uniqe the story is to this game. The theme of finding yourself and who you are (and what you will become) along with having to cope with people who you love and know that the island is taking away what you were and turning into the thing you decided to fight against in the first place is just amazing. Honestly, buy this game if you haven't already and plunge into the island of insanity that is Rook Island. Far Cry 3 is a must have...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												I hated Far Cry 1 with its eagle eye AI spotting you in bushes 100 yards away.  I skipped FC2.  I wasn't going to play FC3 until persuading by a few friends insisted I buy it during the Steam sale.I'm glad I listened.  Far Cry 3 was an awesome dynamic fps experience.  The exploration alone is impressively massive, and it's fun to watch all the AI animal life interact with each other.  It creates a living world that's constantly keeping you busy and on your toes.There's so much to see and do in FC3 from hunting game to poker games.  From climbing tower puzzles to camp liberating missions you do your own way (stealthy or guns blazing).  You'll never be without something to do.  This game has so many memorable moments created by some really cool story missions, but also in the dynamically open world environment.I'm now a Far Cry fan again.  Looking forward to FC4.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												This is for sure one of the most enthralling game I've ever played.It can't be said that it's 100% original hence it merges aspects from various FPS, actions and RPGs, but the quality with it's done is beautiful.I really have nothing to complain about, maybe it's too cocky and for fully enjoy the ambientation you need an high-end computer and the menus give you this porting-feeling.The storyline is well studied and the characters are created in a way that makes you love them while at the same time you will hate them. Except Vas. As it seems, everyone loves him.The ambientation is beautiful, maybe too green and "flat", but every single corner of the island is different from the other with it's personal flora and fauna.And even if i hate RPGs when you have to spend hours to gather resources, I LOVED, seriously, I LOVED roaming the island to kill animals for their leather to make holsters, wallets or quivers. Except Cassowaries. I can't even think of a reason why they are so annoying and OverPowered.THEY ONE-SHOT YOU WITH A KICK! AND RUN FASTER THAN USAIN BOLT ON SPEED!Seriously, ♥♥♥♥ Cassowaries.9/10

												This is hands down one of the most fun games I have ever played (and I've been playing PC games for over 20 years).Sure it's not perfect (I'm not a huge fan of the story or the main characters, the menu system is a bit clunky, a linux port would be nice, and of course there's uplay...), but the core mechanics are extremely well done: very satisfying gun-play, huge environments to explore (using land, sea and air vehicles), a variety of missions, taking over outposts and radio towers, sneaky assassinations, hunting animals, searching for relics, even the little challenges and mini-games are really fun.If you like open world shooters, you will probably love this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												One of the best FPS single player campaigns I've ever played.Pros:- Very comfortable gameplay. Aiming, running and crouching transitions feels smooth. Stealth is one of the best parts of the gameplay for me. The FOV works better than other games.- Melee kills :D- The islands and the variety of environments, caves, interiors, exteriors, on the sea, on the air etc.- The vehicles, the fauna.- The tagging system and the multiple approaches to one situation. Curious how much "MGS V The Phantom Pain" ripped of even from the UIs.- 38 main missions. - Hard mode is well balanced if you like stealth.- Vaas Montenegro, Sam Becker and the other characters. There're no tons of cutscenes but you feel every single one of them had some good moments.- Apocalypse Now references and of course "Ride of the Valkyries" haha! (now I wanna play Blood Dragon again!)- I find the voice acting very well done and natural for the situations each character goes through- Visually it looks amazing for its time and even for today's standards. Again...the island the vegetation etc...The character facial expressions are the bests from all Ubisoft games. Even secondary NPC's have good care in details and it's nice the few different kind of shaders like the glossy ones for eyeballs, the more anisotropic looking for hair, bamboo etc and the standard ones. About Ubisoft...personally I hate the work about this aspect in Assassins Creed games. Of course is a different team but a different engine. In this case Dunia Engine 2 which is very optimized and works outstanding.It's not a con but...The only bad thing that looks completely horrible are the cloud and atmospherics facing camera sprites. The can turn 180° too easy if you break its axis.- Every time you take a screenshot DOF bokeh looks natural (one of the few games did this on the 7th gen).-  Oh! I forgot the OST  with In-Game tracks from Die Antwoord, M.I.A., Skrillex and Noisia, Losers and The Glitch Mob for the trailers among others. Also the incidental tracks are outstanding. Another good one "I'm Sorry" by Brian Tyler.- Now that I play all Far Cry 3 I can say the game is not that far from the retouched screenshots Ubisoft always make public before releasing a game (without mention the E3 demonstration)Cons:- It rainned only once during my whole playthough.- I would love to had better side-quests. They're not bad but more of those related to the main campaign.- Who mapped the skills upgrades button to a "double click"? I thought the entire game skills were blocked and I ran through all the mess of explosions and bullets with only two health bars xD...in hard mode... OK, OK...mostly my mistake!- SPOILER ALERT! Killing Vaas before the end of the game and the lack of a cliche twist about him.- I can't confirm this but people say multiplayer is not that good.Is just will say that this game is very valuable. Don't miss it!

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Uplay first, then game review.As many other reviews pointed out, this game uses UPlay. I don't like that it uses uplay because I bought the game through Steam and would like to play it only through Steam. But as long as it's fast going through their servers and isn't a complete nuisance to sign on, whatever.However, the first time I tried to play this it took me a ♥♥♥♥ing HALF HOUR to get in the damn game. At first it said uplay's servers were busy or offline, which took a while. I thought "Ok, fine, I'll play offline. No big deal." Guess what?! You CAN'T play offline the first time you run the game. So I HAD to go through their servers. When they were finally accessible, I got the Uplay captcha puzzle, which involved putting a single set of numbers from a single picture into two boxes. The rules: One box cannot be blank. The number cannot be copied into both boxes. The numbers cannot be split up. Think the audio captcha will help you out? It specifically says not to put spaces in, then says one set of numbers. Refreshing the captcha didn't help, I kept getting the same damn problem until I found one that had a letter tacked onto the end of the numbers which I put into the other box, and it finally worked. At this point I was pretty mad, I just wanted to play my ♥♥♥♥ing game and instead I'm wasting time trying to figure out the impossible captcha.From this point on it was easy to log in, the only other problem I had was that at one point my game stopped syncing, so when my SSD got scrambled (uplay decided to install itself on my windows drive instead of my programs drive), I lost half my progress. I also didn't know it at the time, but I wasn't getting achievements for storyline events. When I played through them again, I got them. So back up your saves, guys!FINALLY, THE GAMEThe game feels very much like the new Tomb Raider except more open. I also got a few fleeting feelings of Assassin's Creed. Like how it feels to play those games? You'll probably like this one. There's a wide variety of weapons and I like that you can get a lot for free by unlocking towers. Going hunting is actually good for something, as you use it to craft holsters, rucksacks, etc.The story didn't impress me at first, nor the character development, but I'm liking it much more now. I only wish there were more conversation opportunities with your friends! They all seem very one-dimentional, with the exception of Daisy, who just seems much more nuanced in her words and expressions. I will update this as I finish the game, 3 missions to go.The graphics are great, albeit a bit repetative (but they are on an island, so... lots of palm trees are to be expected, I guess). A few problems where I see black/blue shapes but nothing terrible or constant. Sometimes characters vibrate, which makes it ridiculously hard to snipe.Controls are great for the most part, the problem I have is when performing special actions. When I'm climbing a radio tower, stepping onto the very edge, and see ropes where "climb" should appear...it doesn't. I can wiggle one way or the other and sometimes it shows up, sometimes not. So I can jump and sometimes have the game catch me and climb up, or I can fall to my death and start over. Annoying. More annoying is when I'm sneaking around an enemy camp like a boss, killing people, when I sneak up behind someone and the "takedown" option doesn't appear. Again, I move around, sometimes it works. Most of the time though they either turn around and alert the whole camp, or I slice but don't kill them and they alert the whole camp.Open world, lots of places to explore even if climbing towers and liberating camps gets boring. Can't wait to see how it ends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												In praise of the undying bearI really liked Far Cry but really didn’t like Far Cry 2, so I was hoping that FAR CRY 3  would put the franchise back on track. Thankfully it did. The Rook Islands are beautifully realised and provide some of the most impressive and realistic graphics I’ve encountered to date. The islands are lush and colourful and teeming with wildlife, all of which makes for a deeply immersive environment. Even if you ignored all the missions there’s a lot of fun to be had just exploring and hunting. But there are plenty of missions (almost 40 main story missions, a dozen or so side missions, plus a bunch of hunting and supply missions) to be completed. The main story is pretty good for an open world game. It’s not outstanding by any means but it provides sufficient momentum for your stay on the island and includes some pretty cool trippy experiences. Alongside the missions there are numerous items to collect, if you feel so inclined, and there are radio towers to activate and outposts to liberate. I had as much fun completing these tasks as I did completing the missions (although I didn’t track down all the collectibles -- there are just too many of them). It’s not all good however. The game has an incomprehensibly stupid save system. There is only one save slot and you can’t save at all during a mission. So if you have to leave the game mid-mission you have to start right back at the beginning next time you play. I know other games have employed similar systems but I just don’t understand why. The option to save should always be there -- you don’t have to use it if you don’t want to. I also found the looting mechanics to be annoying. Although you don’t have to wait for the prompt to activate the process it’s still too easy to accidentally swap weapons rather than collect loot. And finally, not enough dialogue was recorded for the minor NPCs, and consequently you here them repeating the same statements over and over again. These gripes aside, however, there’s little to detract from what is a great gaming experience. I haven’t tried the multiplayer options yet so I can’t comment on them. I plan on giving them a try later and will update this review if necessary. 4/5
